Gutach: Even more safety for pedestrians
They are not even 100 metres apart: On Tuesday, the new B 33 pedestrian traffic lights at the village car park in Gutach were put into operation - within sight of the older town hall traffic lights.
Two installations so close together: intention or foolish coup?
This question was clearly answered by Gutach's mayor yesterday.
"The town hall ramp was installed at that time because it secures the way to school," Eckert explained yesterday.
The Kluser traffic lights protect cyclists, bus passengers and the inhabitants of Bergle.
The plant, which officially went into operation yesterday, is important for the Sulzbachweg/Kirchstraße intersection.
We have the museum, two churches, the spa gardens, the bus stop, a doctor and a bank, as well as the traffic flow from the residential area 'Grub'.
"With the high volume of traffic and pedestrians, another traffic light had to be installed for their safety," says Eckert.
This is also confirmed by Peter Arnold from the Offenburg District Office.
"According to current measurements on the B 33, around 12,000 vehicles pass through the community of Gutach every day, about ten percent of which are heavy goods vehicles," emphasizes Arnold.
Therefore, the construction of another traffic light is more than necessary: "Safety simply takes precedence here," said Arnold.
A total of four traffic shows had been carried out, and a roundabout was also considered, but was rejected due to the narrowness of the Sulzbachweg/Kirchstraße intersection.
According to Arnold, everything was tested when choosing the location of the traffic light poles: "Using a transporter loaded with particularly long logs especially for us, we tested whether these vehicles could drive out of Sulzbachweg onto the B 33 without bending the traffic light poles.
The traffic light system itself, which costs around 15,000 euros, is "the most modern system currently available on the market," explained Arnold.
The system is equipped with colored LEDs that shine so brightly that the lights are clearly visible to drivers, for example, even when the sun is low.
And it is also economical: the older lighting systems consume around 100 watts, the new ones just eight watts.
There are three lighting systems per direction of travel.
Arnold explained the technology of the new facility: "It is equipped with two radar sensors.
When the pedestrian presses the traffic light button, the upper radar sensor tests the traffic situation.
If the road is clear, green is immediately available for pedestrians, if not, it takes about 15 seconds.
Another radar sensor checks whether the green phase can be ended for the pedestrian.
"If a group or people with walking disabilities cross the road, the green phase is extended, so everyone can cross the road safely," Arnold explained.
Of course, the driver has to think along as a partner here and observe the road.
This was not the case yesterday: the pedestrian traffic light had barely turned green when a luxury class vehicle rushed through - in bright red.
Josef Winkler has been writing the hardships of his childhood and youth from his soul for more than 30 years.
The catastrophes of his Catholic village childhood - the speechlessness, the tendency to brute violence and dull sexuality, the narrowness and joylessness - have been described many times by the Carinthian poet.
The Büchner Prize winner is best known as a prose author, and theatre texts are rare in his work.
Collage of Prose Texts Gerhard Fresacher is therefore putting together a collage of prose texts for his performance "Wetterleuchten auf der Zungenspitze" (Weather Lights on the Tip of the Tongue), which can now be seen in Garage X on St. Peter's Square.
The theatremaker combines elements from the autobiographically influenced novel "The Serf" (1987) with prose miniatures from "Corpse Stalking His Family" (2003).
On the largely cleared stage - an important prop: a crumpled sofa on which copulation and masturbation are alluded to - the eight-member ensemble shuffles through the text material.
Yet director Fresacher seems to have little faith in the text.
The 70-minute performance whitewashes the template with a wealth of directorial ideas, familiar from the repertoire of post-dramatic forms of play.
Especially the actresses get their turn with the sometimes somewhat questionable scenic realizations.
They are touched hard, dipped their heads under water, stapled to the wall with their evening gowns.
Crammed into cellophane or bodice, they stalk through the production on dangerously high sticks, either monologuing loudly or lying on the stage floor completely silent.
However, the text hardly conveys itself in this exerted manner.
The evening has its best moments when singing - the spectrum ranges from Deep Purple to folk songs.
Only towards the end does the overexcited performance calm down a bit, and Winkler's downright absurd humor comes to the fore.
A black box in the car?
US road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the decaying highway system and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that fits into the dashboard of every car.
The devices that record every kilometre driven and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads.
The normally rather boring field of road planning has suddenly sparked an intense debate with colourful alliances.
Liberals have allied with environmental groups and are advocating that the government can use the small boxes to record the kilometres driven - and possibly where they were driven - and then use the information to calculate tax assessments.
The Tea Party is appalled.
The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns.
But while no agreement can be reached in Congress, several states are no longer waiting.
They are currently examining how they can switch to a system in which drivers pay per mile driven over the next ten years.
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs, some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring.
This is really a must for our country.
"It's not something we're just possibly going to use," said Hasan Ikhrata, executive director of the Southern California Assn. of Governments, which plans to record the miles driven by all California drivers in the state from 2025.
The way we pay these taxes will change.
The technology is there.
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund, which is financed by the taxes Americans pay at the gas pump, is broke.
But in America they don't fill up as much as they used to.
Cars consume less fuel.
The state mineral oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon (less than 4 eurocents per liter) has not increased for 20 years.
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax even by one cent when fuel prices are high.
"The gasoline tax is simply not sustainable," says Lee Munnich, an expert on traffic legislation at the University of Minnesota.
His state recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mileage-based payment system.
"This represents the most sensible alternative in the long term," he said.
Bureaucrats call it a mileage-based user fee.
Not surprisingly, the idea is popular with urban liberals, as the tax could be used, for example, to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging exhaust gases.
California's planners are using the system to develop strategies to meet the state's ambitious statutory climate change goals.
But Pennsylvania Republican Bill Shuster, chairman of the House Transportation Committee, has also stated that he sees this as the most viable long-term alternative.
The independent marketers of the Reason Foundation are also taken with the idea of letting drivers pay according to the distance covered.
"This is not a tax that disappears into a black hole," explains Adrian Moore, vice president of policy at Reason.
People pay directly for what they get.
The movement is also supported by two former US Secretaries of Transportation, who in a report in 2011 called on Congress to move towards mileage-based billing.
Last year, the US Senate approved a $90 million pilot project that would have included 10,000 cars.
But the majority in the House of Representatives blocked the move, responding to concerns expressed by rural MPs representing people who often have to travel many miles to work or the city on a daily basis.
Nevertheless, several states and large cities are moving in this direction on their own initiative.
Oregon is the most committed, currently recruiting 5,000 drivers for the country's largest experiment.
These drivers will soon be paying the mileage fees to the state instead of the mineral oil tax.
Nevada has already completed a pilot project.
New York City is also considering such a system.
Illinois is testing it with trucks to a limited extent.
And the I-95 coalition, which includes the transportation departments of 17 states on the East Coast (including Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Florida), is currently investigating how the amendment could be introduced.
The concept is not a universal hit.
In Nevada, where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the devices, motorists were skeptical that the government could track their every move.
"Concerns about Big Brother and things like that were a big problem," says Alauddin Khan, head of strategy and results management at the Nevada Department of Transportation.
People didn't want it.
When the test started, the ACLU of Nevada warned on its website: "It would be relatively easy to turn the tachographs into full-fledged surveillance devices."
There would be no need to build a gigantic, bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data on the daily movements of individuals.
Nevada is one of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology that will allow the state to track the kilometers driven, but not exactly when and where.
This, according to Khan, would also reassure the public.
The hunt for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California.
The company did not originally set out to help states with the taxation of motorists.
Rather, their goal was to gain a foothold in an emerging market for motor insurance where drivers would pay on the basis of miles driven.
But the devices she tested are also interesting for road planners, because they do not work with GPS and only provide limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem.
"People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded," said Ryan Morrison, managing director of True Mileage.
Major mistakes were made in some of these public pilot programmes.
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways to do this.
In Oregon, planners are experimenting with giving motorists a range of choices.
You can choose a device with or without GPS.
Or they may choose no device at all and instead pay a flat fee based on the average miles driven by all residents of the state.
Other bodies hope to sell the concept to a suspicious public by equipping the devices with more functions than with fewer.
In New York City, traffic officials want to develop a device for taxation that will also allow parking fees to be paid, insurance to be paid only for kilometers driven, and speed data from other vehicles to be collected in real time, allowing drivers to avoid traffic jams.
"Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system," says a city planning document.
However, some traffic planners wonder if all this talk about paying per mile is not just a huge diversionary tactic.
At the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the San Francisco Bay area, officials said Congress could solve the problem of the bankrupt Highway Trust Fund simply by raising fuel taxes.
An additional one-off fee or an annual levy could be imposed on drivers of hybrid vehicles or other vehicles with low fuel consumption so that they too pay a fair share.
"There is no reason to have surgery if an aspirin is sufficient," said Randy Rentschler, the Commission's Director of Legislation and Public Affairs.
When we do, hundreds of millions of motorists worry about their privacy and many other things.
Königsfeld: Small team is doing well
The volunteer fire brigade mastered its autumn main rehearsal with flying colours despite a lack of personnel.
Only eleven men participated in the exercise.
In his exercise acceptance, department commander Hans Kammerer had chosen the Feder estate in Burgberger Straße.
A short circuit is said to have occurred there during sawing.
Two people were injured by the resulting fire and smoke, but one of them was still able to send an emergency call.
After Hans Kammerer's first examination of the situation, two weir respirators prepared to enter the building.
After a short time the first person was found and escorted outside.
The second person had to be carried.
This was not so easy, because there was also a narrow staircase to overcome.
The building, a workshop with integrated stables for two horses, was not easy to secure.
There was a lot of wood and also bales of straw stored in it.
There were also electric machines for woodworking.
The first extinguishing attack was via the tank in the vehicle.
A further pipeline was laid via an above-ground hydrant about 100 metres away.
Now three firefighting attacks could be designed.
A hollow jet pipe was also used in the building.
Hans Kammerer's aim in the exercise was also to show what can be achieved with limited personnel.
In case of emergency, support is provided by the Königsfeld day task force.
The commander was satisfied with the course of the exercise.
Networking of universities and companies important
During his visit to the district of Breisgau-Hochschwarzwald, the president of the state parliament, Guido Wolf, also visited Titisee-Neustadt to find out where the workers of tomorrow will come from.
At the Support Centre Hochschwarzwald he investigated this important question together with the managing directors of the vocational schools and the district grammar school and the chairmen of the parents' council.
"Education is an important location factor," emphasized Claudia Stehle, director of the Hans-Thoma-School, who presented the networked school project Bildungszentrum Hochschwarzwald.
Wolf was impressed by the model projects for training.
Since 2011 there has been a successful cooperation between the support centre, the district grammar school and the vocational school centre in the forest town.
He also praised the family friendliness in the district.
"It is important not only to keep an eye on the family phase, but due to demographic change, it is also important to focus on the phase around caring for relatives," Wolf explained.
He also mentioned that more and more employees were taking care of their relatives.
"Without the support of the employers, the resulting burden on the employees can lead to a termination of the employment relationship," Wolf said.
But no one can afford to lose qualified workers, he continued.
A further, particularly important factor is the networking of universities and companies.
"For those who have already become acquainted with the advantages of the region during their studies often remain in the regional economy with their acquired knowledge and skills, which contributes to the strengthening of the region", the president of the state parliament expressed his conviction.
For only if sufficient training places were offered could the demand for skilled workers be met.
In his opinion, the advantage of the district's location is its advantageous position in the southwest of Germany, in close proximity to France and Switzerland.
In addition, on his train journey from Titisee-Neustadt to Freiburg, he experienced the efforts already made to expand local public transport.
"Continue to persevere and ensure that public transport is improved," he said to the local politicians present.
Experience an entertaining afternoon with music
For 15 years now, the Kaul family has been inviting the Dietingen senior citizens to coffee, cake and then a snack.
In the past, the older citizens were served in the rest area.
Meanwhile, this afternoon takes place in the St. Josef nursing home.
The home residents were looking forward to the delicious cakes and tarts.
Later we had sausage salad.
Silvia Kimmich-Bantle and her father Karl Kimmich entertained with common melodies.
The more than 100-year-old natural stone wall as the front demarcation of the old schoolyard, which is about to be renovated, to Kirchstraße is to be included in the renovation cost plan of the city of Bräunlingen once again.
In the days before the Kilbig, a small angle wall was installed during the first work of the renovation of the front schoolyard, to stabilize and statically relieve the more than one hundred year old natural stone wall with balustrade.
According to Alexander Misok of the Bräunlingen city planning office, the further procedure is to involve the State Office for Monument Protection in the planning and to draw up a restoration concept for the old wall.
Afterwards, a cost calculation is to be carried out by experts, which is then to be presented to the local council for decision and determination of the further procedure.
A decision on this will probably be made as early as next year.
After the renovation, paving and planting of trees in the old school courtyard within the two side wings of the school built in 1912, the boundary wall in need of renovation will have to be completely repaired in the foreseeable future and placed on a new foundation.
The historical, one hundred year old boundary wall of the old schoolyard to Kirchstraße is in need of renovation, mainly due to water and frost damage, as there is no drainage, and has an arched slope to the front.
Deep cracks in individual stones are evidence of weather damage, but the wall is not currently in danger of collapsing.
A stable wall is a prerequisite for a schoolyard used by pupils, which has been achieved by the current fortification work.
Originally, the schoolyard renovation was even planned for 2008/2009, but high unplanned expenditures caused a postponement.
An important word in the historical school wall restoration, which has even been used for filming, will be spoken by the State Monument Office.
If specifications should come from this side, the city of Bräunlingen hopes for subsidies from the monument conservationists.
The pupils of the Bräunlingen primary school, who are now again taught in a well renovated old school building with a new assembly hall, will soon be able to use the old schoolyard.
Özdemir wants to receive jazz training in Stuttgart
Cem Özdemir, Federal Chairman of the Green Party, has now also joined the ongoing discussions on the future of music academies in Baden-Württemberg.
"I think it is wrong to give up the holistic education at the Stuttgart University of Music," Özdemir told the "Stuttgarter Nachrichten".
Jazz and classical music belong together, especially at the jazz location Stuttgart.
In doing so, Özdemir, who is considered the favourite for a direct mandate in Stuttgart in the federal elections on 22 September, is contradicting the Green-Red state government.
On the basis of an expert study, this is forcing a reorganisation of the five music universities in Baden-Württemberg.
According to this plan, among other things, the Jazz and Pop course of study will be transferred from the Stuttgart University of Music to the Mannheim University of Music.
US border: "Super tunnel" for drug smuggling discovered
At the border between Mexico and the USA, investigators have discovered and shut down a "super tunnel" for drug smuggling.
According to the US customs authorities, the more than 500 metre long tube between Tijuana and San Diego was equipped with electricity, rail tracks and a ventilation system.
Three suspects were arrested, eight tons of marijuana and almost 150 kilograms of cocaine were confiscated.
According to the information provided, the tunnel had not yet been put into use.
"These cartels are stupid if they think they can dig themselves under the radar," said Southern California District Attorney General Laura Duffy at a press conference outside a San Diego warehouse where one end of the tunnel was discovered.
Addressing the drug gangs, Duffy assured: "If you continue to build such tunnels and try to use them, we are determined to make this a huge waste of your dirty money".
Both the US authorities and the Mexican security forces are in a constant struggle against the drug cartels.
Since 2006, more than 77,000 people have been killed in Mexico in connection with drug-related crime.
Designed by experts
Because of the elaborate equipment of the tunnel, investigators assume that it was designed by architects and engineers and that construction took about a year.
The track system was equipped in such a way that electrically operated cars could be used there.
On the Mexican side, the access is in a building 80 meters from the border.
According to the authorities, a ladder leads 20 metres down to the actual tunnel entrance.
The tunnel has a cross-section of 1.20 metres in height and 90 centimetres in width.
It would thus have been suitable for promoting illegal immigration to the USA.
Two of the suspects were arrested in connection with the discovery of cocaine.
The third, a Mexican, was arrested for confiscating marijuana.
All three are threatened with life imprisonment as the maximum penalty, according to officials.
Since 2006, eight such tunnels have been discovered, the press conference in San Diego went on to say.
However, it was the first time that cocaine had been found in such a tunnel construction.
Cocaine is usually smuggled in small quantities and not through tunnels.
This shows the "desperation" of the drug gangs, whose traditional routes are now cut off, said Bill Sherman of the DEA in San Diego.
They would do anything to get into the United States.
No details were released on the detainees, at least one was said to be Mexican.
You can expect prison sentences of up to ten years.
2014 becomes Geisinger festival year
The anniversary of the town of Geisingen on the occasion of the 1250.
Return of the first documentary mention comes closer and closer.
When the year comes to an end in a good eight weeks, the Jubilee Year will begin.
Geisingen and Kirchen-Hausen were first mentioned together in a document in 794.
In churches a document was made in which both places are mentioned.
On 15 March there is to be an official start to the anniversary year, and since Geisingen does not currently have a hall, this kick-off event will take place in the place where both were first mentioned 1250 years ago, in Kirchen-Hausen.
In the context of the anniversary several events are planned both in Geisingen and in Kirchen-Hausen.
Kirchen-Hausen will celebrate the 1250th anniversary of the founding of the church in July on a festive weekend from 18 to 20 July.
Celebrate your return.
On Friday with a ceremony, on Saturday and Sunday with a festival around the Kirchtalhalle.
On this festive weekend there is also the Kirchen-Hausener Kirchenfest.
On the occasion of the jubilee, director of municipal music Rudolf Barth has written a commissioned composition for the city, which will be performed on three dates.
On 21 June together with the Black Forest Association's midsummer celebration, on 12 July in the Arena with fireworks and on 13 December as the first concert of the Stadtmusik in the new Festhalle.
This will be completed and inaugurated in the anniversary year, the official date is on the last weekend of September, on 27 and 28 September.
On the occasion of the Geisinger city anniversary a new chronicle will be published.
"However, it should not only be a chronicle of Geisingen itself, but also a printed work about the Geisingen of today, which consists of Geisingen, Kirchen-Hausen, Leipferdingen, Aulfingen and Gutmadingen", said Mayor Walter Hengstler.
And the Geisingen of today also celebrates its birthday in 2014, in 1974 the current area was completed with the incorporation of the villages.
The new chronicle will then be presented on November 21 or 22 in the new festival hall in Geisingen.
But 2014 is also a year with many other anniversaries.
The Strohglonki jesters' guild begins on 8 February with a customary evening on the occasion of its 60th anniversary, the Harmonie Gutmadingen turns 90 and has its banquet on 29 March and then celebrates the district music festival from 1 to 4 May.
The Altenwerk Leipferdingen will be 40 years old, the Geising school has been at its new location for 50 years and will celebrate this on 10 May, the Musikverein Polyhymnia Leipferdingen will be 150 years old and will celebrate this during the fountain festival from 4 to 7 July.
The town of Geisingen was first mentioned in a deed of donation, which is in the possession of the St. Gallen monastery, in 764.
The document was made in churches (Hausen), which at that time was the place of jurisdiction.
Both municipalities are therefore mentioned in the same document.
Reason to celebrate this 1250th anniversary in 2014 accordingly, in addition the municipal reform is 40 years behind.
Council sets its sights on track systems
Should the level crossing "Am Hirschen" be extensively rebuilt to increase traffic safety?
Yes, the town councils have decided
Schiltach has to spend 220,000 euros on this.
Deutsche Bahn wants to improve the Kinzigtal railway line next year.
In particular, safety at level crossings is to be increased - trains regularly collide with other vehicles throughout Germany.
If the municipalities agree to the reconstruction measures, they must contribute one third of the costs, the rest is shared by the railway and the federal government.
Schiltach's master builder Roland Grießhaber explained the special features of the "Am Hirschen" railroad crossing to the municipal council.
There, the city plans to build a bulge at the level of the tunnel mouth to the west of the railway tracks.
Larger vehicles, for example those transporting long logs, could also be parked there in oncoming traffic without having to block the tracks.
Grießhaber therefore suggested that a necessary retaining wall should be constructed so that the city could widen the adjoining road in due course to ensure a smooth flow of traffic.
This was controversially discussed in the local council, as some council members questioned the necessity of road distribution: Thomas Kipp summed up the mood of the critics with his statement: "Do we have to spend so much money because of so few vehicles?
Mayor Thomas Haas contradicted: The railway crossing "Hirschen" is regularly used for long timber transports.
Even timber from the "Kuhbach" area is partly transported over this route, because the vehicles, which are up to 20 metres long, cannot use the route at the Häberlesbrücke bridge, because they cannot turn into the main road there.
In addition, the route serves as a diversion for those vehicles that are not allowed to use the tunnel when the main road is closed, Haas argued.
Since it was foreseeable that the Kirchberg and Schlossberg tunnels would have to be rebuilt and renovated, as is currently the case in Wolfach, the "Am Hirschen" level crossing could also be of major traffic significance for a longer period of time.
The councils agreed to have the costs of the proposed widening of the road examined.
Nevertheless, the majority of the participants agreed to the reconstruction of the level crossing with the proviso that the necessary retaining wall be built in such a way that the city could extend the adjacent street in the direction of "Bahnhofstraße" to about 5.5 metres for encounter traffic if necessary.
The reconstruction of the level crossing at the Trautwein tannery, on the other hand, could lead to a completely different problem concerning the access to the steeply rising "Geroltzhäuser Weg".
The administration had had the rebuilding plans of the railway examined by the Breinlinger engineering office, as they had doubts as to whether the planned connection of the Geroltzhäuser Weg would then still be possible without further ado.
The investigation concluded that it could not be excluded that the gradient of the road could lead to longer vehicles being mounted.
The responsibility for this, in turn, rests with the city as the road construction authority.
The conversion could therefore lead to liability disputes.
Since both the timber removal and the turning functioned in the current state of expansion, one should not agree to the reconstruction of the level crossing, Haas argued.
The risk of a collision between the train and a vehicle standing on the level crossing is also significantly lower at this point than at the other level crossings, because the central stopping point is located directly next to it, with which there is a good line of sight.
Even trains coming from the main station would have to be braked to a point where there is no danger of collision.
The majority of the councils refused to give their approval to the reconstruction of this level crossing, as the city of Schiltach would have to "take the brunt of the problem with vehicles sitting on it", according to the councils, as the railway could withdraw from responsibility once the construction work was completed.
The committee considers the conversions at the level crossings "Vor Heubach" and "Vor Kuhbach", for which crossing agreements have already been made with the railway, to be unproblematic.
Esa decides on large space missions: Missions for billions
Distant planets, gravitational waves or black holes - experts from the European Space Agency must now agree on two major projects that they want to launch in the next few years.
There were 30 proposals to choose from, five are still in the running.
Distant worlds.
Astronomers have already found more than 1000 planets near other stars.
Whether there are lives on at least some of them, nobody knows.
The choice is difficult: Should one search for gravitational waves?
Or would you rather explore the origin of the cosmos?
Or search for Earth-like planets and perhaps discover alien life?
These are the very questions that are being asked by those responsible at the European Space Agency Esa.
For their "Cosmic Vision" programme, they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that are intended to give a decisive boost to research.
The budget for such "L missions" is about one billion euros each.
The launch is expected to be in 2028 and 2034.
In early September, the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions.
30 ideas were up for debate, five of which have now been shortlisted.
Numerous committees evaluate the proposals and follow up with the researchers.
A final decision is expected to be made by the scientific program committee in the next few days.
The Esa has selected a total of four major questions to which the missions of the "Cosmic Vision" programme initiated in 2007 are to find answers.
What are the conditions for the formation of planets and life?
The exact processes involved in the formation of stars from large gas clouds - and thus also the formation of planets orbiting these stars - are still in the proverbial dark.
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this darkness.
And if a star has planets, under what circumstances can life develop there?
In order to investigate this question, the "Cheops" space telescope is to be launched in 2017, with which 500 already known planetary systems in our immediate vicinity will be examined more closely.
But the possibilities are limited, Cheops is a small mission with a budget of 150 million euros.
With larger instruments, astronomers could map Earth-like planets and even analyse the composition of their atmospheres in search of "biomarkers": Gases which are considered to be an indication of biological activity.
How does the solar system work?
This question, too, is ultimately intended to shed light on the preconditions for the creation of life.
The magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation emanating from it with the planetary system play an important role.
In our solar system these processes can be studied in an exemplary way.
With the "Solar Orbiter", the Esa has already approved an M-class mission (where the budget is around half a billion euros) for this issue.
The probe is scheduled to be launched in 2017 and will closely observe the surface and activity of the Sun.
Jupiter and its moons are also of great interest to researchers.
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system.
To this end, the Esa is planning the first of a total of three L-missions of the "Cosmic Vision" programme.
The probe "Juice" (Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer) is expected to begin its journey in 2022.
Eight years later it reaches Jupiter and is to study the atmosphere of the planet as well as the icy moons Europa, Callisto and Ganymede.
What are the basic physical laws of the universe?
The universe offers many opportunities to study matter under extreme conditions and thus to investigate whether the laws of nature known to us are still valid there.
Perhaps there are also deviations that could show physicists the way to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be unified.
How was the universe created and what does it consist of?
13.7 billion years ago our cosmos was created by the Big Bang.
In addition to the matter we are familiar with, which is made up of stars, planets and living beings like us, there is Dark Matter, whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxy clusters together, and Dark Energy, whose action accelerates the expansion of the universe.
Until now, researchers have not known which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of a second of the Big Bang, nor what dark matter and dark energy are made of.
With "Euclid", the Esa has already approved an M-mission here as well, which is scheduled for launch in 2020.
Using a special telescope, the probe is to examine the distribution of matter in the universe across the entire sky for the first time, thus enabling conclusions to be drawn about the nature of dark matter and dark energy.
Who could make the race
Of the 30 proposals, only two will be left at the end of the selection process.
According to many experts, the best chance of being granted an L-mission is "E-Lisa", a sophisticated concept for detecting gravitational waves.
Physicists understand this to mean changes in the structure of space-time that Albert Einstein predicted almost 100 years ago.
They have not been proven until today.
Elisa could do that, the scientists behind the project hope.
The mission provides for a detector consisting of two or three probes to be deployed in space.
In contrast to installations on Earth, it could also detect gravitational waves that were created during the Big Bang, thus providing new insights into the creation of the cosmos.
Four other proposals are still competing for the second L mission: a large X-ray telescope called "Athena", which is to explore black holes, "Icy Planets", another mission to the outer planets of the solar system, "Prism", a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation, and the "Exoplanet Finder", which is to detect and investigate Earth-like planets.
Proposals for the return transport of samples from Mars, for the exploration of the Moon, Venus and asteroids, and for solar physics, among others, have already been rejected.
Snowden ready to "cooperate" with Germany on US surveillance
Edward Snowden, the whistleblower of the US secret service, has stated that he is prepared to travel to Berlin and testify before the German Bundestag if the US National Security Agency and its director Keith Alexander do not provide answers about their activities.
German member of parliament Hans-Christian Ströbele met Snowden on Thursday in Russia, where he was granted asylum, to discuss his testimony in Germany.
In a letter from Snowden, which was presented to the media in Berlin by Ströbele on Friday, he writes: "Even though the result of my efforts was demonstrably positive, my government continues to treat a dissenting opinion as a breach of loyalty and tries to criminalize political expression with the threat of punishment, where no defense is possible".
But telling the truth is not a crime.
In the letter, Snowden writes that he is convinced that the support of the international community could convince the American government to drop the charges against him.
The charges brought by the US Department of Justice include espionage and theft of government property.
German Interior Minister Hans-Peter Friedrich told Zeit Online: "If Mr. Snowden is willing to talk to German representatives, we will find ways to make this possible.
Relations between the USA and Germany are burdened by allegations that the NSA has tapped Chancellor Angela Merkel's mobile phone.
Thomas Oppermann, the MEP who chairs the parliamentary committee responsible for the secret service, said that the opportunity should be taken to hear Snowden as a witness if possible "without endangering him and completely ruining relations with the USA".
Ströbele, a member of the Green Party, published a picture of himself and Snowden in his Twitter feed.
He was accompanied by two German journalists during his visit to Russia.
Ströbele explained that according to the lawyer of the former NSA employee Snowden could not return to Russia if he left the country.
If Snowden testifies in Germany, he needs an assurance that he is "safe" there, the MP said.
In his letter, Snowden explains that he is facing a "serious and ongoing" campaign of persecution that has driven him from his home country.
However, he was touched by the worldwide reaction to "my act of political expression".
Citizens around the world, as well as high-ranking politicians - even in the United States - have called the revelations about an uncontrolled system of comprehensive surveillance a public service.
In his letter, Snowden makes an offer of cooperation to the German authorities "when the difficulties surrounding the humanitarian situation have been resolved".
Frontier Airlines charges for hand baggage
Frontier Airlines plans to charge up to $100 for passengers who wish to carry hand luggage on their flight.
Frontier Airlines intends to charge up to $100 for a piece of hand luggage and $2 for coffee or lemonade, although the announcement on Wednesday said that passengers could keep the whole can.
The new fee applies to hand luggage in the baggage compartment above the seat, small bags under the seat are still free.
Frontier explained that they charge $25 if the fee is paid in advance and $100 for passengers who pay only at the gate.
Frontier spokeswoman Kate O'Malley said the $100 fee is designed to encourage travelers to make advance payment.
"We do not wish to charge this amount," she explained.
Airlines began charging for first and second checked baggage in 2008.
Passengers who tried to avoid them therefore stuffed as much as possible into hand luggage, with the result that the luggage compartments above the seat are often overfilled.
Charges are one way to encourage passengers to take less on board.
O'Malley said the new fee isn't really about making money.
It was about Frontier's most loyal customers, who had clearly expressed that it was becoming increasingly difficult to find space in the compartment above the seat.
Passengers who buy their tickets on the airline's website do not have to pay.
This means that a passenger at Frontier's gate may be allowed one piece of baggage free of charge, but the next person must pay $100 for a comparable piece of baggage.
O'Malley explained that Frontier's website and check-in procedures would be changed so that passengers would be informed of the fee before they came to the gate.
Frontier's new hand baggage fee will not come into effect until the summer, but there is no exact date yet.
Passengers often complain about baggage surcharges and other fees, but airlines like to use them.
They argue that the transport of baggage costs money and passengers should pay for this service if they want it.
Many on Wall Street see the new baggage charges as a sign that the airlines are earning enough money to cover the cost of air travel after years of losses.
However, most of them have so far refrained from charging for hand baggage.
Spirit Airlines Inc. was the first to charge hand baggage fees three years ago and was later followed by Allegiant Air, also a budget airline.
The only other airline with such a fee is Wizz Air of Hungary, explained airline consultant Jay Sorensen, who is closely monitoring the additional fees.
He estimated in a December 2011 report that the hand baggage fee would earn Spirit $50 million annually.
Sorensen, who formerly held a senior position with Midwest Airlines, recently flew with Spirit and was curious what to expect at the gate when passengers were confronted with the company's unusual hand baggage charge.
"The boarding process was one of the smoothest I have experienced in my career in aviation," he said.
I expected to see teeth grinding and fisticuffs at the gate.
"The plane was full," he explained, "and the boarding went like clockwork."
Frontier also follows Spirit in the $2 that is charged for coffee, tea, lemonade or juice.
The company explained that passengers who bought lemonade or juice could keep the whole can and coffee was refilled free of charge.
Water is still free.
US Airways had briefly tried to charge for soft drinks in 2008, but reversed this seven months later after passengers complained and no other major airline had followed suit.
Frontiers' move to charge for hand luggage when passengers do not buy directly from the airline is the latest initiative to direct customers to its own website.
Airlines pay online travel agencies like Orbitz $10 to $25 per ticket sold.
This provides an incentive for all airlines to encourage passengers to buy directly from them rather than through an online travel agency.
Frontier has gone furthest in this area, however.
In September, the company began awarding only half as many frequent flyer miles when booking through an online travel agency.
On Wednesday, the miles were reduced once again to 25 percent of the flight distance.
Therefore, a 1000 mile Frontier flight booked with a third-party provider will only earn customers 250 miles.
Passengers can also reserve seats exclusively by purchasing directly on the Frontier website.
Frontier has a loyal customer base at its Denver headquarters, but business is shrinking and the company is losing money.
Revenues declined by 9% and flight capacity shrank by almost 13% in the first quarter, according to the financial report published on Wednesday by the parent company, Republic Airways Holdings Inc.
Republic has tried to get a grip on Frontier's finances as part of the sale of the company.
Proverbs come from the Bible
About 40 women attended the last women's breakfast of this year in the Lutheran parish of Bisingen.
The theme of the day in the parish hall was "Proverbs from the Bible" and "Proverbs from the Middle Ages".
After breakfast, Zita Köhler, the chairwoman of the parish council, gave a lecture on the biblical proverbs.
"Proverbs contain wisdom, rules or warnings," she explained.
She compared several proverbs with the corresponding Bible passages and explained their meaning.
She called proverbs like: Let the wooden eye be watchful as scales fall from the eyes, let it cast an eye on someone, the Lord gives His own in sleep, wash his hands in innocence.
Several times the speaker also let her audience guess which proverb it was.
The parish councillor Christel Dehner took up the idioms from the Middle Ages: Third time's the charm, third time's the charm.
She explained the meaning and origin of the phrases she called "bridges to the past".
At the end a raffle was raffled off.
The prizes were laid out on a table, covered and humorously paraphrased, before being presented to the winners.
Among the visitors of the breakfast round also Roman Waizenegger, the candidate for mayor, joined in.
Learning instead of unemployment: Pilot project for unskilled workers in tourism
A pilot project for the tourism industry is starting today in the Mecklenburg Lake District.
Under the leadership of the Federal Employment Agency, 49 women and men who are already working in the industry as unskilled workers are to be qualified as specialists for hotels and restaurants over three winters.
"What is new is that the six-month courses end with degrees," said Carmen Wiechert of the Neubrandenburg Employment Agency.
The benefits are manifold: the participants do not become unemployed, the companies get trained specialists, who are increasingly missing in hotels and restaurants, and the agency does not have to finance unemployment.
The Chamber of Industry and Commerce in Neubrandenburg and the German Hotel and Restaurant Association (Dehoga) Mecklenburg-Vorpommern are also involved in the project.
NSA explains that an "internal error" and not hackers are to blame for the crash of the site
The shadowy National Security Agency stated late Friday that a bug paralyzed their public website for several hours and not hackers, as was claimed online.
"NSA.gov was unavailable for several hours tonight because an internal error occurred during a scheduled update," the spy agency explained in an e-mail message.
The problem will be solved this evening.
The claim that the failure was caused by a distributed denial of service attack (DDoS) is not true.
In the early evening hours, online server trackers noticed that the NSA website had been unavailable for at least six hours and continued to be unavailable to some users.
Earlier, an NSA spokesperson told ABC News that the agency's sensitive internal network was "in no way" compromised.
Classified information is not in danger, the spokesman said.
At least one group of hacktivists claimed to have crippled the NSA website with a DDoS attack.
In such attacks, the target website is flooded with page views until the servers are overloaded and the website collapses.
The cyber tactics are relatively simple and the attacks are not designed to penetrate the internal network of the target system.
The formerly super-secret NSA, once nicknamed the No Such Agency, is now in the public eye and faces harsh criticism at home and abroad following revelations about its extensive surveillance program that have become public in recent months - a result of secret NSA data stolen and published by disillusioned former NSA employee Edward Snowden.
The growing controversy surrounding the secret service fuelled initial speculation that the incident today was the result of a targeted cyber operation.
The number of people without jobs fell slightly in October by 22 to 1,307.
Although the rate of 3.1 percent is better than last year and also better than in September, "we had hoped for more," says Monika Felder-Bauer, deputy branch manager of the employment agency in Sonthofen.
This is because many companies have so far reacted cautiously when hiring new staff.
According to Felder-Bauer, one reason for this is that "we have hardly any skilled workers in the trades, in health care and in care for the elderly".
Due to seasonal factors, job offers for personnel in the hotel and restaurant industry have been coming in again since September.
The winter season begins there in mid-December.
You will find the complete background report on this in the Allgäuer Anzeigeblatt of 31.10.2013 (page 33).
Bombardier's profits down after decline in deliveries and orders
Canadian aircraft and railroad manufacturer Bombardier Inc reported a 15% drop in net profit on Thursday, after coming under pressure from declining orders and deliveries of aircraft in the third quarter and contract problems in the railroad sector.
Bombardier, based in Montreal, also did not publish flight test data for its brand new CSeries aircraft and did not provide any new information as to whether the aircraft could go into commercial service next September according to the ambitious schedule.
The maiden flight of the test aircraft a month and a half ago has so far been followed by only three further take-offs, which makes it questionable whether the test phase will proceed as planned.
The results fell short of forecasts and led to a price drop of over eight percent on the Toronto stock exchange.
Cameron Doerksen, an analyst at National Bank Financial, lowered his rating on Thursday from "outperform" to "sector perform" in view of the fact that the share has limited price potential in the next one to two quarters.
"Although weaker delivery figures for aircraft were largely expected, we are clearly disappointed with the margin development in the transport sector," Doerksen said in a customer letter.
We believe that Bombardier will receive new orders for the CSeries as the aircraft's test program progresses.
However, if no new orders are announced in the coming months, we expect the market to become more sceptical about the program.
Bombardier hopes that the CSeries aircraft series will catapult the company into the lower market segment currently dominated by Boeing and Airbus.
The first test aircraft was presented to the public in March and flew for the first time in September after months of delays.
However, so far, binding orders for the CSeries are moderate at 177, as potential buyers are waiting for the results of flight tests and want to see if the company's claims regarding fuel efficiency and cost savings potential of the new jetliner are true.
Currently, there are a total of 403 orders and commitments from 15 customers and companies.
CEO Pierre Beaudoin is confident that Bombardier will achieve its target of 300 firm orders when the jet begins commercial operation.
The company management also assured analysts and the media on Thursday that the program was on schedule.
"The test aircraft did not stay on the ground longer than expected," Beaudoin said during a conference call, adding that ground tests and software updates were scheduled while the aircraft was on the ground.
Every manufacturer plans differently.
We decided to take a first flight and then add a revision period, which we did.
This happens during the entire flight program.
The second of five test aircraft is expected to take off in the next few weeks, the rest shortly after, the company said.
Nevertheless, analysts remain sceptical as to whether the first customer will be able to operate a CSeries aircraft twelve months after the maiden flight.
Bombardier stated that it was reviewing its commissioning schedule (EIS) and would update it in the coming months.
"The slow progress of the flight tests - even though they appear to be in line with Bombardier's internal planning - reinforces our view that the commissioning will be postponed until the first quarter of 2015," Doerksen said.
In the third quarter ended September 30, Bombardier's net income fell to $147 million or 8 cents per share from $172 million or 9 cents per share the year before.
The adjusted earnings per share remain unchanged at 9 cents.
Sales fell slightly, from 4.2 to 4.1 billion dollars.
Analysts had expected a profit of 10 cents per share and a turnover of 4.56 billion dollars, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
The world's fourth largest aircraft manufacturer claims to have delivered 45 aircraft this quarter, down from 57 last year.
Net orders fell from 83 aircraft to 26.
The order backlog in the aerospace sector amounted to 32.9 billion dollars on September 30, unchanged from December 31.
"In the aerospace sector, results were in line with our targets, but the low order intake and overall market conditions were disappointing," said Beaudoin.
Sales in the aerospace sector fell by 13 percent to two billion dollars.
Bombardier, the world's largest rail manufacturer, announced that sales in this sector rose by almost eleven percent to 2.1 billion dollars.
The order book in the Transportation Division amounted to 32.6 billion dollars on 30 September, a slight increase compared with 31 December.
The profit margin in the Transportation division was affected by processing problems with some major contracts.
According to company management, there will be new targets for the fourth quarter.
In afternoon trading on Thursday, Bombardier stock fell 8.5 percent to 4.83 Canadian dollars after it was also announced that Google's CFO Patrick Pichette will join the board.
Brazilian Embraer SA, the world's third largest commercial aircraft manufacturer and bomber's closest rival, reported a 10% drop in quarterly profits on Thursday.
USA: Shooting at Los Angeles airport
An unidentified man fired shots at LAX Airport on Friday morning (local time).
While the airport management informed Twitter via the short news service that the shooter was in custody, the "Los Angeles Times" reported that the man was dead.
A security guard had also been killed.
Media also reported several injuries.
US President Barack Obama will be kept constantly informed of the situation, said White House spokesman Jay Carney.
The incident took place in Terminal 3 and eyewitnesses said they saw a gunman with a rifle in one of the departure lobbies, according to several media reports.
A traveller told CNN that many people had sought shelter in panic.
Travelers would have cried and children would have wept.
Panic broke out among the waiting people, and many hid behind chairs out of fear.
He heard two shots, a traveler told the "Los Angeles Times".
An employee of the security agency TSA had suffered a gunshot wound to the foot.
The scene had been "like in a film".
Afterwards he himself was taken to a security area, the man reported.
The shots are said to have been fired near a security checkpoint.
Airport building evacuated
Television pictures showed numerous ambulances and police cars pulling up in front of a terminal.
Hundreds of people were taken from the building to safety.
Users on Twitter posted photos of a special operations team and a rifle lying on the ground.
According to the airport management via Twitter, the incident began at 9.30 am (local time).
The access roads were closed, which, according to CNN, created long backlogs.
Except for landings, air traffic had been temporarily suspended, it was said.
However, CNN also showed several planes during take-off.
Terminal 3 is mainly served by smaller US airlines.
Los Angeles LAX Airport is one of the largest airports in the USA.
Cocaine addict lawyer who warned drug boss about police investigation goes to jail
Basharat Ditta, 42, passed on information to underworld great Neil Scarborough
The lawyer was afraid that his secret drug addiction would come to light
He was sentenced by the Liverpool Crown Court to three years in prison
A well-known defence lawyer, who warned a drug lord against a major police investigation because he was afraid his secret drug addiction could be exposed, was sentenced to three years in prison.
Basharat Ditta, 42, provided underworld great Neil Scarborough with sensitive information about investigations into his drug-trafficking activities after he was compromised by his own cocaine addiction.
The lawyer, nicknamed "Bash" and hailed by criminologists as "first class", was arrested at his home in 2011 after police monitored Scarborough, whom he had represented in an earlier drug case.
Officials observed Scarborough (32) delivering three bags of cocaine to the barrister's home in Blackburn, Lancashire, while he was at a barrister's lunch with colleagues.
The investigation revealed that Ditta was a regular user of Class A drugs, after tests found traces of cocaine in his hair, on his wallet and on credit cards.
Over a period of eight months between January and August 2011, he attempted to obtain unauthorised information about the arrest of two men on behalf of Scarborough and one of his partners.
All four suspects were then under police surveillance as part of a major investigation into heroin and cocaine trafficking in Lancashire, Cumbria, Merseyside, Berkshire and West Yorkshire.
They were later arrested along with 32 others after police seized 1.5 million pounds of heroin and cocaine and 200,000 pounds of cash in a series of house searches.
Ditta, 42, passed on information to the criminals because he was afraid that his drug addiction could become public.
Today Ditta, who works for Forbes Solicitors in Blackburn, was found guilty and sentenced on two counts of obstruction of justice at Liverpool Crown Court after a three-week trial.
He admitted to cocaine possession in a previous interview.
The lawyer was convicted after the police found out during their investigation of Scarborough that he had been in regular telephone contact with Ditta in February 2011.
Two investigators followed the suspect and saw him go to Ditta's house and put the 60 percent purity drugs under the lawyer's trash can in a black golf glove.
Shortly after he had delivered the drugs, Scarborough was on the phone regularly with Ditta, who was at dinner at the Blackburn Rovers football stadium in Ewood Park.
The lawyer returned home, got the drugs and then nine messages were exchanged between the two.
In court, Ditta became known to be a "regular user" of cocaine after class A drugs were discovered in his hair, wallet and credit cards during tests.
Ditta was later arrested, but denied using cocaine and said he talked to the alleged dealer because he was his client, claiming that their discussion was subject to "attorney-client privilege.
During his arrest Ditta took his wallet and tried to remove a number of credit cards, but they were seized and a hair sample was taken from his head.
During the police interrogation, he stated that he ran an office both at his home address and at work and that clients called him at home for legal matters.
In court it became known that he had called key players in the drug trade, some of whom he had previously represented, after significant arrests and informed them of what the investigators knew about them.
District Attorney Anne Whyte said "A criminal lawyer should know better than anyone that you don't break the law."
Ditta is accused of abusing his position as a criminal defense attorney because he got too involved with certain clients.
The relationship in question is not simply that of a drug dealer, but a drug dealer who supplies his lawyer with drugs.
Some of his communications were undoubtedly legitimate, because he was the lawyer of these people.
But this went far beyond the limits of a normal relationship between lawyer and client.
He countered the police investigations as far as possible so that they could continue their criminal activities.
Mr. Ditta thus brought his profession into disrepute.
He was too close to certain clients, particularly Scarborough, and he allowed his independence to be compromised.
Ditta denied any wrongdoing and claimed, "If I were a corrupt lawyer, which I am not, and I wanted to pass on information to Scarborough, I would not wait 15 hours, I would do it immediately."
But after the hearing, Superintendent Lee Halstead of Lancashire police said: "Mr Ditta made the step from a criminal defence lawyer to a criminal the moment he started buying drugs from organised criminals.
His cocaine addiction led to a hopeless compromise and made him receptive to the motives of leading members of organised crime, who instructed him to obtain valuable information about police investigations.
Lawyers must maintain the highest standards of integrity and inspire public trust and confidence.
Ditta betrayed this trust and tried to hide behind the façade of his profession.
Lancashire's Serious and Organised Crime Unit led the investigation into Ditta, which also resulted in three convictions for cocaine possession and obstruction of justice, underlining our determination to bring criminals to justice.
This case should be a warning to criminals and shows that nobody can escape the arm of the law.
We'll find you and take you to court.
Scarborough himself was sentenced to 14 years in prison after he was found guilty of conspiring to traffic heroin, cocaine and cannabis.
Thirty-five other 'persons involved in drug trafficking' were sentenced to total penalties of 153 years for drug offences.
On his website, Ditta published a Q&A section about himself in which he stated that his dream job was to represent clients on death row in America as a lawyer, that his ultimate dinner guest was Mohammed Ali and that inequality of opportunity was the motivation for his work.
Revolutionary work of church music
At the end of the celebrations on the occasion of its 160th anniversary, the Liederkranz Dunningen will frame two church services with the "Deutsche Messe" by Franz Schubert.
Following the great success of the musical "Rock my Life", which thrilled the audience in the spring of this year, the Liederkranz will enrich two church services at the end of the anniversary year with a performance by Franz Schubert of the German Trade Fair.
On Saturday, 26 October, this extraordinary mass will be heard from 19 during the evening mass in the St. Martinuskirche in Dunningen and on Sunday, 27 October, from 10.15 am during the service in the St. Johannes Baptistkirche in Lackendorf.
The so-called German Mass with the original title "Gesänge zur Feier des heiliges Opfers der Messe", D 872, is a sacred musical work by the composer Franz Schubert from 1826 and was considered almost revolutionary at the time of its creation.
The mass is performed within the framework of the church services, as the client Johann Philipp Neumann had in mind.
Under the direction of Hermann Schneider, the choir is accompanied by the wind section of the Musikverein Frohsinn Tennenbronn and Noemi Lokodi on the organ.
Haslach: Skepticism gives way to increasing confidence
With the elections to the parish council in 2015, for example, fundamental changes will take place in the Haslach (SE) pastoral care unit.
There is then only one common parish council for all six parishes.
In a joint meeting on Saturday, the committees from Haslach, Hofstetten, Mühlenbach, Fischerbach, Steinach and Welschensteinach prepared themselves for the changes.
For nothing more can be changed in the fundamental decisions of the diocese and it is up to the parish councils to implement them as satisfactorily as possible.
In the course of the day, it became particularly clear that scepticism about the new is giving way hesitantly but increasingly to confidence.
The extremely constructive discussions of the six committees with the full-time pastoral team ranged from the ideas and expectations of the 2015 innovations to concrete proposals on the future composition and size of the parish council.
Regional Dean Georg Schmitt explained the new guidelines for pastoral care units in the Archdiocese of Freiburg with a presentation.
According to this, the SE Haslach as a church congregation will in future form a corporation under public law, which will assume the rights and obligations of the six individual church congregations to date.
There will be only one joint parish council and one foundation council, in which the pastor is represented by virtue of office.
At least two elected members from each parish should be represented, and in the six parishes so-called community teams are formed locally.
Their task in the future will be to promote church life in the village.
The question about the finances of the individual parish then revealed a considerable need for discussion.
The innovations provide that accumulated assets in the parishes are retained for a specific purpose.
In contrast, the liabilities are transferred to the municipality as a whole.
There were great concerns, especially with regard to the large planned investments, whose obligation then affects all parishes.
"Also in the past, investments were only made in projects that could be managed by the individual parishes alone", put Haslach's parish council chairman Bruno Prinzbach into perspective.
Practical experience with a joint committee for five parishes was described by Barbar Ritter, the chairperson of the committee in the pastoral care unit Schutterwald-Neuried.
In 2006, they set themselves the task of "becoming one, remaining five" and found that this is not so easy.
The committees of the Haslach Pastoral Care Unit then set about answering questions about the future composition and size of the joint parish council and the practical work of the parish teams.
The elaborations will be concretised in further meetings and decided upon in a further joint meeting of all six bodies next spring.
At the end, parish councillor Michael Schöner from Steinach presented the new logo of the pastoral unit, which was approved by a clear majority.
Electricity is becoming more expensive in Pfullendorf
The citizens of Pfullendorf must prepare themselves for higher electricity costs.
As Jörg-Arne Bias, managing director of the municipal utilities, confirmed to the SÜDKURIER, a family of four from Pfullendorf incurs additional costs of 70 to 90 euros per year.
The main reason for the upcoming price increase is the rise in the so-called EEG levy from 5.277 to 6.3 cents per kilowatt hour.
This levy is reset every year in October by the four operators of the major electricity lines.
They quantify the additional costs they will incur as a result of the energy system transformation, which they can levy through a levy on the electricity price.
The Pfullendorf public utility company is the last link in this chain.
The supervisory board of the energy company had even assumed a higher levy in its forecasts, as Jörg-Arne Bias reports.
Now the concrete figures would have to be calculated before the municipal utilities could inform their customers of the exact price increase next week.
"We are assuming an increase of 1 cent plus x," said Bias, with the figure likely to be closer to 2 cents.
Traffic light on steady red: Watch out for waiting time
Sometimes a traffic light just doesn't turn green.
The contact loop in the road does not react or the light signal is defective.
What should you do then - run a red light?
If an affected person has waited long enough at a red traffic light and the crossing is clear, he can continue driving, explains Stuttgart lawyer Ralf Becker in the magazine "Motorrad".
However, the waiting period must be "reasonable", which could be interpreted differently from case to case.
Becker advises to wait at least five minutes before assuming that the traffic light is not functioning properly.
However, anyone who continues the journey despite red lights must be aware that he is fully responsible for any accident caused by them.
Anyone who is patient for less than five minutes may not wait long enough, warns Becker and refers to a decision of the Hamm Higher Regional Court.
In the negotiated case, a driver had ignored the traffic light after about three minutes of continuous red light and had to answer for a negligent red light violation.
The traffic light was not defective, but changed to green a little later.
He was spared a driving ban because of the special situation - but not the fine.
Municipal council is pleased about solid budget
Mayor Ralph Gerster always has a good laugh when the budget is discussed in municipal council meetings.
The community bag in Herdwangen-Schönach is well filled and the administration has not known about debts since 2005.
The 2012 financial year can also be considered a complete success in this sense.
This became clear when the annual financial statements for 2012 were presented.
As Andrea Rothmund explained, the administrative budget of around 7.6 million euros was over one million euros higher than planned.
The surplus of the administrative budget, at around 1,8 million euro, was also about one million euro above the estimate.
The surplus is mainly due to higher trade tax revenues and the municipal share of income tax.
The asset budget was also again well above the planned figures.
Instead of the planned 1.5 million euros, it amounted to 2.5 million euros last year.
"This is mainly due to the higher allocation from the administrative budget," said Rothmund.
Since fewer investments than planned were made in the 2012 financial year, the allocation to reserves was also higher.
Overall, the general reserve was increased by around 2.1 million euros to a total of 4.9 million euros.
Mayor Ralph Gerster thanked Rothmund and her team for their good work.
"You don't just shake this kind of work out of your sleeve," Gerster praised with a glance at the annual financial statements.
He and the municipal councils were visibly pleased with the good figures.
It may sound paradoxical, but it is precisely these good figures that could soon cost citizens dearly.
Due to the good financial situation, the community was able to avoid high collection rates in the past.
According to Gerster, this in turn has led to a number of cuts in subsidies from the state.
There are conditions for these grants from various compensation funds.
Among other things, the cities and municipalities applying for subsidies must provide certain assessment rates.
"We have to look at the issue of collection rates, because in the coming years there are investments pending for which we would like to have subsidies," Gerster announced in this context.
Nagold: Hugo Wermter in the choir for 60 years
At 60 years of age as a singer, Hubert Wermter's history with the men's choir Cäcilia is almost twice as long as that of the autumn festival, during which he was solemnly honoured.
Hubert Wermter stood on stage as usual in the colours of his male choral society.
Even after 60 years, he still enjoys singing with the choir, which has become more than dear to him.
Wermter was also active in the association, including 28 years as a member of the committee.
He received several awards for his commitment and loyalty to the association: Jörg Kohr, pastoral adviser on behalf of the Cäcilienverband Rottenburg-Stuttgart, presented him - since the choir is also a church choir - with a certificate of the association and a letter of honour signed by Bishop Gebhard Fürst.
His singer colleagues presented him with the certificate of the German Choir Association and an engraved pewter plate.
In addition to the honouring, the 31st Herbstfest took place in the usual manner: With the MGV Betra, the Liederkranz Salzstetten, the singing section Baisingen and the local music club, the Vollmaringer had invited a colourful mixture of different choirs and singing styles, which entertained the approximately 400 visitors.
The MGV Vollmaringen opened with atmospheric songs like "Im Weinparadies" and "Lustig, ihr Brüder".
They prepared a little serenade for their honorary singer Hubert Wermter - Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's "Bundeslied".
The men's choir Betra also sang classic choral songs like "Jägerwerben" by Julius Wengert, "Weit, weit weg" by Hubert Goisern and the folk song "Wann du durchgehst durchs Tal".

The singing section of the Baisinger sports club came back to its home territory with "Was isch der Schwob" by Hans Süssmuth and Robert Pappert's "Bierlied", where the Vollmaringer Musikverein provided the crowning musical finale.
For the children there was a small side programme - "Oma Hanne" alias Hannelore Stollsteimer performed a Punch and Judy show and read a few stories to keep the children busy during lunchtime.
Children's dreams come true
The kindergartens and day care centres in the Zollernalbkreis are receiving mail these days.
The Black Forest Messenger, in cooperation with Bauhaus and the Sparkasse Zollernalb, would like to support the institutions in realising their building and beautification wishes.
Does the kindergarten need a new sandbox?
All kindergartens, day-care centres and crèches from the entire Zollernalbkreis can take part in the campaign.
If you have a building or embellishment wish for your facility, you can apply with it to the Black Forest Messenger.
Be creative with your children and surprise the jury of the kindergarten construction site campaign.
A jury, consisting of representatives of Schwarzwälder Bote, Bauhaus and Sparkasse Zollernalb, will select three wishes from all entries.
What are the requirements for participation?
The wish should be realizable with building material with a maximum value of 2000 Euro and on one (action) day.
In addition, the winner himself must provide for many hard-working construction helpers.
What is it about the action day and the helpers?
Bauhaus provides the material with the support of the Sparkasse Zollernalb.
It will be delivered to the kindergarten on the agreed day and should then be processed directly by the helpers.
Helpers can be parents, grandparents, friends, associations and of course the educators and children themselves.
Kenyan press outraged by controversial media law
"We find ourselves in a frightening situation and one may ask: what is stopping Parliament from simply abolishing judicial independence tomorrow," was the question in the newspaper, which considers the bill to be unconstitutional.
"The law is draconian and very punitive and we reject it," said Cyrus Kamau, CEO of Capital Group, which includes CapitalFM, one of Kenya's most respected independent radio stations and news websites.
He said the new media tribunal "will always be biased because it is an extension of the government," and restrictions on content and advertising would damage Kenya's position in the global economy.
"I hope the President listens to us and we appeal to him to reject this bill and send it back to Parliament," he said.
According to The Star newspaper, the new law "effectively puts the government in a stranglehold on the media". In contrast, The Standard writes that democracy and freedom of speech in Kenya has suffered "a heavy blow", and calls the draft "draconian".
The adoption of the law is one of a series of measures to strengthen national security in the wake of the September attacks by armed Islamists on the West Gate Shopping Centre.
The Kenyan media incurred the wrath of the authorities by publishing footage from security cameras showing units sent to the scene allegedly robbing the luxury shopping centre.
Police Chief David Kimaiyo responded by summoning two journalists and a leading media representative for interrogation, although the subpoena was withdrawn after a media outcry.
Under the new law, media houses can be fined up to 20 million Kenyan shillings, and individual journalists can be fined up to one million, as well as the further risk of losing their professional recognition or being excluded from official press accreditation.
The tribunal also has the right to confiscate the property of those concerned if a fine is not paid.
According to the Daily Nation, "even a single penalty can bankrupt most radio stations.
In addition, the newspaper believes that these measures could have a devastating effect on what it describes as Kenya's "vibrant blogosphere".
If they silenced the media, politicians could do whatever they wanted with impunity.
"No one will ever know," wrote Mutuma Mathiu, a journalist with the Nation, who describes the Kenyan media as a crucial control factor in public life.
"If you leave politicians to themselves, they will lead the country into bankruptcy and take us back to the days of hunter-gatherers," he commented.
The Kenyan legislators have already attracted public anger in the past.
In May they voted to reverse the cuts ordered by the National Compensation Commission and reinstated their hefty salaries of around 532,000 shillings per month tax-free - among the highest in the world.
Bad-Dürrheim: A dream comes true for FC
Despite the cold weather and rain, the official inauguration ceremony for the artificial turf sports field lost none of its significance for the city and the football club.
Everyone had probably wished for a more pleasant ceremony last Saturday, but Peter did not want to play along.
So all those who came without an umbrella or who for some reason could not hold one were left behind.
The musicians who framed the ceremony felt the same way as many of the speakers.
That's why FC chairman Albrecht Schlenker, who spoke of the fulfilment of a dream, also got wet.
His thanks went first and foremost to Mayor Walter Klumpp, who was strongly committed to the implementation of the project, to the municipal council, the companies involved and the members of the association who contributed.
Here especially Lothar Held, Paul Weizenegger, Heiner Gail and Peter Graf.
The spry pensioners laid 400 square metres of paving stones for the new paths.
This remarkable voluntary commitment was also honoured by Karl Rombach, member of the state parliament.
Further greetings were given to the municipal sports committee Hubert Baier, the district chairman of the South Baden football association, Kuno Kayan, and Friedrich Knorr from the planning office, who announced a donation for the club's youth department.
Mayor Klumpp recalled that recurring weather-related influences in spring and autumn damaged the original lawn in such a way that it could not be played on.
The first thoughts of how to solve the problem were already made 15 years ago, when the construction of a third pitch on the grounds of the football club or the secondary school at Salinensee was considered.
Both were rejected again.
Six years ago, thoughts of creating an artificial turf sports field arose, which was generally regarded as the ultimate solution.
Concrete planning began two years ago when FC took over the Schabelstube on a leasehold, agreed to a cost sharing of EUR 100,000 for the construction of the pitch and the state approved subsidies of EUR 104,000.
In October 2012, the municipal council decided to assume the remaining 356,000 euros of the total costs of 560,000 euros, Klumpp summarized.
Construction of the 68 by 108 metre artificial turf pitch began on 4 June.
During the construction phase, which lasted over three months, 3000 cubic metres of earth were removed, half of which was used to build a dirt bike track.

A vignette is a "flat rate for frequent driving and thus ecologically counterproductive", explained Florian Pronold, the SPD's chief negotiator for transport, in a letter to his parliamentary group.
There was a threat of diversionary traffic on country roads, which were already accident black spots.
Moreover, the introduction of a toll for all passenger cars would, in Pronolds' view, only be a first step.
"There is a danger that the compensation for Germans will be cancelled at a later date," he said.
