Vienna Airport abolishes passenger calls
Mr Max Maier, please come to gate 24.
Announcements like these will no longer be made at Vienna International Airport in the future.
A large part of the loudspeaker announcements are thus omitted - the noise level is to be significantly reduced.
Creating a more relaxed atmosphere is the aim of this innovation.
As Airport Spokesman Peter Kleemann announced to Radio Wien, Vienna International Airport is following an international trend by discontinuing announcements that concern individual persons.
The airports in Copenhagen, Frankfurt and Dubai, for example, have already decided to do without the noisy calls.
The elimination of these announcements - on average around 200 personal calls are made through the loudspeakers on any given day - should make things quieter at the airport in future.
"Experience has also shown that these individual announcements were perceived relatively little, while at the same time all other information about changed gates or departure times is a bit lost here," Kleemann said in an interview with the radio station.
Highlander-Games at Kaltenhof
In addition to brake van pulling with tractors, there will be a second competition at the agricultural autumn festival at Kaltenhof from 6 to 8 September.
On Saturday, September 7, the Highlander Games will start at 13.30 hrs.
Although they have a Scottish tradition, they have a Swabian touch at Kaltenhof.
Teams and individual fighters compete in the disciplines of tree trunk throwing, horseshoe throwing and water bucket carrying.
The tree trunk is four and a half meters long and weighs 25 to 30 kilograms.
"It doesn't depend on the distance," explains organizer Peter Saile.
The log must be thrown off vertically, should roll over once and then come to rest straight.
This is rated with the most points.
In horseshoe throwing, accuracy is the key.
From a distance of eight metres, the ball is thrown onto a stake.
The participants have to prove their skill and strength by carrying water buckets over 50 meters.
Time and water quantity in a vat are measured at the end.
Two from each "clan" or team may then participate in the individual competition.
The winners of the team and individual competition will receive prizes.
You can start training as early as 10 am.
A suitable outfit is desired, for example the competitors can compete in a tartan skirt.
But also Swabian traditional costume is allowed.
For the "Outfit" the jury awards a few bonus points.
You can register until one hour before the start of the competition.
With the Scottish-Swabian Highlander Games and the tractor pulling, which starts half an hour earlier, there will be plenty of action on the festival grounds on Saturday.
In the evening the brass music lovers will get their money's worth.
At 19 o'clock the birabohemian brass band music from Schömberg creates the big entertainment evening.
The band plays lively polkas and marches.
But their repertoire also includes soulful waltzes and a rich big band sound.
Among the participants will be Heinz Koch from Weilen unter den Rinnen, known as a singing innkeeper and black sausage baron.
In Dornhan he has already performed at the Christmas market and with the fool guild.
On Sunday, the Leinstetten music association entertains for a morning pint, from 2 p.m. the Böffingen farmers' band is a guest, and the "oldies" then let the party come to an end.
Kick-off is already on Friday the Stoppelackerparty with DJ Ralf.
Further programme items on Saturday and Sunday include the vintage car and tractor meeting, exhibitions by companies on the subject of agriculture and forestry.
Other attractions on Sunday are the corn maze, the craftsmen's market and sheep-shearing.
Especially for children there is a petting zoo, straw bouncy castle, tractor driving (under guidance) and tractor surfing.
Organizers are the Förderverein Mehrzweckhalle, the ski club and the tractor friends "Zündkäpsele".
Milk and egg alternatives at a glance
Vegan nutrition requires plant-based alternatives to eggs, milk and dairy products.
Pureed tofu with vegetable cream is a substitute for quark, for example.
The Vegetarian Union names others for World Vegan Day on November 1.
On the occasion of World Vegan Day on November 1, the Vegetarierbund Deutschland proposes a number of vegan alternatives:
Pure vegetable margarine is a good alternative to butter, and yoghurt is being replaced by soya yoghurt.
Instead of milk, soy, oat, almond or rice milk could be used.
Whippable plant cream replaces conventional whipped cream.
There are also vegetable alternatives to eggs.
For example, half a crushed, ripe banana can replace an egg as a binding agent in a cake.
Also 50 grams of applesauce or one tablespoon of ground linseed plus three tablespoons of water are suitable.
Instead of egg, doughs are loosely mixed with, for example, a teaspoon of baking powder, a tablespoon of cornflour and three tablespoons of mineral water.
But 50 grams of soy yoghurt or silk tofu can also serve this purpose.
According to Vebu, about 800,000 people in Germany currently eat vegan, i.e. purely vegetable, food.
Sleepless in New York
On the way to their host families in Weymouth, Massachusetts, the students of the Black Forest High School got to know the American metropolis New York.
After an eight-hour flight, the flight went straight to the Brooklyn Bridge, over which the heart of the city, Manhattan, was reached on foot.
Here already a fascinating view of the world-famous skyline was offered, which is a special attraction in the evening light.
Due to the time difference, the students were on their feet for almost 24 hours, but true to the motto "The city never sleeps", the day in Times Square was decided.
Despite shutdown, the Statue of Liberty was reached by ferry on the second day and could be climbed on foot.
Afterwards, the tour continued via the financial centre around Wall Street to the memorial of September 11th.
On the third day, the students were able to gain an overview of the fascinating city from the 373-meter-high viewing platform of the Empire State Building while enjoying the view.
Afterwards, we went through the hectic hustle and bustle of New York's streets via Rockefeller Center to Central Park, which offered an ideal opportunity to linger a while in the autumn sun.
After a short flight from New York to Boston, the students have now arrived in their host families and are experiencing everyday school life at Weymouth High School.

The newly designed Opschlag shines with a new café.
One that invites you to stay and come back.
One that wants to make the name a program.
Déjà Vu, according to the encyclopaedia, is a psychological phenomenon that expresses itself in the feeling of having already experienced or seen a new situation.
If you visit the café of the same name on the Opschlag in the district town of Kleve, within sight of the Rhine-Waal University of Applied Sciences, you don't have to be left with a pure feeling of déjà vu.
After all, the café with the beautiful name has exactly this as its goal: to make an actual stay not only mentally, but also tangible, a recurring experience.
Because it's fun and just beautiful.
A look inside at Opschlag 8 gives the viewer a good feeling right away.
The ultra-modern, but not cool café ambience looks like a place to feel good.
Here, the team, headed by the founders Mirjam van der Stelt and Daniel Büttner, spoils guests with a wide variety of coffee and cocktails.
We serve delicious cakes or individually filled fresh baguettes.
The owners, both 33 years old, had already made a name for themselves as restaurateurs before the opening of the pretty café on the Opschlag: In Kranenburg they ran the "Art Lounge".
From the move to Kleve an den Opschlag, the sympathetic café lovers hope for a larger audience.
Not least also through the university.
"Although we do not have a specific target group," Daniel Büttner emphasizes.
Rather, they want to address young students as well as seniors and all age groups in between.
Speaking of café lovers.
The congenial owner couple is behind the coffee enjoyment.
Enjoy the fragrant hot brew in the most diverse variations yourself.
Expressofan
Daniel Büttner is more of an Expresso fan and Mirjam van der Stelt the cappuccino drinker.
"Add a baguette - that's my thing," she tells the NRZ.
Two events have already been held in the bright café.
Or rather, one.
Because the harbour festival took place rather outside - the Café Déjà Vu did not benefit from it.
But there was also the Ringelnatz evening.
"Beautiful, successful and funny," the two 33-year-olds thought.
But not everyone's cup of tea.
Perhaps this is one of the reasons why Daniel Büttner is not a real fan of event evenings: "You can't please everybody".
And with an event I always address only those who are interested in the special event.
That's why events will be the exception rather than the rule with us.
"We want to disrupt normal operations as little as possible".
In other words: Déjà Vu also stands for reliability.
In terms of the quality of the products offered here, as well as the team and the beautiful surroundings at Opschlag in Kleve.
The street, which is more and more becoming a gastronomy mile.
To the delight of many Klevers, the guests from near and far and the students who discover the gastronomic mile and thus also the Café Déjà Vu for themselves.

UN proclaims new goals in poverty reduction
The United Nations is now beginning to draw up a series of new goals to replace the Millennium Development Goals for poverty reduction announced twelve years ago.
In the run-up to the UN Summit on Sustainable Development, which began this evening in Rio de Janeiro, Australian diplomats played a key role in pushing for "sustainable development goals" to replace the Millennium Development Goals that expire in 2015.
They have been included in the final draft of the document which will be adopted by world leaders, including Mrs Gillard, at the summit.
UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said at the summit in the evening that the time had come "to think beyond national interests".
"I am pleased that member states have agreed to embark on a process to agree on universal sustainable development goals," he said.
"These goals will build on our progress from the Millennium Development Goals and form an integral part of the post-2015 development framework.
I will spare no effort to implement this mandate given to me by the Member States in order to achieve our vision of sustainable development goals that build on the success of the Millennium Goals".

Security concerns in Mozambique grow in the face of clashes between influential personalities
Thousands of people gathered in the centre of Maputo under the watchful eyes of the statue of Samora Machel, the founder of the state and first president of Mozambique, to raise calls for peace in a rare public demonstration.
"We want peace again, we want stability," said Vanessa de Sousa, managing director of an investment company.
Fearing for the country's future, she swapped her business clothes for a T-shirt with the words "We demand security" in Portuguese and joined the crowd in the capital's Independence Square on Thursday.
For two weeks now, there have been almost daily reports of clashes between government forces and Renamo, which are among the worst clashes since the peace agreement more than 20 years ago.
Renamo was once a notorious rebel movement, initially supported by the white-ruled Rhodesia and later the apartheid government of South Africa in an effort to destabilize the country's independent government.
After the peace treaty of 1992 it became an opposition party.
Analysts consider it unlikely that the country will return to full-scale conflict, but recent events have worried foreign investors and locals alike.
The stakes are high for the rapidly growing economy, as the discovery of huge gas deposits off the coast and coal deposits in the northwest could bring in over $50 billion in investment over the next few years from companies like Rio Tinto, Vale of Brazil, Eni of Italy and Anadarko of the US.
The ruling Frelimo party, the dominant force since 1975, and Renamo blame each other for the tensions.
Renamo claims that the government provoked the recent clashes by attacking its members on 17 October in Sofala province, a traditional stronghold of Renamo.
The attacks on the former rebels escalated when government troops attacked Renamo bases and tried to kill Afonso Dhlakama, the group's leader, Renamo's spokesman told the Financial Times.
The government blames Renamo for the clashes and accuses the organization of attacking soldiers.
President Armando Guebuza has tried to play down concerns about instability.
He told AFP, the French news agency, on Wednesday that Dhlakama considers himself a "loser" who "wants to use all his remaining powers to prove that he can impose his decisions on the government".
Both Frelimo and Renamo stress that they want to avoid war.
But concerns have increased since Mazanga was quoted as saying that Renamo is abandoning the 1992 peace agreement.
He explained to France Télécom that he had meant that Frelimo no longer respected the Agreement.
"Our vision is to resume negotiations and to do so seriously," Mazanga said.
Earlier talks between the parties have done little to resolve the tensions fuelled by a series of clashes this year.
"We have two adult men (Guebuza and Dhlakama) here, who are banging their heads together," says Joseph Hanlon, lecturer at the Open University and Mozambique expert.
None of them is good at negotiating and none of them is prepared to make the necessary concessions.
Renamo, which is pressing for electoral reforms, has already declared that it will boycott the local elections in November.
Presidential and parliamentary elections are scheduled for next year.
Some commentators have interpreted the use of force as an attempt by an ailing movement to obtain concessions and financial benefits from the government.
Renamo's electoral successes have been shrinking since 1992, while a newer party, the Movimento Democrático de Moçambique (MDM), founded by a former Renamo member, is expected to improve in the elections.
Mazanga claims that Guebuza - whose resignation is due when his second term in office ends next year - wants to destroy the country's democracy.
"He does not want multi-party democracy, he does not want transparent elections, he does not want peace because he does not want to give up the presidency," said Mazanga.
It is unclear what Renamo's capacity is, but it has carried out disturbing attacks on police stations and vehicles on an important north-south route.
Most of the fighting took place in the province of Sofala, a few hundred kilometres north of Maputo, but it is in Beira, the port used by mining companies such as Rio Tinto and Vale to export coal.
In June, Rio interrupted the use of the railway for a month after Renamo announced an attack on the line.
Mazanga replied cautiously to the question whether Renamo would repeat this threat.
Renamo wanted to "warn the international community that things are not going well in Mozambique," Mazanga said.
The instability has increased frustration with the government, says Fernando Lima, head of Mediacoop, an independent media company, as many people are already worried about corruption, slow progress in development and a recent wave of kidnappings.
"People think that the government and the president are responsible for the future of the country and he should be the one to find solutions to the problems," he explains.
Omar Sultane, a demonstrator, said that people just wanted stability.
"Nobody cares about Renamo and Frelimo, they just want peace and usable roads again," he explained.
Children should be taught myths and legends as "role models for life", says one author.
The stories of Thor showed that "brute force has no chance against clever tricks", and the Arthurian legend demonstrated how important it is to have a dream.
Many of the myths, however, were "far too wild, too offensive and in some cases too dirty to be taught in schools", which is why Crossley-Holland pleaded for a "careful selection" of age-appropriate works.
"I think it's wonderful that in America myth and folklore are already part of education," he said.
I have been suggesting this as a plan for twenty years.
He added that with authors and teachers who were "overly didactic", children would "switch off completely", because in entertaining stories the messages were conveyed "subliminally".
Crossley-Holland, who translated Beowulf from Anglo-Saxon and is the author of the Penguin Book of Norse Myths and the British Folk Tales, explained: "You can have certain intentions, but you should keep them in the background if possible".
Perhaps the greatest difference between an adult writer who writes for adults and an author who writes for children is the need to convey hope.
Not everything has to be simplified or lead to a happy end, but there is an immanent sense of good and evil.
This must be subliminally represented, revealed by history and not explained.
This is the old story of showing instead of telling.
Hansjakob moves to Freihof once again
100 years ago Heinrich Hansjakob moved into his retirement home in Haslach, on Sunday his last years were brought to life in the "Freihof".
The many spectators were thrilled by the extremely entertaining scene play.
From the time of his arrival and the granting of honorary citizenship until his death, scriptwriter and Hansjakob actor Alois Kraftzcyk had created an entertaining play which received much applause under the direction of Cornelia Volk.
Marcus Zagermann took the audience along as a speaker through the ten different scenes, explaining connections and bridging time leaps from youth to approaching retirement.
On 22 October 1913, Hansjakob returns home to his childhood heaven, to his Freihof.
And then the scene play began, in which Alois Krafczyk shone once again in his parade role as the great son of the city.
In proper style he drove up in the two-in-hand carriage and "Schwarzwälder Füchse" by Erich Becherer from Mühlenbach.
Not only was he received with much applause from the audience, but his sister Philippine also welcomed him.
Billy Sum-Hermann understood incredibly well to put himself in the role of the sister and gave her tremendous life in facial expressions and gestures.
Between the individual scenes, the Mühlenbach farmers' band played suitably selected pieces of music to round off the performance.
Haslach's mayor Heinz Winkler then took the honour of presenting Haslach's honorary citizenship, who, together with part of the city council, paid his respects on behalf of the then incumbent Hättich.
Afterwards the Epiphany Singers paid their respects, who made Hansjakob exclaim: "Oh how beautiful, memories of my own Epiphany come alive again".
With their song "O Jesulein" they delighted the audience in the Freihof as well as the Storchentagskinder with their loud "Heraus, Heraus".
Hansjakob had expressed his criticism of the official church at the time, as well as his concerns about the excesses in agriculture, the consequences of industrialisation or the effects of war.
He found his resting place in his native soil, behind his burial chapel on the Brand near Hofstetten.
"A restless spirit had finally found its rest and had gone home for good," was said at the end of the scene.
There was much applause and many words of praise from the audience for the performance.

Haigerloch: Communion church moves into the limelight
As the town's contribution to the 150th anniversary of the Evangelical Church in Haigerloch, the town's Culture and Tourism Office is dedicating the last of this year's public themed tours on Sunday, 27 October, to the Communion Church.
After visiting the Atomkeller Museum, the Haigerloch period after 1850 should be considered, when Haigerloch came under Prussian rule.
The crowning finale is a visit to the Church of the Last Supper.
There, the tour participants are told the story of the construction of the church and gain insights into the development of the Protestant community in a thoroughly Catholic region.

Tickets are available at the ticket office of the Atomkellermuseum.
For questions and information please contact the tourist office of the city of Haigerloch.

Anja Schlichter leads the tournament

On the last weekend in August the Black Forest Open Air Museum Vogtsbauernhof in Gutach near Hornberg is once again firmly in the hands of children.
Traditionally, the museum welcomes visitors on Saturday and Sunday, 24 and 25 August, as part of the summer holiday programme, to a colourful children's and family festival with numerous hands-on activities and events.
"Young and old can learn different old trades on both days," the press release says.
Whether making soap, turning candles, felting or making ropes, there is something for every age group.
The children are assisted by regional craftsmen from 11 to 17 o'clock.
Work is also being done in the museum workshop.
While building cuckoo pipes, waterwheels or spinning tops, the young guests can demonstrate their craftsmanship.
A lot of fun is also promised by the many old games, such as wheelbarrow races or walking on stilts.
Speed and coordination are required here.
For all little detectives, the open-air museum offers a mystery tour through the museum on Saturday and Sunday, at 12 and 14 o'clock in each case.
On a tour of the site, the children have to guess which stories are true or which are lies.
Furthermore, visitors have the special opportunity to get to know the open-air museum during a carriage ride with Black Forest foxes.
Not only horses, but also many other animals such as sheep, goats, cows and chickens can be seen and admired on the grounds.
In addition, all children can look forward to the clown Otsch on Sunday, who will be playing his pranks with the museum guests from 11 am.
Meanwhile, Hermann Büttner's life is cozy and fairytale-like.
The storyteller takes the little guests at 11, 13 and 15 o'clock into the wonderful world of fairy tales.
In addition, the children's costume dance group from Gutach performs traditional dances at 11.30 am.
In addition, on both days of the event from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., numerous craftsmen such as the broom-maker, the seamstress, the spinner, the weaver and the baker can be looked over the shoulder during their traditional work.
Until the end of the summer holidays in Baden-Württemberg, a varied holiday programme awaits visitors to the open-air museum.

Despite a heart defect, Burt cannot be dissuaded from his dream.
With his savings, a few donations and a mortgage on his old workshop shed, he takes a boat to Los Angeles.
After the film there will be coffee, tea and cake.
Shrill beeps disturb residents
Rhenus Midgard has also invested heavily on land.
They distribute the coal coming from the ships to the dump.
The company has several irons in the fire at this location.
Rhenus Midgard is not only importing coal but is also focusing on wind power plant logistics.
The coal on the storage area in front of the dike shimmers black.
Two huge blue dump and reloading machines distribute or load the coal here as required.
With every movement of the cargo handling equipment, a shrill warning noise sounds over the terrain.
"The signals are for safety reasons and are required by law," says Matthias Schrell, Managing Director of Rhenus Midgard in Wilhelmshaven.
Unfortunately, when the wind is not favourable, this can be heard from far away - and so there have already been some complaints from people from the north of the city.
He takes the complaints very seriously and has therefore made contact with the people affected, says the 40-year-old.
In close consultation with the authorities, technical measures are now being taken to keep the warning signals quieter.
In the future, too, he would rely on open dialogue with the neighbours.
Because Matthias Schrell still has a lot of plans for the location.
Rhenus Midgard is continuing to focus on importing coal for power plants by expanding the Niedersachsenbrücke bridge and is one of the major players in this sector in Europe.
Thanks to the 18.5-metre recessed couchette in front of the terminal, capesize bulk carriers can now also be handled here.
"This year, we want to break the 3 million tonne mark in transshipment," says Schrell.
In addition to the local Eon power plant, the imported coal goes to inland power plants.
If the GDF-Suez power plant is connected to the grid, a good 5 million tons of coal imports per year are realistic.
The three ship unloaders on the bridge and the second conveyor belt could handle up to 10 million.

Ben Greenman: Ten years New York Comedy Festival: The New Yorker
You could say that New York City is the birthplace of stand-up comedy in America: almost a hundred years ago, the variety artist Frank Fay, who worked as a conférencier at the Palace Theatre on Broadway, began telling jokes directly to the crowd in the form of a conversation.
Over the years, Fay's innovation has been expanded, as recently at the New York Comedy Festival.
Launched and directed by Caroline Hirsch, the founder of the stand-up institution Carolines, the festival celebrates its tenth anniversary this year with over sixty shows in small clubs and large theatres.
"Most of these headliners started at Carolines and then became more and more successful until at some point they were too well known to perform in a club," said Hirsch.
We have conceived this festival so that we can continue to work with them.
This year's event features performances by Wanda Sykes, Kathy Griffin and Bill Maher, as well as "Stand Up for Heroes," an annual music and comedy benefit for Army veterans at Madison Square Garden that features Bruce Springsteen, Jon Stewart, Roger Waters and Bill Cosby, among others.
With the festival the world of comedy has also grown.
A number of the comedians taking part in the festival this year have become known through more unconventional channels, such as programmes on smaller TV channels like Comedy Central, FX and Spike.
Nick Kroll became famous with a sitcom on cable TV (the ironic-slippery fantasy football series "The League" on FXX) and now has his own sketch show on Comedy Central.
Jenny Slate was part of the cast on both "Saturday Night Live" and "Parks and Recreation", although she is best known for her viral video series "Marcel the Shell with Shoes On".
Both Kroll and Slate and other young comedians with characteristic voices (the surreal pessimistic Anthony Jeselnik, the ironic W. Kaumau Bell, who focuses on racial issues) are products of the decentralized world of American comedy.
One of the biggest visitor magnets of the festival is an interview: David Steinberg talks to Larry David.
Steinberg began as a stand-up comedian, but has grown into a respected television and film director and an unofficial comedy historian.
From 2005 to 2007, he hosted a television show entitled "Sit Down Comedy with David Steinberg" on TV Land.
The meeting will take place at Town Hall in the middle of Manhattan.
"The city is definitely in the comedy DNA of all of Larry's work," Steinberg said.
He told me that when he is here, he sometimes walks through the alley between two buildings and thinks: "Hey, if I lose all my money, then maybe I'll live here.

Drama in Uruguay: Boys kill play comedians with machete
Two children have confessed to the murder of an 11-year-old in Uruguay.
The two 14 and 12 year old boys had invited their victim to go bird hunting with them.
Armed with machetes and knives, they stabbed the 11-year-old on Tuesday and threw the body into a well, the newspaper "El País" reported on Thursday.
Afterwards they played football in front of their apartments in a working-class neighbourhood.
The body was found the following night in the village of Cerro Pelado, 15 kilometres north of the exclusive beach resort of Punta del Este.
As an alibi, a five-year-old half-sister of the younger one they had taken was supposed to testify that she had been sexually assaulted by the boy.
But when the girl described the course of events to the police without mentioning an attack against her, the two boys admitted to the intentional killing of the 11-year-old.
The older man cited a rivalry in the football match as one of the reasons.
He was provisionally committed to a psychiatric juvenile facility.
Pimp's going to jail
The Constance Regional Court has sentenced a 33-year-old man from St. Georgen to three and a half years in prison for exploitative human trafficking, pimping, threatening, insulting and dangerous bodily injury.
The former Bundeswehr soldier, who worked as a doorman after two deployments in Afghanistan, made a confession as part of a trial agreement.
According to the report, in five cases he met women through internet or telephone contacts and sent them on the street against their will after a few weeks.
He used to break resistance with violence and threats.
He retained the income of the women, some of whom had been working for him for years.
By confiscating mobile phones and SIM cards, he prevented women from having contact with the outside world.
Together with a colleague who mediated the women, he took them to various brothels in the southwest.
There he had them partially monitored to control their income.
In court, the defendant first claimed that he suffered a severe trauma after colleagues in Afghanistan died next to him in an explosion.
After a psychiatric expert indicated that there were serious doubts about the mental impairment and thus about a limited capacity for guilt, the 33-year-old made a comprehensive confession.
The court no longer had to hear any of the injured women.
According to one police officer, after an initial report, telephone surveillance measures were able to identify at least four more cases of exploitative human trafficking.
The tapped conversations had been characterized by high aggression.
In later interrogations the aggrieved parties had confirmed their martyrdom.
Another witness, where one of the women had discovered bruises all over her body, has not yet made a statement.
It is "a completely broken personality" who considers violence and exploitation to be normal in this profession.
The defendant regretted his behaviour yesterday.
"He had broken away from these circles and wanted to lead a very normal life after his imprisonment," he said.
Oil price continues to fall to USD 96 per barrel
Oil prices continued to fall on Friday after concerns over high supply overshadowed a report that China's energy-hungry manufacturing sector is growing.
The reference crude oil grade for December deliveries had fallen by 14 cents to USD 96.24 per barrel in late morning electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange in Europe.
The contract fell by 39 cents on Thursday, which meant a 5.8 percent drop in price in October.
The large crude oil supply has weighed on prices in recent weeks.
The US Department of Energy declared on Wednesday that the US supply increased by 4.1 million barrels last week.
In the course of five weeks, the supply had increased by 25 million barrels.
But on Friday there were signs of stronger demand from two reports of increased activity in Chinese manufacturing.
This points to a continued recovery of China's economy, which grew to 7.8 percent in the third quarter after the previous quarter had seen its lowest growth rate in two decades.
Brent crude oil, a reference value for international crude oil that is also used by US refineries, fell by 26 cents to USD 108.58 per barrel on the ICE Exchange in London.
Court blocks decision on NYPD stop-and-frisk policy
A federal appeals court in the US on Thursday blocked the order of a judge who had called for changes to the New York Police Department's stop-and-frisk ("stop and search") program, and dismissed the judge from the case.
The 2nd US Court of Appeals stated that the decisions of Judge Shira Scheindlin would be suspended until the city had decided on an appeal.
The judge had ruled in August that the city was violating the constitution with the way the program for stopping and questioning people was implemented.
The city appealed against its assessment and the remedial measures ordered, including the decision to set up a monitoring centre to assist the police in changing their policy and training programme.
The Court of Appeal heard the arguments for the requested suspension on Tuesday.
The Appeals Report stated that the judge had to be removed from the case because she had violated the Code of Conduct for US Judges by stipulating that a judge should avoid the appearance of partiality; this was partly justified by a series of media interviews and public statements in which she had publicly responded to the court's criticism.
The judge had ruled that police officers were violating the civil rights of tens of thousands of people because they were inappropriately targeting black and Latin American men with the stop-and-frisk program.
It appointed an external body to monitor the implementation of major changes, including policy reforms, training and supervision, and ordered a pilot programme of body-worn cameras in neighbourhoods where most checks were carried out.
In August, the city of New York agreed to end the practice of storing the names and addresses of people who were released after police checks.
An oral hearing on the city's appeal is planned after 14 March 2014.
The stop-and-frisk tactic was criticised by a number of civil rights advocates.
Controls of this kind have existed in various forms for decades, but the number of recorded controls during the term of office of the non-party mayor Michael Bloomberg rose to an all-time high of 684,330 in 2011, most of them black and Latin American men.
In 2004, four men, all of whom belonged to minorities, filed a lawsuit that developed into a class action.
Proponents of changes to the NYPD's stop-and-frisk program say the changes will end unfair practices and create a more trustworthy and effective police force and influence the way other police departments use the scheme.
Opponents argue that the changes would dampen police morale but not crime; it would also waste money and fail to solve the broader problem of a police force that is under pressure following the loss of thousands of jobs over the last decade.
The judge pointed out that she did not end the stop-and-frisk practice, which is constitutional, but only reformed the way the NYPD implements controls.

Happiness is an oasis that only dreaming camels can reach
With this Bedouin wisdom the first chairman Wolfgang Henne described the history and fascination of the association "Helping Hands".
On Saturday afternoon the tenth anniversary of the club was celebrated, which has already achieved considerable success.

Henne also mentioned a new mother and child hospital in Nouakchott

It should also not be forgotten that Africa is closer than some people think.
From Gran Canaria it is not far to Africa.
Coulson used phone hacking to verify a tip
Former News of the Word editor Andy Coulson allegedly used "phone hacking, surveillance and confrontation" in an attempt to confirm a false tip about an affair of then Home Secretary Charles Clarke.
Prosecutor Andrew Edis QC told the court in the Old Bailey that News of the World had heard a false rumor in May 2005 that Clarke was having an affair with his "attractive special advisor" Hannah Pawlby.
The newspaper hired private investigator Glenn Mulcaire to hack Pawlby's voicemails and tracked her, but Coulson also called her and left messages, the court learned.
"According to the prosecution, Coulson, who is now the editor of NotW, is not someone who stands outside people's homes hoping to catch them in the act, but someone who likes to confront people with a story to see their reaction," Edis explained.
He said NotW uses three methods to investigate stories: Phone hacking, surveillance and confrontation.
The editor is personally involved in the third method.
Obviously he knows about the second one, the surveillance, it can't be otherwise.
How about the first one?
Does he know about the phone hacking?
He denies it, but we say, "Of course he knew."
Rumors of Clarke's affair were first picked up by the feature editors at NotW when a source who was sexually interested in Pawlby was told, "Don't waste your time, she's with Charles."
A tape with voicemails from her phone from at least three occasions was recovered in Mulcaire's apartment in August 2006.
The investigators also found entries on the detective's computer where Pawlby and her sister were stored as "projects".
While the research was going on, Pawlby's grandparents received anonymous phone calls asking for information about her, Edis explained.
Meanwhile, former chief reporter Neville Thurlbeck and former reporter James Weatherup oversaw the monitoring of Pawlby's movements.
On June 18, 2005, Coulson left her a voicemail saying, "I have a story we want to run tomorrow that I would like to talk to Charles about."
Edis explained that Coulson's activities on this story followed the same pattern as those of other key figures, including former Home Secretary David Blunkett.
The jury heard on Thursday that Coulson Blunkett had confronted a married woman about an affair when he himself was involved with co-defendant Rebekah Brooks, who was married at the time.
Coulson and Brooks deny conspiring with others to hack phones between October 3, 2000 and August 9, 2006.
Mulcaire, Thurlbeck and Weatherup have admitted to phone hacking.

In the conflict over the wealth tax, the government and professional football in France have manoeuvred themselves into a dead end after a failed mediation meeting.
President François Hollande received representatives of associations and federations in the Élysée Palace in Paris on Thursday and listened to their complaints.

Gechingen: No absolute protection possible
"We want to involve the residents in the planning process at an early stage", Mayor Jens Häußler opened the public information event on the flood protection concept in Gechingen.
Around 80 participants came to the community hall to have the planned measures explained to them, to ask questions, express concerns and contribute ideas.
Häußler made it clear: "The final decisions are made by the members of the municipal council".
The flood that hit Gechingen unprepared on 15 May 2009 was a decisive event that raised the question of protective measures for the future, said Häußler.
A river basin study had been commissioned with the neighbouring municipality of Aidlingen, which is now the basis for the flood protection concept in Gechingen.
"The aim is to protect as many developed plots of land as possible," says Häußler.
The planning is based on the protection against a flood statistically expected every 100 years according to the German Weather Service.
Climate change is taken into account by a 15 percent surcharge.
In specialist circles this is known as "HQ 100a climate".
The water masses that had caused considerable damage in Gechingen in 2009 were equivalent to a 1000 year flood.
"There is no such thing as absolute protection, but we can achieve a relative improvement," says Häußler.
In order to achieve the protection of HQ 100a climate, around four million euros must be invested in Gechingen, whereby the municipality can expect state subsidies of around 70 percent.
Häußler pointed out, however, that funding would only be granted if an overall concept was implemented.
For this, the municipality is dependent on the participation of the citizens.
An elaborate planning and approval procedure had to be completed.
In the best case, implementation could begin in 2016.
Among other things, the protection concept, which was already presented last week in the municipal council (we reported), provides for local measures in the tributary of the small river Irm from the Stammheim valley.
Following the presentation of the flood protection concept, the participants used the opportunity to voice their concerns.
Among other things, it was questioned why more dams and retention basins were not planned to protect the site.
Gregor Kühn, specialist planner of the commissioned engineering office Wald und Corbe from Hügelsheim, who presented the concept, emphasized that the interaction of all the measures presented was necessary to achieve the desired goal in total.
In addition, it is necessary to find the most economical solution, says Joachim Wald of Wald und Corbe.
Resentment was expressed by residents living near the old town, who suffer from a constant overload of the sewage network even during normal thunderstorms.
The problem is known to the administration and first measures have already been taken.
Häußler pointed out, however, that the guidelines for sewer systems were different from those for flood protection and that this should not be mixed up.
The municipality is obliged to design the sewerage system in such a way that it can cope with two to three years of rainfall.
Making the sewers bigger would swallow millions.

You could call him the Dostoyevsky of the USA.
Philip K. Dick was a godfinder, a metaphysician, his novels and stories also have something serial about them.
Amazing the relationship in the exterior: the piercing eyes, the beard, the high forehead.
And just as Fyodor M. Dostoyevsky, with his massive oeuvre, is to be understood as the founder and apologist of the Russian soul, Philip K. Dick is read as an American prophet, who is certainly worth something in his own country.
Some titles are published by Heyne Verlag, the Haffmans cassette with the 118 stories distributes Zweitausendeins.
Dick explains America - the realm of breathtaking technical progress, coupled with paranoia, security mania and the belief that you are the chosen one.
Dick had experiences of God, his late books read like a mixture of the Revelation of John and a computer manual.
Maybe he was crazy, drugs had fried his brain.
He realized early on that the computers are divinities.
He wrote a theology of the computer and asked what distinguishes a man from a machine, the Creator from his creature.
That's the Blade Runner problem.
The killing.
A master of science fiction.
A fantastic writer.
His stories have inspired film directors like Ridley Scott, Paul Verhoeven and Steven Spielberg.
This story is particularly significant now.
The "Minority Report" dates from 1956, it exudes the smell of the Cold War and the McCarthy Tribunals.
Here the principle of "pre-crime" is developed, "pre-crime", that is, what is now more or less the official doctrine of the White House.
In Dick's world, which is frighteningly similar to ours, mutants look into the future - and the police take hold.
"We record individuals who have not broken any laws," says the head of the agency.
"We'll get them before they can commit a violent crime."
And: "In our society there are no serious criminals, but we have a penal camp full of pesudo criminals". They read time streams.
They assume that bad things will happen and prevent the criminal thought from being put into action.
Dick's narrative seems like the blueprint for the anti-terror laws and the NSA's bugging frenzy.
Anticipation of the attack: This is also how Obama's drone philosophy and practice works.
But Dick's story doesn't end there.
The police chief complains that there is no longer any separation of powers, the military controls everyday life - and what is left of the state.
Then the supervisor himself is monitored and convicted of a future crime.
The system's going crazy.
It's perfect, but it lies.
It invents its own conditions.
Does not only accept errors and sacrifices, but builds on them.
The system creates the danger it fights.
Reading Philip K. Dick means getting closer to the truth again and again.
Testify about the Merkel affair in Russia
Former US secret service expert Edward Snowden could also make statements in his Russian asylum in the US-spa affair around German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Previously, Green Member of the Bundestag Hans-Christian Ströbele was the first German politician to meet Snowden in Moscow yesterday to talk to him about the affair.
NSA revelations fuel corporate paranoia over government surveillance
On a mild day in late August, a German police helicopter flew low over the US Consulate in Frankfurt am Main, the financial capital of Germany.
By order of the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution and Counter-Terrorism (BVT), the German domestic intelligence service, he was to photograph the roof of the US outpost, which is located less than 5 km from the European Central Bank and the Bundesbank.
According to the German media, the BAT wanted to prove the existence of surveillance antennas and the action led to an exchange of words between the USA and the German Foreign Ministry in Berlin.
James Clapper, US Director of National Intelligence, insisted again in September that the US did not use foreign espionage "to steal the trade secrets of foreign companies on behalf of US firms so that they could increase their international competitiveness or profits".
But since Edward Snowden, the whistleblower who has become a whistleblower, has started to publish his cornucopia of US surveillance secrets, European governments and corporate bosses are no longer sure they can take the director at his word.
Reports that the American National Security Agency is spying on Brazilian oil company Petrobas and has obtained data from American cloud providers including Google and Yahoo have taken corporate paranoia to new heights due to government surveillance.
The last straw was the revelation that Chancellor Angela Merkel's phone was bugged, possibly for ten years.
If the most powerful person in Europe can be targeted, then surely company managers are also potential targets.
Snowden has made the intensive cooperation between US secret services and companies transparent.
I think it is conceivable that this data could be used for mutual benefit.
"Germany needs to wake up," explains Oliver Grün, President of BITMi, which represents small and medium-sized IT companies in Germany.
German companies believe that the US now poses almost as great a risk as China when it comes to industrial espionage and data theft, according to a survey published in July by the consulting firm EY.
In the documents leaked by Snowden, however, there has been no evidence to date that the USA has passed on the trade secrets of foreign companies to its own firms.
Politicians have expressed their concern that the EU lacks certain IT and internet facilities and that it should reduce its dependence on the US.
The companies are sceptical about this.
In the Bundestag it was suggested that we should build a German Google.
I can only close my eyes and slowly open them again...
"It doesn't work that way," says Hasso Plattner, chairman of the German software manufacturer SAP.
If you wanted a strong European IT industry, you should not have let it die out 20 years ago.
Everything in Germany is subsidized, from coal to cars to agriculture.
Everything but the IT industry.
Yet the reach and technical sophistication of the US espionage agencies uncovered by the Snowden revelations shocked companies that had previously seen the greatest espionage risk in China.
Cloud computing is undergoing a major change as European business leaders are now more aware that data stored in the US is subject to US jurisdiction and is therefore potentially at risk.
According to a survey conducted by the Cloud Security Alliance, a trade body, following the revelations about US data mining activities with Prism, about ten percent of non-US members rejected plans to use a US provider.
Jim Snabe, SAP's vice president and chief operating officer, says, "We're seeing a new question from customers that wasn't there a year ago - where is my data stored and can you guarantee that it will remain physically within that jurisdiction?
Many German company managers are of the opinion that the latest reports simply confirm what they already knew anyway, namely that powerful states want to steal their most valuable secrets and therefore these must be guarded at all costs.
It is no surprise that industrial espionage is taking place.
It always has been.
"It was an issue for many years and has not changed fundamentally as a result of the current discussion," says Kurt Bock, Chairman of the chemical company BASF.
The Americans spy on us on a commercial and industrial level, just as we do, because it is in the national interest to defend our companies.
Management usually doesn't brag about the countermeasures taken, because that gives attackers advantages.
In large companies, employees have long been told that taking a free USB stick to a trade fair or leaving a laptop unattended in a hotel room is not advisable, to say the least.
Ulrich Hackenberk, member of the board of directors at car manufacturer Audi, says that it has been standard practice for years to collect mobile phones before a board meeting so that they cannot be used as bugging devices.
The German BAT advises managers to use simple prepaid mobile phones when travelling abroad because smartphones may be compromised.
The prepaid mobile phones are thrown away afterwards.
However, there is concern that small and medium-sized enterprises remain vulnerable to hacking and monitoring.
In Germany many of these companies are global market leaders in their respective niche.

CDC publish allergy guidelines for schools
On Wednesday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) published a set of guidelines for dealing with food allergies in children in schools.
These are the first such guidelines issued by the US government as the number of school-age children with food allergies increases.
One in 20 children in the United States now has a food allergy.
The prevalence of food allergies among children increased by 18 percent between 1997 and 2007, according to the CDC.
The guidelines contain information for schools to raise awareness of food allergies among teachers and staff and how to deal with children who show allergic reactions.
It is also recommended that schools stock epinephrine - the EpiPen brand of auto-injection is the most commonly used - to counter a potentially fatal hypersensitivity reaction.
State legislators have recently changed the regulations to make it easier for schools to stock epinephrine.
The report also contains a list of typical symptoms mentioned by children who have an allergic reaction.
Children may say, "It feels like something is pressing on my tongue," "My tongue feels like there is a hair on it," or "My tongue is tingling.
Parents of intersexual children can choose "sex undefined
Germany is the first European nation to recognise a third gender for children born with ambiguous genitalia.
Newborns are no longer rigidly assigned to male or female.
According to the new law, parents no longer have to declare the sex of such children, but can indicate "undetermined" or "not determined" on the birth certificate.
The aim of the law is to relieve pressure from parents to avoid hasty decisions regarding operations for sex assignment in newborns and to combat discrimination against intersex people.
According to the BBC, years later, an intersexual person said: "I am neither man nor woman."
I remain the patchwork created by doctors, mutilated and full of scars.
It is estimated that one in every 2,000 children is not born either as a boy or a girl each year.
They belong to the intersexuals, a group that falls under the diagnosis "sexual differentiation disorder" (DSD), a collective term for people with atypical chromosomes, gonads (ovaries or testicles) or unusually developed genitals.
Wallis Simpson was possibly intersexual.
Understanding of gender identification is still not very well developed, but most experts in the US advise that the best available information should be used for gender identification if identification is not possible, and not to wait for the psychological and physical development of the child before deciding - if at all - to have surgery.
The New York psychiatrist Dr. Jack Drescher, who specializes in the problem of gender identification, said the new German law "sounds like a good thing".
Intersexual children pose an ethical dilemma.
"Some people have life-threatening illnesses that require surgery, but for most children this does not apply," he said.
One could assign a gender without surgery and then wait and see how the identity develops.
The scientific data on how a child develops its sexual identity in the first place is not very accurate.
Nobody knows why it's happening.
It's like the secret of why people are gay.
A report to the European Commission in 2011 states that intersexual people are to be distinguished from transsexual or transgender people because their status is not gender-related but is determined by their biological constitution, which is neither exclusively male nor female but typically defines both at the same time or not clearly as one of them.
These characteristics were manifested in subordinate sexual characteristics such as muscle mass, hair, breasts and stature, primary sexual characteristics such as reproductive organs and genitals, or in chromosome structures and hormones.
The report also provides an overview of the discrimination faced by intersexual and transgender people in the workplace and the extent of harassment, violence and crimes of prejudice.
Boys not conforming to the gender image now have a special camp.
In Australia and Nepal, it is now possible for adults to indicate male, female or "third sex" on official documents.
In June, Australian Norrie May-Welby (52) became the world's first "sexless" person to be recognised after a court granted life-long retention of an "unspecified" gender status.
According to the Ministry of the Interior, German identity cards will in future have a third assignment, X for intersexual, in addition to M and W.
In neighbouring France, gender issues are still controversial, according to a news report on France 24.
In 2011, dozens of French deputies of the strictly Catholic country signed a petition to have "gender theory" removed from schoolbooks.
The US-American website Catholic Online has also spoken out against the German law, arguing: "If the world is dragged into a new state where sex is a choice but sexual activity is not, then we are twisting two more pillars of civilization.
The mother of a newborn baby from Maryland told Baby Zone that she would prefer that babies be assigned a gender at birth.
"Being a parent is stressful enough without further restrictions, especially if you don't know the gender of your own child," she told the parents' website.
Children need stability and security.
Historically, children born with both male and female genitals were called hermaphrodites, after the attractive Greek god who had both sexes.
Only ten years ago, medicine still regarded gender as something that could be erased and then rebuilt.
However, the ethical basis of surgery is now being questioned, now that it is known how complex gender identity is, and that doctors can also be wrong because they do not know how the child will feel when growing up with the sex they have been assigned.
"In the mid-20th century, it was called a 'psychiatric emergency,'" said Drescher.
When such a child was born, they called not the psychiatrist but the surgeon.
The prevailing theory about the treatment of children with ambiguous genitals goes back to Dr. John Money of Johns Hopkins University, who held the view that sex is malleable.
He coined the term "gender identity" and argued that social and environmental impulses - how parents raise a child - interacted with a child's genes and hormones and thus shaped whether a person considered himself male or female.
But in a case from 1966 known as "John/Joan" his theories became controversial.
He advised the parents of a boy whose penis had been cut off in a botched circumcision to castrate the child completely and also to remove his testicles and then raise him as a girl.
"Money presented this case as a successful example of transformation, which it was not," said Drescher.
When the boy was about 15, he switched back to the male sex and married a woman.
But he committed suicide at 38.
According to Drescher, there are still doctors who would practice this model.
But in the 1990s, with the advent of the Internet, survivors of these sex surgeries have come forward who are "not happy with the results".
Take Jim Bruce, a 36-year-old author from Montana, who was born with XY male chromosomes but ambiguous genitals.
The doctors were not clear whether he had a large clitoris or a small penis and were convinced that he could never lead a "satisfying life" as a man.
So his external organ and testicles were surgically removed shortly after his birth in 1976 and he was raised as a girl.
At the age of 12 he received female hormones.
"I knew I wasn't a girl," he told ABCNews.com
I was unhappy, but it was really hard to ask questions.
At the age of 18 he should have a vaginal plastic surgery.
But since he was depressed and knew that something was wrong, he asked for his medical records.
What he found out was shocking.
I was sterilized at birth - and nobody ever told me that.
Bruce was born with a DSD that prevented his body from producing enough testosterone to develop the genitals.
After he learned the truth, he switched back to male identity, received testosterone injections and had his breasts removed.
The operation has rendered him infertile.
Today he fights for others in an organization called Interface Project to make intersex people feel normal.
But Anne Tamar-Mattis, executive director of the California-based legal group Advocates for Informed Choice, is concerned that the German law may "encourage stamping and stigmatisation".
"Many activists are concerned that the German decision may encourage parents to make quick decisions and assign the child an 'unspecified' one," she said.
We fear that this favours intervention.
We think it would be better to assign the male or female gender and then wait and see.
But we do not yet know what the law will do, so we can only speculate.
Tamar-Mattis said her organisation supported the Australian law because "it allows adults to be recognised as the third sex".
"Adults should be able to make their own decisions about their legal gender," she explained.
The German law is about allocation at birth.
This is not a fight that small children should be forced to fight at this time.
When they are adults, they can decide about their own body.
But Dr. Arlene Baratz, a Pittsburgh breast radiologist who has a daughter with a sexual differentiation disorder and supports hundreds of others in a support group, says German law "empowers" both parents and children.
Katie, Baratz's daughter, was born with male chromosomes, but has a DSD called complete androgen resistance.
Because of the receptor defect in the target cells for testosterone, Katie developed female characteristics.
She has a vagina but no uterus and no ovaries.
Today Katie is 29 and married; she works at the University of Pennsylvania as a staff member in child psychiatry.
Although she is infertile, she hopes to be able to have a child through adoption or a surrogate mother.
"The law gives parents space, so they do not have to make hasty decisions," Baratz said.
It gives them the time to do different tests and clarify things, giving them time before they write "male" or "female".
This way everything is fine - you raise the child and love it.
You have a wonderful baby and enjoy the parental happiness.
And you do not have to rush into an operation that is irreversible.
"This includes the children in the decision and removes the fear that drives parents because they think they are not doing the right thing," she explained.
In the end, the child decides on the sex that suits him or her better - and that is wonderful.
This enables children to make the decision themselves.

Living with a future perspective
Actually Waltraud Ries lives in a dreamlike way.
Your house is located in a quiet residential area of Stuttgart with lots of green, an old stock of trees, nice neighbours and not too much traffic.
The city is only a few minutes away by public transport.
"I hope you're not afraid of spiders," asks Waltraud Ries and points to a fat spider on the door frame.
I have been looking for a new apartment for my husband and me for some time.
But you know how difficult it is in Stuttgart.
The reason, however, is not a spider phobia, but rather the worry of not being able to cope with the many steps to the house and in the apartment when she gets older, she explains.
In addition: since a meniscus operation, the mid-fifties had to experience first-hand what it means to move from floor to floor with a handicap.
Recently she published a book on the subject of 'Happy living in old age - Which form of living is the best for me'.
Our apartment is the best example of what is not possible in old age,' she begins to tell.
When she moved into the maisonette apartment with her husband more than 20 years ago, it was simply a beautiful apartment in the middle of greenery.
Today, in her mid-fifties, Waltraud Ries thinks differently.
But she also knows that she is one of the few people who are even dealing with the topic of 'living in old age'.
Most people repress it while they can.
Only the others get old,' she says with a smile.
Only when the suffering is really great do you start to think about it.
"But then it could already be too late," said Ries.
In her book, the interior designer presents 17 living models for self-determined living in old age.
But 'Whichever form of living you choose is always an individual decision', she explains.
There is no such solution for old age.
Even those who can afford to retire in Tuscany or Brittany should always consider that they could also fall ill.
And: 'Without a good knowledge of the national language, one can also be lonely in the dolce vita,' the specialist book author gives those willing to resettle to consider.
Among their models are classic care models, alternative forms of housing or the often quoted pensioners' shared flat.
In old age, everyone has their tics and quirks
But for me such a flat share would be nothing', she says with a wink.
Especially not like in a student flat with a shared bathroom and kitchen.
'In old age you simply need your retreat, too', says Ries.
However, the author does not want to rule out the possibility that a senior citizens' residential community can still function.
But that would have to be different from the classic student flat share.
And sometimes you just want to be left alone,' she believes.
At least in the state capital, she is not alone with this opinion.
'Most old people in Stuttgart want to stay in their own homes as long as possible', is also the experience of Theresa Rütten, head of the Citizens' Service Living in Old Age in the state capital.
Your service advises people on the topic of 'getting older'.
That is why older people in particular would often accept inconvenience and restrictions just to be able to stay in their familiar surroundings, this is also the experience of Stiftung Warentest.
Today there are many possibilities to make the house or apartment barrier-free.
Ries recommends all those who are involved in the age-appropriate conversion of their house or apartment to inform themselves thoroughly first and not to hire the first craftsman.
Today, there are also specialists for age-appropriate conversions.
Even in a rented apartment, one or the other can be realized, and if it is only the toilet seat increase, the interior designer explains.
But it is not always possible to redesign the existing apartment to make it age-appropriate and thus barrier-free, even if it is beautifully located.
Waltraud Ries had to make this experience.
Although it would be possible to install a stair lift inside the apartment, the path to the apartment door, which is also paved with stairs, would be the far greater obstacle.
She will continue to search until she has found the ideal object for herself and her husband.
She dreads the move more than the spider at her apartment door.

According to a translation by Ströbele, the letter is worded as follows:
To those responsible
I have been asked to write to you regarding your mass surveillance investigation.
My name is Edward Joseph Snowden and I was formerly employed by contract or direct employment as a technical expert with the National Security Agency (NSA), the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) of the United States.
In the course of my employment in these institutions I witnessed systematic violations of the law by my government, which prompted me to act out of moral duty.
As a result of the publication of these concerns, I found myself exposed to a serious and persistent agitation that forced me to leave my family and my home.
I am currently living in exile and enjoy temporary asylum granted to me by the Russian Federation under international law.
I am encouraged by the response to my political actions, both in the US and elsewhere.
Citizens around the world, as well as senior officials - including the United States - have judged the revelations about an all-encompassing surveillance system that is accountable to no one, as a service to the public.
These espionage revelations led to many proposals for new laws and guidelines aimed at the previously hidden abuse of public trust.
The benefits for society from these findings are becoming increasingly clearer; at the same time, the risks accepted have been visibly reduced.
Although the outcome of my efforts has been demonstrably positive, my government continues to treat dissent as a breach of loyalty and seeks to criminalize and indict political expression.
Nevertheless: Speaking the truth is not a crime.
I am confident that the United States Government, with the support of the international community, will put an end to this detrimental attitude.
I hope that once the difficulties of this humanitarian situation have been resolved, I will be able to participate in the responsible clarification of the facts concerning the statements made in the media, particularly with regard to the truth and authenticity of the reports, in an appropriate and lawful manner.
I look forward to speaking with you in your country once the situation is resolved and thank you for your efforts to uphold international law which protects us all.
Edward Snowden testified by Hans-Christian Ströbele

Report: Obama campaign considered replacing Biden with Hillary Clinton
President Barack Obama's closest advisors have been secretly considering replacing Vice President Joe Biden with Hillary Clinton in the 2012 election campaign, according to the New York Times.
The unveiling is the most remarkable surprise of the long-awaited work by Mark Halperin and John Heilemann on the 2012 election campaign, "Double Down: Game Change 2012".
The Times has a copy of the forthcoming book and reported on Thursday night that the president's top advisers had held "extensive group meetings and polls in late 2011" to find out if it would look better for Obama's dwindling re-election hopes if he dropped Biden.
According to Jonathan Martin, the Times' national policy correspondent, the book thoroughly traces the history of efforts by senior campaign and White House staff, notably former White House Chief of Staff Bill Daley, to measure the effect on poll ratings of replacing former Secretary of State Clinton with the vice president.
The potential switch was a closely guarded secret within the Chicago campaign infrastructure and the Oval Office.
Only half a dozen of the president's closest advisors - including Daley, Obama's former campaign manager Jim Messina, and former senior White House advisors David Axelrod and David Plouffe - knew about the proposed change.
In "Double Down" it is claimed that Daley was at the forefront of efforts to exchange Biden despite their "close, personal relationship" before finally deciding against such a move after data showed that Clinton's candidacy "would not significantly improve Obama's chances.
In an interview with Martin, Daley confirmed that the government was indeed considering replacing Biden with Clinton.
"I said quite a few things that should be considered, and this was one of them," Daley told the magazine.
You have to remember that the president had terrible poll numbers back then, so we thought, "For God's sake, what are we doing?"
While Daley called the investigation "due diligence," Martin told CNN's Anderson Cooper that considerable effort was made during the re-election campaign to find out whether such a move would pay off in terms of ballot boxes.
"In campaigns, you don't spend that much money on surveys and focus groups unless you seriously think about something," Martin explained on AC360.
However, it is not clear whether Obama knew that his team was considering an exchange.
Martin told CNN that he asked Daley if his then boss had known about the potential change.
Although Daley stated that he did not believe the president was "aware" of the possible change, the former chief of staff admitted that it was "possible" that Obama had known about it.
Martin added that "Double Down" does not provide a definitive answer to the question of whether the political soundings have reached Obama's desk.
Cooper asked Martin if he seriously thinks Obama didn't know about the investigation into whether to drop Biden in the election.
"Possibly," Martin replied.
What happens to my e-mail on the way?
E-mail is actually called electronic letter.
When designing the Internet service e-mail, was the technical implementation of the secrecy of correspondence similar to that of conventional mail?
When designing the early Internet services, the focus was on making communication possible.
As a result, the basic technical protocols have not been designed to provide a stable foundation for a hearing-safe exchange of correspondence.
Therefore, a conventional e-mail is more like an open postcard than a sealed letter.
When user "Anna" sends an e-mail to "Benni", are the computers of the two directly connected?
In the first step, Anna's e-mail program or browser sends the mail to the mail server of her service provider.
For example, if she has a GMail account, that would be Google.
This mail server sends the content to the provider that Benni uses.
On the way the mail can run over several other servers in the internet.
Bennie can then call the content to his provider.
Are conventional e-mails read along on their way through the net?
Most mails are read several times by software robots on the way.
The sender's provider usually checks whether the mail contains malware as an attachment.
A virus check is also performed on the recipient systems.
In addition, the providers check whether it is an annoying and unwanted spam mail which is immediately deleted or at least sorted away into a spam folder.
Do the robots have another task?
With systems like GMail, the robot also determines the information that Google needs to place contextual advertising.
When Anna and Benni communicate via GMail about their upcoming holiday trip, Google can show corresponding links to holiday offers.
Do unknown people also read the e-mails?
The probability that unauthorized persons read a mail is extremely low.
Theoretically, however, this is possible.
In companies, administrators often have the possibility to read electronic mail.
Law enforcement and intelligence agencies also have legal means to intercept or take note of e-mails.
There are also possible illegal spying activities.
Is it possible to protect e-mails against being read?
With encryption according to the OpenPGP standard, an e-mail can be effectively encrypted against being read.
With high technical effort it is also possible to disguise the metadata of an e-mail communication so that it is not even possible to easily identify who has communicated with whom.
How important are Yahoo and Google in the email market in Germany?
Yahoo and Google only play a minor role in the mainly privately used mailboxes, according to a study by Convios Consulting from August 2013.
While the shares of Yahoo-Mail had fallen recently, Google's GMail was able to increase significantly.

Fancy an ice cream that glows in the dark?
A British entrepreneur has developed the first ice that glows in the dark - with the help of jellyfish.
Charlie Francis took advantage of the fluorescent properties of sea animals and created a glowing treat.
The idea came to him after he had read a research paper on jellyfish and was able to convince Chinese scientists to produce the luminous protein artificially.
When consumed, the ice cream reacts with the tongue, raising the pH in the protein and causing it to glow.
Chris explains that the ice cream reacts to the heat in your mouth and glows - so the more you lick it, the brighter it gets.
Charlie, founder of the ice cream company "Lick Me I'm Delicious", says: "The product is incredible, but still at a very early stage of production, so you can get two grams of it for 200 pounds".
The protein used in ice cream reacts with the tongue at a neutral pH.
When the mouth heats the protein, the pH increases and the ice cream glows.
We have been testing it for the last few months and it seemed ideal to launch it on Halloween because it has this wonderful glow effect.
It is probably the most expensive ice cream I have ever made, because jellyfish luminescent material is four times more expensive than gold.
Each bullet costs me about 140 pounds.
But it tastes delicious.
Charlie's experimental Bristol-based company is famous for its unusual flavours, which include beer, cheese, beef and gold leaf.
But his latest creation is to become even more ambitious.
He says, "I'd like to develop an invisible ice cream."
This is impossible in itself because of the refraction of light caused by the ice crystals that make up ice cream, but I suspect we will find a way to do it.
The ice cream uses the fluorescent properties of a jellyfish, which are artificially produced by Chinese scientists

If you're not hot in a game like this, stay home.
Halloween 2013: In numbers
When I was little, Halloween had a magical quality.
My sister and I were allowed to eat sweets, stay up late and dress up for the neighbourhood.
Today I've become more of a Halloween grouch.
For the last two years I have not agreed to distribute sweets from my apartment and I probably won't do it this year either.
But statistics show that I'm a black sheep when it comes to Halloween.
The majority of Americans - 158 million to be exact - are celebrating Halloween this year, spending a total of $6.9 billion on sweets, costumes and decorations, according to the National Retail Federation (NRF).
One thing that I look forward to every Halloween are the trend values.
The costumes will account for about 1.2 billion of the 6.9 billion US dollars spent, according to the NRF.
This year provocative inanimate objects are all the rage.
Women no longer have to wrap themselves in sexy clothes, they can now embody tempting food such as pizza, hamburgers or carrots.
As for men, I expect lots of zombies thanks to The Walking Dead, and I bet the daft punk space men will make it into the Instagram feeds this year.
According to Google, the most wanted costumes are zombies, batman, pirates and witches.
I suppose there's nothing wrong with tradition.
We dressed up our dogs last year and to my astonishment we were not alone with this.
In fact, Americans are spending $330 million this year on costumes for their pets, according to the NRF.
That's a lot of hot dogs.
We're not squeamish about sweets.
Americans will spend $1.9 billion this year, according to The Nielsen Company.
That's about 270 million kilograms of chocolate bars, lollipops, sweets and gummy bears.
So it's good news for the 41 million people who, according to the US Department of Commerce, go trick-or-treating through the neighbourhoods.
In fact, we will buy over 40 million kilos of chocolate for Halloween and - let's face it - eat it.
The only thing we don't want to consume is the sugar-sweet candy corn; yet 15 million kilograms of it are sold around Halloween, according to the National Confectionery Association.
That's about nine billion corn kernels.
It is a mystery I have not yet been able to solve.
Nothing belongs to Halloween more than haunted houses.
They have great names like "Terror Behind the Walls" (which by the way is in a real prison), "Howl-O-Scream" and "The House of Shock".
There are actually 1,200 officially recognized haunted houses in the United States that generate $500 million in revenue, according to America Haunts, and that includes those wonderful photos where you are peeing your pants and then post your friends on Facebook where you can't get rid of them, and then the guy you like leaves you a comment like "nice face".
But let's get back to the pumpkins.
Charlie Brown introduced us to the Grand Pumpkin when we were kids, and carving a jack-o'-lantern is like decorating the Christmas tree - something we did from a very young age.
Fortunately, the "baby in the pumpkin" trend only started last year thanks to Pinterest, so most of us grew up carving the pumpkin rather than sitting in it.
This year Americans will spend about 106 million dollars on pumpkins, according to the US Census Bureau.
The pumpkin lantern, which slowly rots in the front garden, probably originates from Illinois, where 245 million kilograms of pumpkins were harvested this year.
If you want to score big, call Tim and Susan Mathisdon in Napa, California and carve something pretty out of their 921 kilo pumpkin.
