The background to this is a possible shortage of pastors: the Evangelical Lutheran Regional Church of Hanover expects that the number of its current 1,800 pastors will be halved by 2030 according to the current situation.
For young people today, the profession is very attractive and offers good prospects for the future, said Pastor Mathis Burfien (43) in an interview with the Protestant Press Service.
It is attractive to be able to determine the work and daily routine yourself.
With Burfien the regional church has for the first time commissioned a pastor on a full-time post to inspire young people to study theology.
At present, fewer and fewer young people decide to study theology after graduating from high school.
Burfien attributes this to the process of de-churching: "God's voice is quiet, the world is loud".
The profession is characterised by great freedom and diversity.
I am in control of my schedule and can set my priorities where it is important to me.
Pastors could be very close to the people as pastors.
They earned as much as teachers and could make a good living from it.
Certainly, in the free economy more is paid, but theologians have a secure employer.
This, he said, is in the interests of today's young people, who are not only interested in a career, but in a meaningful job.
According to the state church, which covers three quarters of Lower Saxony, around 60 pastors are currently retiring each year.
At the same time about 40 graduates of a theology course begin their vicariate.
In sparsely populated peripheral areas such as the Harz, Emsland or Wendland, it could become difficult to fill vacancies in the future.
Among other things, Burfien wants to organize study days for young people and also invite celebrities who have studied theology.
The study of theology offered a broad education.
You can even become Federal President with it.

Cocker spaniel bitch Ruby had run away after a small traffic accident
Three days later she was discovered in her predicament by a walker in the quarry
Firemen rappelled down a rock face and saved the dog from certain death
The fire brigade managed to bring a puppy to safety, which was stuck on a 15-metre high ledge in a rock face.
Nine-month-old cocker spaniel bitch Ruby had run away after a traffic accident on Sunday afternoon and survived three days alone before being rescued from a quarry on Wednesday.
Scott Alderson, 25, and his girlfriend Becky Hall, 20, who own the dog, came to the Flappit Quarry in Denholme, West Yorkshire to meet Ruby again and thank the firefighters of the West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service.
They had desperately searched for their missing dog and published calls for help in social networks when she ran away to the quarry after the small traffic accident.
Around 14:15 on Wednesday, a walker walking his dog saw the stranded Ruby on the 15-meter high ledge in the quarry.
The Cleckheaton Fire Station technical rescue team rushed to the scene and rappelled down to rescue Ruby, who was then transported upstairs in a dog crate.
Andy Clayton, specialist of the technical rescue team, said: "She was in a dangerous situation.
It was located in the middle of the rock face - 15 meters from the top and the ground.
She did not move a muscle during her rescue - she was frozen stiff.
But she's fine now.
She ate some dog biscuits afterwards.
That was a pretty unusual operation.
The fact that the dog was discovered is incredible.
Peter Lau, technical rescue specialist, said, "Ruby was very lucky."
There was a possibility that she was very seriously injured or worse.
Ruby was taken to the vet for examination, but the vet found nothing except exhaustion and dehydration.
Becky Hall from Halifax, West Yorkshire, said, "Watching the rescue was frightening."
I couldn't believe she was really up there.
It was wonderful to hold her in my arms again.
The vet explained that if the exhaustion had become too great and she had collapsed, she would probably have crashed.
The firefighters did a great job.
It was really brave what they did.
We are just so grateful and each of them was absolutely incredible.
Scott Alderson from Keighley added, "We were afraid it would fall off, but it stayed up."
The firefighters were great.
I can hardly believe where she's been.

George Kerevan: European unbundling gives the Scots the choice
A new day, a new horror story about independence.
This time we are warned that an independent Scotland is needed to join the Schengen area as a condition for EU membership.
This provides the cue for stories of passport controls in Berwick and a barbed wire border along Hadrian's Wall.
In fact, the Strathclyde proposal highlighted the potential economic benefits that more freedom to travel in the rest of Europe would bring, but, as expected, this was not in the headlines.
Nor has anyone mentioned that EU member states often bend their strict rules when it is more convenient for them.
Since Scotland is not currently part of the Schengen area, continued non-observance would be only a small concession to Brussels in return for what is really wanted from the Scots.
So not really a story.
And one that has come so far in years that it already resembles a fossil: I first heard the "independence means passport controls" duck at least 40 years ago.
An interesting point is lost in the constant repetition of this ancient history.
Why should an independent Scotland be expected to dance to the European tune?
Why exchange the yoke of London for that of Brussels, especially now?
This is the real European news: The great post-war plan for the unification of Europe has come to a standstill.
With the euro crisis, the European project has officially died.
Throughout the EU, parties that are hostile to the EU or want to throw the euro overboard as a common currency are gaining ground.
Even in Germany, the eurosceptic Alternative for Germany party - founded only this year - managed to win almost five million votes in the September general election, effectively driving the Free Democrats (the equivalent of the British Liberal Democrats) out of the Bundestag.
There has always been domestic resistance to the plan to create a federalist Europe.
However, the current economic crisis is proving to be a turning point.
Because of the strict austerity policy imposed by Berlin and the European Central Bank, combined with the straitjacket into which the respective national economies are forced by the adherence to the common currency, many people believe that the European project has gone too far.
The euro crisis has little to do with the fact that national governments are creating excessive budget deficits - this was only the case in Greece.
Instead, the Eurosystem has pegged its members to exchange rates that are advantageous for German exporters - and German politicians would like to keep it that way.
Without the possibility of a devaluation of the local currency, Southern Europe finds itself with a built-in productivity disadvantage compared to Germany.
The only option is to cut wages and public spending - spurred on by Berlin.
Behind the current budget and currency problems lies a deeper European productivity problem.
As a result of the "green" energy directives enacted by Brussels - a code for subsidising French and German energy companies at the expense of consumers - European industry pays twice as much for electricity and four times as much for gas compared to the United States.
This is a crippling cost disadvantage, as we have already seen in Grangemouth.
All the wage fixes in the world do not protect the European petrochemical industry from being cornered by cheap American shale gas.
As a result, a revolt is brewing, especially in France, the former cheerleader of the EU.
After the war, France's political elite saw the EU as a vehicle to keep Germany in check and put Paris on an equal footing with Washington.
But Berlin no longer needs Paris as a gateway to political legitimacy and has imposed its own economic policy on Europe, which the ailing French economy is struggling with.
The result: Marine Le Pen's right-wing, anti-EU Front National has just won a crucial by-election, relegating the ruling Socialists to third place.
The Front National is now the most popular party in France with 24 percent of the vote - a timely warning to the British Labour Party that it cannot assume that a split in the right spectrum would automatically mean advantages for the Left.
What is Le Pen doing with her newly won popularity among the white French working class?
She wants to use next year's EU elections to forge an anti-EU, anti-community currency bloc in the European Parliament.
If the anti-EU parties do well in these elections - and this is very possible - then for the first time such a bloc could dominate the European Parliament.
This is the point I'm getting at: In the not too distant future, the growing resentment against the EU and the single currency will converge to abolish the euro.
The EU will not disappear, but it will rather become something like the "Europe of (sovereign) nations" favoured by General de Gaulle.
Germany and some of its satellite economies may hold on to the euro, but France and Southern Europe will return to their own currencies.
I expect Britain to distance itself from this project in the hope of ingratiating itself with the USA.
However, Washington's growing interest in the Pacific region suggests that the UK will be alone in the Atlantic rain.
Where is Scotland in all this?
We can choose to be a region of (ultimately) Little England.
Or we can defend our own economic interests - which includes telling Berlin and Brussels what they can put up where.
I suspect Scotland could do quite well in a looser European federation, provided we keep our own currency.
Cooperation with other, similarly thinking countries is easier in a non-federated Europe of nations.
Otherwise, we should consider doing the same to Norway and retaining our economic independence.
The SNP government in Scotland is - remarkably - the most successful political movement against austerity in Europe and won a spectacular majority in 2011 for rejecting the proposed (and implemented) cuts, which were the responsibility of Labour Chancellor of the Exchequer Alistair Darling and the subsequent Tory-Lib Dem coalition.
It would be ridiculous for Scotland to opt for independence now, only to have Berlin and Brussels impose austerity measures.
Early Puberty: Grow up faster
African American and Hispanic girls tend to reach puberty earlier than their white peers, as studies show.
Physical changes do not yet directly mean puberty
There is no evidence that hormones or other chemicals are responsible
Experts believe that epidemic obesity is a trigger for early puberty
The trend towards early puberty is less pronounced in boys
Former CNN correspondent Pat Etheridge is a journalist specializing in children's health and family issues.
Should a mother be concerned when her daughter starts to grow breasts and pubic hair at the age of seven or eight?
Speaking at the annual conference of the American Academy of Pediatrics Association of Pediatricians this week in Orlando, Florida, pediatric endocrinologist Dr. Paul Kaplowitz explained that these early physical changes were relatively normal among American girls and represented a new norm.
"I spend a lot of time reassuring parents - usually this is not a sign that puberty is approaching quickly," Kaplowitz explained.
Obvious signs of development, such as growing breasts, pubic and axillary hair and body odor, appear earlier in girls.
Nevertheless, there has only been a slight shift in the age of the menarche (occurrence of the first menstrual period) in the last 40 years.
In the United States the average age is 12.5 years, slightly less than 12.75 in 1970.
"When the development of the breasts begins, it takes at least another two to three years until the menarche," said Kaplowitz, also author of the book "Early Puberty in Girls: The essential guide to dealing with this common problem".
Time is the most accurate test of how puberty progresses.
It is controversial what actually represents the beginning of puberty, but it is considered "precocious" if the breast enlargement is accompanied by a growth spurt before the age of eight years.
In most cases, the process slows down or stagnates - something that a pediatrician can monitor closely.
If progressing more rapidly, tests by an endicronologist may be indicated to rule out serious problems such as tumours or cysts.
There are treatments available to delay early menstruation and ward off another consequence: premature aging of the bones, which can ultimately lead to growth inhibition and thus small body growth in adults.
The recommendations for drug or hormonal therapy are based on the child's age, developmental speed, growth rate and emotional maturity.
Psychosocial aspects are also important.
Kaplowitz is reticent about medication, but he admits: "Suppressing puberty can alleviate behavioral problems and the feelings of girls to be different from their peers.
The other big problem is understandable: parents simply do not want their very young daughters to have the period.
"They worry about the risk of pregnancy or how they handle the hygiene side," Kaplowitz said.
"It was a shock," recalls a woman whose daughter got her period at ten.
Even though there were first signs and we had talked about menstruation, she was not emotionally prepared.
She came home from school scared and excited because she was the first in her circle of friends.
There are many extensively published theories on the causes of premature puberty.
But there is no conclusive evidence that hormones in milk or other foods, chemicals in the environment or sexual messages in the media are causative.
Boys reach puberty in a similar way to girls in the past.
Kaplowitz believes that the most convincing premise is the epidemic of obesity.
He supported the conduct of a study in 2001 on girls aged six to nine years, which established a link between body fat and the onset of puberty.
Other research supports this conclusion, but there are many other factors that play a role.
In this country, African American and Hispanic girls tend to reach puberty earlier than their white counterparts.
There are different explanations for this.
Globally, early puberty seems to be influenced by all kinds of things, from economic conditions to climate and genes.
Another mystery: Although boys grow facial and pubic hair earlier, the trend towards full earlier puberty is not as pronounced as in girls.
Other doctors at the AAP conference underlined the complexity of the issue.
The appearance of acne and pubic hair is common even in babies and toddlers.
"We need to be careful how we identify the true onset of puberty," said Dr. Lawrence Silverman, a pediatric endocrinologist at Goryeb Children's Hospital in Morristown, New Jersey.
Parents should not hesitate to seek advice from their pediatrician on how to speak to their child.
"This may mean having to have a conversation earlier than expected," Kaplowitz advised.
If you remain calm, the child usually reacts well.
Girls who blossom early need the assurance that the process is a normal part of life, even if it happens sooner than expected.
Jumbo manufacturers argue about seat width in the face of large orders
A dispute has broken out between leading aircraft manufacturers over the width of tourist class seats on long-haul flights, setting the tone for a bitter clash at this month's Dubai Airshow.
The dispute revolves around the seat width offered to passengers on long flights in coach - not always the most sought-after by airlines, but this designated space is key to the efficiency claims of the latest Airbus SAS and Boeing Co. aircraft.
Airbus this week called for an industry standard requiring a minimum seat width of 46 cm (18 inches) in coach class, but US arch-rival Boeing says the airlines should decide.
The confrontation comes at a time when aircraft manufacturers are competing to sell even larger versions of their twin-engined long-haul aircraft and are expecting record orders at the event from 17 to 21 November.
The design of the rear section of the aircraft - in particular whether there are rows of nine or ten seats - is decisive for the stated economic results that the new "mini-jumbo" design is intended to deliver.
Boeing claims that its modernized "777X" seats 406 passengers in coach class seats that are over 17 inches wide, allowing ten per row.
Airbus states that the competing version of the A350 carries 350 passengers in 18-inch wide tourist class seats, with nine per row.
Aircraft giants often hand out blows about technical details by means of advertising in the trade press.
Airbus is now appealing directly to the public before the Dubai Airshow, where the 777X is expected to win the race with over 100 orders.
Recently, the company presented an ad that could be the beginning of a new ad war, showing backers a picture of three people squeezed together in a restaurant, and the title: "Would you accept this?
"Boeing is proposing long-haul flights in seats that are narrower than regional turbo-props," says Airbus sales director John Leahy.
With changing eating habits, people are getting fatter, but aircraft seats have not changed radically.
Between the early 1970s, when the Boeing 747 defined modern long-haul travel, and the end of the century, the weight of the average male American between 40 and 49 years of age increased by ten percent, according to data from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
The waist circumference of the average male American in the 21st century is 100.8 cm according to US health statistics.
Airbus says its rival is sticking to a seating concept from the 1950s, when the average girth of the newly christened "jet set" was narrower.
According to Airbus, studies have been carried out which show that an additional inch (2.54 cm) per seat increases sleep quality by 53 percent.
Boeing disputes Airbus' figures on seat dimensions and says that it is not at the manufacturers' discretion to decide how airlines balance airfares and furnishings.
The company also explains that, according to research, the experience on the plane depends on more than the width of the seat.
"It really comes down to giving airlines flexibility to do what they think they need to do to be successful," explains Boeing's flight cabin expert Kent Craver.
They do not want us to dictate to them what makes them profitable.
They know their business better than anyone else.
For passengers it is about more elbow room, but for manufacturers it is increasingly becoming an issue that can have an impact on sales.
Behind the dispute is a race for aircraft orders with an estimated volume of at least 700 billion US dollars at list prices in the coming decades, which could have a lasting effect on the export balance of the USA or Europe.
As Reuters first reported in July, seat layout is the driving force behind the debate about the new jets.
Both Airbus and Boeing claim 20 percent more efficiency per seat in their latest twin-engine long-haul designs than the market leader in this segment, the 365-seat Boeing 77-300ER.
Boeing's statements on the results depend in part on comparing the 777X, with its ten seats per row, with the original design of nine seats in the 777.
The increased costs per unit are still lower than in the case of currently used machines with ten seats per row.
"Boeing is therefore squeezing more seats into its aircraft to make it more competitive with our products," says Kevin Keniston, Head of Passenger Comfort at European Airbus.
On the other hand, analysts say full cabins with ten seats per row with existing 777s indicated that many passengers chose the tighter arrangement, which could be accompanied by cheaper air fares.
"Eighteen-inch seat width would be great for passengers, but the reality is: from an economic point of view, the Airbus offer is driven by the threat of the 777," says Mary Kirby, cabin furnishing expert, founder and editor of Runway Girl Network.
Airbus and Boeing do not offer seats, but a catalogue of suppliers from which the airlines can choose.
The world-traveling jet salesmen even carry tape measure to measure the interior at the competition.
Even if they advertise comfort, all manufacturers also offer jets with high density designs for budget airlines and regional flights.
Airbus offers an A350 with ten-seat rows, but has not yet sold one.
Until recently, Airbus emphasised the importance of more adaptable cabins and offered wide aisle seats for some jets.
Without the support of the only other manufacturer of large modern jets, experts say that the call for a new industry standard will probably fizzle out, but could divert attention from the wave of 777X sales.
New anti-nicotine vaccine could end the pleasure of smoking
Scientists have developed an anti-nicotine vaccine that could spoil the fun of smoking.
A single dose of the vaccine could protect mice from nicotine addiction for a lifetime.
More trials are needed before tests on humans can be carried out, which may take several years, but Professor Ronald Crystal of Weill Cornell Medical College in New York said the initial results are good.
"We are very hopeful that this type of vaccination strategy can one day help millions of smokers who have tried to quit, using all the methods available on the market, but have found that their nicotine addiction is stronger than these approaches," Cornell said.
The new vaccine contains a harmless virus that has been modified to contain the genetic information needed to produce nicotine antibodies.
The virus selectively infects the liver cells, which then produce a constant stream of antibodies.
The antibodies hunt the nicotine molecules in the blood and neutralize them before they reach the brain, so a smoker does not experience a nicotine high.
In experiments, vaccinated mice given nicotine maintained their normal activity levels.
Mice without vaccination, however, took a "time-out", the researchers explained, a sign that the nicotine had reached their brain.
The experiments are described in the journal Science Translational Medicine.
Previous tobacco vaccines failed because they contained antibodies.
Vaccinations had to be given so frequently to maintain antibody levels that they were expensive and impractical.
However, the cost of the new vaccine is likely to be much lower because it turns liver cells into antibody factories.
As Professor Crystal said, a future vaccine for humans, if it was safe, could be given to children before they were tempted to try a cigarette, thus preventing nicotine addiction.
But more likely, smokers would use it to quit.
"They then know that when they start smoking again, they no longer feel pleasure in it because of the nicotine vaccine, and that helps them to break the habit," he explains.
British scientists said the results were interesting, but warned at the same time that more research was needed.

Foreign workers with 457 visas could be subjected to "authenticity tests
The government is considering an "authenticity test" for foreign workers with 457 visas as part of extended measures.
Should the test be introduced, it would be applied via a criterion designed to prevent the 457 from being used to fill unskilled jobs or as a back door for family and friends to move to Australia.
A government proposal for discussion was published today after former Labor Party MP Maxine McKew condemned the government's comments regarding foreign workers because they could be considered an insult by Australia's neighbors.
"Vociferous statements such as 'foreigners should get in line at the back of the queue' and 'Australians should get in line first' are a very unpleasant backslide at a time when unions are demanding a protected labour market," she told the Australia India Institute today.
Historically, this meant that white workers were to be protected - and if some in the region were to hear an echo of this historical artifact, I wouldn't be surprised.
The proposal for discussion outlines twelve measures once envisaged by former Immigration Secretary Chris Bowen.
Immigration Secretary Brendan O'Connor, who was in Sri Lanka yesterday for talks on human smuggling, has implemented five of the recommended changes, the others are still under consideration.
If the "authenticity criterion" is taken over, then someone applying for a visa could be checked as to whether "the application is genuine in cases where the applicant is related or personally connected with the holder or a relevant person of the supporting organisation".
Companies could also be required to account for the number of 457 visa holders, after companies that initially wanted to support only a small number of workers eventually hired hundreds.

The distraught nine-year-old son of the man who came with him to Australia has been taken care of by an adult cousin who was also on the boat since his father died on Wednesday.
Australian authorities brought the man to the Christmas Island Hospital where he died.
A study has been announced by the UK government to increase the benefits of the HS2 rail project for Scotland.
The work of HS2 Ltd proposes to implement high-speed links between Scotland and the north of England from the start of Phase 1 in 2026.
Minister of Transport Baroness Kramer said the project "will bring Britain closer together".
Scottish Transport Minister Keith Brown said he was delighted to be working with the British government on this plan.
Phase 1 consists of a new high-speed rail link between London and the West Midlands.
After completion of Phase 2 there will be connections to Manchester and Leeds.
In June the government corrected the estimated cost of building the high-speed rail link between London and northern England from £32.7 billion to £42.6 billion.
The British government, which is in discussions with Transport Scotland, has commissioned HS2 Ltd to look for further route capacity and travel time improvements for the north of England and Scotland.
This includes the possibility of a journey time of ultimately three hours or less from Glasgow and Edinburgh to London.
Baroness Kramer said: "Our aim for HS2 is to create a truly national route network that will bring Britain and its cities closer together.
We're going ahead with HS2 because it has enormous advantages.
Without it, we are facing a capacity crisis in our rail network.
But it also concerns the connection between 18 British cities, including Glasgow and Edinburgh, which is being improved thanks to HS2.
Scottish Secretary of State Alistair Carmichael commented: "Today's announcement is good news for Scotland."
On behalf of the Scottish Executive, Keith Brown called on Carmichael to make a "clear" commitment to Scottish integration into the HS2 network.
Brown said: "The high-speed rail link has the potential to deliver huge economic benefits to Scotland, but at the same time the economic strength of Scotland provides an argument for fast rail links throughout the UK".
We are therefore delighted to be working as a partner to the UK Government to explore the options for a high-speed rail link in Scotland that will create benefits for all and complement the Glasgow-Edinburgh link that the Scottish Government is already planning.
I look forward to examining the investigation report with UK ministers next year and jointly deciding on the next steps.
Provisions on electronic equipment on aircraft remain provisionally in force in Australia
Australian air passengers must continue to turn off tablets and smartphones during take-off and landing, despite efforts in the US to relax regulations on such devices.
The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allows U.S. airlines to change their regulations so that passengers can read e-books, watch videos or play games on their devices during critical phases of flight, provided they are in "flight mode".
During most of the flight, passengers are already allowed to do this, but many people find it annoying that they are not allowed to read their e-books during take-off and landing.
Australian airlines are monitoring the decision, which requires a huge amount of work on the part of US airlines to implement, but have no immediate plans to change their regulations.
The air traffic control authority CASA also said they would look into the announcement, but stressed that the restrictions on the use of electronic equipment during critical flight phases still apply in Australia.
"CASA currently has no specific regulations regarding the use of electronic equipment on aircraft," it was announced.
The issue is subject to regulations requiring airlines to maintain safety at all times and passengers to follow the safety instructions given by cabin crew.
Virgin has already held talks with CASA about expanding the use of its Wi-Fi entertainment system on flights and has stated that it is open to change, but that this must be initiated by the legislature.
"We would welcome a review of CASA's approval of electronic devices, as we believe this would improve the customer experience now that we offer (wireless entertainment) in-flight," said a spokesperson.
Qantas declared that they will stick to the current regulations for the time being.
"Our current policy is not to use electronic equipment during take-off and landing, and we have no plans to change that at this time," the company stated.
The FAA regulations apply to US airlines.
However, we are always interested in developments in regulations from which passengers can benefit and will certainly take a close look at the FAA decision and the reasons behind it.
For US companies, this decision has different effects depending on the age of the fleet.
They must demonstrate that their aircraft can tolerate the radio interference from mobile devices and change manuals, training materials, carry-on baggage programmes and customer instruction.
"Once an airline has confirmed the tolerance of its fleet, it can allow passengers to use portable, lightweight electronic devices such as tablets, e-book readers and smartphones at any altitude," the FAA announced.
In rare cases of poor visibility, the crew will instruct passengers to switch off the equipment during landing.
The group also recommended that heavier equipment be safely stowed under the seat or in the compartments above the seats during take-off and landing.
Before the district derby against Schalke, BVB supporters who had travelled with them had used flares to create ugly scenes in the Veltins-Arena.
Borussia Dortmund then announced harsh consequences.
Before the Bundesliga football match on Friday against VfB Stuttgart, the Ultras reacted with silence - for the time being.
The acoustics were unusual, almost spooky, and the spectators could enjoy them until shortly before the kick-off of the Bundesliga match between German runners-up Borussia Dortmund and VfB Stuttgart in the Signal Iduna Park.
Mostly the fans of the guests could be heard with their songs.
The South Stand, on the other hand, where the most loyal - and loudest - BVB fans are standing, initially presented itself as exceptionally quiet: No chants, no battle cries.
The podium of the Capo, which otherwise coordinates the joint cheering, remained unoccupied.
And at the very front of the grandstand, a large flag with the inscription "Section stadium ban" was waving lonely.
Only when goalkeeper Roman Weidenfeller, as always the first BVB player to enter the pitch, was there a brief burst of cheers.
When his teammates followed, there was loud singing and waving scarves - but not everywhere.
Nothing moved in the central blocks 12 and 13 of the south stand.
Even the fact that stadium spokesman Norbert Dickel once again listed the positive experiences of the last few days - derby victory, victory over Arsenal, contract extension of coach Jürgen Klopp - did not create a festive mood.
It was only five minutes before kick-off that the Capo climbed his podium - and the tension, which had been almost palpable with his hands until then, was released in a loud scream as Dickel, as usual, questioned the mood on the stands in the stadium.
Last, as always, was the south stand - and finally, as usual, the loudest place in the stadium was here again.
And at the latest when the kick-off from the south grandstand was accompanied by the loud call "Derby winner stands up", everything was back to normal.
The silence before was probably a reaction to the events of the past days.
Immediately before the FC Schalke 04 district derby, some of the BVB supporters who had travelled with them fired flares into the spectator stands and onto the pitch - and almost hit goalkeeper Roman Weidenfeller in the process.
The game was started late because of the chaotic scenes.
BVB boss Hans-Joachim Watzke then received the top Dortmund Ultras in his office - and if you believe Watzke's words, this was a rather uncomfortable appointment for the fan representatives.
"There will be massive cuts for the entire Ultra movement," the BVB boss announced on Thursday evening at a panel discussion in Frankfurt.
As an immediate measure, Watzke forbade the Ultras to choreograph for the home game against VfB Stuttgart.
"I have forbidden it," he declared.
We cannot abandon the zero tolerance policy on pyrotechnics.
In addition, the Ultras were shown various ways of punishing them - they now have until Tuesday to decide on one.
Otherwise, according to Watzke, BVB will determine a sanction by the end of next week.
"This will be decisive," assured Watzke.
It will be interesting to see how the reactions on the south stand will turn out.
Pawnshops are booming in Singapore as the crisis has reached the middle class
In a pawn shop in the Bendemeer shopping centre in Singapore, Janani Amirthalinga exchanges a gold bracelet, a ring and a pair of earrings to pay her daughters' school fees.
"My husband and I have just bought a house, all my money is in it," says Amirthalinga.
Although she earns 3.000 Singapore dollars (approximately 1.730 Euro) per month as an administrative employee and her husband also works, the monthly family income is not enough, she explains.
In fact, demand in parts of Southeast Asia - where household debt is increasing - is so strong that ValueMax, where it made its swap, became the third pawnshop listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange this week.
Pledging jewelry is not only a quick way to get money - 1,300 Singapore dollars in the case of Janani Amirthalinga - but also almost as cheap as an unsecured bank loan.
Typically, pawnbrokers in Singapore charge an APR of 17 percent, which is only slightly higher than the 15.4 percent charged by United Overseas Bank, a local lender with a branch in the same shopping center.
However, pawnshops offer the advantage that no credit check or proof of income is required here, which is why loans can be obtained faster than from banks.
For this reason, millions of people in the region turn to pawn shops after families feel the pressure of rising living costs and increasing household and consumer debt.
After five years of robust growth since the global financial crisis and cheap credit due to loose fiscal policies in developed economies, families with lower and middle incomes are turning to pawn shops to make up the difference when the economy stutters.
This week the rating agency Standard & Poor's described growing household debt, mainly due to rising mortgages, as a risk factor for the creditworthiness of Asian banks.
Malaysia, Thailand and Singapore have the highest budget debt in Asia in relation to gross domestic product, according to the agency's estimates.
Malaysia heads the list with 80 percent of GDP, an increase of 60 percent in 2008.
Economists are also worried about the high level of consumer debt in Thailand, which narrowly emerged from a technical recession this week.
On Thursday, the data showed continued weakness in exports and weakening consumer demand.
"In the end, this means that as costs rise, people in the middle to lower segment (the income scale) will try to supplement their income wherever possible," says Song Seng Wun, an economist at CIMB, a Malaysian bank.
Historic highs in gold prices over the past two years have reinforced the trend towards pledging personal effects as people take the opportunity to turn family jewellery into cash.
In Singapore, about 70 percent of the items pledged in the 200 pawn shops of the city-state are gold.
People say to themselves, "The gold price looks good, let's pawn Grandma's gold chain and get it back next month."
The largest Thai pawn shop operator, EasyMoney, has seen a 20 percent increase in customer numbers in its branches in recent months.
The growth in the deposit business is so strong that ValueMax, which operates the Bendemeer branch and 15 others in Singapore, is looking to expand not only into neighbouring Malaysia - where the company operates four homes - but also outside Asia, said Yeah Lee Ching, managing director of ValueMax.
The company is financing this with 60 percent of the 66 million Singapore dollars it raised this week with its IPO in Singapore.
While some lenders have been caught in the crossfire because of high interest rates, Yeah explains that not only do pawn shops offer lower interest rates than other lenders, but they don't directly increase debt.
"Customers lend items they already own, and liquefying personal valuables does not increase household indebtedness," she explains.
The pawnbroking business is increasingly accepted by society as a short-term, secured financing.
Also, not all people who use pawnshops are in financial difficulties.
Rich people from Singapore also come to ValueMax stores to pawn gold bars and Rolex watches, for which they receive up to 60 percent of the purchase price in cash.
Customers from every social class come to us.
"These include wealthy people who borrow for a business or investment in the short term, or small businesses that need to bridge cash flow shortfalls," says Yeah.
Sometimes they just need money very quickly.

325 million Australian dollars bailout package for Tasmanian health care
The Australian government is insisting on the tough conditions attached to the 325 million Australian dollars bailout package for Tasmania's healthcare system to ensure that the state government cannot waste the money.
Federal Health Minister Tanya Plibersek has announced that the Commonwealth will take "immediate action" to avert a crisis caused by an ageing population of the island state, a higher rate of chronic illness and systemic constraints.
The funding for a four-year period was decided after government consultations with independent Tasmanian MP Andrew Wilkie.
"The government has put together an emergency rescue package that we believe addresses the unique challenges facing the state," Plibersek said today.
The $325 million package includes $31 million in emergency aid for election services.
A further 2600 operations, including orthopaedic surgery and cataract treatment, are expected to eliminate backlogs.
In addition, there is money for day hospitals in Hobart and Launceston, better aftercare after inpatient stays, specialist training, mental health services and the introduction of a system for electronic recording of health data in local hospitals.
"These investments are in line with ideas that affected clinic staff have told me are the best way to improve the Tasmanian healthcare system," said Tanya Plibersek.
The Minister insisted on strict reporting and accountability of the Tasmanian government.
The state would have to maintain the current level of funding to receive money from the Commonwealth and report monthly on where the extra money was spent.
A three-member commission will be established to ensure that the state provides health services as effectively and efficiently as possible.
As Wilkie explained today, the $325 million will be of little use unless "it is accompanied by real reforms that put Tasmania's public health system on a more sustainable course.
Nevertheless, he praised the government for responding to his request for urgent assistance, which he first expressed to the Prime Minister in early May.
"I am confident that federal aid will make a major contribution to taking the state's public health system off the list of concerns," Wilkie said.
According to the state government, these electoral achievements will largely make up for the recent cuts.
However, Peter Dutton, the health policy spokesman for the opposition at federal level, believes that today's announcement is only a "patchwork solution".
"We are in the current situation because the Labor State Government has withdrawn $430 million from the health care system," he told ABC TV.
It can't be that a state government rips almost half a billion dollars out of the system and the Commonwealth puts in 300 million and then pretends it's good news.
Dutton called on Plibersek to guarantee that not a single dollar of the rescue package would be spent on additional bureaucracy.
Guillaume Nicloux's adaptation of Denis Diderot's novel impresses with exceptional production equipment and contemporary details, but is also heavier than necessary.

When she rebels, she is confronted with the extreme cruelty of an extremely sadistic matron and becomes the object of erotic fascination of another.
The film never slips into lechery or sensationalism - and therein lies its problem.
The solemn seriousness with which the film is told also makes it a torturous penitent shirt for the audience.
Syria has destroyed its ability to produce chemical weapons, according to a monitoring group
Syria has destroyed key facilities for the production of chemical weapons and poison gas ammunition, the Global Monitoring Group on Chemical Weapons said Thursday, while in the north of the country there were serious clashes near one of the sites where allegedly toxic substances are stored.
Also on Thursday, a Syrian activist group announced that more than 120,000 people have been killed since the beginning of the civil war almost three years ago.
The announcement of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) came one day before the deadline on
1 November, which the Hague-based organisation Damascus had set to destroy or make "inoperable" all facilities for the production of chemical weapons, including all machinery for mixing chemicals into poison gas and filling ammunition.
The completion of this process, which is essentially the first stage of destruction, is an important milestone in an ambitious timetable aimed at the destruction of all Syrian chemical weapons by mid-2014.
The destruction of the facilities means that Syria can no longer produce new chemical weapons.
However, Damascus has yet to start destroying the existing weapons and supplies.
It is assumed that there are about 1,000 tons of chemicals and weapons in the country, including mustard gas and the nerve gas sarin.
The announcement came at a time when fighting took place in the town of Safira on Thursday, where experts say there is a chemical weapons production facility and storage facilities, according to the UK-based Syrian Human Rights Observatory.
The activist group, which tracks the number of deaths through a network of activists in Syria, said on Thursday that 120,296 people died.
Of these 61,067 were civilians, including 6,365 children.
On the government side, 29,954 of them belonged to the army of President Bashar Assad, 18,678 were pro-government fighters and 187 Lebanese Hezbollah militias.
Also among the dead were 2,202 deserted army soldiers and 5,375 opposition fighters, many of them foreigners.
On 25 July, the UN estimated the number of deaths in this conflict since March 2011 at 100,000.
This figure has not yet been updated.
The conflict has forced about two million people to flee the country.
Assad's troops have been fighting against the rebels in Safira for weeks, many of whom have links to al-Qaeda groups.
The Observatory said there had been losses on both sides on Thursday, but did not give details.
The fighting underscores the danger faced by chemical weapons inspectors, as their mission to free Syria from its toxic arsenal is a race against time in the midst of a raging civil war.
According to the OPCW, which works closely with the United Nations, the team "is now convinced that it has seen and witnessed the destruction of all major production and mixing/bottling facilities mentioned by Syria.
Therefore "no further inspection activities are planned at this time."
Earlier this week, inspectors stated that they had completed the first round of inspections and visited 21 of the 23 sites indicated by Damascus.
Due to security concerns, the visit of two facilities was not possible, the inspectors said.
On Thursday, the OPWC declared that the two sites had been "abandoned" according to Syria. and the chemical weapons programme objects there had been transferred to other named facilities that had been inspected.
It was not immediately clear whether the Safira site was one of the two facilities that OPCW inspectors were unable to visit.
Syria has submitted a plan for the complete destruction of its chemical weapons, which must be approved by the OPWC Executive Committee next month.
"I take my hat off to the bravery and courage that you all have shown in carrying out the most challenging mission ever undertaken by this organisation," said Ahmed Uzumcu, the Director General of the monitoring organisation in a commentary published by OPCW.
For three years now, the mainly Sunni Muslim rebels have been fighting in this civil war against Assad's government and its security forces, to which many Alawite members belong, a secession of Shiite Islam.
Looking ahead to further developments, Rami Abdurrahman, head of the observation group, said there had been a strong explosion at an air defence facility in the Syrian coastal province of Latakia on Wednesday.
The cause of the explosion is not known, he explained.
Anger over verdict for Bali bombers
Survivors and relatives of the 202 people who died in the Bali bombing in 2002 reacted angrily to the verdict for the last of the instigators to be brought to justice, as they believed Umar Patek should be shot dead on sight.
Patek, who has been on the run for almost ten years as one of the most wanted persons in Southeast Asia, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison for his role in the construction of explosives for the bomb attack.
With parole, he could be released after 15 years.
The 45-year-old was found guilty of mass murder for the attack on two nightclubs in Kuta's popular tourist district, in which 202 people died, including 88 Australians, and many more were injured.
A conviction was also handed down on a number of terrorism-related charges, including a wave of bomb attacks on churches in Indonesia on Christmas Eve in 2000.
The public prosecutor's office had demanded a life sentence, even though it could have applied for the death penalty for the man, who is also known as the "Demolition Man" because of his reputation as a master bomb maker.
The decision has brought back painful memories for June Corteen, a mother from Perth who lost her 39-year-old twin daughters Jane and Jenny in the devastation wrought by Patek and his co-conspirators nearly ten years ago.
Fighting with tears, she said Patek should have been sentenced to death.
I really think he should follow in the other guys' footsteps.
"He should be put before a firing squad," Corteen told AAP.
I have to live every day with the fact that I will not have any more grandchildren and I will never see my daughters again.
The Sari Club was razed to the ground when a huge bomb exploded in a small truck parked in front of the nightclub on 12 October 2002 shortly after 11pm.
Peter Hughes was in Paddy's Bar, where just 20 seconds earlier a suicide bomber exploded a backpack filled with explosives.
He fell into a coma for a month after the attack and "died" three times while on life support.
Hughes said Patek deserved the same fate as the three other members of the terrorist cell Jemaah Islamiah - Amrozi, Mukhlas and Imam Samudra - who were responsible for the massacre and were executed four years ago.
Really, this guy should get the death penalty before anyone else.
To let him live - no, there is no reason to let him live.
To get 20 years after killing 202 people and injuring many hundreds is not much.
Patek is the last of the Bali bombers on trial.
He evaded arrest for almost a decade, but was finally apprehended in January 2011 in the Pakistani city of Abbottabad, where US forces killed former al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden barely four months later.
During the trial, an FBI agent testified that intelligence reports indicated that Patek was in Pakistan to meet bin Laden with the aim of rebuilding the link between Southeast Asian terrorist groups and al-Qaeda.
"He didn't turn himself in," Corteen said.
Until recently, he showed no remorse for how much suffering he had caused other people.
The verdict comes ahead of the tenth anniversary of the attack this year, which will be commemorated with commemorations in Bali and Australia.
"There will be many tears this year," said Corteen.
Patek can still appeal against his decision.
FAA: Passengers can now use electronic devices on airplanes (but cannot make mobile phone calls)
Air travelers can now use their electronic devices to read, work, play games, listen to music and watch movies from takeoff to landing, but not use their cell phones, according to new guidelines issued Thursday by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) in the United States.
But passengers should not expect these changes to be implemented immediately.
How quickly they would be implemented would depend on the respective airline, FAA employee Michael Huerta explained at a press conference.
Airlines must demonstrate to the FAA that aircraft comply with the new regulations and that they have updated their flight crew training manuals and stowage arrangements to reflect the new rules.
The FAA stated that it has already received plans from some airlines to expand the use of portable electronic devices on aircraft.
Among these airlines were Delta and JetBlue.
"Depending on the status of the plan, we could approve the expanded use of electronic equipment very soon," the FAA announced in a statement.
Currently, passengers must turn off smartphones, tablets and other devices when the aircraft doors are closed.
You may only take it off again when the aircraft has reached an altitude of three kilometres and the captain gives the green light.
When entering the landing approach, passengers must switch them off again and may not take them off again until the aircraft has landed.
Under the new guidelines, airlines whose aircraft are protected against electronic interference can allow their passengers to use the devices during take-off, landing and on the tarmac, the FAA explained.
Most new commercial aircraft and other aircraft converted to use Wi-Fi at high altitudes should meet the criteria.
Laura Glading, President of the Professional Flight Attendants Association, welcomed the changes.
"Once the new regulation is safely implemented - and we are working closely with the airline on this - both sides will benefit," commented Glading.
To be honest, we are tired of feeling like watchdogs on this issue.
Nevertheless, Internet connections for surfing, exchanging e-mails, text messages or downloading data remained prohibited under three kilometres, the authority explained.
Passengers are requested to put smartphones, tablets and other devices into flight mode.
So still no "Words With Friends", the Scrabble-like online game that actor Alec Baldwin played on his smartphone in 2011 when he had to publicly leave an American Airlines jet because he refused to turn off the device while the plane was parked at the gate.
And heavier equipment such as laptops must continue to be stowed away, as there is a risk of injury if they fly through the cabin.
Mobile phone calls during the flight will also remain prohibited.
The regulatory competence for telephone calls lies with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), not with the FAA.
FAA may lift ban on certain electronic equipment during takeoff and landing
Last month Mark Rosenker of the National Transportation Safety Board, safety expert for national transportation issues, told CBS News that cell phones are still considered a risk.
"Cell phones are really a problem, not only because they could potentially interfere with navigation devices, but because we at the FCC know that airborne transmissions can also interfere with transmitter masts," Rosenker said.
An industry advisory committee set up by the FAA to investigate the issue recommended last month that the government allow wider use of personal electronic devices.
In recent years there has been increased pressure on the FAA to relax restrictions on use.
Critics like Missouri Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill argue that there are no valid security reasons for the ban.
The restrictions are also increasingly difficult to enforce because the use of the devices has become ubiquitous.
In some studies there is talk of up to a third of passengers forgetting or ignoring to switch off the device.
The FAA began restricting the use of electronic devices by air travelers in 1966 after reports of interference with navigation and communication equipment by VHF radios carried by passengers became known, which at the time represented the latest technology trend.
New aircraft are far more dependent on electrical systems than previous generations of aircraft, but they are also designed and approved by the FAA to be free of electronic interference.
Airlines have been offering Wi-Fi to passengers for several years now, when the flight altitude is reached.
Aircraft adapted to Wi-Fi systems are also less sensitive to interference.
The vast majority of passenger planes should be suitable for the increased use of electronic devices under the new guidelines, Huerta said.
Today's electronic devices generally emit much less radio radiation than previous generations.
E-readers, for example, emit only minimal radiation when you turn the pages.
However, when downloading or sending data, the transmission values are stronger.
One of the advocates of easing restrictions on the use of devices by passengers is Amazon.com.
In 2011, company employees loaded a passenger plane full of Kindle e-readers and made a test flight to identify problems, but could not find any.
Members of the FAA Advisory Committee expressed mixed feelings about the risk involved in using equipment.
Douglas Kidd of the National Association of Airline Passengers said he believed the interference from the devices was genuine, even though the risk was minimal.
Other committee members said that there were only isolated reports of pilots arguing that the devices interfered with aircraft systems, and most of them were very old.
However, the committee recommended that the FAA should allow pilots to order passengers to switch off their equipment in the event of an instrument landing in poor visibility conditions.
A group from the travel industry welcomed the changes and described them as a reasonable adaptation for travellers who would be extensively equipped with technology today.
"We are pleased that the FAA recognizes that a pleasant passenger experience does not conflict with safety," said Roger Dow, CEO of the U.S. Travel Association.

Is Europe's elite ready to do business with Britain?
Business for Britain was launched in April with the aim of bringing business together to define what those who provide prosperity and jobs in Britain want to change about our relationship with the EU.
To this end, we commissioned the largest and most comprehensive survey of British business leaders and asked them what they think about Britain, the economy and the EU.
YouGov surveyed over 1,000 business leaders, roughly reflecting British business sizes, sectors and regions.
The results of the survey will surprise many.
We have found that the vast majority of companies are now exporting outside Europe, focusing on countries that are modernising and growing, while those in the EU are stagnating.
They want governments to favour new trade links with countries like China, India and Brazil rather than dwell on the long and arduous process of reforming the obscure EU institutions.
Asked for their views on specific statutory issues - from antitrust to product legislation - the majority of business leaders believe that control over these key competences should be brought back to Westminster.
There was general dissatisfaction with the single market, as companies said the cost of Brussels regulations now outweighs the benefits of being part of Europe's trading zone - even 40 per cent of large companies agreed, traditionally the most pro-European.
Finally, and probably most tellingly, our survey of business leaders revealed that a clear majority want Britain to move towards a change of course in the agreement and a relationship with the EU based on trade, not politics.
This realisation, which is found among companies of all sizes and leading corporations, shows that business is pushing for a "meaningful change" that will bring the book of action back to Britain.
There is a lot at stake - a change to the agreement and better conditions for Britain would lead to a change of opinion in favour of staying in the EU in a referendum at 16 per cent.
The Prime Minister should have no doubts: This survey shows that the British economy is behind his plan to renegotiate the British conditions for EU membership.
It also shows that companies expect a renegotiation to bring about a significant shift in the balance of power back to Britain.
A better deal for the British economy is possible and increasingly necessary as the Euro-Zone moves towards a closer economic and fiscal union.
The priority must be jobs and growth in the UK, as the results of our survey show, which for businesses means an increased focus on trade and a fundamental change in the Brussels approach to regulation.

Two YMCA staff from New South Wales (NSW) have been charged with child sex offences before charges were brought against Jonathan Lord, a childminder from Caringbah, in 2011, the Royal Commission on Child Sexual Abuse learned.
However, in its opening statement to the Commission, the YMCA stated that "the organisation has never been involved in any incidents of child sexual abuse".

Lord had been convicted earlier this year of sexual assault on twelve boys during his two years of service with the YMCA.
He was sentenced to at least six years in prison.
Hare denied, however, that the YMCA had a cultural problem that prevented employees from reporting Lord's child safety violations.
Staff testified that they had observed violations, including Lord being alone with children, babysitting them privately, letting them sit on his lap, telling one that he loved it, and letting children play with his cell phone.
Danielle Ockwell, whose supervisor was Lord and who had asked for child protection training because she was concerned about his behavior, testified that the children's service director, Jacqui Barnat, who was Lord's supervisor at the YMCA Caringbah, "was very intimidating and most of the time very aloof.
The manager stated that he would not accept statements from employees that they did not dare to report to their superiors.
Instead, he said, their friendship with Lord had rather affected their judgment, which is why they had not reported him.
Hare explained that he had shared with the board of directors of the YMCA NSW his view that the lesson to be learned by the organization from the "Jonathan Lord incident" was "not about reporting" by staff, and the board agreed with him.
Hare said the decision to urge employees to sign confidentiality agreements shortly after the allegations appeared was made by Liam Whitley, the director of the YMCA's Children's Services Department.
He said that this was to prevent contamination of the evidence, but that it was "overzealous" and poorly implemented.
The YMCA NSW was not a child-resistant organisation during the period that Jonathan Lord was employed there between 2009 and 2011, Professor Stephen Smallbone of Griffith University, an expert on child sexual abuse, told the commission.
He explained that there had been "serious problems" in the recruitment, screening, induction, training and supervision of staff.
The hearing was adjourned until 20 December.

Chinese newspaper to be "reformed" after appeal
A Chinese newspaper, which on its front page had demanded the release of a reporter accused of defamation, should be reformed, a press regulator said.

"The editorial management of Neuer Express was disorganized," the regulatory authority announced in a statement.
She said that it had been decided "to impose administrative punishment on Chen Yongzhou and withdraw his reporter's license.

Drug tunnel with its own railway between the USA and Mexico discovered
One of the most sophisticated tunnels for drug smuggling between the USA and Mexico, fully equipped with lighting, ventilation and electric railroad operation, has now been discovered.
The US authorities described the tunnel measuring 120 by 90 centimetres as one of the most sophisticated passages they had ever found.
The tunnel, which runs in a zigzag pattern over a length of almost six football fields, connects warehouses near Tijuana, Mexico, and San Diego, USA.
There are countless inconspicuous warehouses in the area, which makes it easier to hide trucks loaded with drugs.
The tunnel had been closed before drugs could be transported in it undetected, the authorities explained.
Eight and a half tons of marijuana and 148 kilograms of cocaine were seized when the tunnel was discovered, according to the court's records.
Three men, who according to the authorities worked as drivers, were charged with possession and intended sale of marijuana and cocaine.
If they are found guilty, they are threatened with prison sentences of between ten years and life.
In Nogales, Arizona, smugglers rely on an extensive underground network of drainage canals.
The tunnel is the eighth major passage discovered in San Diego since 2006.
Some of the largest tunnels were discovered after the marijuana harvest in central Mexico in October, posing a challenge to the drug cartels on how to get their product to the consumers quickly.
In 2010, authorities found a nearly 640-meter-long passage with rails that ran from a kitchen in an apartment building in Tijuana to two warehouses in San Diego.

According to encyclopedias, veganism is subordinated to vegetarianism, but differs from it in a very considerable way.
Because while vegetarians allow themselves the consumption of cream cake, ice cream or a hearty Edam, these gourmet treats are not on a vegan's menu.
Milk, cheese, egg, beside the renouncement of meat and fish the vegan abstains from all consumption of animal products - also honey is negated.
What remains, one may ask, but on closer inspection the vegan nutritional world is characterized by a considerable inventiveness.
"Spreads are very popular," explains Ute Henkelmann, the owner of the local health food store, which stocks a variety of special products for vegans.
Reuben Proctor also likes to visit the shop in Domgasse.
Since 13 years the native New Zealander lives vegan, in Lampertheim he finds (almost) everything he needs for life. "In 1997 I changed my diet and became a vegetarian".
At the turn of the century the next step was taken and I became a vegan.
"But the conviction came not only because of nutrition, but because of the choice of shoes," says Proctor, who prefers imitation leather to normal leather.
He realized that it is possible to do without animal products in other everyday matters as well.
First and foremost, being vegan is an ethic.
"I don't want animals to have to die for me," says Proctor, expressing the vegan maxim that applies to all consumer behavior.
Instead of mourning after burgers, scrambled eggs or jelly bears, the vegan quickly discovered completely new products and the enthusiasm grew.
"It's a double bonus," Proctor says today, "in fact, being vegan is not a renunciation, not asceticism, but an enrichment. Proctor attributes the assumption that a change in diet reduces the choice of food options to the power of habit.
And it was exactly this conditioning that caused many a well-meant attempt to fail.
"The addiction factor is a very decisive factor that makes many give up quickly, similar to smoking," Proctor makes a comparison.
And objects: "Certain tastes cannot be determined by the animal".
Often it is the spices or the way they are prepared that determine the taste.
"But you can also create the same effect in other ways," the vegan points out.
For example, Proctor brings aubergines, mushrooms and a few vegan sausages to a barbecue.
He pays attention to a balanced, varied diet, where it should also have a hearty taste.
Of course you want something between your teeth, that's legitimate.
"It should taste good, but this cannot be reduced to animal food alone," says Proctor.
He had not suffered any health problems, including eating disorders, another widespread assumption.
For me the changeover had a positive aspect.
I do not take in any foreign cholesterol and have an increased vitamin content.
There are high performance athletes who eat exclusively vegan food.
"My blood work's fine. I'm getting frequent checkups," Proctor says.
Many critics of vegansimus warn against vitamin B12 deficiency in particular.
"Since animals are fed on feed instead of grazing on pasture, it is questionable whether the vitamin B12 content of the meat you buy in the freezer is high," says Proctor.
Vegans can also take the coenzyme in the form of tablets.
"My B12 levels are fine," he explains.
Proctor did not have to go far to procure food.
After all, staple foods are everywhere and every supermarket now has soy milk and other products.
Everything I need I can find on the spot.
Just once in a while I buy something special.
"Many people overlook the fact that only the finished products are expensive, but as we all know, the same is true for "ordinary" finished products.
In any case, the preparation of vegan dishes is much cheaper and less time-consuming than generally assumed.
"There is a lot to discover in the home kitchen, with a few small tricks you can achieve good, if not partly better results," says Proctor.
Margarine instead of butter, a little more baking powder and carbon dioxide instead of egg, with his vegan cheesecakes Proctor was able to amaze even his in-laws.
Family celebrations gives the Veganer a new spice.
That has dynamics, when you cook together, it has a new significance.
"The situations that can arise are as different as the people themselves," says Proctor.
But of course he has also been met with scepticism.
Don't you like my food anymore?
"Am I supposed to feel bad about drinking milk now?" - with such questions one must act as Veganer with intuitive feeling.
"I do not reject people, I am part of this society," Proctor does not want to be an enclave.
And more exactly regarded the everyday life does not appear then at all so veganfremd as assumed - and the Veganer not so limited in the everyday life as generally accepted.
Fast food is also allowed.
You can get fries everywhere!
"Many kebab shops offer falafel, or even a vegetarian yufka," says Proctor.
In a pizzeria, he avoids pasta dishes or orders a pizza without cheese, all a question of habit.
The restaurants are slowly adjusting to it.
"When I started to eat vegan food 13 years ago, everything was much more difficult", the New Zealander can trace a development: "You have to talk to people, make them aware of it".
"If there is enough demand, they might be inclined to add to the menu," he hopes.
Vegan restaurants are developing, such as the galley in Mannheim or the Café Vogelfrei.
Proctor hopes that other restaurants will have at least one vegan dish on the menu.
Basically, vegan food is for everyone.
Anyone can eat them, so they are exactly the opposite of exclusive.
"Meat dishes, on the other hand, are exclusive, in the truest sense of the word, because they exclude others," Proctor notes.
"If you want to avoid food scandals, then veganism is a sure way to make the vast majority impossible from the outset," says Proctor.
The purchase of vegan products can be somewhat difficult at the beginning.
Especially when one learns to understand that peanuts can also contain animal additives as colouring agents, it seems that by following the ethics of so many hurdles and traps one quickly loses heart.
This is not the only reason why Reuben Proctor and Lars Thomsen have written a book: "Veganissimo - Animal Ingredients and their Alternatives" explains the many ingredients that are added to food and cleaning products.
"Little by little, you develop a scanner eye and know which signs and logos to look out for "Sometimes it's better to take small steps than to stop or stumble," Proctor knows.
Veganism, it is an important moral cue that strikes at consciousness.
He may not quite manage to get rid of his habits, but at least he can teach the consumer to critically question his habits.

Tax for foreign property owners against London's speculative bubble
The Treasury has provisionally calculated the CGT measure, but is still waiting for the final decision from Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne, who in the 2012 budget imposed a stamp duty of 7% on homes costing over £2 million, as well as annual fees for buyers who hold homes as a company rather than individuals.

Scientists have been able to shed more light on how the tail wagging of a dog relates to its mood.
Earlier research had shown that happy dogs wagged their tails more to the right (from the dog's point of view), whereas in nervous dogs it was the left side.
But now scientists say that other dogs can perceive these subtle differences and react to them.
Professor Georgio Vallortigara, a neuroscientist from the University of Trento, said: "In humans it is well known that the left and right hemispheres of the brain respond differently to stimuli that evoke positive or negative emotions.
Here we have tried to look at this in other species.
He also noted that in dogs, just like in humans, the right hemisphere of the brain is responsible for the movement of the left side and vice versa, and that the two hemispheres play different roles in the emotions.
To learn more about how dogs react to the lateral tail wagging of their conspecifics, the researchers monitored the animals while watching these films of other dogs.
They measured the heart rate of the four-legged friends and analysed their behaviour.
Probably we will soon understand why the tail moves sometimes in one direction, sometimes in the other
Professor Vallortigara said: "We showed the dogs films with dogs - either a lifelike version or a silhouette to eliminate other distracting aspects, and we were able to control the movement of the tail more to the left or right".
When the animals saw an otherwise expressionless dog move its tail to the right (seen from the perspective of the wagging dog), they remained completely relaxed.
But if the tail was mainly tilted to the left (again from the perspective of the dog wagging), their heart rate increased and they looked restless.
According to Professor Vallortigara, the dogs do not intentionally communicate with each other through these movements.
Rather, he is convinced that the dogs would have learned from experience which movements to worry about and when not to worry.
He said: "If you have different encounters with other dogs and the wagging of the tail in one direction is more associated with friendly behaviour and the right side produces less friendly behaviour, then you react on the basis of these experiences.
The researchers say the findings could help dog owners, veterinarians and trainers to better understand the emotions of their pet.
John Bradshaw, expert on dog behaviour and visiting fellow at the Faculty of Veterinary Science, University of Bristol, explained that this was not the first study to examine whether left and right are important for dogs.
Last year, a team from the University of Lincoln found that dogs turn their heads to the left when looking at an aggressive dog and to the right when looking at a happy dog.
In another research paper at the University of Victoria in Canada, it was stated that "Dogs are more likely to approach a robot dog when its 'tail' is wagging on the left rather than on the right, rather than becoming restless - the exact opposite of the Italian study.
According to him, the differences could be due to the fact that the dogs in the various studies did not interpret the animals in the films or the robot dogs as dogs.
A study of how dogs react to real dogs could help, he explained.
"While there is considerable evidence in many different mammals that the two hemispheres of the brain are used for different purposes, many of the details have yet to be determined - and dogs are no exception," Bradshaw said.
But since their behaviour can be easily recorded, it will probably not be long before we understand why the tail sometimes moves in one direction and sometimes in the other.
