Pope Francis appoints first cardinals in February
Pope Francis will appoint new Cardinals of the Catholic Church for the first time on 22 February, the Vatican announced on Thursday.
Cardinals are the highest ranking clerics in the Catholic Church after the Pope, and it is they who elect a Pope, so Francis will thus appoint the first group of men who will eventually participate in the election of his successor.
There are currently 201 cardinals.
However, a Cardinal who has reached the age of 80 can no longer take part in the election of the Pope - this falls to a group of 120 "Cardinal electors".
In a statement announcing the news, Father Federico Lombardi, a spokesman for the Vatican, said that a meeting of all the Cardinals would take place before the ceremony for the appointment of the new Cardinals, also known as the Consistory.
"Pope Francis has decided to announce in advance his decision to convene the Consistory in February so that other meetings requiring the participation of Cardinals from all over the world can be planned," said Lombardi.
Jack Valero of Catholic Voices said that the number of Cardinals eligible to vote would probably have fallen by February.
He explained that a Pope normally appoints as many Cardinals as necessary, so that the number of Cardinals eligible to vote would again be 120, and as many Cardinals over 80 as he wishes.
The Consistory next year is important because it will be the first since the election of Francis in March this year, Valero said.
There is currently a certain overhang on the part of Europe and especially Italy.
"It will be interesting to see if the new pope will appoint cardinals from the rest of the world to restore the balance," he said.
Forty percent of Catholics live in South America, but they have only a tiny number of cardinals.
The Cardinals will also be the first to be called, since the formation of the Council of Cardinals founded by Francis, a group of eight Cardinals from around the world charged with finding ways to reform the Church.
In the past, the pope decided everything alone.
"Now Francis has chosen these eight cardinals to help him," said Valero.
He explained that it was "quite possible" that Francis would ask the Cardinals for advice.
But so far we have not been in this situation - this is all completely new.
Valero said that typically bishops from large cities are called to be cardinals, but Francis was "full of surprises - so we do not know who he appoints".
GM recalls new pickup trucks in the USA for seat back repair
General Motors is recalling nearly 19,000 of its brand new 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra pickup trucks to fix a problem with the manually adjustable seat back, according to a statement released Friday by the U.S. Vehicle Safety Regulatory Commission.
On some of the cars there may be a defect in the mechanism for resetting the front seat back.
For this reason, they do not comply with the federal guidelines for vehicle safety in headrests.
"If the vehicle is hit from behind, it is possible that the head restraint will not protect the occupants properly, increasing the risk of injury," the message said on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) website.
The recalled models were produced between 1 August and 10 September.
The delivery of GM trucks began in June and represents the most important model launch of the leading US car manufacturer since the insolvency-related restructuring in 2009.
GM informed vehicle owners about the defect in the first half of October.
The NHTSA was unable to review the notification letter because of the 16-day government shutdown, which had a negative impact on car sales in October.
Sales of the Silverado and Sierra trucks, newly developed for the 2014 model year, rose by 20 percent in the first ten months of the year, GM said on Friday.
In October GM sold 42,660 Silverado and 16,503 Sierra pickup trucks.
GM shares rose 1.4 percent on the New York Stock Exchange to $37.47 on Friday afternoon.
Cry of despair from an Obama voter
I elected President Obama twice in the hope that change was possible
He says Obama has made laudable efforts that have been thwarted by the Republicans' blockade tactics
The blockade policy does not excuse the website problems of Obamacare, the drone attacks
Obama's memoirs about the 2008 election campaign are a sad reminder of what could have been possible
Nathaniel P. Morris is a second-year student at Harvard Medical School.
I'm currently reading a terribly sad book.
It is a book that I thought would cheer me up during the gloomy second year of my medical studies and give me hope again.
It is called "The Audacity to Win" and describes the memoirs of Barack Obama on the 2008 presidential election.
When I finish my patient transcripts in the evening and go to bed, the book takes me back to a time when politics inspired millions and took the breath away from talking.
The election turned into a landslide victory and newsreaders paused to remind us of the historical significance of this hour.
My classmates cried with joy and my parents collected all the newspapers they could find.
A young team of visionaries was on its way to the White House and the nation was ready for change.
When Obama took office in 2008, he had approval ratings of 82%.
And then I close the book.
Switching back to the present is a rude awakening, as if you are being ripped out of a dream.
It is difficult to remember these optimistic times - they seem to be a vague memory, a sad reminder of missed opportunities.
In the years since I first cast my vote, something has indeed changed.
But it's just not something I could have imagined.
I recognize the great and varied things that Obama has achieved, from the passage of the Affordable Care Act for health insurance to the military withdrawal from Iraq, the end of the forced concealment of homosexuality in the army and the killing of Osama bin Laden.
I, too, believe that party-political blockade tactics have overturned too many efforts to move our nation forward: immigration reform, a public option for health insurance, and the closure of Guantanamo Bay, to name a few.
But after defending the Obama administration countless times against colleagues and acquaintances, I have come to the end of my attempts at explanation.
I have reached a point of political despair.
The Republican blockade policy cannot explain why foreign heads of state are allowed to wiretap or the killing of innocent children by drones overseas.
It cannot explain why the National Security Agency collects data on the private lives of Americans and why whistleblowers who disclose government misconduct are punished.
It cannot explain why Anwar al-Awlaki, a US citizen, was assassinated without trial, nor why public funding and spending limits were circumvented during the presidential election.
It does not justify the findings of a report that says the White House's efforts to silence the media are the "most aggressive ... since the Nixon administration".
And most recently, it cannot excuse the inability to create a simple website in the more than three years since the adoption of the Affordable Care Act.
I don't know if this is what I should have expected.
Whether, at 18, I should have understood that the work of government could contradict the political campaigns that preceded it.
Obviously, the office of deputy is not a predictable course, as an opposition party and random events like the Newtown massacre shape the public discussion.
But when I look at the above examples, they seem to be largely elected by the government itself.
And that's what bothers me the most.
I voted for Obama again in 2012, not because I was excited about his candidacy.
Mitt Romney presented a confusing and half-baked alternative, he seemed unable to define his direction and positions.
I had the impression that a second term for Obama, free from the pressure of future elections, would fulfill the hope we had heard about for so long.
But with the approval ratings for Obama falling below 45% this week, this book has made the return to 2008 all the harder.
It awakens in me a longing for the many promises that have vanished into thin air.
This week I read a section in the book that describes how Obama suffered a heavy loss against Clinton in the Pennsylvania primaries.
In a meeting with the election workers after the decision, he told his staff that they had to get back on track and follow the purpose of their cause.
"I want us to find our magic again," he said.
We need to remember who we are.
It's five years later, Mr President, and I couldn't agree with you more.
The views expressed in this Commentary are solely those of Nathaniel Morris.

Two months after the election, the Electoral Commission officially declared Palmer the winner of Fairfax's Sunshine Coast seat by a 53 vote lead after the recount.
Palmer called for a revision of the vote-counting process to speed it up.

Why shouldn't we have a system where you walk in, enter the data into a computer, dial immediately and have the result at 6:30 in the evening?
Palmer also criticized the use of pencils to mark the ballots.

To vote with pencils these days is unbelievable.

Palmer, 59, said his policy included an international airport for the Sunshine Coast and that he would take his new position "very seriously".
A public office is about serving the public.

RBS suspends two currency traders
The Royal Bank of Scotland has suspended two traders from its foreign exchange department, according to two people who are familiar with the situation; this is a further indication that the global regulatory investigation into the suspected manipulation of the currency market is rapidly gathering momentum.
Some of the world's largest banks, including UBS, Barclays, Deutsche Bank and RBS, have confirmed that they are cooperating with the authorities in the investigation of the world's largest financial market, where $5.3 trillion changes hands daily.
The two traders would be the first RBS employees to be suspended in the expanding investigation that the Libor interbank scandal is causing.
The bank, which did not comment on the suspensions, confirmed this month that it had received requests for information from authorities.
"Our investigation on this issue continues and we are cooperating fully with the FCA and other regulators," the bank said two weeks ago.
Last month, people close to the situation stated that RBS had passed on to the UK regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority, the records of emails and instant messages sent by and to a previous merchant.
This trader, Richard Usher, left RBS in 2010 and is reported to have been relieved of his current position as European Head of Forex Spot Trading at JPMorgan.
Rohan Ramchandani, head of European spot trading at Citi, was suspended this week and Matt Gardiner, formerly senior currency trader at Barclays and UBS, was suspended this week at Standard Chartered.
None of these dealers was accused of any misconduct.
Usher's instant message group included bankers at Barclays and Citigroup, said people close to the situation.
UBS announced this week that it had taken steps against some of its employees after the Swiss regulator Finma announced that it was investigating suspected manipulation of the foreign exchange market at a number of Swiss banks.
At least six authorities worldwide - the European Commission, Finma, the Swiss Competition Commission, the FCA, the US Department of Justice and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority - are currently investigating allegations that bankers have colluded in currency market transactions.
HSBC, Citigroup, JPMorgan and Credit Suisse have also initiated internal investigations or received requests for information from authorities, said people familiar with the situation.
Banks scour instant messages and e-mails from several years in search of cases of misconduct.
The news of this research has sent traders into turmoil in an area that has been one of the most profitable of investment banks' trading units in recent years, but has been under pressure this year as low currency volatility limits the opportunities for speculators.
Some bankers have tried to play down the affair, saying that it is almost impossible to manipulate the vast and highly liquid foreign exchange market, but leading traders believe that this is not necessarily true.
One leading trader noted that despite the enormous daily volume of foreign exchange trading, the fragmentation of liquidity between the various trading platforms and the increasing use of banks' own internal platforms means that "you can influence the market with very low ticket prices".
The news came out the same day that Credit Suisse announced that it had terminated a trader in its London Exchange Traded Funds office this week after he caused a loss of nearly six million dollars at the end of last year.
The Bank promptly informed the relevant authorities and cooperated with them.
"We are certain that the trader acted alone and that the matter has been contained," Credit Suisse said.

Supreme Court confirms Obama's health care bill
It is a great victory for the Obama administration: the US Supreme Court ruled today that the health care bill, which is closely linked to Barack Obama, is constitutional.
The judges ruled by five to four votes that the individual mandate of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act - which forces US citizens to take out health insurance or pay a fine until 2014 - is constitutional under the state's fiscal authority.
The Chief Justice John Roberts sided with the four more liberal members of the Chamber, while the Judges Scalia, Thomas, Alito and Kennedy decided against.
The court also upheld the remaining sections of the 2,700-page law, and held that the requirement in the Health Care Act that states must either expand Medicaid eligibility or otherwise eliminate all state Medicaid funding was not unconstitutionally restrictive.
The lawsuit against the law had been filed by 26 states and the National Federation of Independent Business.
The bill had been decisively rejected by all leading Republican presidential candidates, including eventual challenger Mitt Romney, in the 2012 pre-election campaign.
Norway: Norwegian place makes itself with giant mirrors light
With huge mirrors the inhabitants of a Norwegian village have brought light into their dark valley.
Because of the low sunshine, Rjukan, which is located in the Vestfjord valley, normally sinks in the shade of the surrounding mountains from autumn to spring.
With three gigantic reflectors at a height of 45 metres, a dream of the century came true on Wednesday.
"Finally!", enthused Mayor Steinar Bergsland at the launch ceremony on TV2.
Some of the inhabitants of the valley put on sun chairs, others put on sunglasses to be on the safe side.
Until now, sun-seekers had to take a cable car to a nearby summit in winter.
Ten years ago, local artist Martin Andersen presented a proposal to direct the rays into the valley with mirrors.
But this basic idea had already existed in the village since 1913.
After several years of debate, the city council had finally approved the project, which cost 5 million crowns (around 615,000 euros).
A similar construction has been providing winter sunshine to the Italian Alpine resort of Viganella for several years.

He thanked those present for their willingness to cooperate and stressed that the Care Day was a suitable instrument for strengthening the connection between man and nature.

Friederike Tribukait from the Department of Nature Conservation of the Freiburg Regional Council explained this ecological aspect following the welcoming address by District Administrator Tilman Bollacher, who had assumed patronage and wished the campaign every success.
According to Tribukait, the tourist destination of the vision coincides with the aim of preserving the now heavily overgrown old Allmend pasture field with its specific protected habitat types by opening and connecting it to the still existing pastures.
Certain species such as rare butterflies and grasshoppers are unable to overcome barriers in the form of forest areas.
They need these free connections for the preservation of the species.
Tribukait said that she did not want to miss the opportunity to take up the cudgels for the planned biosphere area.
The current measure not only fits seamlessly into this planning.
A biosphere reserve also offers the opportunity for sustainable economic and ecological development on the basis of the internationally recognised Unesco status and thus a continuous addition to what has been achieved with the Life Project and the previous Care Days for the future.

A group of helpers should take care of clearing juniper bushes and maintaining a dry stone bar.

Google, Samsung, Huawei sued over Nortel patents
The group, which owns thousands of previous Nortel patents, launched an avalanche of patent infringement lawsuits against mobile phone manufacturers on Thursday, including Google, the company it outbid in Nortel's bankruptcy auction.
Rockstar, the consortium that bought the Nortel patents for $4.5 billion, sued Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, HTC Corp, Huawei and four other companies for patent infringement in the US District Court in Texas.
Rockstar is jointly owned by Apple, Microsoft, BlackBerry, Ericsson and Sony.
Google is accused of patent infringement in seven cases.
The patents relate to technology that matches search terms on the Internet with relevant advertising, according to the lawsuit, which goes to the heart of Google's search engine business.
Representatives from Samsung, Huawei, HTC and Rockstar were not directly available.
Samsung, Huawei and HTC make mobile phones that work with Google's Android operating system, which competes fiercely with the mobile products of Apple and Microsoft.
In 2011, Google made an initial bid of 900 million dollars for the Nortel patents.
Google increased its offer several times and most recently offered 4.4 billion US dollars.
After being outbid on Rockstar's Nortel patents, Google acquired Motorola Mobility for $12.5 billion, a deal that was also partly motivated by Motorola's library of patents.
"Although Google failed in its attempt to acquire the patents at the auction, Google has infringed the patents and continues to do so," the complaint states.
Rockstar is demanding high damages from Google, claiming that Google's patent infringement was intentional, the accusation said.
Egypt first freely elected president sworn in
Mohammed Mursi takes the oath of office, but his day of triumph is unlikely to mark the end of political disputes in Egypt.
The Islamist Mohammed Mursi promised a "new Egypt" when he was sworn in as the first freely elected president of the country, succeeding Husni Mubarak, who had been expelled from office 16 months earlier.
His inauguration at the Supreme Constitutional Court also made Mursi the first freely elected Islamist president in the Arab world and Egypt's fifth head of state since the fall of the monarchy some 60 years ago.
He took the oath before the 18 judges dressed in black robes of the court, which has its seat on the Nile and is modelled on an ancient Egyptian temple.
"We are striving for a better future, a new Egypt and a second republic," said Mursi at the ceremony, which was broadcast live on state television.
"Today, the Egyptian people have laid the foundations for a new life - absolute freedom, true democracy and stability," said 60-year-old Mursi, a US-trained engineer and member of the Muslim Brotherhood, a fundamentalist group that since its inception 84 years ago had been targeted by the respective governments, mostly as a banned organization.
Hundreds of soldiers and policemen were guarding the building when Mursi arrived in a small car convoy shortly after eleven o'clock local time.
Only a few hundred supporters had gathered in front of the court to cheer on the new president, and unlike the presidential pageantry of the Mubarak era, traffic was stopped only briefly so that the car convoy could cross the usually busy road connecting the city centre with the southern suburbs.
Mocked as the uncharismatic "spare wheel" of the Brotherhood, his personal prestige has increased since his victory and a Friday speech in which he presented himself not only as the candidate of the Islamists but of all those who wanted to bring the aspirations of the 2011 uprising against the authoritarian Mubarak to fruition.
"Egypt today is a civil, national, constitutional and modern state," Mursi, dressed in a blue suit and red tie, told the judges in the wood-panelled chamber where he took the oath of office.
Later Mursi went to Cairo University where he was to give his inaugural address.
He was officially greeted by an army band playing the national anthem, which he listened to in the watch position.
The military leader Field Marshal Hussein Tantawi was present.
Upon his arrival, he was greeted by hundreds of people in the largest lecture hall of the university with chants of "The army and the people are one hand".
The University of Cairo, built in 1908 as a bastion of secular education, developed into a stronghold of Islamist student groups in the 1970s.
Mursi took a symbolic oath on Friday in Tahir Square, the birthplace of the uprising that led to the end of Mubarak's authoritarian rule last year, and vowed to reclaim presidential powers that the military council had taken over from the outlawed head of state.
But by taking the official oath before the court and not, as usual, before parliament, he is bowing to the will of the military, which indicates that the power struggle will continue.
Mursi's speech in Tahir Square was full of dramatic populist gestures.

You thought travel agencies were a thing of the past thanks to the Internet?
Flight Centre seems to be bucking the trend.
The company has raised its profit outlook for the full year and expects record holidaymaker revenues in Australia and the UK.
The travel company now expects an adjusted annual profit before taxes of between $325 and $340 million, compared to $305 to $315 million in its previous forecast.
If the current targets are met, this will mean growth of 12 to 17 percent compared to the record profit of $290.4 million in 2011/12.
Managing Director Graham Turner announced that Flight Centre achieved an eight per cent profit in the first half of the year and had a strong start to the second half, particularly in the Australian and UK private business.
"Our ten countries have been profitable since the beginning of the year and some of them are well on the way to record annual revenues before interest and taxes," he said.
These include Australia and the UK, which are typically among our strongest earnings drivers.
In Australia, the leisure industry recovered in the second half of the year, which compensated for a slightly weaker market for business travel.
The leisure business of Flight Centre in the UK performed similarly well, while business customers also spent less.
The US business recovered from the seasonally weaker first half of the year, so that a profit for the full year is expected for the third year in succession.
Flight Centre shares rose 3 cents yesterday to $38.20.
Schools are encouraged to focus more on mathematics, spelling and grammar
In future, in courses on English literature, pupils will have to deal with at least one play by Shakespeare, a 19th century novel, romantic poetry and contemporary British novels from 1914 onwards.
The exam also includes "unseen texts" to encourage wider reading.
The combined course of English literature and language is abolished.
From 2015, students must take a separate GCSE exam for language, with strong incentives to choose English literature as a separate qualification.
Tomorrow the Ministry of Education will publish the new curricula for English and mathematics - the first subjects to be radically redesigned.
Other core subjects will be changed next year.
In a separate initiative, Ofqual, the Examinations Inspectorate, will announce a reorganisation of GCSE structures, including a new grading system and less coursework.
In a speech this summer, Education Minister Michael Gove said there was a "broad consensus that we need to reform our examination system to restore public confidence", stressing that the GCSEs would become "more challenging, ambitious and rigorous".
Studies show that less time is spent on mathematics in English schools - 116 hours per year or three hours per week per school year - than in most other countries.
In contrast, Australian schools teach an average of 143 hours per year and students in Singapore receive 138 hours.
While there will be no formal requirement to include more time for maths in the curriculum, coalition sources say that the comprehensive maths exam - combined with a greater weighting of the subject in rankings - will probably encourage schools to add more lessons.
In the curriculum more attention is paid to "real life problems", including financial mathematics.

Salem: Johanna Rahner at the Ecumenical Discussion Forum
The next Ecumenical Discussion Forum on Monday 21 October in the New Museum of the Castle will focus on the theme "To Hell with Hell - Theological reflections on how to deal with the last things today".
The speaker is Professor Johanna Rahner.
The Ecumenical Discussion Forum is an initiative of the Catholic and Protestant parishes of Salem, Salem Castle and the Lake Constance District Cultural Office.
In the forum Johanna Rahner wants to pursue the question of how people today classify the "last things" after death.
If people in past centuries had known too much about this and had relied on those images of heaven and hell "that still shape our ideas today", contemporary prophetic teaching about the hopes for perfection would be characterized rather by a certain embarrassment or even speechlessness.
"The greater hope has been duly driven out of Christians by criticism of religion," says the speaker.
She had "provided us with so many question marks that we seem to have lost the exclamation points".
Johanna Rahner continues: "But the decisive challenge remains the annoyance of death".
Connected with this is the question of that longing "which dreams of everything being good in the end".
Johanna Rahner, born in Baden-Baden in 1962, studied Catholic theology and biology at the Albert-Ludwigs-University of Freiburg from 1982 to 1989.
She received her doctorate in 1997, also in Freiburg.
The habilitation for fundamental theology and ecumenical theology followed in 2003 at the Westphalian Wilhelms University.
Since 2010 Johanna Rahner has held a chair for systematic theology at the Institute for Catholic Theology at the University of Kassel.

On the way through mud, rivers and jungle for free medical care
Dr. Georges Bwelle brings free medical aid to remote villages in Cameroon
Bwelle and his team spend almost every weekend treating hundreds of patients
There are not many doctors in this West African country, only one for every 5,000 people
Vote here or with your mobile device
Dr. Georges Bwelle is one of the top 10 "CNN Heroes of 2013".
You can vote for him or one of the other heroes in the Top 10 to vote for him as "CNN Hero of the Year".
The winner will receive 250,000 dollars to continue his extraordinary work.
For 21 years, Georges Bwelle watched as his sick father repeatedly lost consciousness and traveled to hospitals that did not have the means to help him.
Jamef Bwelle was injured in 1981 in a car accident near Yaoundé, the capital of Cameroon.
At first, he only had a broken arm, but then an inflammation formed that spread to his brain and caused a hematoma that would affect him for the rest of his life.
"There were no neurosurgeons in Cameroon," says Georges Bwelle.
We would have taken him out of Cameroon if we had the money.
Instead, Bwelle spent years accompanying his father to crowded clinics and hospitals to get the treatment they had to offer.
"It is not easy," comments Bwelle.
You can leave the house at five o'clock in the morning and run to the hospital to be first, and yet you are not first.
There are a lot of patients.
Some people even die because they have to wait.
The situation has hardly changed since Belle's father died in 2002.
According to the World Health Organization, there is only one doctor for every 5,000 people in Cameroon.
In contrast, the ratio in the United States is one doctor for 413 people.
But even if there were a doctor for them, most of the Cameroonians could not afford the visit.
Two out of five people in the country live below the poverty line and almost three-quarters of health care spending in the country is private.
"The only problem they have is poverty," says Bwelle.
And poverty makes it impossible to enjoy life.
Seeing his father and so many of his countrymen suffer made Bwelle decide to do something about it.
Dr. Georges Bwelle and his team of volunteers performed 700 free operations last year.
He became a doctor himself and works as a vascular surgeon at the Central Hospital in Yaoundé.
He also founded a non-profit organization called ASCOVIME, which travels to rural areas on weekends and provides free medical care.
Since 2008, he and his volunteer group have helped nearly 32,000 people.
Almost every Friday, he and up to 30 people squeeze into minibuses and drive with the tied up medical equipment on the roof over unpaved terrain to the villages in need of help.
Not everything always runs smoothly.
More than once they had to push the vehicles through rivers and mud.
But when they arrive, they are welcomed like heroes: a feast, singing and dancing and the best accommodation the place has to offer.
In these villages, free medical care is really a reason to celebrate and Bwelle - with his broad smile and boundless energy - likes to be part of the cheerful celebration.
The next morning, the team then begins examining hundreds of patients.
"We treat 500 people per trip," says Bwelle.
They come from within a radius of 60 kilometres around the village - and they do so on foot.
Each of these weekend clinics offers medical care in a number of areas.
Many people are treated for malaria, tuberculosis, malnutrition, diabetes, parasites and sexually transmitted diseases.
Others receive crutches, donated eyeglasses or free birth certificates - a document that is required for school, but which many poor families simply cannot afford.
In the evening, the team performs simple operations with local anesthesia.
The operations are usually performed in a school, town hall or an apartment; after the operation, patients get up and go to the recovery area to make room for the next person.
The lighting for the operating theatre and the disinfection equipment is powered by the group's generator and so Bwelle and his volunteers work until the early hours of Sunday morning.
It's an exhausting workload, but the village musicians usually help to keep the team motivated.
"They drum all night so that we can stay awake and continue our work," says Bwelle.
On Sunday, the team will return to the city, tired but proud of the work they have done.
The group - a mixture of Cameroonian doctors and foreign medical students - performed 700 free operations last year and knows that its work makes a huge difference to the people it helps.
One man explained that the free surgery for a hernia that he had received now enabled him to work again.
"This changes the future of my family," the man said.
In addition to weekend clinics and his work as a surgeon at the hospital, Bwelle also works at night in private clinics in Yaoundé.
With this second job, Bwelle said, he is financing 60 % of his charitable work; the rest comes from private donations.
"I really don't know when he's sleeping," says Katie O'Malley, a second-year medical student at Drexel University in Philadelphia and a volunteer in Belle's group.
He is always either in hospital or trying to raise money for the organization so that he can go on these campaigns.
For medical and nursing students like O'Malley, who come from the USA and Europe and support Bwelle, this is a chance to gain practical experience that they would never get at home.
"We can scrub in on surgeries where we help draw blood or hold the instruments for Dr. Belle," O'Malley explains.
That would never be possible in America as a second-year medical student.
The students usually pay for their trip to Cameroon themselves and often bring donated medical supplies with them.
But once they are in Yaoundé, Bwelle takes care of the accommodation, transport and instruction.
"He's a hero without a doubt," O'Malley says.
He dedicates his life to this organization and his desire to help the Cameroonian people knows no bounds.
For Bwelle, the almost constant work is not a burden.
Helping others to a happier life and thus fulfilling a promise he made to his father gives him great joy.
"I'm so happy when I do this work," says Bwelle.
And I think about my father.
I hope he sees what I'm doing.
I do it to make people laugh again and to ease the pain.
Visit the ASCOVIME website and find out how you can help.
Mastered the battle excellently
The role of Santiago, the old man in Hemingway's novella "The Old Man and the Sea", is tailor-made for Horst Janson.
Janson himself is an old hand in his profession, the art of acting.
No one can fool old Santiago when he's fishing.
So the two complement each other just great.
You almost think you can see the wrinkles on the old man's neck that Manolo, the fishing boy, talks about.
When Santiago sits on the chair, tired and bent over by life, Janson is real.
In addition, the role of the old fisherman is through and through a character role that Janson masters excellently.
Hemingway told the story of a fighter, a brave man who does not give up and finally wins the fight against the fish through his knowledge and also his willpower.
Janson is on stage for long stretches as a solo actor.
He manages to focus the audience's attention on himself, so that his monologues are never boring for a moment.
His efforts to finally pull the fish to the surface of the water are so real that the audience forgets that the sea consists only of blue illuminated water bottles.
Director Jens Hasselmann lets the old man act in the boat in front of the fishing village.
In the course of the performance he puts the active scene in the light: the hut of Santiago, the bar of the singer Marie-Luise Gunst, who sings about the Cuban way of life with her songs and her wonderful voice.
The four musicians play Cuba's rhythm to it and are also guests of the bar.
Tourism: Descent to the Romans
On a length of about 120 meters below Cologne, a sewer from the Roman era has been preserved.
Anyone who visits Cologne cannot get past the cathedral.
The two towers rise some 157 metres into the sky, making it the second highest church building in Europe.
But only a few visitors, who marvel at the two filigree church towers, suspect that there is also a lot to discover under the cathedral.
Rainer Schulze is an expert on the Cologne underworld.
The meeting point for his guided tours is the service centre of Cologne Tourism directly at the cathedral.
The tour begins quite unspectacularly: "We start in the underground car park," says Schulze.
In the seventies, the city fathers wanted a car-friendly city, and therefore only what was not too big remained of the remains of the old city wall.
Most users of the car park today therefore hurry past the Roman remains and only park their car.
But if you take a closer look, you will discover an archaeological site separated by metal bars on parking deck D2.
You can see ruins of palm-sized stones, about five meters high.
"They are remains of the Roman city wall, which was built in the second half of the first century AD," says Schulze.
Before returning to daylight, Schulze lets the participants on the upper parking level take a look into a dark, 15-metre deep shaft.
This is the fountain of the old cathedral, which unfortunately is hardly noticed.
The next station of the tour is the Praetorium, and here the participants descend again into the depths.
Here we experience the official residence of the once most powerful man north of the Alps, the praetor of the CCAA.
A visitor would like to know what CCAA means.
"The abbreviation stands for "Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium", which in good German means "city under Roman law and city of the Agrippineses, founded under Emperor Claudius at the place of the altar for the imperial cult".
And the Praetorium is the former governor's palace, the power centre of the Roman Empire on the Rhine.
From the anteroom of the exhibition a tunnel access leads to the Roman sewer, which is preserved here over a length of about 120 metres.
"You can walk along the so-called Cloaca Maxima if you like", Schulze cheered up the guests.
Schultz still has one surprise left.
After getting the key at the cash desk, he leads the group to a 16-meter deep, accessible shaft.
"We are now in the Mikvah, a ritual Jewish bath," he explains.
The Jewish community built their baths deep into the ground in order to get to the groundwater that was essential for the ritual ablutions.
To this day, different water levels can be read in the lower end of the mikvah, whose origins date back to the eighth century, due to changing levels of the Rhine.
The mikvah will become part of an archaeological zone in the town hall square, for which construction work is due to begin shortly.
However, it will still take several years until completion.
Leg almost chopped off: New edition of Rocker Process
A bloody attack in the rocker milieu is being rolled up again after over four years.
A trial for attempted manslaughter, dangerous bodily injury and damage to property against two 30-year-olds has begun at the Regional Court in Frankfurt (Oder).
It is accompanied by strict security measures.
The defendants were silent at the outset.
They are said to have been active in the rocker scene and to have belonged to the bandidos at that time.
The public prosecutor accuses them of having stabbed and beaten up three men in a car in Finowfurt in June 2009 together with unknown accomplices.
All victims were seriously injured, one man almost lost his leg.
The victims are said to have belonged to the competing group Hells Angels.
One is said to have been a high-ranking member from Berlin.
Apparently a chase with several cars had preceded it.
According to the prosecution, it was about turf wars and a show of force.
The two defendants had been acquitted in a first trial in early 2012.
A court spokesman said at the time that it could not be proven that the men had actually been involved in the bloody feud.
The perpetrators had worn masks and had not been recognized.
The Federal Supreme Court overturned the verdict after the public prosecutor's office had appealed and referred the case back to the Regional Court for retrial.
One of the defendants is currently in open execution for another crime.
At the beginning, the main focus was on the reconstruction of the events on the night of the crime.
The inspector investigating at the time was called as a witness.
The focus was on mobile phone conversations of the defendants and other persons whom the police had tapped.
What is difficult is that rockers almost always abide by a law that is ironclad for them in court - and do not testify.
This also applies to the victims.
In the first trial, only one of the victims had unpacked.
Public prosecutor Stefan Golfier of the public prosecutor's office in Frankfurt (Oder) said when asked that new leads had emerged since the last trial.
Eleven more trial days have been scheduled for the trial.
The throwaway society does not think
The night was long, the music was loud and the mood was good, but at some point we went home.
The only thing is that hunger is noticeable in the bellies of the people in the passenger and back seats.
Sure, one or the other cocktail or champagne may be responsible for this!
What could be more obvious than to drive to the next drive-in to treat yourself to a little something?
I admit, I like to be there when it comes to fetching fast food late at night or early in the morning.
A few fries, a coke, a burger - and then it's off home and to bed!
But on the way home, the obvious differences between me and other hungry disco goers become apparent.
After all, what must be missing that you throw your fast food bags out of the car window with constant regularity?
Especially at the weekends, discarded paper bags are lying at the side of the road and in parking lots.
"Why?" I ask myself.
Are the people too stupid to take the bags home or to the next trash can?
It's not just that the paper stuff spoils the landscape.
Bags have also covered up traffic facilities such as crash barriers and caused accidents.
But the "throwaway society" in question does not think about such things, probably it does not even know what this word actually means.
If you're out and about in the evening, especially with several people in the car, you know what a back seat can look like after a night of partying: Clothes, bottles and other rubbish are piling up there.
A few bags more or less wouldn't make any difference - in contrast to the street, where nobody wants to trample on the leftovers of others.
I can already see the day coming when the cities and communities will be too stupid to clear away - and the fast food chains will have to demand a deposit for their bags.

In an unprecedented admission, John Kerry declares that US espionage has "gone unreasonably far"
John Kerry, with an unexpected admission, hinted at a softening of the defensive stance of the US with regard to its surveillance programmes, saying that in certain cases espionage had gone "unreasonably far".
The Secretary of State also admitted that he and Barack Obama were jointly responsible for switching to "autopilot" when the explosive revelations by whistleblower Edward Snowden about the NSA's espionage activities became public.
The leaked information has plunged the US government into a diplomatic storm of indignation from its allies.
Speaking at the Open Governments Conference in London on a video link, Kerry said: "There is no question that the President and I and others in government have learned of some things that have gone virtually on autopilot simply because of the ability to do so, which goes back to the Second World War and the difficult years of the Cold War and, of course, to 9/11.
He then became the first high-ranking member of the US government to admit that US espionage had crossed a line, but also stressed that no rights had been abused.
He said, "In some cases, this has gone unreasonably far."
The President is determined to provide clarity and is therefore conducting a thorough investigation so that no one need feel that there is abuse going on.
I assure you that the rights of innocent people will not be affected in this trial.
Kerry insisted, however, that NSA was a force for good and that many lives had been saved through their surveillance operations.
He added: "We are dealing with a new world where people are ready to blow themselves up."
There is a radical extremism in the world that is bent on killing people, blowing up and attacking governments.
So what if you were able to intercept it and stop it before it happened?
We have indeed prevented airplane crashes, attacks on buildings and the murder of people because we learned of such plans in advance.
Meanwhile, US lawmakers will travel to Europe to dispel concerns about alleged American espionage and convince Europeans of the need to continue to cooperate with the US in the anti-terrorism effort, the chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on European Affairs said on Thursday.
Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut said he had spoken this week with representatives of the European Parliament and others and was concerned about their threats to stop participating in anti-terrorist organizations due to frustration over National Security Agency surveillance.
"It is very important for the national security interests of the United States that Europeans remain on board with our joint efforts against terrorism," Murphy, who is a Democrat sitting in the Senate for the first time and serves as Chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Foreign Relations and European Affairs, said in an interview in Washington.
I am also going to Europe to make it clear that we must continue to work together in the fight against terrorism, despite their anger about NSA programmes.
Media reports that the NSA has collected millions of phone records in Europe have strained relations with some US allies, although the head of the secret service said this week the reports were inaccurate and based on a misunderstanding of metadata collected by NATO allies and exchanged with the United States.
Other revelations quoted documents passed on by Snowden according to which the NSA had monitored the mobile phone of Chancellor Angela Merkel and up to 34 other heads of state worldwide.
The head of the national intelligence services, James Clapper, defended spying on allies as necessary and stated that this was common practice on both sides.
In all the turmoil, Murphy said his agency was preparing for the trip of the Congress to be held this year and hoped the delegation would include members from both parties and chambers.
The names of the other participating MPs are to be published in the coming days.
He said the exact itinerary is still being worked out.
While Murphy emphasized that the purpose of the trip was to improve relations, he also spoke of the fact that there would be some "serious words".
He said that European governments must be honest with their people about the kind of spy programs they themselves have been using for years.
"While we can change our surveillance programmes to better protect the rights of Europeans, they must also accept the fact that we are not the only ones spying," Murphy said.
Meanwhile, John Kerry will travel to the Middle East and Poland this weekend to address the resentment about US strategy in Syria, Egypt and Iran and US surveillance activities.

A return to the very American ideal of labour rights as human rights
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have introduced a bill to establish union organizing as a civil right.
"As unions die, so do middle-class jobs," said Ellison, a Minnesota Democrat and vice chair of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.
I am therefore proud to present the Employee Empowerment Act together with the civil rights icon John Lewis.
This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal opportunities for discrimination in union organising as other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-union forces.
Supplementing the national labour law to provide a means for workers exposed to discrimination to organise trade union representation, to seek justice in a civil court - and to obtain compensation or fines - is a useful and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
In fact, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to link back to a very American idea.
Despite the setbacks that unions have faced in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan and other states across the country - Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognize, extend and respect labor rights.
There was a time when millions of Americans still remember when this country mentioned democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right of association in the same breath.
When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas Mac Arthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution to ensure that Hedki Tojo's militarized autocracy was replaced by democracy.
Fully aware that the workers and their trade unions had a role to play in creating a new Japan, they used language that explicitly recognized that "the rights of workers to unite and to bargain and act together are guaranteed.
When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism was replaced by a strong democracy.
Recognizing that the workers would have to organize and make their voice heard in the new nation, the Germans inserted a clause that explicitly stated: "The right to form associations to secure and improve working and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and every profession or trade.
Agreements that restrict this right or aim to reduce it are null and void; measures aimed at reducing it are unlawful.
When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Commission on Human Rights, which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as adopted by the United Nations as a global treaty in 1948, Roosevelt and the other authors inserted a guarantee that "everyone has the right to form or join trade unions for the protection of his or her interests.
For generations Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.
When this country advised other countries on how to form civil and democratic societies, Americans stated that the right to form a union - and to have that union participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with companies and government agencies - must be protected.
After these rights came under fire in America, it is indeed very wise to recall the American ideal that the working population must have the right to unite and be heard in a free and open society.
As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the labor movement did not limit the strength of the nation but increased it.
By raising the living standards of millions of people, labor has miraculously created a market for industry and raised the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack the work forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History remembers, and so should we.
The formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights as protection against discrimination in the creation of employee representation bodies - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis renew the ideals that made America great in the past and kept the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily halts law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close
A US federal judge on Sunday provisionally stopped the implementation of a law in Louisiana, which lawyers say would probably have led to the closure of all five abortion clinics in the state.
This measure, which was made law by Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal in June and is scheduled to take effect on Sept. 1, would force doctors who perform abortions to obtain a right to admit patients at a hospital within a 30-mile radius of their practice.
However, the judge's decision means that for the time being, doctors can continue to carry out abortions legally while applying for such a right.
"Plaintiffs may continue to operate within the law while seeking to obtain these rights," Federal Judge John deGravelles wrote in his ruling.
A hearing for the judge is scheduled within one month to give the law a more permanent decision.
Abortion advocates welcomed the decision, the latest in a series of judgments against similar measures, saying it would give doctors more time to obtain hospital admission rights.
"Today's decision means that women in Louisiana are evading a devious law that seeks to take away their health and rights," said Nancy Northup, president and chairwoman of the Center for Reproductive Rights, which sued on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the judgement also extended to the doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the complaint and had also applied for referral rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have enacted similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key sections of a Texas law that would have forced most of the remaining clinics in the state to close were stopped by a federal judge on Friday.
Abortion advocates and the American College of Ostretricians and Gynecologists as well as the American Medical Association agree that referral rights of doctors require unnecessary restrictions.
Opponents of abortion argue that the measures serve to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the effects of closing clinics.
Only one doctor who performs abortions in Louisiana has patient referral rights, the Center for Reproductive Rights reported.
If all other doctors in the state are forced to stop abortions, that doctor would stop performing the operation for fear for his safety, the group said.

Delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment options lead to higher death rates from ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James have put a video tribute online for their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural areas of Australia have a higher risk of dying of ovarian cancer than women in cities.
Researchers analyzed the medical data of more than 1100 Australian women diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after diagnosis.
Research director Susan Jordan of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that for those who lived in rural and remote areas of the state, the risk of mortality during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New drugs could slow down lung and ovarian cancer
The researchers investigated the medical care of the women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that a woman's age at diagnosis, type of ovarian cancer, existing pre-existing conditions, and social and economic status also influenced the chances of survival.
The survival rate was lowest for older women and those whose cancer was more advanced at the time of diagnosis.
For those who lived in rural and remote areas of the state, the mortality risk during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.
Although the study did not investigate why out-of-town women are more likely to die of ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects late diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynecological oncologists, and they are usually found in larger cities," she said.
Despite the improvement of telemedicine services to counteract the distances, she suggested as a possible remedy the strengthening of the service of doctors flown in to enable specialists to provide care for women closer to home, as well as treatment programmes for people outside their region.
Dr. Jordan said the study showed poor long-term survival rates in women with ovarian cancer regardless of geographic status and underscored the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer funded study is published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a young mother of 33 years from the Gold Coast learned that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.

The increase in the number of people living in highly urbanised areas without gardens, the popular practice of asphalting front gardens for parking purposes and the decreasing size of gardens are other factors threatening the industry, which has an estimated £5 billion in annual sales.
In Greater London, where the proportion of homeowners has fallen from 61 to 43 per cent over a period of 6 years, the lowest spending on garden products per household is reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that living for rent or small gardens do not mean that people cannot grow plants.

The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retailing due to increasing home ownership and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather after unfriendly weather conditions in March and April last year.

In view of the galloping technical progress that threatens to transform our cosy home into high-tech control centres, our columnist Bernd Matthies takes comfort in the fact that he has a very familiar electronic accessory.
As I'm writing this, my eyes fall on the spiral cable connecting the handset to the phone, and I think: Wow, how retro is that?
But there is a thought behind it: If it wasn't for the cable, all the listeners would be flying around the house in no time at all, and that would be even more retro.
Anyway, on the disgusting (disgusting?
No, typo: electronic) sector the rule that the world's first of today is the electronic waste of tomorrow, bought - obsolete.
And anyone who still has a tube TV in their living room, for example, is simply saying that they reject television in principle.
Why these considerations?
Because the rush of the Ifa at the radio tower this week again shows us our absolute incompetence in questions of electronics.
The layman, who used to be a blind master of the washing machine and CD player, today doesn't even understand the purpose of the appliances that are spread out in front of him with incredibly vain expert talk: "Connected Home, Wearables, Health Care and Urban Technologies" is what the press office promises us.
Yeah, what's up?
What is there to talk about with people who apparently voluntarily spread such quark?
Basically, for the last 20 years or so, the main issue has been that we should network our house.
So that the yoghurt reorders itself, so that the fire detector on holiday in the Maldives tells us that there is a fire in the study.
And wouldn't it be wonderful if we could switch the air conditioning on from the office on our imminent arrival ...?
Yes, but this requires air conditioning.
But one dream will certainly come true soon: We lift our watch, tell her loudly "Suck!" - and at home the vacuum cleaner robot goes off.
Crazy.
Everything boils down to nothing less than a revolution: "The boundaries between white and brown goods are becoming blurred," whispers an industry expert, you can connect the washing machine to a headphone, the steamer sends the weather report and the data glasses show how long the pizza will take in the oven, but that doesn't help because we're stuck in traffic jams.
We also know from daily practice that if a new-fangled device is really urgently needed, the battery is guaranteed to be empty.
Which is another reason why the spiral cable on the phone will survive the next radio exhibitions.

Thousands of Israeli children from the Gaza Strip area returned to schools on Monday after spending the summer in shelters as rocket and mortar fire fell on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas and schools in Gaza remained closed as the area recovered from the fighting.
The school launch brought a sense of joy and expectation to the rocket-injected communities in southern Israel, but the signs of fighting are still fresh.

Many children from our area urgently need a return to a routine.

"Those were difficult times, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the border with Gaza to offer his support.
Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities such as Saad stayed in their homes or left their homes to move to safer areas further away from Gaza and escape rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still hesitant to return.
The Ministry of Education announced that about a dozen families have not yet returned.
Their children were temporarily placed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a town on the border with Gaza, which is severely affected by Palestinian bombardment.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said "we will make sure that you acquire knowledge and offer you security".
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday on an indefinite ceasefire.
The ceasefire brought an immediate end to the fighting, but important problems remain unresolved, such as Hamas' demand for an end to the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza's air and sea ports.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the handing over of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to start in Egypt later this month.
More than 2,100 Palestinians were killed in the war, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children, according to Palestinian and UN estimates.
Israel denies this information and estimates that at least half of the killed were combatants, but did not provide concrete evidence of this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells at Israeli cities during the fighting, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in the Gaza area and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools, which were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in the shelters and fighting continues, last week the education authorities postponed the start of the school year.
"I hope that the school will be open again soon so that we can continue to learn like the children of the world and Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.

The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for homes in the Australian capital rose 1.1 percent in August, according to Monday's RP data.
This increase brings the total increase in June, July and August to 4.2 percent, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was 10.9 percent, more than twice as high as the increase in the 12 months to August 2013, but the increases were not evenly distributed across the country.
RP Data's head of research, Tim Lawless, said that Sydney and Melbourne are driving a two-tier market.
Figures from RP Data show that house prices in Sydney rose by 16.1 percent last year, compared to 11.7 percent in Melbourne.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, where prices rose by an average of five and six percent.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices rose by only 1.4 per cent over the year.
Mr Lawless went on to say that with the start of spring, there would now be a rise in available-for-sale properties for the next few months that would put the market "to a real test".
"Considering the continued high rate of auction prices, a generally rapid rate of sales and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will continue to rise over the next three months," he said.

There are also some other wear-related complaints.

However, I can count the years in which I can still play handball on one hand.
I also have to say that after my long stay in hospital in 2012, I also became quite humble about my health.

Konstantin Wecker's relentlessly honest memoirs
It is actually more a philosophical testimony than a biography, which Konstantin Wecker, singer-songwriter, pacifist, political activist, ex-prisoner, has put down on paper in "Mönch und Krieger" on 287 pages.
Not chronologically, but rather more fragments of thought for fragments of thought, the Munich-born on June 1, 1947, wrote down his memoirs, each chapter introduced by a suitable song text.
And he is ruthlessly honest: from masturbation as a high school student to shoplifting and drug use, he leaves no human weakness out.
Also to show how he himself learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow men.
Abstract, but all the more important, terms also occupy a large space: Love, soul, ego, being in the now, spirituality - he tries to get to the bottom of all this, in a very philosophical, but also very personal way.
And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political commitment - and also how he was influenced not only by music (the opera lover became a soul and rock musician), but also by his time in prison.
The latter also brought the bon vivant Konstantin Wecker closer to the ascetic monk, who is created "by subtraction", as he says, "by leaving out everything unnecessary".
But between all the highly intellectual views there are also short anecdotes about grounding: about brawls in a pub frequented by GIs, for example, or a mad car ride in which he aimed at a tree head-on.
There too he is ruthlessly honest.
Lenny Henry: My father never took me in his arms.
Never said "I love you."
Henry was one of seven children of a family of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley in the Midlands in 1958.
His father, who died when Henry was 19, worked in a factory and their relationship was limited.
Henry is rehearsing for a comedy, Rudy's Rare Records, which is partly based on an imaginary conversation with his father and originated from the series on Radio 4.
The soundtrack is a mixture of reggae and rap, with lively melodies.
But Henry had to work his way through some difficult childhood moments.
He attended "many" therapies after his mother's death, and Henry is pensive about his relationship with his father.
It was hard to know him.
You never saw his face, only heard his voice: "Stop the noise.
Leave your sister alone.
Move it!
I want to watch cricket.
My older brothers Seymour and Hilton - who were grown up when I was a child - would go to the pub with him and talk about things like the shape of a beer glass or the beauty of a cricket match.
I never had a conversation like this with him.
For most of my life, he was this serious guy in the corner reading the paper.
Henry recently opened a foundry in Dudley and, although conditions are better than when his father was alive, he gained some insight into what life might have been like for him.
It's a little lighter now, but they are dark, smoky, deep stygian labyrinths with flames and smoke and lots of soot.
My father used to just lie down in the bathtub and then you could slowly hear him start singing because he could wash the foundry off him.
As I walked around there, I realized that he had been doing this for years to put food on the table, and my respect for him grew.
Nevertheless, Henry grew up as a child without any expressions of love from his parents.
My father never hugged me, he never said "I love you".
It was only when my mother was feeling bad towards the end of her life that we began to say, "I love you, I love you, I love you".
Through his own daughter Billie, with Dawn French, he was able to share the love he had missed as a child.
Would you stop with the "I love you"?
Stop hugging me!
Dad, I'm 22!
with Dawn French.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She's a great mother.
It is still friends with French, to whom he was married for 25 years.
Dawn is a good person.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She's a great mother.
Henry's own mother was diabetic.
That contributed to her death.
So when I became very, very overweight and showed symptoms of diabetes, my doctor said "You have to be radical.
So I did this fitness thing and also had to go on a drastic diet to reverse the symptoms.
It's very hard.
And it's exhausting.
Nobody likes to eat carrots.
Henry's career change is perhaps reflected in his elegant, short beard.
Since he was praised by the critics for his Othello, he has been appropriated by the theatre.
It was followed by The Comedy of Errors, and then Fences by August Wilson.
This is a different experience than the sitcoms and comedies that filled his busy working life.
He started when he was only 16 years old, working in a factory.
A DJ discovered him on stage imitating people and wrote to New Faces about him.
His television career began in the mid-seventies. "I was the only black impersonator/comedian on TV for quite some time."
He learned his trade.
Not only did I have to grow up in front of the public, but from 1975 to 1985 I had to learn how to become an efficient joke-telling machine while being a star through television, and that was really difficult.
Lenny 1975 at New Faces
Since his manager owned the stage rights to the Black and White Minstrel Show, a light entertainment program in which people "painted themselves black", Henry performed his comedy there for over five years.
It was very unpleasant for my family.
I kind of wish it never happened, but I don't regret that I did.
It was a strange, uncomfortable position for me, but I worked on huge projects and learned how to deal with a large audience.
But this "longstanding award-winning light pillar of British television" was also a "grotesque parody of black people."
By introducing characters who both mocked and celebrated British black culture, Henry worked on an alternative comedy circle in the eighties.
The first series of the Lenny Henry Show went on the air in 1984, and in the nineties he was known as chef Gareth Blacklock in the comedy series Chef!
Commercials, documentaries, TV series and film roles shaped his next decade, but after his BBC series LennyHenry.tv 2008 he thought: "What are you going to do next, Len, because it all feels like you're just passing time or treading water a little bit.
After that came a documentary series for Radio 4 called What's So Great About ...?
The first episode was about Shakespeare.
I was really allergic to Shakespeare.

Put a few words in your mouth and you'll understand why we all love Shakespeare so much.
Henry performed 20 lines from Othello's last speech for the documentary and he was thrilled.
I felt like I could do it.
It was almost as if someone had finally put my head on straight.

In the conflict between Shiite Huthi rebels and the Yemeni government, the Huthis have called for civil disobedience in the capital Sanaa.
Huthi supporters occupied central streets in Sanaa on Monday, a spokesman for the Huthi party "Ansar Allah" said.
The access to the parliament had also been blocked.
Yemeni media report about a traffic chaos in the capital.
According to the online edition of the newspaper "Yemen Post", Huthi leader Abdulmalik al-Huthi had called for the measures on Sunday evening.
According to the newspaper, Huthi threatened a further escalation of the conflict if his demands were not met.
The Shiite Huthis are fighting for more independence from Sunni-ruled Yemen and demand the resignation of the government.

Some 30,000 rebels have set up protest camps along the major access roads of Sanaa.

Kenya registers officials to curb "ghost workers
Kenya has started to biometrically register all state officials in order to delete "ghost employees" from the government payroll.
Employees who do not register in the next two weeks will not be paid any more, according to a government announcement.
The government suspects that thousands of people will continue to receive salary payments after they leave the civil service.
When President Uhuru Kenyatta took office in 2013, he promised to fight corruption in the civil service.
An audit earlier this year found that at least $1 million (£700,000) per month was being lost in payments to "ghost employees" and other abusive financial practices.
The government suspects that salaries will continue to be paid into accounts after a person has died or left the civil service, reports Wanyama Chebusiri for the BBC from the capital Nairobi.
All officials must now appear at identification centers over the next two weeks to ensure that their data is recorded on biometric registrations, was announced in a government memo.
All those who would not do so without a credible excuse would be taken off the payroll, the statement continued.
"This approach will contribute significantly to the rationalisation of the civil service by determining the actual number of civil servants and also by adjusting the payroll at both levels of government - thus eliminating 'ghost workers'," said Anne Waiguru, Cabinet Secretary in the Ministry of Decentralisation and Planning.

Five heirs of Berthold Albrecht, son of Aldi founder Theo Albrecht, are demanding 19.4 million euros in damages from Achenbach and two of its companies in insolvency proceedings in a civil case at the Düsseldorf Regional Court.
This was announced by a court spokeswoman on Monday.
The application states that Achenbach had cheated in the purchase of works of art and classic cars and that Berthold Albrecht had charged higher purchase prices than those actually paid.
As a result, the agreed commission was also higher.
Achenbach had purchased valuables for Albrecht for 121 million euros.
Children need roots and wings
He was in the teaching profession for 44 years, 23 of them as headmaster.
From this time Manfred Richter knows many experienced Petershausener and Kollbacher from their time as students.
His methods were sometimes unconventional, but always carried by his striving to see the human being in the student.
The Schneekoppe is the most famous mountain of the Giant Mountains.
Manfred Richter loves the painting with the motif from his home country.
Richter was born in 1930 in Trautenau/North Bohemia, today Trutnov.
At the age of 14, after four years of secondary school, he became interested in the teaching profession.
One year later the Sudeten Germans were expropriated.
Within half an hour the family had to leave their house.
After a few months in a camp, they went to Bavaria in 1946 - in a freight car.
So Richter ended up in Senkendorf in Upper Franconia.
The teacher training took place in Bamberg.
For this Manfred Richter had to walk six times a week ten kilometres to the next railway station, take the train to Bamberg, walk three kilometres across the whole city to school and back in the evening.
After two months, Manfred Richter was given a sleeping opportunity in a Red Cross home in Bamberg: together with up to 15 fellow students in a dormitory.
In 1951 he passed the first state examination and in 1954, after three years of teacher training, the second state examination.
Since Upper Franconia did not have a free teacher's position for him, he applied to Upper Bavaria and came to the school in Kollbach on 1 November 1954.
The "Fräulein-Zimmer" was his first "official residence" in the school building.
In 1958 he moved into a three-room official residence in the newly built teachers' house next to the school.
Manfred Richter bought this house in 1980 after the school in Kollbach was closed in 1968.
Until then there were three classes in Kollbach in the Petershausen-Kollbach school association and five in Petershausen.
From the 1968/69 school year onwards, these were combined in Petershausen in the present town hall.
When the school association Indersdorf was founded, only the primary school remained in the village.
In order to avoid downgrading in the now smaller school, the then headmaster Georg Sigl moved to Karlsfeld - and Manfred Richter became his successor.
But Petershausen grew, and from September 1982 the children and their teachers were able to move into the present building, which was extended in 1997 after Richter's retirement.
Manfred Richter praises the uncomplicated generosity of the then Mayor Ludwig Götz, who had a workshop and, when the extension was built in 1997, cellar rooms built at the community's expense, although this was not eligible under the guidelines for school buildings.
"Mayor Goetz was very school-friendly," Richter recalled gratefully.
In his whole career Manfred Richter has never forgotten the speech of a government representative who had responded to a school council's lecture on law and justice: "One must never forget love". Manfred Richter put into practice what he had heard there as a young teacher.
"You have to give the children two things: Roots and wings," says the now 84-year-old.
And he had to learn: "It doesn't always work out". It is not quite clear whether he means just his pupils or just as much his own six children.
In any case, Richter's actions were sometimes unconventional.
When students fought, he did not give them punishment, nor did he sentence them to detention.
At the community's expense Richter had two pairs of boxing gloves purchased and let the two opponents compete against each other, even if there should be a violet.
For the good of the school, Richter, as headmaster, maintained a good relationship with the then mayor Ludwig Götz (CSU).
After his retirement, the non-partisan judge was persuaded by the latter to be the last on the CSU list to run for municipal council in 1996.
But Richter was preselected to sixth place and joined the CSU.
