HR4-RADTOUR 700 cyclists make stopovers in the spa gardens of Bad Salzhausen and Schotten
When cyclists stop off in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten on their tour, it is nothing special in itself.
On Friday, however, the number of people taking a break was impressive: The 700 participants of the hr4 bike tour and their accompanying horse enjoyed a break in the lower Kurpark of Bad Salzhausen and later an open-air party in the Schottener Alteburgpark.
Under the motto "Cycling and partying on newly discovered paths between Nidda and Kinzig", the participants had met in Bad Vilbel on Thursday and witnessed a concert by Van Baker & Band.
On Friday things got serious: The cyclists tackled the first stage, the 60 kilometres via Florstadt to Bad Salzhausen and on to Schotten.
In Bad Salzhausen, the athletes were welcomed by Mayor Hans-Peter Seum, who had taken part in the race in Bad Vilbel by bicycle, and the head of the Bad Salzhausen Own Plant, Petra Schwing-Döring.
All kinds of good things had been prepared to refresh body and soul: The countrywomen from Ranstadt and Nieder-Mockstadt had baked 85 trays of apple, plum, crumble and cheesecake, which were delicious for the capable cyclists.
"Only countrywomen can bake such cakes," praised a participant from Aulendiebach as he ordered another piece.
Cold refreshments could be purchased at the drinks stand of the Geiß-Nidda gymnastics club.
The "Duo Bravo" entertained the visitors with well-known melodies from operettas and musicals and received enthusiastic applause.
The beautiful ambience of the park had a relaxing effect.
One gentleman also enjoyed a head massage from his partner: "He deserved it, after all, he has already reattached bicycle chains that have come off today".
Meanwhile the mayor and the plant manager still had to work: They were interviewed at the fountain in front of the Trinkkurhaus by reporter Rainer Janke and took the opportunity to advertise Bad Salzhausen on the radio.
Promotion head Tobias Hagen, who has been the tour leader since the first hr4 bike tour in 2004, could only take a short breather, as he had a lot to do with the technology on site.
His pickup truck, in which he used three telephones and a radio to communicate with his employees and the 15-man motorcycle squadron of the Hesse police force, wrote Facebook entries and made reports, also needed a check.
"The majority of the participants come from the Rhine-Main area," he said, "but cyclists have also come from Gießen or Fulda, from Lauterbach or the Taunus, and even from numerous cities in Westphalia.
The number of participants depends a little bit on the available accommodation capacities.
In category I the participants will be accommodated in hotels, in category II in collective accommodations.
The cyclists had a good impression of the health resort when they set off again after an hour and a half: "Bye!"
"It was nice in Bad Salzhausen!" they waved goodbye.
After arrival in Schotten the group was allowed to take a short break.
But in the evening the cyclists were challenged in the idyllic Alteburgpark.
Under the direction of the Schottener Gesellschaft für Tourismus und Stadtmarketing (GTS), the park had been given a nice festive atmosphere and of course, delicacies such as tarte flambée with well-chilled Federweisser had been prepared.
Mayor Susanne Schaab, GTS Managing Director Markus Hoßfeld and MSC Chairman Wolfgang Wagner-Sachs in his function as a member of the board of the ADAC Hessen-Thüringen welcomed the visitors.
The three were visibly pleased about the "many operations in Schotten".
DJ Tobias Hagen then released the dance stage.
The opportunity to move swinging in the open air was eagerly taken despite the sporting activity on the bicycle.
The guests were increasingly joined by citizens who were just as impressed by the good atmosphere as the large crowd of cyclists.
On the second day, the cyclists had the stops in Birstein, Wächtersbach and Bad Orb - including a concert with the Trenkwalders - on the programme.
Yesterday, after 180 kilometres of cycling, the athletes arrived back in Bad Vilbel.

In Rona Fairhead, the BBC may have found the great director it needs.
She arrives with a proud train of fame from the banking world, media management and the inner circle of the Tory party.
And she has her own frontline experience.
She began her career at the global management consulting firm Bain and Co., before joining Morgan Stanley, Bombadier, ICI and the media world of Pearsons.
She was Chairman of the Financial Times for seven years and resigned when the top post at parent company Pearsons went to a younger male colleague.
Her severance pay was reportedly nearly £1 million.
Their political ranking is also solid.
She was recommended to David Cameron by Lord Browne, the former chairman of BP, when he was looking for more private sector expertise in Whitehall: she became an advisor to the Cabinet.
Her husband is a former Tory councillor.
Already in May I described the task of the chairman with a poisoned chalice.
Not only is the BBC at the heart of public life as a huge and complex entity, but there is also an internal paradox in its structure.
The trust works in two directions: inwardly on the first guard of its own management hierarchy in the BBC, but also outwardly as a voice of public concern and concern when things go wrong.
This creates an almost untenable duopoly that calls for a complete and comprehensive reform.
But what new arriving chairman would risk running, hitting everything and dismantling an institution as complex as a Chinese dynasty, while perhaps losing his own job in the process?
It's a difficult task.
And as if that wasn't enough, many are also interested in seeing the BBC downsized - power, money and status obsolete.
As competition approaches and new technologies threaten old, convenient securities, the upcoming royalty negotiations pose particular risks for the BBC.
For the modest sum of £145.50 per year, the British public is buying into what is certainly the largest media company in the world.
The BBC tells a good story: it says it reaches 96 per cent of all households and costs only 40 pence a day for each of them.
And it seems that the BBC is rising again on the popularity scale: 53 percent support it today, compared to 31 percent 10 years ago.
The viewing and usage habits for the BBC have changed: I get news headlines on my mobile phone these days and see missed programs later on my iPlayer.
But it remains a very beloved and remarkable institution.
She needs a considerable chairman - I hope she has found him.

Berkeley declares housing market "normal" again
One of London's most prominent property developers pointed out that the housing market in the South East of England had "returned" to normal levels.
Home ownership in the capital was in high demand and subject to huge price rises, which led the Bank of England to set mortgage lending limits in June due to widespread fears of a credit bubble.
Tony Pidgley, founder and chairman of the board of the top-tier construction company, Berkeley, said on Monday: "Since the beginning of the current financial year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since the peak in 2013" and added that this provides a "stable environment for action".
The London property market was well positioned during the downturn as foreign buyers pushed into the capital.
According to information from the land registry, prices in the city area rose sharply by 18.5 percent last year alone, far more than the average increase in England and Wales as a whole.
Average retail prices at Berkeley's private, low-cost and student offerings rose by about one-fifth last year and were around £423,000 at the end of April.
However, a stronger pound has made property ownership in London less attractive to foreign buyers in recent months - some have also been deterred by the introduction of new property taxes and political rhetoric about a possible "villa tax" ahead of next May's general election.
London real estate broker Foxtons warned last week that the April mortgage market report, which presented tighter lending rules, would also lead to lower market growth in the second half of the year in both property sales and prices.
New data from the Bank of England on Monday shows a drop in mortgage approvals in July, which also suggests that the housing market is cooling.
Hamptions International, another real estate agency, revised its forecast for London's property price rise in 2015 downwards to 3 per cent, based on already weakening house price awareness.
The volume of transactions in London's most expensive areas such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington has now fallen by a quarter every year, according to broker WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, the desire to own a home in the capital is a blessing for Berkeley, as the amounts due on forward sales amount to more than £2.2 billion.
Mr Pidgley added: "Demand for the right, well-planned product in the best locations remained stable and as a result, forward sales have also remained stable.
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes in the year to the end of April - almost a third more than the 2007 peak before the crisis.
Annual pre-tax profit rose by 40 per cent to £280m and turnover by 18 per cent to £1.6bn.
In a memo on Monday before the company's annual meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that Berkeley's revenues for the current year are expected to be in line with current market expectations.
The analysts unanimously estimate the annual pre-tax profit at £ 450 million.
Berkeley shares were trading steady at £23.96 in London this afternoon.

Exclusive excerpt from Howard Jacobson's highly acclaimed new novel about love and the letter "J".
They melted, that's the best way to describe it, they slowly dissolved like a cardboard box that you left standing in the rain.
Occasionally, a woman told him that he was too serious, exhausting, intense, distant and perhaps a bit scratchy.
And then shook his hand.
Prickly he knew.
He was prickly, like a hedgehog, yes.
The final victim of this prickiness was a just beginning affair, which had been more promising for alleviating the lonely boredom of his life than usual, and might even have brought him some satisfaction.
Ailinn Solomons was a quivering, delicate beauty with untamed hair and a fluttering heart from a village in the North Island that was even more remote and harsh than Port Reuben.
She had come south with an elderly companion who Kevern thought was her aunt, and who had inherited a plot of land in a damp but paradisiacal valley aptly named Paradise Valley.
No one had lived in the house for several years.
The pipes were leaking, there were still spiders in the baths, slugs had left their marks on all the windows and thought they owned all this, and the garden was overgrown with weeds that looked like giant cabbages.
It was like the house from a children's fairy tale, both threatening and enticing, a garden full of secrets.
Portrait of the author: Howard Jacobson, whose novel "J" is on the longlist for the Man Booker Prize 2014.
The shortlist will be announced next week.
Kevern had sat with Ailinn holding hands on the broken deckchairs in the high grass and enjoyed an unusually warm spring afternoon. Both had absent-mindedly latched on to the service console, which provided the country with soothing music and news, when the sight of their crossed brown legs reminded him of an old song by a long-forgotten black entertainer his father liked to listen to with the shutters closed in the house.
Your feet are too big.
Due to their inherent aggressiveness, songs of this kind were no longer played on the console.
Not forbidden - nothing was really forbidden - just not played.
It has been successfully obsoleted, just like the word obsolesce.
The general taste achieved what decrees and regulations could never have done, and just as people choose from books the from dishwasher to millionaire memoirs, cookbooks and romance novels, they chose ballads for music.
In the euphoria of the day, Kevern began playing an imaginary piano and singing Ailinn's big feet in a grossly comical serenade.
Ailinn didn't understand that.
"That was a famous song by a jazz pianist named Fats Waller," he explained to her, automatically putting two fingers to his lips.
His father had always done this to stop the letter J before it came out of his mouth.
It had started as a game between him and his father when he was a child.
His father had played it with his own father, he had told me.
If you start a word with a J without putting two fingers over your lips, it will cost you a penny.
It hadn't been a very funny game even then, and it wasn't very funny now.
He knew that this was expected of him, that was all.
It had to explain what jazz was.
Ailinn had never heard any.
Jazz was not played, even if it was not directly forbidden.
Improvising was no longer modern.
There was only room for one "if" in life.
At the beginning of a melody, people wanted to be quite sure where it would end.
So is the mind.
His unpredictability made people nervous.
And jazz was musically expressed mind.
Although he had turned 10 without having heard of Sammy Davis Junior, Kevern knew something about jazz from his father's half-secret collection of old CDs.
But at least he did not have to explain to Ailinn that Fats Waller was black.
At her age she probably couldn't remember a time when pop singers weren't black.
Again, no laws or constraints applied.
A conformist society meant that every element of that society gratefully agreed to the principle of group endowment - grateful as those spared by fate.
People of Afro-Caribbean origin were suitable for entertainment and sports because of their temperament and physique, so they sang and ran.
People who originally came from the Indian subcontinent were blessed with electronic talent as if by nature, and they were entrusted with the task of ensuring that no family was left without a functioning service telephone.
What was left of the Polish community took care of the sewage system; what was left of the Greeks smashed plates.
Those from the Gulf States and the Levant, whose grandparents had not left the country quickly when WHAT HAPPENED WAS happening - for fear of being accused of starting fires, for fear that the flames would consume them next - had opened labneh and shisha-pipe restaurants, kept their heads down and became depressed with inactivity.
Each according to his abilities.
As she had only heard ballads, Ailinn found it difficult to understand how the insulting words Kevern had just sung to her could ever be set to music.
Music was an expression of love.
"They're not really insulting," Kevern said.
Except maybe for people whose feet are too big.
My father never insulted anyone, but he loved this song.
He talked too much, but the neglected garden gave him the deceptive feeling of security.
Nothing could overcome the sound insulation of the huge cabbage-like leaves.
Ailinn still did not understand.
Why would your father love something like that?
He wanted to say that it was a joke, but hesitated to put two fingers to her lips again in her presence.
She already thought he was a little weird.
"It seemed funny to him," he said instead.
She shook her head in disbelief and blocked Kevern's view.
There was nothing else to see in the whole world but her uncombed raven-black hair.
There was nothing else he wanted to see.
"When you say it," she means without conviction.
But that still doesn't explain why you're singing it to me.
She seemed genuinely worried.
Are my feet too big?
He looked again.
Your feet aren't that straight.
Maybe your ankles, a little bit...
And you say you hate me because my ankles are too thick?
Hate you?
Of course I don't hate you.
It's just the stupid song.
He could have said, "I love you," but it was too early.
"Your thick ankles are exactly why I like you," he tried instead.
I'm a bit perverse.
That didn't sound right.
It was supposed to be weird.
When he tried to be funny, he often got himself into trouble because, like his father, he did not have the reassuring charm needed to tame the cruelty inherent in jokes.
Maybe his father wanted to be cruel too.
Maybe he, Kevern, wanted to be.
Despite his kind eyes.
Ailinn Solomons blushed and rose from her deck chair, knocked over the console and spilled the wine they had drunk.
Elderflower wine, so drunkenness was no excuse for him.
In her excitement she seemed to tremble like palm fronds in a storm.
"And your pigheadedness is exactly why I'm pervertedly attracted to you," she said...
Except I'm not.
He felt sorry for her, both because of the unnecessary unkindness of his words and the fear that appeared in her eyes when she rebelled against him.
Did she think he was gonna hit her?
She had not told him about life in the cold northern archipelago where she had grown up, but he had no doubt that it was essentially like this.
The same huge and ice-cold ocean broke here and there on the shore.
The same confused men, with even thicker skin and more morose after WHAT HAPPENED THAN their ancestors as smugglers and beachcombers had been, moved from pub to pub, always ready to raise their hand against a woman who refused or ridiculed them.
Stubborn?
They would have shown her a thick fist if she wasn't careful!
They first snog - snogging was the most commonly used word for an erotic attraction between men and women, an antidote to the meaningless love ballads from the console - they first snog and then hit.
In Keern's view, this was an unnecessary refinement, since the snogging itself was already an act of violence.
Ailinn Solomons gave him a sign to go through her body.
He rose from his deck chair like an old man.
She also felt leaden, but the force of his grief surprised her.
It wasn't the end of the world.
They hardly knew each other.
She watched him move away - just as her companion watched him from an upstairs room - a man weighted down by something he had conjured up himself.
Adam's leaving the garden, she thought.
She felt a sudden pain for him and men in general, although some had raised their hands against her.

Military officials in Lesotho denied that they had planned a coup to overthrow the government and said they were acting against police officers accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and announced that the country's army had surrounded his official residence and occupied government buildings in the capital Maseru.

Military spokesman Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there was de facto no coup d'état, but that the military was responding to the threat of "political fanatics" who were about to be armed by the police.
"What happened this morning was that the Lesotho Defense Forces Staff acted after receiving several intelligence reports that within the police force there are some elements who actually wanted to arm some of the political, party political young fanatics who were on the verge of wreaking havoc," he told Voice of America.
The South African government spokesman Clayson Monyela said the military action gave the impression of a coup.

Speakers for the Lesotho military said on Sunday that the soldiers were retreating to their barracks and the situation in the capital was calm.

Euro-zone production at a 13-month low
The rise in production in the euro zone slowed in August to the lowest point in 13 months, according to a closely watched study.
The final Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) fell to 50.7 in August from 51.8 in July.
A value above 50 indicates an expansion.
New orders declined and factories suffered slumps at a time of rising tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures arrive before the meeting of the European Central Bank (ECB) on Thursday.
The markets expect the Bank to have a clear plan for dealing with a hesitant recovery in the eurozone and the threat of deflation with inflation at just 0.3%.
There is speculation that the head of the ECB, Mario Draghi, may provide further details later this week as to whether he is considering quantitative easing for the Euro-Zone, similar to those made by Britain and the US during the financial crisis.
"Although small growth is better than no growth at all, the slowing effects of increasing economic and geopolitical uncertainties have become more apparent to manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, senior economist at Markit.
The factory PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to its lowest level in 11 months at 51.4.
Meanwhile, in the bloc's second largest economy, France, the PMI fell to 46.9.
France remains a problem child, as does Italy's descent from solid expansion to stagnation.
Evidence that growth incentives in the key industrial mechanism Germany, as well as in Spain and the Netherlands, are no longer effective is not reassuring either," said Mr Dobson.
The decline in industry is likely to fuel the fire of analysts who expect further monetary or fiscal stimulus.
Positive news came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, its highest level since late 1999.
Howard Archer, chief economic expert at IHS Global Insight, said: "The best that can be said for the eurozone Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index for August is that the sector continues to grow thereafter.
He added: "Producers in the eurozone are obviously finding life quite difficult at the moment, as the current heightened geopolitical tensions - especially with regard to Russia and Ukraine - are adding to uncertainties in the continuing difficult conditions in many countries.
These increased uncertainties have clearly affected the economy - in particular, and consumer confidence, and are likely to lead to some orders being delayed or even cancelled, especially large orders.
He said that it is "increasingly likely" that the ECB will eventually have to initiate some form of QE, "although we suspect that this will be limited.

4 tips for better underwater photos and videos
If you like to take pictures or videos under water, there is a selection of equipment available.
The cheapest option is a waterproof point-and-shoot, like the Nikon Coolpix AW120, or an action cam like the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both of which are available for about $300.
I took these photos at a family party with several cameras, all of which are available for less than $350.
Regardless of the equipment, there are a few rules for the best results.
Check your equipment twice.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery compartment and other compartments are sealed tightly.
Also set your camera to the photos or videos you want to take.
Some cameras and camcorders have scene and recording modes that optimize exposure time for the dim underwater conditions.
And before you jump in, check to what depth your equipment is functional.
Some cameras are only approved for up to 5 feet, others up to 50 or 60 feet.
Search our shopping guide and reviews for digital cameras for both traditional and waterproof models.
Take multiple shots - because many will not work.
Point-and-shoot cameras have an LCD that you can use to compose images, action cams usually do not.
Even if you have an LCD, it's difficult to watch it underwater, and the correct picture setting is a matter of luck.
So you take a lot of pictures.
If your camera has a bracketing mode that allows you to take a series of shots with slightly different exposure settings, use it.
Stay close to the surface.
The light gets dramatically worse the further you move away from the surface.
So if possible, stay close to the surface when taking pictures in a pool, a lake or the sea.
This also allows you to add more color to your photos; the deeper you go, the less color you will see.
Get close to the objects.
This is also good advice on land, but it is even more important under water because of the poor lighting conditions.
It is especially important if you work with an action cam: These devices often have a fixed wide-angle lens, which means you need to get closer to your subjects if you want them to fill the entire frame.
Andrew Lawson was the sort of man whose character changes things, even in such a huge organisation as the NHS.
As a consultant anaesthetist, he dedicated his career to the task of sparing the sick both the agony of the disease and the agony of treatment.
Among his patients, his wife recalls, was an MI6 employee who had to live with the devastating effects of torture.
Lawson knew that the diagnoses and illnesses were important to the doctors, while the people being treated were mostly busy with something completely different: Pain.
One day in 2007, however, he was the one whose suffering began.
"I did not feel," he wrote in May of this year.
I had trouble getting up.
As he struggled with the flu-like symptoms, he noticed that he was impatiently blaming his wife Juliet.
"I want everything right now rather than later," he noted.
When Juliet was on a business trip for a week, Lawson felt unusually and without reason worried.
Something was in the air.
He asked a colleague to do an X-ray of his chest.
Only two weeks ago he had been in the French Alps for skiing.
The result of the X-ray examination was available.
He suffered from mesothelioma, an incurable cancer that attacks the pleura, the skin covering the lungs.
As with most cancers, the exact trigger is usually difficult to determine.
For example, while some smokers develop lung cancer, not all lung cancer patients have been smokers in the past.
But mesothelioma is different.
In almost all cases, the trigger is asbestos exposure - contact with the fibre building material, which was once considered a "miracle material" but has now been recognised as fatal.
For most of us mesothelioma is a disease that we can easily ignore.
After all, asbestos is a product of the past.
The most dangerous type of asbestos has not been used in the United Kingdom since the 1960s, when industry voluntarily undertook not to use it.
Even where it was still in use, only people in certain industries worked directly with the fabric - plumbers, construction workers, carpenters and shipyard workers, for example.
As an industrial hazardous substance from another time, it hardly seems to be a cause for concern today.
But this complacency is misplaced.
Britain, it seems, is today experiencing the peak of a mesolthelioma epidemic.
There are more deaths from mesothelioma here than in any other country in the world.
With a total of 2,500 deaths per year, twice as many people die from this disease as in traffic accidents.
Annual numbers of mesothelioma deaths since 1980 and projected future deaths in the UK
The reason why we are experiencing the deadly effects now, although asbestos has been illegal for years (in 1999 all types of asbestos were banned), is that mesothelioma develops only after decades.
And the scourge of mesothelioma is not limited to former workers in the construction industry.
Asbestos was, and often still is, present in the homes we live in, the offices we work in, the schools we study in and the shops we shop in.
And therefore mesothelioma knows no class barriers, financial limits, professions or age.
The privileged bastions, from the elegant department stores in London to private schools, are not a shelter.
The Parliament buildings are contaminated with asbestos.
Even in the hospitals, where we are supposed to get well after all, have already been identified as the initial focus of this deadly carcinogen.
Andrew Lawson was not old.
He wasn't a plumber either.
It was indeed difficult for him to imagine where he might have come into contact with asbestos.
Then he found out.
"It looks like there was a lot of asbestos in the tunnels at Guy's Hospital, where I did my training for six years," he wrote.
Everyone - students, nurses, doctors and doormen - use the tunnels.
One wonders how many of my peers will suffer from the same disease?
Unfortunately, he was able to answer this question at least partially.
"Of the four doctors trained at Guy's Hospital who have been diagnosed with mesothelioma in the last five years," he wrote in a letter in 2010, "I am the last one still alive.
How many more of us are gonna get sick?
Andrew Lawson was diagnosed with mesothelioma at the age of 48 years.
He was 55 when he died on 17 February of this year.
That was an unusually long survival period.
Fifty percent of all mesothelioma patients die within 8 months of diagnosis.
The disease is always fatal.
So we can only repeat Lawson's question: "How many more of us are going to get sick?"
The UK's leading expert on mesothelioma, Professor Julian Peto, estimates that between 1870 and 2050, when the asbestos epidemic in Britain is expected to come to a halt, a total of 90,000 people will have fallen victim to the disease.
Right now, most of them have no idea they're gonna die like this.
An asbestos mine in Quebec, Canada Alamy
A quick look at the files of the courts, to which the affected persons often turn for compensation claims, shows how widespread the scourge of mesothelioma already is.
In June of this year, for example, Marks & Spencer admitted to having negligently exposed Janice Allen to asbestos.
She worked for the chain for nine years, from 1978 to 1987, and was responsible for the clothing department at two locations - one of them the flagship store on Oxford Street.
Mrs. Allen was only 18 years old when she started working for M&S.
Now she has two kids in their twenties.
"Before this thing," she says, "I had never heard of mesothelioma, I didn't even really know anything about asbestos.
I never thought it would affect me.
There are few people who know much about asbestos.
The fact is that the term asbestos refers not to one substance but to a group of six minerals.
The name derives from the word "asbestos form", a description of the fibre structure that makes the material resistant and flexible.
Three of the six were used in the construction industry.
Chrysotile, also known as white asbestos, is by far the most commonly found asbestos in buildings today.
It was used for roof panels, floor panels, pipe insulation, boiler insulation, even for brake pads in cars.
It is less lethal than other forms of asbestos, but is still considered by the EU and WHO as a "major health risk" with possible fatal consequences.
However, brown asbestos (amosite) and blue asbestos (crocidolite) are more dangerous.
Britain was once the world's largest importer of brown asbestos, and experts suspect that "there is clear but indirect evidence that this was a major cause of the uniquely high mesothelioma rates.
A Marks & Spencer employee was exposed to asbestos at the flagship store in Oxford Street, London Alamy
Janice Allen may not have considered herself a typical mesothelioma victim, but the work of Julian Peto suggests that her story is by no means unusual.
He presented a study of the affected people, which shows that "a significant proportion of mesotheliomas without known exposure were caused by work or in the home probably by environmental exposure to asbestos.
According to him, a large part of these contacts are based on the "normal use and aging" of our buildings.
It seems that nobody can assume to be safe.
A report by Goddard Consulting, which investigated the Palace of Westminster, shows how people, even in the heart of government, may have been unknowingly exposed to the substance.
In 2009, Goddard reported that the service shafts and pipes behind the Parliament's committee rooms were contaminated with asbestos, the deadly fibres of which could be stirred up by something as harmless as "strong air movements".
Members of Parliament are often accused of looking after their own interests, but here it looks like the opposite is true.
While the Parliamentary Employment Service Directorate insisted that Westminster Palace had received a "clean bill of health", it is now clear that £1 billion of work over several years will be required to renovate the Parliament, modernise the electrical installations and remove asbestos, and that after the 2015 general election MPs are more likely to meet in the nearby QE2 conference centre than on the green benches at Westminster.
The Goddard report also pointed out that "the presence of asbestos was not handled in accordance with the relevant regulations.
No one can know if this mismanagement will cost lives.
All you can do now is wait.
One person who has never been able to accurately determine exposure to asbestos is Graham Abbott, a general practitioner.
Like Andrew Lawson, 50-year-old Abbott suspects that he was exposed to asbestos while working in hospitals.
"I have worked in a hospital where asbestos claims have been positively decided," he says, "but I can't prove it in my case.
It is so difficult to remember all the places you have worked and the dates.
What he remembers exactly is the day in early December 2009 when he got some kind of fever.
He was 45, and he was performing surgery just late at night.
Suddenly I had chills.
It was all of a sudden.
I felt terrible.
I didn't think I'd make the drive home.
As a doctor, Abbott knew that the pain came from the pleura, the skin around his lungs.
But like Janice Allen, he had no reason to suspect mesothelioma.
He didn't go to work for a month.
Surprised doctors took X-rays of his chest and applied pleural catheters to take fluid from his lungs and test it in the laboratory.
However, his complaints remained without diagnosis.
His health slowly improved and he returned to his workplace.
From time to time, however, the symptoms returned, often after exercise and heavy breathing.
In 2011 a patient of Abbott with similar symptoms came to his practice and was later diagnosed with mesothelioma.
But even now Abbott did not link this to his own case.
After all, his patient was several decades older and had worked directly with asbestos.
The connection in this case was clear.
In September 2011, Abbott's condition worsened again and his family doctor brought his CT scans and X-rays to an expert group.
In December 2011, exactly two years after Abbott first felt ill, a camera-equipped probe was inserted into the cavity between the pleura and the pleura.
I'm an optimist.
I usually just keep going," he says.
To be honest, I wasn't that worried.
But Rachel, my wife, was worried.
The result of the biopsy was available in the week between Christmas and New Year: "I was told it was mesothelioma."
Graham Abbott: Diagnosis Mesothelioma
Suddenly Abbott had appointments with Macmillan nurses, one of whom recommended that he get a lawyer.
Only now did he understand the scale of the epidemic.
"It turned out that asbestos was very common, especially in large public buildings where pipes were often insulated with asbestos," he says.
The people who were exposed to asbestos in these buildings are now falling ill.
And so mesothelioma now affects younger people who have not worked in the typical professions.
The most dangerous pipes with asbestos insulation in hospitals were underground, so patients were probably not exposed to the substance.
But many employees who moved from one building to another in pedestrian tunnels (like Andrew Lawson) or ate in underground canteens (as Graham Abbott often did) were most likely to come into contact with the toxic substances.
It turns out that for several decades after the war, hospitals may have been life-saving for patients, but life-threatening for the doctors treating them.
It is still being removed today.
Students placed their Bunsen burners on asbestos mats.
And it's not just hospitals.
Asbestos has been widely used in offices, shops, libraries and town halls due to its fabulous insulating and flame retardant properties.
Even schools.
In fact, many people have probably had their first contact with asbestos in a classroom.
All over the country, in thousands of chemistry lessons, schoolchildren have placed their Bunsen burners on asbestos mats.
The issue of asbestos in schools is now frequently raised on websites.
And meanwhile, such innocent objects in our homes as floor tiles or shed roofs have asbestos as standard.
"It's an industrial toxin that is present in much of our real estate," notes Andrew Morgan, the attorney who represented Andrew Lawson in his lawsuit against Guy's Hospital.
In one case, the only contact that came to mind for a woman affected was the demolition of a garden shed in the 1970s.
So watch how you tear down your garden shed.
The impact of the diagnosis, and the knowledge that the disease is incurable, is immense.
"It takes a while to process," says Graham Abbott.
I went back to work and tried to keep going, but I realized that I couldn't concentrate on what I was doing.
I spent two weeks in the office.
Then I knew I had to go and take care of myself.
Well, I'm not gonna have another Christmas.
One of the greatest difficulties was the change of perspective from the position of a doctor to that of a patient.
Like countless patients before him, he remembers how overwhelmed he was by all the information he had to cope with.
"It was very difficult to record all this," he says.
"I asked my doctor "how long do I have left?"
And they gave me about 12 more months.
I remember thinking, "Well, I'm not going to have another Christmas.
That's it.""
Mesothelioma is particularly insidious because it is our life-support mechanism - breathing itself - that causes the deadly cancer.
Most cases of mesothelioma are caused by contact with asbestos.
Asbestos consists of very small fibres.
When the asbestos is whirled up and the fibres are inhaled, they can settle in the pleura, the skin around the lungs.
Asbestos fibres irritate the pleura and can cause cell mutations.
"The problem arises with inhaled needle-shaped asbestos fibers," says Professor Tom Treasure, a cardiothoracic physician who moved to Guy's Hospital in 2001.
Ironically, the very hospital that Andrew Lawson suspects of having exposed him to asbestos is now, ironically, a leading center in the treatment of mesothelioma.
Treasure knew Lawson and treated some others who were probably also exposed to asbestos during their hospital training.
Once the asbestos needles reach the lung tissue, Treasure says, "the breathing process pushes them to the edge where the skin is.
By nature it is invasive from the beginning.
The usual options for other cancers do not work so well in mesothelioma.
The effectiveness of an operation, for example, is hotly disputed.
Some think it's worth a try.
Treasure denies it.
"You can't cut out the pleura," he says.
You can't get around it with a knife.
Meanwhile, the cancer "does not respond very well to chemotherapy," which "shows effect" but does not cure.
"Sometimes there are long-term survivors," Treasure says.
But in the end, they all die.
Fortunately, some patients actually live long, much longer than expected.
The author Stephen Jay Gould died 20 years after the diagnosis.
Two and a half years after his own diagnosis, Graham Abbott is still struggling.
After contacting Mesothelioma, Abbott got in touch with Andrew Lawson, who four years after his diagnosis had become a one-man support and counseling office for fellow sufferers.
"Hello, cancer control center," he'd answer the phone happily.
"It was very positive," Abbott says.
He had received his diagnosis 4 years earlier and was still very active.
Originally, Abbott had been offered six cycles of chemotherapy that would last four months and would likely extend his life by only one month.
"I was desperate," he says.
I was gonna give up.
But Lawson managed to "put things in a slightly more positive light."
After consulting several doctors, Abbott decided to continue his treatment with Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski, cardiothoracic specialist at Guy's.
"We had an advantage in that I didn't have to be referred, I just called and got an appointment," Graham admits.
A normal patient would have to receive a referral and wait for approval of the treatment.
Money is crucial for mesothelioma sufferers to be able to take advantage of the best available therapies.
But when these treatments inevitably fail in the end, many sufferers are left with another financial worry - about the future of the families they leave behind.
And so they turn to the courts in the hope of compensation.
Andrew Lawson contacted Andrew Morgan of Field Fisher Waterhouse LLP.
"It has been known since 1898 that asbestos is extremely dangerous to health," says Morgan.
But what changed in the 1960s was that it was recognized that even very low levels of exposure posed a health risk.
And this is where the negligence of the companies began to play a role.
Andrew Lawson and Guy's Hospital eventually settled their case, but it was not what Morgan calls "full compensation" because Lawson could not prove with absolute certainty that his mesothelioma was due to asbestos contact at Guy's.
However, after investigating his death, a spokesman for Guy's confirmed that "the asbestos fibers in the affected basement area were removed in the 1990s.
It was too late for Andrew Lawson.
How asbestos can be removed
In fact, for mesothelioma sufferers seeking compensation, it is a huge problem to attribute the fatal asbestos exposure to a company or workplace - usually decades after the incidents.
Many of their former employers have been sold or closed down.
Insurance documents can be lost.
And those who resist claims know that the time is for them, but certainly not with the plaintiffs.
In response, this year there has been significant new legislation that makes it easier for mesothelioma sufferers to claim compensation even if their previous employers are no longer to be found.
The Act has set up an insurance industry-sponsored fund of £350 million for anyone diagnosed after July 2012 who can prove they have had contact but cannot sue anyone.
In these cases, the plaintiffs receive 80 per cent of what a court could have awarded them in a normal damages case - about £120,000.
Some 300 successful applications to the programme are expected each year.
Andrew Morgan, like so many mesothelioma sufferers, thinks that £350 million is a "very good job" for the insurance industry.
"This is a deal by insurers for insurers," he says, suggesting that this amount is a quarter of what insurers would have had to pay if time hadn't passed and mesothelioma sufferers could find the companies and sue them normally.
Mike Penning, then Minister of Labour and Pensions, also admitted that the law was "not perfect".
But both Penning and Morgan admitted that, with seven deaths a day, quick action was necessary.
"People are suffering so much and need help today," Penning said during the second hearing of the Mesothelioma Act last December.
By this time Graham Abbott had been in the hands of Prof. Loic Lang-Lazdunski for 19 months.
After their initial consultations, Lang-Lazdunski recommended an operation from which he expected a positive effect, unlike Tom Treasure.
This was accompanied by radiotherapy and chemotherapy - a triple therapy with which Lang-Lazdunski can present a survival rate over five years of up to 40 percent.
Abbott felt strengthened.
"That's obviously one of the most important things," Abbott says.
You see this in patients all the time.
There's something that's gonna keep you going.
If you give up, you're gonna get worse real fast.
Graham Abbott underwent the operation in March 2012.
At the end of August he had completed the last of the six cycles of chemotherapy.
Aftercare scans showed no signs of the disease.
Then I had a scan in March 2014.
There were several cancer spots around my breast.
I just turned 50.
It's not life-threatening.
It's life-ending.
Again, Abbott underwent six cycles of chemotherapy.
Now there is no trace of the tumours visible.
But the process is physically and mentally very exhausting.
You need to think about practical things - about the money when I am no longer here, for example, or showing my wife how to set the boiler time.
When you receive bad news, you become negative.
You must look ahead.
As the father of Ellie, 16, and Tamsin, 14, it's not always easy.
"It's hard for parents," he says.
It's hard to know what to say and how much.
When I received my first diagnosis, I told my girls that I had a disease that I would not grow old with.
They reacted very differently.
Tamsin is very sociable and impetuous.
She told her friends and we soon got a lot of phone calls.
Ellie was more reserved.
She didn't say much.
Such conversations are something that all cancer patients have to go through.
But for mesotheliomeric patients such conversations are not tinged with hope, not a trace of hope for survival.
The disease brings (as it ultimately did for Stephen Jay Gould) a grim security.
As Andrew Morgan says, "Mesothelioma is not life-threatening.

China denies Hong Kong right to government election, demonstrators swear revenge
On Sunday the Chinese parliament decided against the nomination of candidates for the 2017 elections by Hong Kong's electorate, despite increased calls for democratic reforms.
This move is likely to fuel the long-announced protests in Hong Kong's business district, while activists began planning and mobilizing within hours of the announcement.
The decision of the Chinese People's Congress allows the communist leaders in principle to reject all candidates who are not loyal to Beijing.
"This is not unexpected, but it makes us angry," said legal expert Emily Lau, leader of the Democratic Party.
This is not what Beijing promised.
The people of Hong Kong have been lied to.
And it is clear that we are dealing with an authoritarian regime.
In his defence of the Chinese decision, Li Fei, Deputy Secretary General of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said that allowing public nominations in the elections would be too "chaotic" for the Hong Kong government.
Since 1997, when Britain returned control of Hong Kong to the Chinese, Beijing has promised to let its people elect the head of government from 2017.
The Chinese leadership presented Sunday's decision as a democratic breakthrough because it gives Hong Kong citizens a direct right to vote, but the decision also makes it clear that the Chinese leadership is keeping a firm grip on the process through a closely Beijing-controlled nomination committee.
In addition, a new clause stipulates that only candidates "with love for the country and love for Hong Kong" will be admitted.
The decision follows a summer that saw some of the largest and most high-profile protests in Hong Kong for several years.
Behind the pro-democracy campaign in Hong Kong is the movement Occupy Central With Love and Peace, whose organisers have threatened to close down the financial district if Beijing does not allow genuine universal suffrage.
On Sunday evening, within hours of the announcement, hundreds of Occupy-Central supporters had gathered in the rain outside the Hong Kong government headquarters.
During the demonstration, the organizers said that their movement had reached a new level of civil disobedience and that they were planning waves of protest in the coming weeks.
However, they did not provide further details on this, apparently in order to avoid problems with the authorities.
In an online communication, the organizers announced that the movement "has considered the occupation of the central district only as a last resort, an action that should only take place when all opportunities for dialogue have been exhausted and there is no other choice.
We are sorry to say that today all opportunities for dialogue have been exhausted and the occupation of the Central District will definitely take place.
The Hong Kong authorities have been preparing for days for Beijing's announcement, and tightened security measures, including police forces and barricades, were in place outside the government building on Sunday.
The unrest is compounded by the feeling of many in Hong Kong that they are slowly losing control of their city.
The influx of people from the mainland increases competition for products and services.
There is also a growing fear that Hong Kong's values such as democracy and freedom of speech are beginning to crumble under growing pressure from Beijing.
Some criticised the demonstrations by the Occupy Central movement for endangering business operations - Hong Kong's lifeline.
"The protests they are talking about could cause great economic damage, depending on how many are involved and how long they last," said legal expert Regine Ip, who has long criticised the movement.
We do not want to arouse any fears that Hong Kong will get out of control.
This impression is bad for investments.
China's state-controlled media also recently reported on democracy activists in Hong Kong as subversive agents controlled by Western powers.
This summer, activists organised an unofficial referendum on voting rights, in which 780,000 people took part - more than a fifth of Hong Kong's electorate.
In July, tens of thousands took part in one of the largest democracy demonstrations in the history of the region.

Feminists criticize race issue and police behavior after Ferguson
The unarmed teenager was killed earlier this month by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo.
The participants raised their hands in the air and sang, "Hands up, don't shoot," while waiting for the funeral.
After two weeks of protests in Ferguson, Mo, over the shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown, blogger Miriam Zoila Perez noted a change in online discussions among white feminists.
In their experience, white feminist commentators put gender before race when it comes to addressing reproductive rights and income inequalities.
However, as tensions rose in the Midwest and received attention across the country, Perez saw that white women's responses were 100% race related.
Compared with the responses of black women shortly after the August 9 shooting, the personal essays with titles such as "Thoughts on Ferguson by a White Woman" and "Feminism is not just about the oppression of women" came relatively late.
But for Perez, this meant an important change.
"I don't think you find many people in feminism who talk about being white and privileges in such a high-class way," she said.
People felt compelled to express something about the incidents.
It is characteristic of the crisis we are in and because the situation in Ferguson is so ethnicized that they have to express that.
For English professor Koritha Mitchell of Ohio State University, Ferguson brought to light problems that black American women face every day, but which are not considered "women's issues" in the cultural arena.
"I can post something funny about me and my partner on Facebook and get 150 likes from anywhere," Mitchell said.
When I post something about how colored people are under siege in their own country, the silence is deafening.
"How can it be safe for women to talk about a relationship in public, but not about safety in public space?" she asked.
For black women like Mitchell, who have studied race, gender and sexuality in the history of the US, there is no dichotomy between race and gender issues.
For them, black women have not had the luxury of neatly separating the issues; they live in the combined reality every day.
While white women now link the issues of race and gender in mainstream feminist circles, Angela Hattery, professor of women and gender studies at George Mason University, says that her predecessors did the opposite.
"Between 1865 and 1890, at least 10,000 black men were lynched and the reason was almost always the rape of a white woman," Hattery said.
White women had to be involved in the story to justify the lynching.
For Hattery, the split between white and black women came at the point where white women campaigners for women's suffrage like Susan B. Anthony analyzed the country in the late years of the 19th century and found that the fight for the right to vote could only be successful for one group at a time: Women or black people.
"They made the decision to campaign for women's suffrage, and black suffrage was to come later," Hattery said.
When you remember such things, you become powerfully aware of why colored women do not trust white women.
We didn't do our job well.
We have never helped black women protect their husbands and sons.
Even after women were given the right to vote in 1920, it took a decade before white women organized against lynching in the Association of Southern Woman for the Prevention of Lynching.
The group was formed almost 40 years after the original request for help from black women, says Mitchell.
For Mitchell, the flood of white feminist reactions to the issues raised by Ferguson - police behaviour, racial discrimination - is a mirror of the times when white feminists "played catch" with the problems black women have faced for generations.
"Wouldn't it be great if activists who have such traditional feminist platforms took the right to raise a child as seriously as they take the right to birth control," Mitchell asked.
Second generation feminists who built their careers on the struggle for reproductive rights and access to contraceptives are now trying to understand what this means.
The well-known white feminist activist Gloria Steinem went on Facebook two weeks after the shooting of Michael Brown and published a trenchant article by Rebecca Carroll, a columnist for the Guardian, calling for more protests from white Americans on the issue of racism.
"I hope that women who have a different but parallel reason to understand an inherent danger in the body - and opinions about race that are significantly different in public opinion polls - will lead the changes," Steinem wrote.
Although Steinem stands for a more intersectional feminism that addresses both racial and gender issues, some are stunned by her comments on the race issue in America.
Christina Sommers, a researcher at the American Enterprise Institute and author of "Who Stole Feminism?" told She The People that young men in the United States, especially young coloured men, "are far more vulnerable than their sisters," but Steinem's comments on Ferguson contradicted her earlier criticism.
There are now hundreds of special programmes for girls and young women, but almost nothing for boys.
But when the White House recently launched a small program, My Brother's Keeper, to help vulnerable young black and Hispanic men, there were angry reactions from many feminists, including Gloria Steinem.
The relationship between the police and the black community is not the only problem that is pushing itself to the forefront of mainstream feminism.
After the US Border Patrol apprehended nearly 63,000 unaccompanied minors on the country's southwestern border this year, the issue of immigration reform is also coming to the surface again - this time as a women's issue.
Andrea Mercado, co-chair of We Belong Together, an organization that mobilizes women for immigration reform, said that to reconsider the issue as a major women's issue, all she has to do is publish the stories of immigrant women.
"These speak for themselves," said Mercado.
When the vast majority of work visas are issued to male immigrants, the women who accompany them are in a position where they are vulnerable to domestic violence and exploitation.
"These stories resonate with women's organisations," she said.

Leonidas invited to the gladiatorial arena
Not only the gladiators stood ankle-deep in the mud at the first Rheinbach Roman Day in the amusement park.
However, the event's appeal was strong enough to attract well over 1000 visitors yesterday, who braved the rain showers and autumnal cold and were completely enthralled by the historical spectacle.
There was a colourful array of representations, performances, games, exhibits and information about the time of the Romans and their significance for the Rhineland.
The main attraction of the day was undoubtedly the martial fighting troops from the gladiator school "Amor Mortis", who used every break in the rain to demonstrate their robust fighting skills in the arena prepared with soft sand.
Gladiator owner "Leonidas" proved to be a humorous and knowledgeable presenter and sent his men one after the other into the ring for heroic duels in different gladiatorial genres.
First it was the "Provocators"' turn with a rectangular shield and short sword as well as a leg splint on the left leg and an arm splint on the right arm.
This was followed by the "Essedarii" with breast shield, short sword and throwing plant as well as iron gladiator helmet, leg and arm protection.
Especially impressive was the performance of the "Retiarius", who competed against the "Secutor" with a throwing net, trident and dagger and knocked the fellow down after a short fight.
There the swords clashed metallically, the shields rattled and the plants flew buzzing through the arena, which could make one fear and anxiety for the health of the gladiators.
But the impressive "Summa Rudis", the muscular referee, always had an attentive eye on them.
"We wanted to revive everyday Roman life and make the culture of Roman times tangible," said Lorenz Euskirchen, chairman of the organizer "Freundeskreis Römerkanal", explaining the intention behind the spectacle.
After two years of preparation, the amusement park became for one day an "Oppidum Romanum", a Roman city, as Vice Mayor Claus Wehage stated in his greeting.
After all, the Romans did not only bring war and conquest to our region, but also the Roman culture and numerous buildings that we still admire today.
Remains of it could also be marvelled at on the occasion of the Roman Day, such as "aqueduct marble" from the eleven-metre high and 1400-metre long Roman canal bridge, which once stood near Lüftelberg.
The Frontinus company juxtaposed water and energy supply in the past and now, and Managing Director Petra Fricke knew: "We still benefit today from the knowledge of that time".
This was also confirmed by surveyor Ralph Heiliger from the "IngenieurteamZwei" from Rheinbach, who presented surveying instruments of the Romans such as Chorobat, Groma or Dioptra.
The Roman Villa in Blankenheim presented sketches and models from the excavations in 1894 as well as bricks from the original hypocaust, the hot-air heating system that once heated the Roman Villa.
Also impressive are the footprints left by wolves and foxes two millennia ago in the clay kicks before they were fired.
In 2011, the Office for the Preservation of Archaeological Monuments at the Rhineland Regional Association had excavated the remains of a Roman villa in the Gewerbepark Nord in Rheinbach.
The walls of a farm building with a kiln for drying grain and malting were found.
The building probably belonged to a Villa Rustica, an agricultural estate, explained archaeologist Dr. Jennifer Morscheiser.
She presented a number of finds from these excavations in a glass showcase, including a large plate, several fine glass vessels and parts of a delicate necklace.
The villa probably existed from the first to the fourth century A.D. until the Germanic invasion of the then Roman Rhineland, Morscheiser suspects.
The children were also occupied with the Roman windmill game, similar to today's mill game, or they wrote their names on wax tablets with metal pens, just like the Roman schoolchildren of old.
At the stand of the Roman Baths Zülpich the children were allowed to lay mosaics themselves, at the stand of the Glass Museum Rheinbach they could make glass mosaics and at the stand of the Nature Centre Eifel Nettersheim they could operate a heavy wheat mill made of stone to grind the flour for a flat bread or muesli.
The visitors drove through the amusement park in a faithfully reproduced Roman touring car pulled by two cold-blooded horses and also passed the impressive stand of the Städtisches Gymnasium, which presented the results of its "Roman Project Weeks" here.
With a Roman Week from 13 to 21 September, the Wachtberg community will also be involved in the Roman Year 2014, which has been proclaimed throughout the Rhineland and is intended to commemorate the death of Emperor Augustus 2000 years ago.
Together with the local history and history associations as well as the Wachtberger Wander-Verein, the Partnerschaftsverein and the Laienspielkreis Oberbachem, thematic hikes, a lecture, cooking evenings as well as guided tours for school classes are offered and remind of Wachtberg's Roman past.
For example, a Roman legionnaire will talk about his work on the draughty Wachtberg, plants will be presented as living monuments from Roman times and a witty lesson in international understanding between a group of Wachtberg "Germanic tribesmen" and Romans who have moved to the area will be presented.
The Adendorf primary school dedicates a project week to the Roman theme.
With the Roman Week, the numerous traces of the Romans in Wachtberg, which are often no longer visible at first glance, are to be made tangible again.
A small presentation in the Wachtberg town hall will commemorate the discovery of the Berkum Matron Shrine in 1879.
Ebola: Epidemic burdens West Africa's economy
The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is also a severe blow to the economy.
Markets are orphaned - and international companies keep their distance.
The devastating Ebola epidemic dealt a severe blow to the economy of West Africa.
The harvest rots in the fields, the mines are abandoned and the markets deserted - the virus has severely affected the region.
Even some international companies are already distancing themselves.
"The Ebola epidemic is not only a medical crisis, but also an economic one," says Donald Kaberuka, head of the African Development Bank.
Liberia is hardest hit
"It is a total disaster, we are losing a lot of money," says Alhaji Bamogo, who sells clothes at the second largest market in Liberia's capital Monrovia.
Only those who want to buy food or something to disinfect against Ebola are allowed on the market.
Liberia has been hit hardest by the virus, with more than 600 people killed by the fever in this country alone.
Recently, the health authorities declared that the disease had spread to every corner of the country.
The virus has also spread in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Nigeria.
In total, more than 1500 people have already died, and thousands more have been infected.
Foreign companies are withdrawing employees
Everywhere in the resource-rich countries, companies are suspending their operations.
Foreign companies such as the steel group Arcelor Mittal are withdrawing their employees, and several international airlines are no longer flying to the affected regions.
Local traders and farmers are also reacting: Only few merchants still leave their home towns to get supplies.
In some areas in Sierra Leone and Liberia, which are under quarantine, cocoa and coffee beans, which are important for export, are rotting in the fields.
The farmers do not dare to leave their homes for the harvest.
Food is becoming scarce
"People will travel less and less," says Phillipe De Vreyer, Parisian expert on the economy of West Africa.
The man, for example, who normally goes to the market and sells his vegetables, prefers to stay at home.
The population is therefore feeling the consequences of the epidemic directly and urgently: food is becoming scarce.
Stocks of staple foods such as rice are dwindling in the markets.
At the same time, the region, which is heavily dependent on international companies, is threatened with damage to its image - with far-reaching consequences.
The greatest danger is that international companies will avoid the area for a long time, says Philippe Hugon from the French think tank Iris.
The decisive factor is how far and how long the virus will continue to spread.
Investors could get the impression "that it is dangerous to live in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, and therefore to invest", warns Hugon.
The disease also burdens the strained national budgets of the states
The disease is also a burden on the already strained national budgets of the affected states.
The rating agency Moody's fears that their budgets will be severely strained by high spending on the health care system and additionally by the deteriorating economy.
The African Development Bank has already promised to help the health systems of the countries concerned with 60 million dollars (45 million euros).
The effects are also already noticeable in Nigeria, where only a few cases of Ebola have been diagnosed so far.
It is true that the oil-rich region in the southern Niger Delta has not been affected so far.
But elsewhere, many people are already staying at home for fear of infection.
Reservations in hotels are also declining significantly.
Shooters celebrate their 50th anniversary
The shooting club "Tannenwald" Berngau celebrates its 50th anniversary from September 12 to 14.
Preparations are in full swing at the Tannenwald Shooting Club for the 50th anniversary celebrations from 12 to 14 September.
A big entertainment evening with the group "Dorfrocker" is planned for Friday, September 12.
On saturday at 6pm is the big firecracker shooting.
Afterwards, there will be an atmospheric evening with the "Stoapfälzer Spitzbuam" in the large marquee.
Brass band provides the music
Highlights on Sunday are the festive service and 9.30 am in the parish church and the big procession at 2 pm.
In the afternoon there is also the prize giving of the federal and Gaussian shooting.
A particularly beautiful sight will be the 25 festival ladies with their dirndls.
The festival band is the brass band Berngau.
Mayor Wolfgang Wild and State Secretary Albert Füracker have taken over the patronage.
The original name "Schützengesellschaft Tannenwald Berngau" dates back to 1907, when the association for "social entertainment by means of practice in room nozzle and small bore shooting" was founded on 21 March.
In 1937, the Nazi regime had initiated the dissolution of the association.
It was not until 1964 that 19 young men came together again, who on 30 April in Gasthaus Lukas launched the "new" shooting club "Tannenwald" Berngau.
Karl März and Adolf Ried led the club as master shooters through a difficult initial period, in which the main task was to find a clubhouse and install the shooting equipment.
As early as autumn 1965 the shooting club started in the "Leininger" inn with two teams in the round competitions.
In the following years, the sport shooters, who were now organized in seven teams, established themselves in all classes up to the 1st Gauliga.
The club records tumbled every year and the magic limit of 380 rings was first reached by Rudi Meier in 1980.
Just as the performance of active shooters has increased, so has the number of members.
After the clubhouse "Leininger" no longer met the requirements of a modern shooting club, the then board of directors under the leadership of Johann Rinn decided to create a future domicile in the cellar rooms of the new "Landgasthof Härteis".
After 2700 hours of work, on May 8, 1988, Pastor Strasser gave the church blessing for the new rifle ranges.
One of the great highlights in the history of the club was certainly the 44th Gauschießen, combined with the ceremonial consecration of the new marksman flag in July 1991.
On April 23 and 24, 1994 the shooting club celebrated its 30th anniversary.
In 1995 a banger group was founded.
Josef Schmalzl became a boeller referent.
A big challenge for the "boellerer" and for the association as a whole was the organisation of the Bavarian boeller meeting 2005.
In many hours of voluntary work, the club members modernised the rooms and the shooting range in the Berngauer Hof last year, bringing them up to the latest state of the art.
Eleven teams in lap competitions
The sporting achievements of the shooting club can also be seen.
A total of eleven teams are currently participating in the round robin competitions: six air rifle teams, one air pistol team, one KK1 sport pistol team, one youth team and two AH teams.
The 1st team with Lars Ellrich, Katharina Ellrich, Steffi Grad and Kerstin Kellermann has moved up from the Gauoberliga (highest league in the Schützengau ANB) to the Bezirksliga 1 in the 2013/14 round.
The 2nd team with Verena Moosburger Alexandra Meier, Eva Schuhmann and Tobias Graml has moved up from the Gauliga Nord to the Gauoberliga.
In addition to the shooting sport, events such as buck shooting, carnival and king's ball, club outings and Christmas parties have a long tradition.
The marksmen are also present at the festivals in the parish and community.

Just try it out: Laura, Lena, Lisa, Marie, Bettina, Emma and director Lisa Neitzel (from the left) are looking forward to welcoming their comrades-in-arms.

"Three in the group of eight to twelve-year-olds, six in the group of twelve to 15-year-olds," says the 20-year-old.
With more active people, the whole thing would be much more fun, "you could dance completely different choreographies," she says.
Those who feel like dancing can join the training session on Thursdays between 5 and 6 p.m. or on Fridays between 5 and 6.30 p.m. in the dance hall at the former Hotel Meyer, Freistraße 9, without obligation.

Afterwards different choreographies are rehearsed.
JazzDance has the characteristic that there is no fixed form and is therefore open to many styles.
Elements from folklore and classical music to sport and acrobatics are used in jazz dance.
Of course the sociability does not come too briefly.

In a group you can make friends, share a wonderful hobby and do a lot for your own motor development.

Genetic disorder often misdiagnosed
One British woman says she thought she would die as a result of a misdiagnosis over many years.
Karin Rodgers lived almost her entire youth in the belief that she had only a few years to live after being diagnosed with another disease.
She actually suffered from Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) - a group of inherited disorders that damage nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.
Charity CMT UK said that misdiagnosis is a common problem for people with CMT because so little is known about the disease.
Approximately 23,000 people in the UK are believed to suffer from CMT, which can lead to motor disorders such as muscle weakness, unsteady gait and bent toes.
Patients also suffer from numbness or pain. The disease is incurable and progressive, which means that the symptoms get worse over time.
When Rodgers was 13, she believed that she suffered from Friedreich's Ataxia (FA), a disease with very poor survival chances.
Rodgers thought she would be in a wheelchair before she turned 18 and die before her 30th birthday.
The mother of two children, now 51 years old, said: "As a child, I knew that I could not do the same thing as the others.
I kept falling down and everything took longer with me.
I could never roller-skate or skateboard with the other children and was often teased at school about the way I walked and skated.
Rodgers said that at the age of 13, after several operations to relieve her Achilles tendon and stretch her feet, she looked at her medical records when her doctor left the room and read that she suffered from FA.
"I felt guilty because I was curious, so I didn't tell anyone, but I went home, looked for the disease in the library and wrote to the FA Society," she said.
When I received an answer, I was shocked and panicked terribly.
I thought that I would be in a wheelchair at 18 and die at 25, and in between slowly losing all my abilities.
I went through all this alone with myself and planned my own funeral.
She said that when she turned 17, she realized that her abilities had not decreased as much as she had imagined and consulted her doctor.
He just stood up and hugged me and said, "my dear, I don't think you have, or you'd be in a wheelchair by now."
I think you have something far less life-threatening.
After some genetic tests she was diagnosed with CMT.
"When he explained to me what CMT was, I felt like a winner," she said.
Charity CMT UK has launched a CMT awareness month to raise awareness of this disease.
Former staff sergeant Berni Diether has been working as a fireworker since the closure of the former military training area
For almost ten years, there has been no shooting on the former military training area in Münsingen.
Nevertheless, lethal ammunition still appears every month in the heart of the Swabian Alb biosphere reserve.
