Since that time, the 6500 hectare area has been the core of the Swabian Alb biosphere reserve, which is open to hikers and cyclists on 13 marked trails.
Tax burden of businessmen in the Washington area increases with economic recovery
An economic recovery means more customers, more sales and new jobs.
It also means higher taxes.
State and local tax assessments for companies in the country rose slightly last year as the economic recovery accelerated, according to a newly released study last week, and companies in the Washington area were no exception.
Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia area collectively paid $27.6 billion to state and local governments in fiscal 2013, an increase of 3.8 percent from the $26.6 billion in 2012.
The state and local corporate tax burden increased by 4.3 percent to $671 billion last year, compared to 3.9 percent the year before, and it was the third consecutive year of growth after several years of declining tax assessments in 2009 and 2010.
State taxes rose more than local taxes, by 4.3 percent, according to the study, which was conducted by the service agency Ernst & Young with the Center for State Taxation, a tax policy group.
More than half of the district's tax revenue, 56 percent, comes from corporate taxes, while 36 percent of Maryland's revenue comes from businesses.
Virginia generates the lowest tax revenue from companies, at 28 percent.
Much of the increase in tax revenues is due to a recovery in corporate real estate values, the researchers say, leading to a 3.7 percent increase in real estate taxes this year after three consecutive years of growth rates of less than 1 percent.
While a large part of these profits came from large states such as California, New York and Texas, the process also seems to apply to the Washington area.
Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia together paid over $10 billion in state and local real estate taxes last year, compared to $9.6 billion in 2012 - a 4.2 percent increase over the course of a year.
But the apparent recovery in real estate values is not as effective in increasing state and local tax revenues in Maryland, where real estate taxes account for just over one-fifth of corporate tax returns.
Companies in Virginia and D.C. pay almost half of their state and local taxes in the form of real estate taxes.
"Here's what's happening in Maryland: a large percentage of real estate, particularly in the tax zone around D.C., is either owned by the government or by non-profit organizations that don't pay real estate taxes," said Douglas Lindholm, executive director of the Center on State Taxation.
Maryland is therefore forced to rely much more on income taxes, for example, to provide the same services that other states offer.
The recent recovery in corporate tax revenues cannot be attributed solely to the recovery in the real estate market
Corporate revenues also appear to be recovering, according to the data.
Companies in the region reported income taxes paid to government organizations of $2.3 billion compared to $2.1 billion in 2012.
Maryland raised $1 billion in corporate income taxes, the highest in the region.
While the trend is in the same direction, the local tax burden for companies is not increasing equally in all three places.
The rate of increase in the district was 4.3 percent, in line with the national average, while the increase in Maryland was much higher, 4.9 percent.
Only Virginia reported below-average tax revenues of 4.1 percent.
Virginia has by far the lowest corporate income tax rates, at 6 percent in all three offices (all three have fixed corporate tax rates).
The corporate tax rate is 8.25 percent in Maryland and a relatively high 9.975 percent in the district.
A similar study by the US Chamber of Commerce earlier this year showed that Virginia has lower state and local corporate taxes and a better overall tax climate than Maryland.
In the study the district was not examined.
Despite its advantages, Virginia is under pressure from its southern neighbor.
North Carolina has passed legislation to lower its corporate tax rates this year from 6.9 percent to 6 percent, the same rate as Virginia, and the rate will drop to 5 percent next year.
If the state continues to meet its income targets in the coming year, this law could reduce the state's corporate income tax rate to 3 percent by 2017.
Meanwhile, small businesses in the Washington area seem to be doing better, and therefore paying more state and local taxes, according to the latest study.
Corporate taxes paid as personal income taxes by small businessmen - a transitional structure under which most small businesses are organized - in the District, Maryland and Virginia rose 20 percent last year to $2.4 billion, a much faster growth rate than corporate taxes overall.
The researchers say that the trend and increase in corporate taxes across the country is likely to continue this year, with a 6.2 percent increase in overall additional tax revenues for the state and local governments in the first three quarters of 2014 compared to the same period last year.
Nevertheless, the Washington area could lag behind if the federal government's spending cuts affect the region's labor market.
Twin city: German beer for Guangzhou
Hops and malt - a popular combination also in China.
German beer enjoys an excellent reputation in China.
Frankfurt's twin city in China now wants a brewery and is also hoping for a direct flight connection between the two cities.
German beer, brewed in Frankfurt's twin city Guangzhou - this is the urgent wish of the officials in China.
"We would be very happy if a German brewery were to settle in our city," said the vice party secretary of the southern Chinese metropolis, Li Yiwei, during a visit of an SPD delegation to his city this week.
Time and again during the course of the conversation, the functionary of the ruling Communist Party of China returned to this concern of the twelve million metropolis.
Guangzhou, which is also called Kanton in Germany, is one of the richest cities in China, Li advertised.
This is why people have the purchasing power to be able to afford German beer.
Hessian SPD leader Thorsten Schäfer-Gümbel, who led the German political delegation, promised the host that he would look around in Germany for a possible partner for the project.
"It doesn't take much for beer: good water, grain and joie de vivre," he added at a lunch with the party leader in Guangzhou.
Mr. Li already radiated this joy of life, he flattered the host.
Thereupon the functionary from Guangzhou toasted with Schäfer-Gümbel - but with red wine, which was served with the meal.
The Chinese brand Tsingtao goes back to the German art of brewing.
Tsingtao beer is brewed according to the German Purity Law.
More business traffic
A second wish of the Chinese hosts would be a direct flight connection between Frankfurt and Guangzhou, said Vice-Party Leader Li.
Lufthansa had offered the flight earlier, but cancelled it in 2012 for economic reasons.
"It would be worth it again," the local politician was convinced.
"Business traffic between our two cities continues to grow."
Currently, travelers must take the detour via Changsha in Hunan Province, Li complained.
The administration of Guangdong province, whose capital is Guangzhou, is also hoping for the flight connection.
The vice governor of the province, Chen Yunxian, emphasized this wish during his talks with the Social Democrats.
"That's a very good idea," Schäfer-Gümbel replied - Chinese Vice Minister Li Jinjun, an intimate connoisseur of Germany, nodded in agreement.
Cultivated partnership
The affable deputy party leader of Guangzhou hopes to visit Frankfurt next year for a partnership meeting.
Li Yiwei was already on the Main, but not yet in this function.
He only came into office this year after his predecessor was promoted from office on corruption charges.
The local party leader Wan Qinglian also had to leave.
The action against Guangzhou officials is part of a nationwide campaign against corruption in the party and administration, which is being vigorously pursued by head of state Xi Jinping.
The new top politician Li Yiwei had worked for an American company before his party career, which is highly unusual in the Chinese Communist Party.
Before taking office in Guangzhou, he was a top functionary in Fujian, where the car manufacturer VW is building a large plant.
Frankfurt has officially entered into more than a dozen city partnerships.
The connection to Guangzhou, 9000 kilometres away, is one of those that is maintained by both sides, for example through a student exchange.
Last year the 25th anniversary of the German-Chinese connection was celebrated.
With its economic power, the southern Chinese metropolis on the Pearl River is almost as strong as the whole of Hessen.
Next year, it wants to achieve a gross domestic product of 250 billion euros, Li reported.

Instead, it quickly became a platform for players who wanted to publish their bravura in games, a "YouTube for live games," according to an insider.
The Twitch interface.
And "let's play", a video genre in which know-it-alls give the (mostly older) games a touch of secret science theatre, is already very popular on YouTube.
It's just that YouTube is often mentioned when trying to describe Twitch, so the news that YouTube was going to buy Twitch was received somewhat bored, a textbook example of an established engineering company buying up a potential competitor.
It's a mystery why the deal with YouTube didn't happen, as the company was reportedly willing to pay as much as Amazon.
All we know about it right now is this statement from Emmet Shear, president of Twitch: "We chose Amazon because they believe in our community, they share our values and long-term vision, and they want to help us get there faster.
Another secret is, quite honestly, the incredible success of Twitch.
For snobs like me, who say they prefer to play sports rather than watch, it's hard to understand the attraction of watching others play instead of taking control of the console.
It's one thing to look over a friend's shoulder at 3 a.m. as she sneaks through Resident Evil, and it's quite another to watch a wacko get shot in the head 20 times in a row in Call of Duty.
You could be watching all these games right now.
Another problem is that many of the most popular games today are first-person games, so watching them without any control over your perspective can be a really good recipe for headaches.
I admit that the fast-paced games in which the Roger Bannisters of our electronic age complete entire games in record time are entertaining.
But as long as there isn't a game or humor virtuoso involved, his twitch channel probably isn't that interesting.
But what do skeptics like me know about it?
Twitch is accessed by 55 million different visitors per month and is the fourth largest source of Internet traffic peaks.
And how exactly does Amazon want to make money out of this?
It's hard to imagine Twitch being integrated into Amazon Instant Video as elegantly as YouTube could have easily swallowed Twitch.
But Twitch has something that every company would like to have: thousands of young men who are courted as advertisers.
As the chairman of Twitch, Shear, said, Amazon and Twitch "both believe in the future of gaming," and the medium shows no signs of shrinkage, not even - gulp - as a spectator sport.

After that one could look further.
Clever ways to save on university textbooks
Since the cost of university textbooks is more than $1,000 per year for many students, almost two-semester student Matt Schroeder came up with a clever savings idea.
He invented a loan system for books from students in higher semesters and offered nominal compensation to delay the resale.
"My math book usually costs $180, but I got it for $10 for a semester and a Chick-fil-A cookie," said Schroeder, 19, who attends Covenant College in Georgia.
The books needed for the last semester cost him $430, he said.
He spent $120.
The college administration said that students spend an average of more than $1,200 a year on textbooks and study materials, but that there are several cost-containment options for students.
Online shops and creative approaches like the Schroeders are increasingly the solution of choice for students.
Textbook rentals are becoming more popular, allowing students to use a book for a semester, often at a much lower price than when they bought it.
Neebo Inc, which operates more than 250 university bookstores, reported that textbook rentals have doubled since 2011.
Industry surveys show that about a quarter of the books in college bookstores were rented last spring semester, said Neebos vice president Tevor Meyer.
Less than half of all textbooks are bought in campus bookstores, according to the trade association National Association of College Stores.
Here is the multiplication table for the best deals.
Buy online
Some new books cost only a third of the price of those available in the Campus bookshop.
The ninth edition of "Calculus" vno Ron Larwon, Bruce Edwards and Robert Hostetler costs almost $290, but can be purchased from specialized textbook retailer Chegg.com for $239.99.
Buy used
If you don't mind the notes of others or normal traces of use, used books are a good option.
"Calculus" is available on Chegg.com for $93.49.
Matt Casaday, 25, a graduate student at Brigham Young University, says he spent 42 cents on Amazon.com for a used copy of "Strategic Media Decisions: Understanding The Business End Of The Advertising Business."
The book sold new for $48.
Academics such as Ingrid Bracey, head of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst College Without Walls, recommended that students ask their professors whether previous editions were permissible.
Sometimes the updates are not relevant for the seminar papers.
In such cases, older editions can often be purchased for a fraction of the cost of the latest edition.
Besides Chegg and Amazon, Half.com from eBay Inc is a popular alternative for used books.
Rents
Hiring textbooks is worth considering if you treat them reasonably well, remember to return them and you do not want to keep the books after the course is over.
You can save more than 80 percent of the cost of a newly purchased book.
For example, a student could rent "Calculus" for the duration of a semester for about $20.
Find out about the terms and conditions of the shop where you are renting from, including any penalties you may incur for writing notes, underlining or showing signs of use.
Tenants beware: If you do not return the book, the penalties may even exceed the price of a new book.
e-books
E-books instead of conventional textbooks are also an option.
Sometimes these books are rented de facto by providing an electronic license for a certain period of time from wholesalers such as Amazon.com, Chegg and Barnes & Noble Inc.
You can rent "Calculus" from Chegg for 6 months for about $61.
Bracey says that students in literature courses often find the best deals because many classics can be downloaded for free today, while science and engineering textbooks can be very expensive.
Look around anyway.
Joe Gault, 29, who will soon be attending Pepperdine Law School, recommends using the ISBN number to determine the price of books, as this way you can be sure to find the right textbook.
And before ordering online, according to Gault, one should check whether the book is actually in stock.
He learned that lesson the hard way.
He bought a book that had a four week delivery time and eventually paid full price at the college bookstore.
Why "Guardians of the Galaxy" did not become a box-office hit
"The Expendables 3" by Sylvester Stallone brought in less than $30 million of its $90 million budget in the US, while "Sin City: A Dame to Kill For" brought in only $12 million of its $70 million budget.
The film "Sex Tape", which was tailored to Cameron Diaz, only earned 14.6 million dollars on the opening weekend, while children's films such as "Taming Dragons Made Easy 2" also disappoint in terms of revenues.
An article by Telegraph film critic Robbie Collin suggests that the lack of quality in the children's films could be the reason for this.
Collin described 2014 as "the worst year" yet for children's films and described "Taming Dragons Made Easy 2" as a purely "functional" fantasy sequel.
However, for films for a slightly older target group, it seems that the quality of the films is not necessarily the problem.
In July, Entertainment Weekly compared the average CinemaScore and Metacritic ratings for each summer movie release shown on at least 2,000 screens between Memorial Day and July 20, 2013 and in the current year.
The results are based on the opinions of cinema audiences and film critics and indicate that this year's film hits are on a par with those of last year.
Some commentators believe that this development is due to changing viewing habits and the growing popularity of web streaming services like Netflix.
Director Jon Favreau, who is currently working on Disney's upcoming Jungle Book movie, told the Hollywood Reporter website: "I think times are changing.
We must accept this and not try to chase after the past.
In contrast to the current weak box office results of Hollywood productions, Netflix recently generated $1.2 billion in streaming content sales, almost twice as much as last year when sales were $837 million.
Last summer, director Steven Spielberg criticized the film studios for focusing too much on film adaptations of comics and predicted a "meltdown" of Hollywood.
In the light of the current downturn, some commentators argue that his gloomy prophecy may well contain a kernel of truth.
However, other representatives of the film industry are more optimistic due to the potential box office hits expected in summer 2015, including Avengers: Age of Ultron, Minions and Jurassic World:
X-Men producer Simon Kinberg recently described the decline in box office results as simply "cyclical" and told Hollywood reporters: "Next summer will be the biggest summer ever at the box office, and no one will worry about business anymore.

TWO young bush walkers were brought to safety with the winch after being trapped in the Blue Mountains in NSW during the night.

Under this treetop reigns calm
We showed a mighty tribe at our puzzle task of the summer series "My piece of the Rhöner Glück" last Friday.
Several of these giant trees still exist in the district, the specimen shown is the "Geißruheiche" above Unterweißenbrunn.
A bumpy footpath leads up to the approximately 600-year-old oak tree.
We pass paddocks, piles of basalt stones and seas of basalt stones.
A little below the quarry vom Bauersberg, one kilometre north of the road to Weisbach, there it stands.
The natural monument looks vital, it towers above the other trees in the area and, with a circumference of over eight metres, is reminiscent of an American sequoia.
A small Buddha on a tree stump indicates that this is a spiritual or mystical place.
But despite intensive research, there were only hints as to the origin of the name.
Dr. Wolfgang Schneider consulted the Bischofsheim archives and interviewed elderly people from Unterweißenbrunn to find out what their relationship is to the goat resting oak.
The result of his investigations remained the rather sober explanation for the name.
According to this, up until about 80 years ago, goatherds were said to have driven their animals from Unterweißenbrunn to the meadows, which had been painstakingly cleared and freed of stones.
At the foot of the tree the animal keepers, exhausted by the climb, are said to have rested.
In the meantime, the area has regained its importance, as herds of goats are actually grazing on the meadows again.
The area has also been declared a core zone of the biosphere reserve, Schneider added.
However, one should be careful when entering the stone accumulations, because the basalt warmed up by the sun is also a popular habitat for adders.
A hiking trail leads from Unterweißenbrunn to the tree, which is somewhat hidden.
Other paths are signposted, which climb up towards Hochrhön and invite you to take an extended hike.
Where is the moated castle?
However, a moated castle, which is searched for in our next task, is rather seldom to be found at this altitude.
The reflection in the ditch already gives a good impression of the building, but we have some historical buildings in the district, to which the building portrait could fit.
Where is our "piece of the Rhöner Glück"?
My piece of Rhöner luck
As with previous Main-Post series in previous years, there are prizes to be won if they have the right solution.
Those who like to take pictures themselves can also participate.
You can send us the solution and also your very personal "piece of Rhöner Glück" under this keyword at the e-mail address red.neustadt@mainpost.de.
The best photos will be published.
After weeks of tug-of-war, Italy's prime minister and current EU president Matteo Renzi has pushed through the nomination of his foreign minister Federica Mogherini as head of EU foreign policy against strong conservative opposition at last week's EU special summit. She will succeed Catherine Ashton from Britain.
As the pro-government daily La Repubblica reports, Renzi sees the appointment of his Mogherini, who is also considered a favourite in the government team, as strengthening the position of the Social Democrats and his own in the EU.
He also expects this to give a boost to his "reform package" in Italy.
Last but not least Renzi hopes to calm down the left-wing party base, which has repeatedly rebelled against him, because Mogherini is assigned to it - albeit in a rather moderate way.
The prevailing opinion in Rome is that this will create a political balance with regard to the conservative representatives with Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and Donald Tusk, who has been nominated as President of the Council.
For the EU's chief diplomat will also be deputy to Commission President Juncker.
The pending approval of the EU Parliament is considered certain.
Otherwise President Giorgio Napolitano would hardly have called the nomination of the 41-year-old politician from the ruling Democratic Party (PD) an "important recognition" of Italy's role in the EU.
La Repubblica spreads optimism that the Mogherini, who has proven herself in leading party offices for almost two decades and is known for her ambition, will be able to meet the "enormous challenges".
The Roman-born woman is married and has two daughters.
The political scientist, who holds a doctorate in political science, began her party career in 1996 in the youth organisation of the then Democratici di Sinistra (Left Democrats), which merged with the Catholic Centre Party Margherita in 2008 to form the current Social Democratic PD.
In 1999, Mogherini became Vice-President of the European Community Organisation of Socialist Youth for three years.
With her election to the Left Democratic Party Council in 2001, she entered into high party politics and worked in the Foreign Policy Department, of which she soon became head.
It occupied traditional focal points of Italian foreign policy such as the Middle East, became known through studies on the NATO mission in Afghanistan, in which Italy is participating with a contingent of troops, and cultivated contacts with the Social Democrats in Europe and with the Democrats in the USA.
Since 2008 she has been a member of the Chamber of Deputies, where she is an expert in defence and European and international affairs.
When Renzi became prime minister in February 2014, he appointed Mogherini as his foreign minister.

Norwegian Cruise about to close a deal with Prestige Cruises of $3 billion
Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd NCHL.O, the third largest cruise operator in the world, according to industry experts, is conducting advanced negotiations to acquire competitor Prestige Cruises International Inc for about $ 3 billion.
A deal would give Norwegian Cruise, a company with a market value of $6.8 billion, access to Prestige Cruises' luxury cruise ships and its wealthy clientele, while competing with larger rivals such as Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd (RCL.N) and Carnival Corp (CCL.N).
An agreement could be announced as early as this week, sources said on Sunday, warning that talks could also end inconclusively.
The owner of Prestige Cruises, the private equity company Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N) also owns a 20 per cent stake in Norwegian Cruise.
The sources asked to be able to remain anonymous, as the negotiations were not public.
Representatives from Norwegian Cruise and Prestige Cruises did not respond to requests for comments, while a spokesman for Apollo declined to comment.
The Miami-based company Norwegian Cruise operates 13 cruise ships on routes between North America, the Mediterranean, the Baltic Sea, Central America and the Caribbean.
Its revenue in 2013 was $2.57 billion, an increase of 13 percent over 2012.
Prestige Cruises, also based in Miami, operates under the brand names Oceania and Regent, which together operate eight cruise ships on routes to Scandinavia, Russia, the Mediterranean, North America, Asia, Africa and South America.
It reported revenues for 2013 of $1.2 billion, an increase of 6 percent over the previous year.
The cruise industry as a whole is worth about $29 billion and is expected to grow in the next few years as the middle class in emerging markets such as China and India is strengthened.
The companies are trying to position themselves as the best choice among cruise operators for these new customers.
Prestige Cruises applied to the US regulatory authorities for an initial public offering in January 2014.
Apollo is the majority shareholder in the company since an $850 million deal in 2007.
Norwegian Cruise was created in its current form in 2000 through a merger with a cruise operator owned by Genting Bhd (GENT.KL), a leisure and casino conglomerate controlled by Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay.
Apollo invested $1 billion in Norwegian Cruise in 2008.
Norwegian Cruise went public in January 2013.
According to the regulatory authorities, Genting held 28 percent of the shares at the end of June, Apollo held 20 percent and the private equity company TPG Capital LP held 8 percent of the company.
Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Norwegian Cruise together hold 82 percent of the passenger capacity on American cruise ships, according to the original application documents for the IPO of Prestige Cruises.

Putin demands from Kiev to start "statehood talks" with eastern Ukraine
According to Russian media reports, Russian President Vladimir Putin demanded on Sunday that the Ukrainian government stop fighting against the separatists in the east of the country and immediately begin negotiations on the "statehood" of the breakaway region.
His spokesman Dimitri Peskov later clarified that Putin did not mean that the territory of eastern Ukraine, which is under the control of the separatists, would become part of Russia, but that its status vis-à-vis Ukraine would have to be redefined in order to give the Russian-speaking region the power to represent its rights and interests.
Putin's call to the Kiev government to negotiate on an equal footing with the pro-Russian insurgents, however, fits in with the strategy he seems to have been pursuing since the beginning of the riots five months ago: helping the separatists take territory and putting pressure on the Ukrainian government to allow the newly proclaimed Novorossiya region de facto independence for an alliance with Russia instead of the West.
In an interview with state television channel one, Putin condemned the Ukrainian military campaign to recapture the separatist-held territories in the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which were taken in March and April after Moscow annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea on March 18.
Recently, the Kremlin and the separatists have referred to the occupied territory as "Novorossiya" or "New Russia", a term that recalls the pre-revolutionary heyday of the Russian empire.
Putin pointed out that all those who, in the wake of campaigns by Ukrainian politicians for the elections on Oct. 26 and while government groups attack civilian communities in the areas held by separatists hope for early peace talks are "caught in their illusions", reported Itar-Tass.
"We need to start detailed talks immediately, not only on technical issues, but also on the political organization of society and the state status of Southeast Ukraine, in order to protect the interests of the people living there," he said.
Peskov said that Putin's reference to statehood must be seen in the context of the greater autonomy that the Kiev leadership has been discussing for months to allay fears in Russian-speaking areas that their cultural and linguistic rights are at risk.
Only the Ukrainian government can give the eastern territories the necessary autonomy, said Peskov.
This is not about negotiations between Ukraine and Russia, said Peskov, "because it is not a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but an internal conflict in Ukraine.
The Kremlin spokesman's clarification to correct the "misinterpretation" of Putin's remarks underlined Russia's claim to leadership in dealing with the separatist rebellion in the East, in contrast to the direct annexation of the Crimea, where the majority of the 2 million inhabitants are ethnic Russians.
Moscow would have far greater difficulty in annexing the Donetsk and Luhansk regions of eastern Ukraine, as most of the 6.5 million inhabitants are not Russians and pre-conflict polls show a large majority in favour of staying in Ukraine.
The autonomy, which was raised by Russian diplomats in international forums, would give regional governments in Ukraine the power to negotiate their own trade agreements and foreign relations, thus giving the Kremlin de facto control over an area linking Russian territory with the Crimea.
The peninsula in the Black Sea, annexed five months ago, is the home port for most of the Russian navy as well as an important commercial port and historic coastal region.
The regions between the Rostov region in Russia and the Crimea are also rich in mines, factories and foundries, which produce important components for the Russian military.
Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko suggested in his inauguration speech on 7th June that Ukrainian legislation - after new elections - should consider additions to the constitution that would give the respective territories greater control over their finances and the status of languages.
But his idea of autonomy seems to be in sharp contrast to that of the Kremlin and the separatist rebels, whose arming and incitement Moscow is accused of.
Putin's last call on Kiev to negotiate on an equal footing with the separatist leaders followed a further advance by the rebels last week after Russian troops and tanks entered eastern Ukraine via the previously peaceful region along the Sea of Azov.
The Russian-backed separatists took control of Novoazovsk in a coup d'état that Ukrainian security officials feared was the first step in a campaign to take over the strategic coastal region as far as the Crimea.
For this reason, massive civil and military preparations have begun to fortify Mariupol, a steel industrial port with a population of 500,000, located between Novoasovsk and the narrow access to the Crimean peninsula.
Poroshenko spoke at a meeting of EU leaders in Brussels on Saturday, urging action to prevent further Russian aggression against Ukraine, a former Soviet republic that has been independent for 23 years.
"We are close to a point of no return," Poroshenko warned.
Thousands of foreign troops and hundreds of foreign tanks are now on the territory of Ukraine.
The EU summit did not decide on any concrete actions, the leadership demanded the draft of further sanctions against Russia, which should come into effect in case of an unspecified escalation of the Ukrainian crisis.
Ukrainian soldiers had to withdraw from their positions in Ilovaisk after two Russian tank columns and 1,000 soldiers entered the Donetsk region last week to support the besieged separatists, Colonel Andriy Lysenko, spokesman for the Ukrainian National Security and Defence Council told reports on Saturday in Kiev.
The first presumably 63 Ukrainian soldiers who were trapped by the Russian invasion of Ilovaysk were exchanged on Sunday for 10 Russian paratroopers captured a week ago on Ukrainian territory, Lysenko said on Sunday.

In a 911 call, Professor confesses to shooting his girlfriend
In an emergency call, Professor Shannon Lamb told the police in a somewhat shaky voice that he had shot his girlfriend and that the officers had to come to his house.
Lamb felt it was important to stress that his "sweet dog" was still alive and probably excited, however, and he said the dead woman's family contacts could be found on her cell phone.
Inside the house, officers found the body of Amy Prentiss and a handwritten note scribbled on a white pad: "I'm so sorry, I wish I could take it back, I loved Amy and she's the only woman who ever loved me. According to the authorities, this was in the letter and it was signed by Lamb.
There was no indication that Lamb, who taught two online courses for Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, had already traveled 300 miles to the school grounds where, according to police, he shot and killed a popular history professor, Ethan Schmidt, at the door of his office.
Delta State University Police Chief Lynn Buford said university employees heard the shooting at 10:18.
He said Lamb made the fateful 911 call sometime after that.
By the end of the day there was another death: Lamb took his own life when the police surrounded him.
One day after the university shooting, which forced students and faculty to hide behind closed doors, authorities are still trying to get a picture of what motivated Lamb.
The details released by investigators at both ends of the state, as well as what students and staff who knew him testified, helped paint a picture of a talented but potentially difficult teacher.
Students said they were looking forward to his classes.
The police in Gautier, where Prentiss died, said he had no history of violence or criminal history.
Schmidt himself had mentioned Lamb in a book he had written in which he mentioned the "wonderful people" with whom he shared his academic life.
They both taught in the Department of Social Sciences and History, which has a faculty of 17 members, and many students took courses from both.
At the same time, there were some tendencies towards problematic behaviour.
One student, Brandon Beavers, who praised Lamb, said he also seemed a little excited and nervous, "as if there was something wrong with him."
Another student, Mikel Sykes, said that Lamb had told him that he was dealing with stress at the end of the 2014-15 academic year.
Lamb had previously asked Delta State University for a medical leave of absence, saying that he had some kind of health problem.
This year he taught only two online courses.
Recent changes in the university's employment policy meant that the doctorate for which Lamb had worked so hard would not guarantee him an automatic route to appointment as an assistant professor.
University President William LaForge said he knew nothing about a conflict between Lamb and Schmidt, but "of course there was something in Mr Lamb's mind."
These are questions that Lamb can no longer answer.
After fleeing the campus, police later found Lamb's trail when he drove back into Mississippi from Arkansas.
Before he could be arrested, Lamb killed himself with a .38 caliber pistol in the backyard of a house about a mile south of his home on the outskirts of Greenville, Mississippi, Washington County Coroner Methel Johnson said.
His car was still running in the driveway.
It was not immediately clear why Lamb went to that house, but Johnson said she thought he knew the people who lived there.
Lamb grew up around here.
Lamb began his work at the university in 2009, which has 3,500 students in a city of about 12,000 inhabitants, teaching geography and education.
He received his doctorate in education in the spring.
One of Lamb's long-time friends described him as intelligent, charismatic and funny.
Carla Hairston said she was 15 and Lamb was 20 when they met through mutual friends.
She and her friends were in high school, and he was the cool older guy who tried to teach her to play the guitar for a few years.
He was the ladies' man back then.
All the girls melted away when he was around," said Hairston, now 40 and living in Brandon's Jackson suburb.
Lamb and Prentiss were obviously together for some time.
In the 911 call, Lamb said "I killed my wife," but there was no record of a marriage.
They had a dog named Lightning who lived with them in the brick house that borders a bayou in Gautier.
The police said the dog was fine.
Prentiss' ex-husband, Shawn O'Steen, said they divorced 15 years ago but remained friends and had a daughter who was now 19 years old.
"She was totally devastated," O'Steen said about his daughter.
She and her mother were absolutely best friends.
O'Steen said he had never met Lamb, but through his daughter Abigail he had heard that Lamb was interested in music and played the blues.
Lamb met Prentiss when he and Abigail both performed at a summer fair three years ago.
Later on they played one or the other gig together.
O'Steen said his daughter writes and sings her own music.
Prentiss was a nurse who worked online for various companies.
Mike Shaffer, a bartender and sometimes entertainment coordinator at The Julep Room, a dimly lit bar near Gautier, said he last saw Lamb and Prentiss Night on the night of September 5th, after Lamb finished his guitar and harmonica playing in front of a sparse audience.
There was no sign that anything was wrong.
"Just a happy couple," he said.
We were cleaning up and joking around.
I mean, they both had a good sense of humor.
Schmidt, the dead professor, directed the freshman seminar program and specialized in Native American and colonial history, said Don Allan Mitchell, an English professor at the school.
He was married and had three small children.
He studied at Emporia State University in Kansas and was president of his fraternity and student committee.
At the Delta State Campus in Cleveland, about 900 people, including faculty, staff, students and community members, attended a candlelight memorial service on Tuesday night.
Schmidt's wife Liz and brother Jeff Schmidt also took part in the vigil, while the university choir sang "Bright Morning Star" and "Amazing Grace".
Classes will resume on Wednesday.
"We are trying to get our students to return," said LaForge.
The crisis is over.
This is a day of healing.
Amy and Rogelio Solis reported from Cleveland, Mississippi.
Associated Press authors Emily Wagster Pettus in Greenville, Mississippi, and Rebecca Santana in New Orleans contributed to this report.

UN chief says there is no military solution in Syria
Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon says his response to Russia's increased military support for Syria is that "there is no military solution" to the nearly five-year conflict, and more weapons will only exacerbate violence and misery for millions of people.
The UN Chief reiterates his call on all parties, including the divided UN Security Council, to unite and support inclusive negotiations to find a political solution.
Ban told a press conference on Wednesday that he plans to meet the foreign ministers of the Council's five permanent member nations - the US, Russia, China, Britain and France - in the margins of the General Assembly ministerial meeting later this month to discuss the situation in Syria.
He regretted that the divisions in the Council and within the Syrian people and regional powers "make this situation unsolvable".
Ban called on the five permanent members to show the same solidarity and unity in dealing with the Syrian crisis as they have shown in reaching a nuclear deal with Iran.
8 survey results that show that Donald Trump is to be taken seriously.
Some have tried to brand it a flop.
Others have dismissed it as a joke.
And some are waiting for a breakdown.
But no matter how some Republicans try to pull Donald Trump down from the top ranks in polls, it has not (yet) worked.
Ten of the last eleven national polls showed Donald Trump leading in double digits, and some are beginning to seriously wonder what it means for the chances of nomination of the real estate mogul.
Of course it is still too early in the parliamentary term.
No one is saying Trump is likely to win the Republican nomination.
Experts stress that at this time in 2011 Rick Perry's leadership was handed over to the rising Herman Cain, none of whom won any state in the nomination process.
And there are many reasons why he would have to fight in a general election.
But maverick groups like Jeb Bush's Super PAC and the conservative business group Club for Growth are now recognizing Trump's staying power and beginning to let their dollars flow to bring him down.
Here are some recent survey results that indicate that the real estate mogul is not just a temporary phase:
Trump's popularity ratings have turned 180 degrees.
Just before Donald Trump announced his candidacy in mid-June, a survey by Monmouth University showed that only two out of ten Republicans took a positive view of the real estate mogul.
By mid-July, the figure had risen to 40 percent.
At the beginning of August, the figure was 52 percent.
Now six out of 10 Republicans have a positive view of Donald Trump.
About three out of ten say they have a negative opinion.
And these numbers are holding up in early states.
A Quinnipiac poll in Iowa last week found that 60 percent of Republicans have a good opinion of Trump.
Two-thirds of GOP voters GOP would be happy with Trump as candidate.
In a CNN/ORC poll last week, 67 percent of Republicans said they would be either "enthusiastic" or "satisfied" if Trump was nominated.
Only two out of 10 say they'd be "upset" if he was the candidate.
Only Ben Carson creates about the same amount of enthusiasm as Trump (43 percent say they are "enthusiastic" vs. 40 percent who say the same about Trump).
The next in enthusiasm?
Marco Rubio with only 21 percent.
On the other hand, 47 percent of Republican voters say they would be "dissatisfied" or "angry" if Jeb Bush, the establishment's favorite, became the candidate.
A majority of Republicans do not see Trump's temperament as a problem.
While Donald Trump is widely criticized for his bombastic and insulting statements, 52 percent of Republican-leaning Irish voters believe the real estate mogul has the right temperament for a president, according to ABC News/Washington Post on Monday.
The same number applies in the nation's first primary state, the state of Iowa, where the same 52 percent of Republicans think he has the personality for a commander-in-chief, according to Quinnipiac last week.
Yet 44 percent think he doesn't have the personality to effectively carry out his office, and nearly six out of 10 independents say his temperament doesn't fit in the White House, according to ABC/Post.
Republican voters are getting used to the idea.
When they put on their scholarly hats, Republican voters think Trump is real.
When asked who is most likely to win the GOP nomination, four out of ten say Trump is the best bet, according to a CNN/ORC poll last week.
This is a change since when four out of ten bet their money on Jeb Bush at the end of July.
Full disclosure: GOP voters have not had the clearest crystal ball in the past.
At this point in the last cycle, four out of ten Republicans thought that Rick Perry would win the nomination, compared to only 28% for the final candidate Mitt Romney.
Nevertheless, it turns out that a large number of GOP voters regard Trump's campaign as plausible.
Even if the Republicans rallied around another candidate, Trump still beats almost everyone.
Some experts point out that the fragmented field is likely to contribute to Trump's leadership, while anti-trump support is diffusely distributed among more than a dozen other candidates.
But a survey by Monmouth University in early September shows that in a hypothetical neck-and-neck race between Trump and most other Republican candidates, Trump is gaining majority support.
He is 13 points ahead of Carly Fiorina, 14 points ahead of Marco Rubio, 15 points ahead of Walker, 19 points ahead of Jeb Bush and finally 33 points ahead of Rand Paul, John Kasich and Chris Christie.
It's a neck-and-neck race with Ted Cruz.
The only candidate to beat him?

Smokers have a higher risk of tooth loss
A long-term study in Potsdam suggests that smoking damages not only the lungs but also the teeth.
The good news is that if you do without, the risk decreases quickly.
Smokers have a significantly increased risk of losing their teeth early.
This is the result of a long-term study by an international team of researchers, including several employees of the German Institute of Nutrition Research (DIfE) in Potsdam.
Compared to non-smokers, the risk of premature tooth loss was 2.5 to 3.6 times higher among smokers.
The scientists had observed more than 23,300 participants.
The main causes of tooth loss are caries and inflammation of the gums, emphasises the DIfE.
The authors emphasize that smoking is a risk factor for this periodontitis.
The connection between smoking and tooth loss is therefore due to more frequent gum inflammation in smokers.
It is not clear to what extent smoking also increases the risk of tooth decay.
However, people who stopped smoking could reduce their risk within a short time, the researchers write in the "Journal of Dental Research".
However, it could take more than ten years before the risk falls back to the level of non-smokers, explained first author Thomas Dietrich of the English University of Birmingham.
One had to convince people to become non-smokers, explained Heiner Boeing, head of the study at DIfE: "Smoking shortens the life span.
Not smoking is good for the lungs and blood vessels and, according to our findings, also leads to good dental health up to an advanced age.
In Germany, over 20 percent of the population between the ages of 65 and 74 is affected by toothlessness, the DIfE reported.
Earlier studies had already indicated that smoking increases the risk of early tooth loss.
The new long-term study substantiates the findings.
Archaeologists come across remains from late antiquity on the banks of the Rhine in Cologne
Once again, archaeological finds have been made on the right bank of the Rhine in Cologne.
Near the construction site for the new Rhine boulevard, archaeologists from the Roman-Germanic Museum have excavated skeletons and remains of historical buildings, said museum director Marcus Trier on Tuesday.
Since the beginning of construction work on the Rhine, historians have been searching for so-called ground monuments.
The museum is always consulted as a specialist office for archaeological ground monument conservation for all building projects in the Cologne urban district.
The archaeologists have now found what they were looking for in the third construction phase of the Rhine Boulevard.
It was already known from text documents that a fortress had stood at the site in the 4th century and a church in the 8th century, explained Trier.
In addition to the remains of the fortress and the church tower, a cemetery with around 350 graves was discovered, which probably belonged to the church.
Young woman freight train
After a young woman died in an accident at the train station in Geilenkirchen-Lindern, the federal police asked the population for help.
Early Wednesday morning around 1.40 a.m., the woman, coming from the direction of the station building, crossed the tracks at the end of the platform and was caught by a freight train coming from Mönchengladbach.
According to the federal police, she suffered severe injuries by being caught in the train.
She received emergency medical treatment on site and was brought to a hospital by rescue workers.
The investigating officers have no information about the reason for the young woman's night-time crossing of the tracks.
The incident may have been observed by witnesses or residents may have heard acoustic perceptions.
Residents or passers-by of Linderner Bahn, Ziegelbäckerweg, Thomashofstraße and Leiffarther Straße (L364) are eligible.
Information that provides information about the cause of the accident can be obtained from the Federal Police hotline, which is available around the clock and free of charge, by calling 0800/6888000 or any other police station.
EU Commission proposes new court in TTIP dispute
To defuse the dispute over the planned transatlantic free trade agreement TTIP, the EU Commission has proposed a comprehensive reform of the current arbitration system.
The controversial private arbitration bodies for disputes between corporations and states are thus to be replaced by a more transparent system, which in its mode of operation corresponds much more to traditional courts.
"We want to create a system that citizens trust," said Cecilia Malmström, the EU Commissioner responsible, at the presentation.
The Swede intends to introduce the proposal as a European negotiating position in the free trade talks with the USA.
The German government announced support.
TTIP is intended to create the largest free trade zone in the world with 800 million people.
The plans to reform the current arbitration procedures specifically provide for the EU states and the USA to jointly select independent judges for a new investment court.
They are to come in equal parts from the EU, the US and third countries.
A second instance is also planned for the first time.
It would allow for appeals against judgments.
Up to now, the parties to the proceedings agreed among themselves on arbitrators; there was no possibility to appeal against their decisions.
In the discussion over the past months it has become clear that citizens did not trust the old ISDS system in terms of fairness and justice, Malmström commented.
In the long term, it says it wants to work towards an International Investment Court.
For example, disputes between Chinese companies and EU states could be settled there.
The investor-state arbitration proceedings (ISDS), which are mainly demanded by large corporations, are considered to be one of the main reasons for the great resistance in Europe against TTIP.
Opponents criticise the traditional arbitration courts as a kind of parallel justice through which companies can claim damages at the taxpayer's expense, undermine national laws or enforce a reduction in consumer and environmental standards.
In initial comments, anti-TTIP organisations such as Campact described the proposals of the EU Commission as insufficient.
The main criticism was that they should not apply to the already negotiated free trade agreement with Canada (Ceta).
The German State Secretary for Economic Affairs, Matthias Machnig (SPD), on the other hand, described the plans as great progress.
In the reform, the Commission is taking into account key points which Federal Economics Minister Sigmar Gabriel had worked out in spring with other EU trade ministers.
The old system of private arbitration courts is off the table.
The French government also welcomed Malmström's plans.
The European business association BusinessEurope warned against restricting business' ability to take legal action by introducing too many new rules.
Especially small and medium-sized enterprises could be disadvantaged by this, it was said.
It remained unclear on Wednesday when the talks on the free trade agreement TTIP (Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership) could be concluded.
The negotiations have been underway since mid-2013.
However, the issue of investor protection has not yet been discussed with the USA.
Originally, a framework for the agreement should be in place by the end of this year.
This date is considered to be no longer tenable.
Delicate Folk by Sufjan Stevens in Hamburg
Eleven years ago Sufjan Stevens sits on stage in the Prime Club in Cologne (today: Luxor).
Next to him is a flipchart on which the shy-looking folk singer has recorded the picturesque US state of Michigan in felt-tip pen.
The entire audience, about 40 people, is almost moved by Steven's lecture.
He uses various locations, which he repeatedly draws on the map, to tell about what his meticulously and delicately arranged songs tell.
Where they were created and what it looks like there, in his home country.
Since then, Stevens has proven to be a wonderfully creative lunatic.
With the third album "Greetings from Michigan: The Great Lake State", released in 2003, cleverly composed songs are released, which harmonically nestle very close to American folk of the late sixties, but can drift into the great opulent at any time.
The rumor arises that "Michigan" would be the first part of a daring series: Each of the 50 US states would be sung about in succession.
But already in 2004 and near the Rhine, "Seven Swans" has been released and positively breaks certain expectations.
Stevens appears here in a reduced form.
Live, guitar and banjo are enough for him.
One year later, the New York-based musician returns to the series.
With "Illinois" ("Sufjan Stevens Invites You To: Come on Feel The Illinoise"), a widely acclaimed masterpiece was released in 2005.
Overflowing with ideas and stylistic finesse.
The album entered the American Billboard Charts and is not missing in any annual best list of the influential music media.
After extremely productive experiments, Stevens then uses very extensive electronic set pieces on "The Age of Adz" (2010).
This sixth decent studio album is still broadly orchestrated, but carried by programmed sequences or beats and plays with all kinds of effects and reverb.
Long since emerging from the smaller clubs, the stage shows here become a colourful spectacle of neon headbands and large fluorescent stage decorations.
Currently Sufjan Stevens is touring Germany as part of a five-piece band.
In the dark Hamburger Mehr!
Theatre he mainly presents the "Carrie & Lowell", which has been available since March.
Although almost 2000 guests are now sitting spellbound in their chairs, Stevens, who has matured considerably, returns to intimacy and folk.
Without a word to the audience, the group of excellent musicians plays through the broadly enriched album.
From the audience one hears: the performance is "more opulent" and one could "basically throw away the record".
Only to an encore Stevens modestly thanks the band, plays acoustically few older songs and finally bows down under thunderous applause.
Jeremy Corbyns debut at Prime Minister's Question Time
Since his election, Mr Corbyn's debut at the Prime Minister's Question Time is eagerly awaited
The new Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is due to make his debut at the Prime Minister's Question Time and is expected to take on David Cameron for the first time.
Mr Corbyn will rise to ask the first of his six pre-set questions shortly after midday, with his performance likely to be closely scrutinised by the media and Labour MPs.
He called for "less theatre and more facts" at this weekly event.
He also said that he could skip some meetings to leave them to colleagues.
The meeting will be the first parliamentary test for Mr Corbyn's leadership as it comes after his appointment as a member of the shadow cabinet and after his speech at the TUC annual meeting on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the Labour leader's decision to remain in silence while singing the national anthem on Tuesday at a commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain has provoked criticism from a number of Tory MPs and has been the focus of several front page stories in the newspapers.
Mr Corbyns' decision not to sing the national anthem has attracted attention
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said that he had "stood in respectful silence" and he had acknowledged the "heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain".
But a member of Mr Corbyns shadow cabinet, Owen Smith, told the BBC Two Newsnight programme that he advised the Labour leader to sing the national anthem "regardless" of his belief that the monarchy should be abolished.
Nearly a dozen Shadow ministers have refused to serve on Mr Corbyn's top team, citing economic, defence and foreign policy differences, while less than a sixth of the Parliamentary Party originally supported him as leader.
BBC's political correspondent Robin Brant says that political differences are "piling up" even within Labour, following Mr Corbyn's comments on the position on the European Union and the limits on profits.
Mr Corbyn told the TUC conference that Labour was putting forward amendments to remove the whole idea of a limit altogether.
Hours later Mr Smith, the Shadow Labour and Pensions Minister, said that the party was "very clear" that it was only against government plans to lower the limit from £26,000 to £23,000.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron, since becoming Tory leader, across the parliamentary dispatch box in the last decade.
The Labour leader, who has promised a different policy approach, says he has "crowd-sourced" ideas for questions to Mr Cameron and has been given more than 30,000 suggestions.
The Islington North MP has said that the Prime Minister's Question Time is too confrontational, and that he will refrain from both "repartee" and barbed arguing, and instead has chosen to focus on serious issues such as poverty, inequality and the challenges facing young people.
Mr Corbyn has said that Angela Eagle, the Shadow Minister of Economics, will represent him when he is not attending - for example when Mr Cameron is travelling abroad.
He also brought up the idea that other colleagues occasionally take the floor and that he had approached John Bercow, the Speaker of the House of Commons, to discuss the issue.
When he became leader in 2005, Mr Cameron said that he wanted to move away from politics in the style of "Punch and Judy show", which is often linked to the Prime Minister's Question Time. But a few years later he admitted that he had failed in this.
As it was first broadcast on television in 1990, Question Time with the Prime Minister was seen as the main barometer of a leader's judgement and his leadership in the House of Commons and his standing among his fellow MPs, although critics have argued that it has become a caricature and needs far-reaching reform.

Pound sterling rises due to accelerated wage growth in the United Kingdom
The pound rose sharply according to data indicating an increase in UK wage growth. At the same time, the FTSE 100 was increased by the bidding target SABMiller.
Between May and July, the result excluding bonuses in the United Kingdom grew by 2.9% compared with the same period of the previous year.
Since 2009, this percentage has been the fastest and most accurate estimate of the timing of an interest rate increase.
The pound rose by more than 1% against the dollar to $1.5505 and had climbed up to 0.84% against the euro to €1.3730.
The FTSE 100 Index closed with a 1.49% increase to 6,229.21.
SABMiller was the outstanding share in the market and jumped 20% after receiving a takeover bid from rival AB InBev.
A transaction would combine the two largest brewers in the world, bringing together brands such as Budweiser, Stella Artois, Peroni and Grolsch.
Burberry shares were up 0.9% after encouraging news from rival luxury goods group Richemont.
Richemont's latest sales figures beat all expectations and also showed that sales in China - a key market for Burberry - are growing again.
Glencore shares rose 5% after the mining giant said it had raised $2.5 billion by selling shares as part of its strategy to reduce debt.
The shares of the packaging and paper group Mondi were the biggest losers on the index, with a fall of 4.3% after Goldman Sachs set its rating for the company Rating to "sell".
JD Sports increased by 3.1% after the sportswear company reported pre-tax earnings of 46.6 million for the half-year.
The head of JD Sports says that higher wages are endangering the expansion.
JD Sports CEO Peter Cowgill says that a higher minimum wage for UK workers could mean "more spending power in the pockets of potential customers".
But it is unlikely that this purchasing power will compensate for the higher labor costs at his company, he says.
The costs could affect JD Sports' expansion plans, he added, and that could mean fewer additional jobs.

It works both ways - in the potato kebab developed by the Oldenburg snack bar owner Hani Alhay.

Metcash launches down-to-earth campaign to combat Aldi incursion
Metcash is trying to protect the IGA branches from an Aldi deployment in South Australia and Western Australia.
Food wholesaler Metcash has launched a down-to-earth campaign to defend the market share of IGA retailers in South Australia and Western Australia in the run-up to a $700 million Aldi invasion.
As Aldi prepares to open two distribution centres and the first 120 stores in South Australia and Western Australia early next year, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with local food suppliers and building the IGA brand through mainstream marketing and social media marketing, as well as events such as the Adelaide show.
IGA retailers and suppliers are jumping on board, with brands such as Dunsborough ice cream maker Simmo, who distributes samples in IGA stores, and shopkeepers who sell discounted tickets to the South Australian Football League to loyal customers.
Metcash is expected to release further details of its defense strategy on September 29 when the food, alcohol and equipment wholesaler holds its annual investor strategy day.
The stakes are high as South Australia and Western Australia account for nearly 30 percent of Metash's IGA stores and generate higher profit margins than Metash's IGA network in the Eastern States.
Buyers in South Australia and Western Australia are notoriously provincial and IGA retailers have a much stronger market share than in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland - over 30 per cent in South Australia and 24 per cent in Western Australia compared to around 14 per cent in the Eastern States.
However, analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe that twelve months after opening its first stores, Aldi will snatch away about five percent of the grocery market in these two states, taking sales away from all existing players, but mostly independent retailers.
According to a report released this week, Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath estimated that IGA retailers could lose $360 million in sales per year and Metcash $250 million by the end of 2016.
This forecast is based on the assumption that next year Aldi will open 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA, and will achieve sales of $500 million and $600 million in each store.
The loss in the food and grocery business and volumes on Metcash's high fixed cost base could cost Metcash approximately $13 million in earnings before interest and taxes, Mr Kierath said.
At the same time, Metcash is losing market share in the Eastern States, mainly to Aldi and Coles, although a recent survey by Roy Morgan found that IGA shoppers are the most loyal.
Morgan Stanley estimates that Metcash's sales in the food and grocery business will fall by 3.8 percent in 2016, 4.1 percent in 2017 and 2.1 percent in 2018, reducing its market share from 14 percent in 2015 to 10.3 percent by 2020.
Last week, leading fund manager Hamish Douglass, the founder of Magellan Financial Group, told a business dinner in Melbourne that Metcash is likely to be within a decade. Metcash disappear.
Metcash refused to respond publicly to Mr Douglass' comments.
But it is believed that a Metcash board member contacted Mr Douglass last week.
IGA's market share has declined from 18 percent to 14 percent since 2010, and revenues from Metca's food and grocery business, which serves approximately 1,200 IGA retailers, have fallen 43 percent since 2012, reflecting operational debt reduction while putting pressure on sales and margins.
However, the wholesaler is fighting back and investing more than $150 million to match retail prices with Coles and Woolworths on hundreds of products each week, helping IGA retailers improve their stores with faster-growing fresh foods and delivering a better choice of private-label foods.
Metcash's chief executive, Ian Morrice, says that price adjustments and store redevelopment programmes will gain momentum and hopes that the wholesaler will return to profit growth in 2017 for the first time in four years.
Thanasi Kokkinakis is supported by the president of the Australian Tennis Federation Steve Healy
Thanasi Kokkinakis deserves more praise than criticism for his behaviour.
Thanasi Kokkinakis was one of the "collateral damage" in the recent storm around his friend Nick Kyrgios and, according to Steve Healy, president of the Australian Tennis Federation, deserves praise rather than criticism for his own behaviour.
Kokkinakis, the younger of the talented duo, which is often referred to as the "Special Ks", came into the limelight at the Montreal Masters through Kyrgios' notorious clash with Stan Wawrinka.
In a fiery qualifying match in Cincinnati soon after, Kokkinakis and his opponent Ryan Harrison had to be separated twice by the referee, with Harrison exclaiming, "Wawrinka should have beaten Kyrgios and I should beat the kid.
While he was last seen smashing a tennis racket after a spasm thwarted a potential US open win by Richard Gasquet, Kokkinakis was steadfastly defended by Healy.
The teenager is currently in Glasgow, competing with Sam Groth for second place in the singles behind Bernard Tomic in the Davis Cup semi-final against Britain.
"One thing that I'm pretty upset about is that I think Thanasi got a little bit involved in the argument," Healy said.
He broke a racket when he lost in the US Open because of a cramp, but he is not the first player who broke a racket out of frustration with himself, and I know Thanasi well enough to know that he is not proud of it.
But, really, he's done extremely well in the US Open, even under the rather provocative circumstances with Harrison and so on, and I think he deserves a lot of recognition.
He has a great team around him, he has a great family around him, and I think he was treated a little too harshly.
He is a very mature 19 year old, he works very hard and he fits in the team and so on, he has never had a problem with the other players, he is respected in the locker room, he trains hard, he is in good shape, he is a very stable and mature young guy and I think he deserves to be judged on his own merits.
Healy also supported the decision not to include Kyrgios in the important preliminary round, which begins on Friday, and he describes the "joint decision" as the right one for everyone, but he assures the Canberra man that he will return to the team as a long-term fixture".
"First of all, we want the team to be completely focused on the competition and not on all the controversy around [Kyrgios]," Healy said.
And I think that Nick made the climb very quickly, as people like Federer and Murray have pointed out. He is rising in the eyes of the public and he has made some bad mistakes and deserves all the criticism he gets, but we try to support him, we try to make him understand the consequences of his actions. Some time out of the limelight, where he can only think about it, I think it's appropriate and it's best for the team and it's best for him.
Europe's refugee crisis: Hungary declares state of emergency, closes the border, holds back refugees
Hungary declared a state of emergency and sealed off the southern border with Serbia on Tuesday, detaining anyone who tried to enter the country illegally. All with the aim of stopping the influx of migrants.
Chaos followed at the border when hundreds of migrants gathered in a no-man's land and Serbian officials reacted with indignation.
The people who had fled from violence were stuck for an unknown period of time in a strip of land on the road between the two checkpoints of the countries, building tents and settling there.
But frustrations grew.
As a police helicopter hovered over them, the migrants chanted "Open the border!" and shouted insults against the Hungarian riot police.
Some rejected food and water in protest.
Serbia's Foreign Minister declared that it was "unacceptable" that migrants were sent back from Hungary while more and more were arriving from Macedonia and Greece.
(Serbia) wants to be part of the solution and not collateral damage.
Talks with Brussels and other countries must take place in the coming days," said Ivica Dacic in Prague.
The turmoil on the Hungarian-Serbian border came one day after the 28-nation bloc failed to agree on a common immigration policy at a contentious meeting in Brussels.
However, the ministers agreed to share the responsibility for 40,000 people who sought refuge in overpowered Italy and Greece. They expressed their hope that eventually - next month or by the end of the year - an agreement would be reached that the EU states would accept another 120,000 refugees, including some from Hungary.
Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called for a special summit of the European Union on Tuesday to discuss the continent's immigration crisis.
However, Hungary did not pin its hopes on early action from Brussels or its neighbours.
The state of emergency declared on Tuesday in two southern regions gave authorities more powers to deal with the crisis, allowing them to close off roads and speed up asylum procedures.
Meanwhile, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said that his country also plans to build a barbed-wire fence along its border with Romania to stop the influx of migrants through the country - after it finished a fence on the Serbian border.
CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prisoners were used in the race to build the barbed wire fence between Hungary and Serbia.
In recent months, Hungary has become a major bottleneck for many war refugees from Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East and a point of entry to the European Union.
However, Prime Minister Viktor Orban has insisted that most arrivals are economic refugees looking for a better life and not war refugees entitled to protection - a view that strongly contradicts other EU states, including Germany.
The new laws that came into force in Hungary at midnight make it a crime to cross the border or damage the 4-meter (13-foot) high fence that the government had built along the southern border with Serbia. These laws also set higher prison sentences for convicted traffickers.
"Due to the situation created by mass migration, the Hungarian government is declaring a state of emergency," government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters in the southern city of Szeged.
We say it very clearly: illegal border crossing is a crime.
Parliament has yet to give its procedural approval to the military deployment expected next week, but Associated Press reporters have seen heavily armed soldiers with vehicles and dogs for days at the border.
Gyorgy Bakondi, Orban State Security Advisor, said that authorities caught 45 people trying to cross the border, while 15 others had already penetrated deeper into the country.
They come over by damaging the fence, they are now in police custody and accused of committing crimes under the new laws.
Authorities are in the process of quickly repairing the fence.
Hungarian officials also closed two of the seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning after a train wagon with barbed wire arrived to close the borders.
Chaos surrounded the main border crossing near Roszke, Hungary, when the Hungarians opened a small office in a metal container to process people's data and a crowd of people pushed to squeeze in.
About 20 managed to get in, but thousands remained outside.
Another group of migrants blocked the main motorway link between Serbia and Hungary, saying that they would refuse food and water until they were allowed to enter Hungary.

Vice President Joe Biden, who has not yet announced whether he will run for president, has the support of 15 percent of the democratic voters in the primaries.
More than five months before the start of the primaries, most democratic voters say that it is too early to say that their opinion has been determined which candidate they will support.
But Clinton's supporters are more consistent in their choice than the other candidates.

Clinton's advantage with Democratic voters under 50 has evaporated, and she and Sanders are now on an equal footing.
Clinton, however, still has a big lead among older voters.
Last month Clinton was ahead of Sanders in the Liberals by a double-digit margin, but Sanders now has a 5-point lead in that group.
About half of the Democratic voters in the primaries nationwide say that they would enthusiastically support Clinton if nominated by the party.
A quarter would support her with some reservations and another 15 percent would only support her because she is the candidate.
Six percent would not support them.
Perhaps not surprisingly, Clinton's current supporters are particularly enthusiastic about her.
The views are more mixed among those who currently do not support Clinton - only about a quarter would enthusiastically support it.
While 48 percent of Democratic voters in the primaries say they enthusiastically support Clinton, fewer Republican voters say the same about their top candidate Donald Trump (35 percent).
When Clinton's supporters are asked in an open question why they want her to be the candidate, the most common answer is that she has the right experience (16 percent), followed by the view that it is time for a woman to become president (13 percent) and that she is the best candidate for the job (10 percent).
Clinton's supporters also mention her association with Bill Clinton (9 percent).
Agreement to deal with the problems and eligibility are also cited.

When democratic voters in the primaries are asked who would be their second choice for the party, Biden is in the lead.

If Biden decides not to run for the Democratic nomination, Hillary Clinton's lead over Sanders increases from 20 points with Biden in the race to 30 points without him in the race.
Fifty-five percent of Democratic voters see Clinton as the candidate with the best chance of winning the election; however, this figure has dropped from 78 percent last month.

Majorities consider Clinton, Sanders and Biden to be honest and trustworthy and equipped with strong leadership qualities.
Biden scores best on honesty among the three candidates, while Clinton's strength is leadership.
Thirty percent of Democratic voters do not believe that Clinton is honest and trustworthy, twice as many say that about Sanders (15 percent), but 27 percent have no opinion about him.
Democratic voters in primaries generally also see Clinton, Sanders and Biden ideologically in line with their views.

But it is a different story in the American public at large.
Half of the Americans are now dissatisfied with their statement, while only about a third are satisfied.
Public opinion was divided on this issue in March, shortly after the problem came to light.
Most Americans said the e-mail controversy had no effect on their general opinion of Clinton, although 36 percent said their opinion of her had worsened.

Five members of the Brotherhood charged with the death of a Baruch college freshman
Nearly two years after a student died during a harassing ritual at a fraternity in Pocono Mountains, Pennsylvania, murder charges have been filed against five people.
Members of New York's Baruch College Pi Delta Psi Brotherhood brutally attacked Chun "Michael" Deng during an initiation ritual in September 2013 and delayed his transport to hospital, contributing to his death, police said.

Mr. Deng finally complained of a headache, then passed out.
Members of the Pi Delta Psi Brotherhood did not call 911 after Deng fainted and allegedly waited an hour before taking him to a hospital, police said.
However, they had time to change Deng's clothes, google his symptoms and contact Andy Meng, the national president of the Brotherhood, for advice, police chief Chris Wagner said at a press conference.

He could not be resuscitated, and he died the next morning from his injuries.
According to an autopsy report, Deng was repeatedly subjected to blunt force injuries to the head, trunk and thighs.

Fraternities and their members must be held accountable, and this step by public authorities is very important.
A county grand jury of Monroe recommended a third degree murder charge for the first five members.
