The Baruch College has banned the fraternity, and the national fraternity has revoked its affiliation with the local chapter.
This is what will happen if the Fed raises rates
An interest rate hike will come and the bull market will start to sway, bond yields will rise and the economy will slide into recession.
We know that.
What we don't know is how long all this will take and how long it will last.
In particular, the story offers little guidance to the business community on how to proceed.
A recession came within just 11 months of the first interest rate hike and lasted 86 months.
The Federal Reserve's aggressiveness in raising interest rates is often, though not always, a factor in how the economy and financial assets react.
This is why representatives of the US Federal Reserve have so vehemently emphasized that investors should not focus on when it starts to raise interest rates, but rather on the period of time needed for normalization.
In fact, several variables play a role.
In the end, however, market participants may find that all the excitement over a rate hike may have been exaggerated.
"The Fed's first increase since the global financial crisis will inevitably be interpreted by some as a signal for the end of the era of 'cheap money'," said Julian Jessop, chief economist at Capital Economics, in a statement to clients.
In contrast, we do not expect US interest rates to gradually return to normal levels, but still at levels too low to lead to the seismic shock that many seem to fear.
However, this does not mean that there will be no impact.
Here is a look at how some sectors of the economy might react, based on historical trends:
As the market saw last month, anticipating rate hikes can make things volatile for a while.
Once the raise arrives, the impact is not so dramatic.
"There seems to be a tendency for asset returns to stall 12 to 24 months after the initial increase, which may again reflect the lag in monetary policy," said Deutsche Bank analysts in a recent study of what happens after Fed rate hikes.
More specifically, the market has been on an uptrend for most of the past 35 years - about 14 percent - on its way to raise rates, fairly flat for the 250 days after that (average gain of 2.6 percent), then back to normal after 500 days, with an average return of 14.4 percent over the past six previous cycles, according to a recent analysis published by Bob Doll, chief investment strategist at Nuveen Asset Management, at Barron's.
Deutsche Bank said that the impact on equities tends to occur later in the rise cycle and that the yield starts to decline.
Recessions are a fact of economic life, but interest rate hikes often encourage them.
In the current case, the Fed is facing some conditions that did not exist before and that could accelerate a recession.
Most notably, GDP will be close to its lowest point in the event of a Fed rate hike.
According to Deutsche Bank, in the 118 interest rate hikes since 1950, nominal GDP was only twice below 4.5 percent.
Although the second quarter of 2015 was at 3.6 percent, few expect this to continue and, according to the Atlanta Fed, only 1.5 percent expect the third quarter to show a decline.
Interest rate hikes in such a fragile economic environment could be risky and raise the question "if it's different this time," said Deutsche Bank.
Market participants have been preparing for a Fed rate hike all year, and all eyes were on this week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which ends on Thursday.
While many strategists and economists believe that the FOMC could approve an increase in this meeting, futures trading only gives a 25 percent probability.
"In our study, all of the rise cycles from 1950 to the present have been in a super-cycle with increasing momentum in GDP, dwarfing pre-recession highs very quickly after the start of the recovery," the report says.
In contrast, this is clearly a slow recovery from what was the worst recession in the observed period.
The current cycle is by far the longest the Fed has waited for since the end of the last recession; the record was 35 months, and that is 74 months so far.
Fixed income was also volatile as the market anticipates an interest rate hike and the pattern is quite similar to the capital market.
The main difference is that the effect is faster for bonds than for equities when they change their strategic course.
For bonds, yields seem to change direction as soon as the first increase/decrease in the cycle occurs.
At the end of the cycle of increases, bond yields fall immediately, Deutsche Bank said.
Charles Schwab's strategists believe that the rise in interest rates will cause yields between longer and shorter bonds to move closer together, flattening the curve.
High-yield bonds often bring better returns in such a climate, although "we are still cautious about expecting higher returns," said Kathy Jones, fixed-income analyst at Schwab, in an analysis.
Interestingly, Jones says that the markets have already adjusted to Fed strategy expectations.
"In addition to the strength of the dollar and the decline in inflation expectations, there are some signs that the market has adjusted to the prospect of tighter monetary policy," she wrote.
Short-term interest rates have risen, the yield curve is flatter, credit spreads have widened and volatility has increased - all features of the market when the Fed tightens its strategy.
By and large, companies that do most of their business in the US will benefit as interest rates rise and local products become more attractive.
Multinational companies with high debts will be worse off, as a rising dollar will make their products more expensive on the global market, as will the financing of their debts.
"History shows that "quality" stocks tend to react extremely positively three months after an initial rate hike," Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report to clients.
Companies with strong balance sheets outperformed companies with weak balance sheets by an average of 5 percentage points after each of the interest rate increases in 1994, 1999 and 2004.
Companies with high returns on capital and low stock volatility also outperformed their low quality counterparts by an average of 4 (percentage points) and 3 (percentage points) respectively.
Debt is becoming a big problem.
Companies with a high proportion of flexible interest rates will lose the most, Goldman said.
Outside of pure equity games, consumers will also benefit from the rising dollar.
Savers could see gains through higher returns, although experts disagree on how quickly this will happen.

Internet sales rose the slowest in August and Black Friday may be responsible
In the first three months of 2015 there was a seven percent increase in online sales.
Last month saw the lowest result since records began in 2000
Online sales increased three years ago due to the use of mobile phones for shopping
Experts believe that Black Friday in November has slowed spending
For over a decade virtual shopping has boomed and many of the UK's main shopping streets have been transformed into ghost towns.
But experts say there are now signs that online sales are stagnating, after new figures showed only seven percent in the first three months of 2015.
Total expenditure for August presented the lowest increase in growth since records began in 2000, with only five percent year-on-year growth.
Experts say there are signs that online sales are stagnating after new figures showed only seven percent growth in the first three months of 2015
"If you look at the growth rates for previous years and go back to 2000, this has always developed over time," Andy Mulcahy, editor of the IMRG Sales Index told The Guardian.
He explained that online sales increased three years ago, when shoppers started making purchases with their mobile phones.
It meant that more people could shop online and that people could do so in different environments, such as at home on the sofa.
But now it is levelling off and we may see growth slow down.
The Black Friday phenomenon imported from America is cited as one reason for the drop in sales.
Experts believe that buyers are holding back their purchases before this event, which takes place on the last Friday in November.
Last year, five times the average number of shoppers gathered around their computers to make their bargains, and some merchant websites crashed.
Experts believe that Black Friday, when buyers fought each other for bargains, could discourage buyers from making purchases.
A study by the British Retail Consortium found that out of every £5 spent, just over £1 was spent online.
For some products, such as televisions and washing machines, more than a third of purchases are now made via web shops.
At the same time, more than a quarter of people buy clothes and shoes online instead of in the fashion chains in the city centres.

The co-defendant had been informed, the functionary justified himself.
This transfer was formulated as "damage compensation".
Why settle? The judge and the prosecutor wanted to know
The first defendant then stated that he did not agree with this formulation because the association had never suffered any damage.
But what am I supposed to do when the lawyer says, "You're all off the hook with him"?
"Am I a legal representative?" he asked.

HP still employed around 302,000 people at the end of the 2013/14 financial year.
After-market, the Hewlett-Packard share fell 2.3 percent.
The group from Palo Alto, California, which grew up with printers, is currently splitting up: the computer and printer business is to be bundled in a new company before the end of this year - separate from the more promising areas with computer servers and data storage for companies and other services.
Both business units are to be listed on the stock exchange.
Disappointing PC sales and weaker demand from corporate customers for its services have recently affected the world's second largest PC manufacturer after Lenovo.
In the third quarter of the financial year at the end of July, sales of PCs and printers fell by 11.5 per cent.
Sales fell by 8 percent to almost 25.4 billion dollars.
As a result, revenues declined in 15 of 16 quarters.
HP is responding to the changes in the industry with a split and massive job cuts.
The 76-year-old company, led by Meg Whitman, has been slow to respond to the fact that customers are increasingly buying smartphones and tablets instead of traditional computers, and are doing more and more business online.
Whitman's restructuring plans provide for a total reduction of around 55,000 jobs.

Time of decision on interest rates for the US Federal Reserve
The world will watch as the Federal Reserve meets on two days, Wednesday and Thursday, to make the important decision of whether or not to raise interest rates for the first time in almost a decade.
A survey of 80 economists polled by Reuters found that just over half of those who thought the Fed would do so last week now think the Fed will stay a little longer and keep rates at the current level of 0-0.25 percent.
It is a historic event because it is seven years since the Fed set rates to ZERO.
"For the first time, we are approaching a situation where a major central bank may leave the zero band and start a process of normalization of interest rates," said Angel Ubide, senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The US economy is on a relatively good performance level, trillions of dollars are added to the balance sheet and generate only low inflation.
However, the Fed cannot ignore the less rosy outlook for global conditions.
It has warned the markets to prepare for an increase, but the indications are that the chances against such a move are good.
The decision will be announced at 20.00 CET on Thursday
Dead gunman at Delta State University left a letter of apology
After shooting and killing his girlfriend in Mississippi on Monday morning - and before shooting and killing his colleague later that day - Shannon Lamb wrote a note to say he was "sorry" about the first murder and wanted "he could undo it," authorities announced on Tuesday.
The police in Gautier, Mississippi, said that Lamb, a lecturer in geography and social science education at Delta State University, called the emergency number around 10:00 a.m. Monday morning
and said he shot someone and killed someone.
Lamb told the emergency call centre employee that the police had to send policemen to his home.
He said, "I shot my wife last night" and he also mentioned that there was a "cute dog" in the house, but he said "nobody will disturb", but probably will be excited.
The police asked the caller for his name, but he did not give it.
Lamb gave no explanation for his shooting.
When police entered the scene, they found the body of Amy Prentiss, 41, and a handwritten note from Lamb, 45, saying, "I'm so sorry, I wish I could undo it.
I loved Amy, and she's the only woman who ever loved me".
After writing the note, Lamb drove 300 miles to Delta State University, where he killed Ethan Schmidt, a professor of history, before finally taking his own life on Monday night when police surrounded him.
University President William LaForge said he knew nothing about a conflict between Lamb and Schmidt, but "of course there was something in Mr Lamb's mind."
Despite reports on Monday that Lamb allegedly believed that Prentiss also had a relationship with Schmidt, authorities said on Tuesday that there was "no information, no evidence" of a "love triangle".
Prentiss was described as a "good person" by Shawn O'Steen, who testified that they were married for about seven years.
The two were divorced 15 years ago but remained friends.
O'Steen said he and Prentiss had a daughter who was 19 and she was "devastated.
He said that Prentiss and her daughter were "absolutely best friends".
Prentiss worked online from home, according to Linsday Knowles, who was identified by the Sun Herald as a close friend of Prentiss.
Knowles said that Prentiss, who owned a dog named Lightning, had been seeing Lamb for about three years.
"She always wanted to help other people," Knowles said.
The police said Lamb called relatives at a certain time on Monday to tell them "he's not going to jail".
When police caught up with him on Highway 1 near Greenville later that night, Lamb drove his car to the side, fled on foot, ran into the woods and killed himself with one shot.
Lamb received his doctorate from Delta State University in the spring of 2015, as his life story indicates on the university's website.

Eurowings: Lufthansa is restructuring the Group
Lufthansa is planning a major restructuring of the Group.
The Lufthansa Group wants to save half a billion euros a year just by improving its organisation.
150 of the approximately 1000 managers worldwide will lose their jobs as a result of the Group restructuring.
There are, however, new negotiations with the pilots' union.
Lufthansa is reorganizing its corporate structure and upgrading its low-cost subsidiary Eurowings.
The airline announced on Wednesday that the aim of the realignment is to achieve an annual earnings contribution of around 500 million euros from cost and revenue synergies.
Among other things, Lufthansa will no longer have an executive board for the passenger business.
The low-cost airline Eurowings should be developed as independently as possible.
Karl Ulrich Garnadt will in future be responsible for Eurowings in the executive team headed by Carsten Spohr.
With the new line-up, Spohr underlines the importance of Eurowings, with which the group intends to compete against Ryanair and Easyjet in future.
Up to now, the organisation of the 120,000-strong company was complex.
The airlines operated under the umbrella of the Passenger Airline Group, which accounts for three quarters of the annual turnover of 30 billion euros.
New negotiations with the pilots
In the collective bargaining conflict with the pilots' association Cockpit (VC), negotiations are to be resumed this Thursday after the strike was stopped by the court.
This was announced by the union.
The subject of the discussions will be the retirement scheme for pilots.
Cockpit wants to achieve sustainable results "in a year with a forecast record result" as quickly as possible.
The conflict between the union and the airline led to several strikes in the past months.
In addition to the transitional provision for pilots, the background is the "Wings" savings concept.
It provides for Lufthansa to outsource routes to the Group's own low-cost airline Eurowings in its fight against competitors.

Surely David Cameron knows The Lorax better?
It's one thing that all parents soon learn: if your child loves a book, it won't be long before you know it almost by heart.
Unless you might be David Cameron.
When he was asked by a provider of childcare systems to name his favourite children's book, the Prime Minister decided to use The Lorax, Dr Seuss' environmental fable published in 1971.
It was a difficult choice, Cameron writes in a message on the SuperCamps website, and continues: "funny, moving, creative and with a powerful message, it's a book I like to read to my children, because there always seems to be a picture or a message that we have missed so far.
All well and good, except that the following paragraph, in which Cameron supposedly describes the plot of the book, instead gives a summary of the 2012 movie version, which added new characters and details to expand on the rather short original text.
"In the midst of the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where all nature is gone and even air is a commodity, a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of Audrey, the girl of his dreams, by fulfilling her wish to see a real tree," reads one. One love interest was Dr. Seuss, whose real name was Theodor Seuss Geisel and who died in 1991, but is completely unknown.
As if that wasn't suspicious enough, the text presented by Cameron reads in part like the summary of the Lorax film presented on the Internet Movie Database website, which begins: "In the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where everything is artificial and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of Audrey, the girl of his dreams.
Although he admits to being a pragmatic father, it seems unlikely that Cameron is so unfamiliar with the plot of the book. Here, an unnamed boy hears the local environment devastated by the money-hungry, tree-cutting, Thneed-knitting Once-ler, despite protests from the eponymous Lorax, a squatting, moustached creature "who speaks in the name of the trees.
Most likely, such a relatively minor PR task was delegated to a helper who did not read The Lorax to a child 20 times in a row.
A Downing Street spokeswoman said the text probably came from Cameron's constituency office.
SuperCamps confirmed that the text was supplied by Cameron's staff, but did not give any further direct comments.

The brexite stockpile (brexite = Britain's exit from the EU) could gain in popularity if the economy goes into a slump by 2017
David Cameron's half-baked renegotiation strategy to keep Britain in the EU is getting deeper every day, even without the choice of the ingenious Jeremy "Is it yes or no? Corbyn to the leader of Labour or the TUC, which fell out violently over Europe on Tuesday.
Foreigners also have their Corbyns and Nigel Farages.
A European diplomat friend recently said that some member states, as deeply entangled in various crises as the EU is and not always through their own fault, are fed up with Britain's self-made agenda of split concessions and disruptive treaty changes that they usually do not want.
In Brighton, the TUC decided at its annual meeting that they do not like it when they threaten social protection either.
We might as well call it Dave and George's selfie agenda.
Prime ministers and finance ministers climb at summits or bilateral meetings in foreign capitals, take a photo of themselves in front of a famous local monument, with or without local celebrities, then come home and say they are winning allies for reform.
It's always about me.
My European friend, who wants Britain to look outwards from the EU tent - "Don't leave us alone with France," says Berlin - and suggests that more and more short-sighted ministers and officials in some capitals have come to the point where they don't care whether we stay or go.
Germany's cautiously prudent Chancellor Angela Merkel is an ally, but she has been in power for 10 years and wants to leave office before it looks bad for her, as has happened with the overly persistent ones like Thatcher (11 years), Mitterrand (14) and Kohl (16).
France's François Hollande looks forward to his re-election or replacement in 2017.
He is also a fading force.
Poland may soon have a nationalist right-wing government, Spain a left-wing one.
It's hard to imagine that they'll break a leg to help the Selfie Brits, whose energy would be better spent on preventing Scotland from leaving the UK - something they don't want either, because most have similar separatist tendencies.
Therefore, some such ministers may even deliberately plan to make unhelpful remarks, entirely SNP-style, during Britain's 2017 referendum campaign to speed up the brexite process, my friend suspects.
"The renegotiation was a bust" and "Britain gained nothing of value from the renegotiation."
Europeans know how predatory Fleet Street can be at their expense and what EU-sceptics the oligarchy of press barons is, but they were not during the Tony Benn inspired referendum in 1975, which supported our entry in 1973 with a 2:1 ratio.
You may faintly remember Boris Johnson, the arch-euro-opportunist who made a name for himself as an "EU straight banana" Brussels correspondent in the early 1990s.
For all his craziness, Ed Miliband knew who his enemies were.
These included the medley of tax-fearing villains, phone-hacking foreigners and the pseudo non-residents that most of our major newspapers have.
Actually, Tony Blair thought similarly about them, but found that when you're in a cage with a hot gorilla, it's better to hand out bananas to distract him rather than become his lunch and dinner.
In fact, Miliband was more Blairian than Blair himself when he opposed Cameron's referendum frenzy because Blair had put principle above the EU's unadopted constitution, which was then rejected by French and Dutch voters in 2005, opening a back door for him.
The press has never forgiven him for that either.
But the nice Jeremy Corbyn, who gave me a friendly pat on the back on Monday in Westminster - I told him not to waste any more time on me - seems in danger of repeating Neil Kinnock's boycott Murdoch strategy of the 80s, a mistake then and now.
It may take time, but he must develop a coherent strategy to win the media, not with me, but certainly with Andrew Marr, whose BBC sofa he left on Sunday.
Corbyn's official position on Europe is - to put it nicely - under development.
He says that we should stay in a reformed EU.
Well, for most people outside of Ukip's traditional blue dye tendency and the wilder climes of Tory's Little Englishism, I think everyone can say yes.
It's what Hilary "A Benn but not a Bennite" Benn said on radio and television this week when the boy scout in him struggled not to admit that Corbyn's appointment of provocative John McDonnell as shadow chancellor was a bad idea.
It reminded me of the 1970s, when his old father tried to be disloyal to his Labour cabinet colleagues on television, without going too far and losing his cabinet job.
Hilary's fight was even more attractive.
But fighting to stay "under any circumstances" - Benn's phrase - was not what McDonnell said, nor what JC told his comrades-in-arms and MPs at their closed meeting on Monday night, according to all reports.
Whatever the maudlin bottom-up image of Corbyn is trying to convey - remember that it even touched me - news discipline remains important in the age of 24-hour TV, and especially in the maelstrom of social media, a hotbed of paranoia and betrayal.
It is right not to give Cameron a free ticket to Europe that would allow him to take Labour's support in the referendum campaign for granted, as McDonnell said.
Simon Jenkins must think so.
But McDonnell and Corbyn's fundamental ambiguities about EU membership - in line with their Bennite siege economy, their anti-capitalist past - is no longer just a matter of esoteric discussion among left-wing dissidents, for whom the narcissism of small difference is a central tenet of dogmatic disputes.
As with his ambiguities about Nato - Tom Watson is adamantly convinced that JC will not launch a campaign for withdrawal - foreign diplomats will be obliged to try to find a sense of purpose in everything for their superiors at home.
Why should Paris or Berlin waste political capital - they also have suspicious voters - to make concessions to the British when all this can be pointless?
The US is already quite disappointed with the poor military performance in Iraq, Libya and Syria, even with a reduction in the cost of the Tory government in power, which I was reminded of at Monday's launch by something called the British Influence Security Forum.
Experts criticize Public Health England report on e-cigarettes
Allegations by a government-funded agency that e-cigarettes are less harmful than smoking emerged from a meeting of 12 people, some with ties to the tobacco industry, researchers said.
Experts writing in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) joined Lancet in criticizing the evidence used by Public Health England (PHE) in their report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published the "Policy Report" last month and describes it as a "comprehensive review of the evidence".
However, some researchers have questioned the robustness of the data and pointed to the links between some experts and the tobacco industry.
An editorial in the medical journal Lancet last month attacked the "extremely windy foundation" on which PHE based its main conclusion.
Two other researchers write in BMJ and have asked whether the claims "are based on stone or sand".
Martin McKee, Professor of European Public Health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Simon Capewell, Professor of Clinical Epidemiology at the University of Liverpool, said: "A fundamental principle of public health is that strategies should be based on evidence of effectiveness".
They said that the public expects PHE's claim that "the current best estimate is that e-cigarettes are about 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed review of evidence and modeling.
In fact, this statement comes from a single meeting of 12 people convened to develop a model for a Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) to synthesise their opinions on the harm caused by various nicotine-containing products; the results of the meeting were summarised in a research report.
McKee and Capewell said a sponsor of the meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose managing director had previously received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent study.
He also signed BAT's references to public health in a sustainability report, they said.
One of the 12 participants in the meeting stated that he was receiving funding from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but not the funding he reportedly received previously from the tobacco company Philip Morris International, they added.
The reasons for selecting the members of the panel are not provided, but they include several well-known e-cigarette champions, some of whom also cite industry funding in the paper.
Some other participants in this meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
The meeting was also attended by the tobacco management of PHE.
The group's research "significantly admits" that there is a lack of "hard evidence of damage to most products for most criteria," wrote McKee and Capewell.
However, none of these links or limitations are discussed in the PHE report.
McKee and Capewell said PHE's claims that "there is no evidence yet that e-cigarettes serve as a way for children or non-smokers to smoke" were premature.
Prof. Kevin Fenton, Director of Health and Well-being at PHE, said that the BMJ's allegations had already been acted upon earlier.
He said, "E-cigarettes are much less harmful than smoking."
Every second lifelong smoker dies of his addiction.
All the evidence suggests that the health risks of e-cigarettes are small in comparison, but that we still need to study the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear duty to inform the public about what the evidence proves and what it does not, especially when there is so much public confusion about the relative dangers compared to tobacco.
Almost 80,000 people die each year from a smoking-related disease and smoking costs the National Health Service £2 billion a year.
By clearly presenting current evidence that e-cigarettes are not without risk, but represent only a fraction of the damage caused by smoking, we are fulfilling our national responsibility.
BBC should give up EastEnders, says former head of Channel 4
The former chairman of Channel 4, Luke Johnson, has said that the BBC should stop broadcasting programmes like EastEnders and The Voice. He said that commercial rivals would "give their right arm" for hit shows like the Albert Square Soap.
Johnson said that the licence fee should only be used to make the kind of programmes that are not broadcast by other UK broadcasters.
He criticised the BBC for placing public service programmes, likely to be seen by a smaller audience, in highly controversial time slots against the most popular shows of their rivals and of channels like BBC4.
After the BBC's director general, Tony Hall, said the company wanted to do more in partnership with other organisations, Johnson said he had tried unsuccessfully to get in touch with the BBC for six years during his time at Channel 4.
"I have problems with the idea that the BBC commissions or broadcasts programmes that would also be clearly shown by non-subsidised rivals," Johnson told the House of Lords Communications Committee as part of its investigation into the future of the BBC.
If you want to keep the broadcasting fee, which I don't think is a good idea in the medium or long term, you should at least put your production on programs that others don't make or commission.
They are broadcasting The Voice in a prime time slot because they want to achieve the broadest possible support for their future.
The idea that no one else would show this is a joke, it is ridiculous, it is of course nonsense.
Johnson said, "I don't see why a regressive tax would finance programs that could be financed without subsidies.
The Voice is one such programme, EastEnders is another, admittedly both in-house productions.
Honestly, other channels would give their right arm for this.
I try to see how this public television should be.
I don't think that would reduce the BBC at all.
Johnson, a series entrepreneur who ran Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010, said the BBC was to blame for the hunt for ratings "because of the ambitions of the people who work there and because they believe this is the best way to secure long-term support.
His comments on the BBC's most popular shows reflect what the former head of Sky, Tony Ball, suggested in his MacTaggart lecture in Edinburgh in 2003 that the BBC should sell shows like EastEnders.
Johnson said that the more public niche programmes "should go to BBC4, where you can't really measure the audience, but they do their job, and they can argue, when they go on their hypocritical missions to justify £4 billion in licence fees, "Well, of course, we have created all these obscure programmes that nobody has seen.
They put her in a time window where no one ever wanted to see her.
Regarding the broadcasting fee, Johnson told the committee: "I urge you to find a more regressive system in terms of conditions, who can get the best value out of it.
Of course you all think, we all think, that for £150 a year you get a great value here, but for people who think £150 is a lot of money, I wonder if that's true, because they don't consume much of the BBC.
Former Sky- and Channel 5 boss David Elstein, who also testified before the committee on Tuesday, called for the BBC to review its Reithian mission to "inform, educate and entertain".
He said little of the BBC's production was now officially classified as education - he said it was 1% of its TV production and 0.1% on the radio - and it should take its cue from the public television stations in Australia and Canada to change this to "inform, educate and entertain".
On the question of partnerships, Elstein said the BBC should do more in areas such as the Proms, of which he said only a handful are shown on television, and form alliances with commercial broadcasters to make everything available online.
Sonogenetics' can control brain cells through sound waves
The video shows how the nematodes change direction the moment they are irradiated with sound impulses.
Scientists have bred worms with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves.
The tiny nematodes change direction the moment they are irradiated with sound impulses that have frequencies too high for the human ear to be heard.
The pulses work by switching on motor neuron cells that are genetically modified to carry the membrane channels that respond to ultrasound waves.
More on this topic: Researchers read and write brain activity with light
The researchers said the worms demonstrated the power of a new technique called Sonogenetics, in which ultrasound can be used to activate a number of brain, heart and muscle cells outside the body.
Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told The Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep brain stimulation, an invasive procedure that delivers electrical impulses to the brain of people to treat the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
Roundworms do not usually respond to ultrasound, but Chalasani found that they did when surrounded by a fluid with microscopic air bubbles.
The bubbles, he found out, amplify the ultrasonic waves that then penetrate the worms.
The amplified ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels, which are found in the membranes of some of the worm cells.
The sound waves cause these ion channels to open and activate the cells to which they are assigned, according to a report by Nature Communications.
To create ultrasound-guided nematodes, Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carry TRP-4 ion channels.
When he applies ultrasound to the altered creatures, the sound waves are amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted into the worms, where they switch on the altered motor neurons.
The procedure has some similarities with Optogenetics, a groundbreaking tool that enables scientists to switch neurons on and off with impulses from light.
But Chalasani said that Sonogenetics could have some advantages over this technique.
Unlike light, which must be sent down an optical fibre to the desired location in the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue unhindered and can thus be sent into the brain from above the skull.
"We believe that with gene therapy and a therapeutic virus it is possible to make targeted human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments," Chalasani said.
Other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells, he added.

One of the parody ads produced by Special Patrol Group.

Another of the anti-gun trade posters greets commuters on the subway.

They toyed with the invention of a more realistic dubious corporate advertising, but "by bluing it in with bright colors and animation, it sticks more.

Eight golden rules for living in student residences
Eleven years ago, as a self-forgotten 19-year-old, I moved into a dormitory, still believing in Berets and moral relativism, but only now do I remember the tense smiles of those I annoyed - and the numerous, long-winded complaints about others.
Most of what I have learned can be distilled into eight simple rules.
Moving into student residences ranges from slightly nerve-racking to absolutely terrifying.
It's tempting to chat: People talk about where you're from, if and where you took sabbatical, where you are in relation to Corbyn and why you "honestly don't love or hate Marmite, because seriously, guys, it's just a yeast extract HAHAHA, I'm in my room."
Take a breath.
And help others to do the same - ask questions and show interest.
It directs the conversation and helps you find out the people you like as opposed to those you would not talk to even if your eyelashes caught fire and they were fire extinguishers.
Let people.
People's rooms are often transformed into drinks receptions, movie-night venues and community meeting places, but they are also the places where people get dressed and adjust their underwear.
In this regard: Don't think about starting a relationship in college
Introverts receive rough treatment at the university.
Your room should be a refuge, but many student residences form a room-to-room stroll culture that is friendly and social and can lead to lifelong friendship.
It can be hell for someone trying to recover.
Nothing in the culture allows you to say, "I like you, and I want our friendship to continue, but you have to go away so I can get back the energy I spent interacting with you."
Try to sense when a fellow student is exhausted from socializing - and send him an SMS instead of knocking.
Speaking of knocking, do it.
A guy in my dormitories had the idea that an unlocked door was an invitation.
He saw some things.
Make friends through baking.
Since you're starting college at the height of your back mania, knocking on people's doors to introduce yourself with a plate of brownies is less odd than the 1950s greeting "Welcome to the neighborhood, I baked you something. Now smile when I ask you some personal questions."
Offering homemade treats is a great way to make friends.
Your roommates feel obliged to talk to each other and may end up associating your face with a delicious surprise.
Of course this depends on whether you are a decent baker.
Badly mixed lumps of flour, sugar and fat cause people to pretend to be asleep when you knock.
Stealing food is a common crime in dormitories.
Of course stealing chicken is a theft, but is taking a drop of milk for your tea?
Check with the dairy owner.
Chances are they'll say to help themselves even if they're cooking inside.
If someone steals your things, it's annoying, and you have my sympathy - but try to deal with it in a more balanced way than my roommate, who added a detergent to her milk to punish thieves.
She's in prison now.
You should not make any noise that keeps people from sleeping or from working.
It is not only about being a decent person, but that you are, in the truest sense of the saying, one of the people who sit in the glass house.
A girl in my hallway asked her neighbours if they would mind turning down Drum & Bass a bit, because it's three in the morning and she had an exam in the morning.
They reacted to this with even louder music.
When they finally stopped at 5 o'clock, she kindly let her neighbours sleep for another two hours before she let her own music bawl, locked her door and went to her three-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future spouse happened to move into the same dormitory?
Conversely, wouldn't it be profoundly embarrassing if you thought a roommate was your future spouse, if you had to make a pass at her, break up with her again, and then have to see her every day, and perhaps witness her pulling all your mutual friends over to you?
Of course, the heart goes its own way - but if a hot roommate is definitely not your future spouse, at least try to talk some sense into your abdomen.
In the exciting moment when you notice that someone has left his keys in his unlocked room, the line between a joke and bullying is finer than it seems.
A good prank is funny, but it only takes moments before it becomes a boomerang.
Teach a valuable and fun safety lesson by hiding - but never mess up someone's room with toothpaste and shampoo.
Lock your door and put your keys in a glass of water, which you then put in the freezer - but don't staple your belongings to the ceiling more than twice.
terraced houses for refugees, single parents, low-income earners
The real estate entrepreneur Markus Gildner is building terraced houses in Eckental in Central Franconia for people who do not have much money.
For refugees, for example - but also as a signal: "Not only refugees need housing, but also single mothers and low-income earners.
"I show how you can still build cheaply and well today," says the 44-year-old in an interview
Thousands of refugees will crowd into the housing market.
The entrepreneur Markus Gildner believes he knows how quickly affordable housing can be created: He is building terraced houses for refugees in a project.
Mr. Gildner, many refugees will be pushing into the housing market.
Which solution do you offer?
Markus Gildner: The mass accommodation in containers or gymnasiums has no sustainability.
Because the people stay here for the most part.
In view of the flow of refugees, we will need sufficient living space for the coming decades.
A quite banal, three-storey terraced house is the solution.
Gildner: A terraced house needs the least space.
It facilitates integration.
It's different when you put people in apartment buildings.
Each of the six houses currently being built in the pilot project consists of three housing units for four asylum seekers each.
Each living unit has two bedrooms, a bathroom, a kitchen and a lounge.
It may be that many refugees will say, it is peace again, I am going back.
Then the houses can easily be rebuilt according to the respective needs.
What are the costs?
Gildner: The price for 160 square metres of living space per house is 184,000 euros, not including the land.
That's manageable.
It took six months to build.
That is appropriate.
Did the building regulations complicate their plans?
Gildner: In terms of building law, I carried out my project correctly.
It is always particularly complicated by the threatening sword of Damocles special construction and the parking regulations.
Creepy.
It is still assumed that whoever creates three apartments in a row house needs at least three parking spaces.
Only in the cities there is no room for this.
And refugees and asylum seekers have no cars.
How did the residents react to their terraced house project?
Gildner: There were those who accused me of creating luxury buildings for asylum seekers.
Which is definitely not true.
But aren't you intensifying the competition for affordable housing?
Gildner: The truth is that we have had a building boom in Germany over the last five years, but luxury apartments have been built that hardly anyone can afford.
My project has the message that ordinary people also need housing.
Not only refugees, but also the single mother or the low-income earner.
I show how you can still build well and cheaply today.
That's the point.
Markus Gildner (44) studied microsystems technology in Regensburg and initially focused on environmental analysis.
iOS 9: How to get the new iPhone operating system when Apple update is released
The new operating system can be requested by going to the settings app, tapping on "General" and then selecting "Software Update".
When it is ready, the phone gives you the option to download and then install.
Some have encountered problems after installation because they receive an error message stating that the "software update failed".
To work around this problem, users are advised to either wait until the rush returns or try to update via iTunes.
The phone itself guides you through the rest of the process.
This may mean deleting apps to make room - but Apple has made this less likely by streamlining the update. It will also be easier to do this if you use a special tool to delete apps and then reinstall them once the process is complete.
It is worth making sure that your phone is charged during the update or is near a charger so that the battery is charged.
If the charge is too low, Apple will not allow the update to continue because the phone might shut down halfway through the update and this could cause the update to stop.

Viennese architect Karl Mang died at the age of 92
Karl Mang, one of the doyens of Viennese architecture, is dead.
He already died on 5 September at the age of 92, as the Künstlerhaus announced on Tuesday.
With Mang, the Künstlerhaus loses an honorary member and at the same time "one of the most important architects of the second half of the 20th century in Vienna", as it was stated in the broadcast.
Born in Vienna in 1922, Mang studied architecture during and after the Second World War at the Technical University in Vienna under Friedrich Lehmann.
Since 1952 he worked as a freelance architect, but also as a teacher, writer and institute director.
From 1972 to 1983 he was president of the Austrian Institute of Design.
In the 1980s he was commissioned to furnish the Treasury in the Vienna Hofburg and to convert Palais Lobkowitz into the Austrian Theatre Museum.

Strict controls are carried out in order to qualify for membership of the Schengen area.

Confronted with the subject matter through personal experience, she read a lot of literature and decided to become involved in euthanasia.
When the Ecumenical Hospice Aid called for volunteers, it immediately contacted them and was involved in the foundation in 1995.
Godefroid is part of a team of 45 volunteers - 43 women and two men - who accompany patients and their families in private households, hospitals, nursing homes and the St. Vincent Hospice.
They are all carefully trained.
Angelika Godefroid is good at her job and the experiences and lessons learned.
"I see life from a different perspective, consider it precious and appreciate the moment," she says.
The outpatient ecumenical hospice service is free of charge and independent of denomination.
Financial support from health insurance companies and donations from relatives and associations make it possible to provide training, further training and supervision for the dying and grief counsellors.
Training courses for new employees are offered every two years.

FedEx results mixed, financial outlook for 2016 lowered
FedEx reported disappointing results for the last quarter and the delivery giant lowered its earnings outlook for a full year due to weaker demand for freight services and higher costs in its ground transportation service.
The company also said that it plans to hire about 55,000 seasonal workers for the holidays.
At that time last year, FedEx announced that the company would hire 50,000 seasonal workers for the holiday period.
The share fell over 2.5 percent in pre-market trading 45 minutes before the opening on Wednesday.
FedEx Corp. said to earn a profit between $ 10.40 and $ 10.90 in the fiscal year ending next May, 20 cents less than the previous forecast.
Analysts expected $10.84 according to a survey by FactSet.
The lower outlook comes despite price increases, which average 4.9 percent and will take effect on January 4, and despite higher surcharges for ground transportation of heavy and large parcels, which will be levied from November.
The company said that it nevertheless expects earnings to increase year-on-year due to cost reduction, higher revenues and growth in online retailing.
Chairman and CEO Fred Smith said the company is "delivering solid earnings considering the weaker than expected economic conditions, particularly in manufacturing and global trade.
The plans for the holiday employment were announced a day later than those of rival UPS, which plans to hire 90,000 to 95,000 additional workers, about the same number as last year.
In the quarter ended August 31, FedEx earned $692 million, up 6 percent year-over-year.
Earnings per share were $2.42 per share, just behind the $2.44 per share predicted by twelve analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Sales increased by 5 percent to $12.3 billion.
Six analysts interviewed by Zacks expected $12.23 billion.
FedEx has seen a decline in international priority shipments in recent years, which has caused turnover in its Express Shipping unit to stagnate.
But the boom in online shopping has boosted results at FedEx Ground.
In the last quarter, revenue from ground transportation increased by 29 percent, but the operating result was basically flat due to higher costs for larger packages and self-insurance.
The Express unit recorded higher revenues due to higher prices, while earnings declined due to higher labour costs in the freight business.
In pre-market trading, about an hour before opening, FedEx shares fell by $3.85, or 2.5 percent, to $150.15.
On Tuesday they closed with an 11 percent loss for the year and 17 percent below a record high on June 11.
At their most anticipated meeting of the year, Federal Reserve strategists spend two days this week sitting around a 27-foot Honduras-Mahogany table to decide whether it is time to raise interest rates for the first time in almost a decade.
Threatening above them at one end of the decorated two-storey boardroom is a mural of the United States.
The card is a reminder that Fed Chairman Janet L. Yellen and her colleagues should put the nation's economic interests before anything else.
The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate from Congress: maximize US employment and keep prices stable here.
But since the great recession, Fed leaders have acknowledged that there is an unwritten third mandate: financial stability.
And this third mandate could be the X factor in a decision that is too narrow to predict. It will be announced on Thursday whether the U.S. economy is ready to start weaning itself from the unprecedented stimulus provided by near-zero short-term interest rates since late 2008.
Although most economic data show that the economy is growing solidly, the recent turmoil in global financial markets may make the already cautious Fed representatives fear that this volatility could be exacerbated - even if only by a quarter of a percentage point - by raising the interest rate on Bunds.
"Obviously, the labour market and inflation will be the most important thing they observe," said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at the brokerage firm Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
"But I think if they were looking for an excuse not to raise interest rates, the increased uncertainty around the global market is enough justification to continue to wait," she said.
There is no consensus on what the Fed will do, which in itself is unsettling the financial market.
About half of the economists recently surveyed by Bloomberg have predicted a rate hike this week.
However, the financial markets expect the Fed to wait, with a key indicator showing only a 30% chance of a rise.
This suggests that the stock market will fall if the Fed raises the rate, unless the strategists soften the blow by promising that a further increase is far away.
On Tuesday the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped by 228.89 points or 1.4% to 16,599.85.
The action was triggered by expectations that Fed policy will maintain the rate this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
It would be a surprise if the Fed raised rates at this point," he said.
If she does, "she would have to go very far in her statement to calm the financial markets so that they do not panic."
Other experts argued that a rate hike would calm the financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed will act.
Only a month ago the Fed seemed well on track to raise the rate by 0.25 percentage points this month, the first small step in a slow tightening of monetary conditions that would test the strength of the US recovery.
Yellen had said in the spring and early summer that she expected the rate to rise this year despite complaints from liberals that more economic progress was needed.
Although job creation slowed down in August, the improvement in the labour market was solid this year.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1% last month, the lowest in more than seven years and close to the level that the Fed considers full employment.
Wage increases have shown signs of recovery.
And although inflation has consistently been below the central bank's annual target of 2%, the Fed representatives said that the main reason was the temporary effect of significantly lower oil prices.
The economy "can cope with higher interest rates and needs them because of the tightness in the labor market," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
But financial markets around the world flinched at the end of last month after China devalued its currency.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 16% below its peak in May as investors feared that a slowdown in the Chinese economy would curb global growth.
The market has recovered somewhat this month, with the Dow now almost 10% below its May high.
For the Fed representatives, the market turbulence affects the complex calculation of when to raise interest rates.
"If events in the financial markets and news of the weakness of the Chinese economy in the last few weeks had not occurred, they would have tightened the reins in this session," said Stephen D. Oliner, senior research fellow at UCLA's Ziman Center for Real Estate and a former Federal Reserve employee.
Now he predicts that she will wait at least a month to get a better grip on the effects.
"There is a lot of uncertainty about what the impact on the US economy will be, and there is almost no reliable data to describe developments in China," Oliner said.
The health of the global economy is not one of the Fed's main concerns, so technically it should not be involved in its decision-making.
But in the end, the Fed has become the monetary authority of the world.
The influence of the central bank has been enormous in recent years.
The mere indication in 2013 by the then head Ben S. Bernanke that the Fed could "narrow" its monetary expansion caused confusion around the globe.
In a world where markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, Fed representatives can be expected not only to monitor developments elsewhere, but also to consult with other central banks and experts to gain a better understanding of the global economy.
Their decision making is "more art than science," said Zachary Karabell, head of global wealth management strategy for Envestnet Inc.
Jeffrey Lacker, President of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, VA., noted this month that "the Fed has a history of overreacting to financial market movements that appear to be unrelated to economic fundamentals.
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, who advocates an interest rate increase, cited decisions in 1998/1999 as an example.
A financial crisis in Asia led the Fed to cut its key interest rate by 0.75 percentage points in three sessions "despite limited discernible effects on growth in the USA", said Lacker.
A year later, the Fed representatives reversed these cuts.
The Fed should only prioritize aspects of financial stability during a severe crisis like the 2008 market collapse, said Adam S. Poznan, former member of the Bank of England's Interest Rate Setting Committee.
The recent turbulence is not coming near this level, he said.
"She certainly doesn't want to get into a situation where she's afraid of an interest rate hike because the markets are upset," said Poznan, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still contains the dual mandate and does not mention financial stability, and until that is changed, I don't think it should be ahead of its time.
Do you need a great Thai market?
Try LAX-C in Chinatown.
Yeah, Chinatown
The store / warehouse was opened in 1997 and is owned by LAX-C Inc.
LAX-C is often referred to as Thai Costco and is a Thai wholesale market which also sells to the general public.
Yeah, he's in Chinatown, not Thai Town.
The market/warehouse is a one-stop shop and offers a bewildering array of fresh, frozen and dried goods, popular Thai and Asian snacks, and tableware, furniture, religious decorations and Christmas decorations.
There is even a car department if you need motor oil.
The store is huge and it takes over an hour to stroll through the aisles.
If all that shopping makes you hungry, there is a meal for you in the LAX-C BBQ Express.
The cookshop (good and inexpensive) in this store is located near the cash registers and has various take-away options.
What there is here: Do you need anything - anything - Thai?
LAX-C probably has it.
Products are inexpensive and a number of them are sold in large quantities.
Fresh products include Asian specialities and regional Thai herbs, fruit and much more.
The meat counter is extensive, as is the fish counter - the staff behind the counter will clean and fillet the fish and even fry it for you if you wish.
A good part of the shop belongs to the massive freezer department. Here you will find frozen curry leaves, bitter melon and galangal, whole ducks, fish, beef blood and bile, pork natural gut, fish balls, regional sausage, commercially prepared foods and more.
Who buys here: restaurant owners and cooks, also individual families and individuals.
The wide aisles are suitable for shopping trolleys and forklift trucks.
You will find here: fresh Monthong Durian next to the cash desk.
Where he is: The store is located in an industrial area of Los Angeles on the outskirts of Chinatown and downtown - a few blocks away from Philippe The Original.
Parking: LAX-C has its own parking area, together with other shops and restaurants.
Even if the shop is well attended, it is not difficult to find a parking space.

Brazil's paediatric society Rio Grande promotes nutrition for healthy breastfeeding
The Brazilian paediatric organisation SPRS is trying to educate women in a shocking way about the importance of good nutrition during breastfeeding. She does this by presenting pictures of babies sucking on breasts painted with depictions of unhealthy foods.
Breast milk consists of a variety of proteins, fats, vitamins and carbohydrates that give babies all the nutrients they need to build a strong immune system.
Due to the additional energy requirements, pregnant women and young mothers are advised to increase their daily calorie intake by about 500 calories per day.
However, new research suggests that a higher calorie intake is not the only dietary adjustment mothers should make.
A recent study led by Robert Waterland, professor at the Baylor College of Medicine in Texas, showed that a healthy diet of pregnant women actually affects the genes of their babies and protects them from developing tumors.
Unfortunately, an unhealthy diet of the child can negatively influence the immune system.

The Bernried municipal council approved the building application for the 2.3 million euro sports hall.
And he made an exception.
The roof may become flatter for solar power systems.
The plans for the long-awaited gymnasium construction at the Bernried sports grounds are progressing step by step: In the latest meeting of the municipal council, the elaborated building application was unanimously approved without much discussion.
Previously, the committee had decided, among other things, on an application for an "exemption" or "exemption" from the valid development plan.
The "exception" was about the permission for a special form regarding the roof construction.
According to this, a "gable roof with non-central ridge and roof overhang" is to be erected.
The background to the planning is the intended use of the roof area for solar systems: "This will give us a wonderfully large south-facing roof together," explained Mayor Josef Steigenberger at the meeting.
The "exemption" was again about the roof pitch, which for energy reasons - in contrast to what is stipulated in the development plan - should be less than ten degrees.
The volume of the hall is thus significantly reduced.
An "exemption" became necessary because the development plan does not allow any "exceptions" with regard to the roof pitch - although the Bernried local council generally tends to be rather restrictive when applying for an exemption.
However, the construction of the gymnasium is not a recurring project: "We are not setting a precedent with this," says Steigenberger.
The construction of the gymnasium at the sports centre is a joint project of the municipality and the SV Bernried.
Costs of around 2.3 million euros have been taken into account.
Grants are expected from school and mass sports promotion.
In the next procedural step, the building application for the 18 x 36 metre hall will now be submitted to the district administration office for examination.

Refugees need shelter: Study warns of housing shortage
The situation on the German housing market is tense.
More and more refugees are also looking for an affordable place to stay.
The pressure on the housing market is growing.
Social housing is facing a challenge.
The distribution struggles in the German housing market have long since begun.
With the arrival of refugees and job seekers from the EU, more and more people are pushing their way into a market that is already overcrowded in many large cities.
They compete with low-income citizens for the last affordable housing.
To meet the demand for affordable housing, 400,000 new units would have to be built each year until 2020.
This is the result of a study commissioned by the association "Sozialer Wohnungsbau".
For comparison: 260,000 units will be completed in Germany this year.
This means that 140,000 apartments are missing.
After the first three months of their stay, refugees are no longer obliged to live as asylum seekers in initial reception accommodation.
Many then come across the housing market and join the long lines in front of the rental apartments.
According to the Federal Statistical Office, however, less than half of all asylum seekers lived in rented accommodation last year.
However, the negative development of the housing market is not only due to the increasing number of refugees.
The study also identifies significant omissions in housing policy in recent years.
He said that Germany is facing a housing deficit that is growing from year to year.
Currently, there is already a shortage of around 770,000 housing units in the conurbations, complains Matthias Günther, author of the study.
Many working people therefore had no choice but to live in shared rooms in large cities.
Young adults involuntarily stayed longer at "Hotel Mama" because of the slump on the housing market.
The number of square metres per capita in the large cities has fallen for the first time in recent years.
To solve the problem, the alliance "Social Housing" proposes a new start.
At the same time, new incentives are intended to revive social housing construction.
For example, the land transfer tax could be waived and the land tax for subsidised housing could be temporarily suspended.
In addition, according to the alliance, attractive tax depreciation options are necessary.
The support programme for refugee accommodation of the state bank KfW is already well received by cities and municipalities.
A good week after the launch, 184 million euros had already been called up on Monday evening, more than half of the approximately 300 million euros available.
Now the project could even be increased.

4 people killed after police shoot rubber bullets at demonstrators in Nepal
Four people, including a 4-year-old boy, were killed in southern Nepal after police fired rubber bullets into a crowd demonstrating against the proposed new constitution, an official said Wednesday.
The violence erupted on Tuesday evening in the Rupandehi district, some 175 miles west of the capital Kathmandu.
Bishnu Prasad Dhakal, senior district official, said that more than 1,000 demonstrators had gathered outside a police station, some of them throwing stones and fire bombs.
Mr Dhakal said that the police used tear gas and then fired into the air before resorting to rubber bullets.
20 police officers and five civilians were injured, he said.
It was not immediately clear why the rubber bullets used, which are known to kill but are traditionally used as a less lethal alternative, apparently produced such a high death rate.
The clash was the latest in weeks of violent protests in Nepal's southern plains, where members of the Madhesi ethnic group say new provinces being formed under the proposed new constitution would reduce their political influence.
There were also protests in western Nepal by the Tharus ethnic group, who want their own state.
At least 40 people, including 11 police officers, have been killed in violent clashes since the 10th anniversary of the war.
He was killed on August 8 when the four major political parties signed an agreement to divide the country into provinces - an important step towards a new constitution, but a very controversial issue in Nepal, which has been centrally governed for centuries.
Work on a new constitution has been underway since 2008, but legislators accelerated the process after the devastating earthquake that killed thousands of people in April.
Legislators voted this week on certain clauses in the draft constitution in Kathmandu, and officials said the new constitution could come into force on Sunday.

Reporting by Yasmeen Abutaleb; edited by Christian Plumb
For slightly overweight diabetics, weight loss surgery can be helpful.
The benefits of weight loss surgery for slightly overweight people with type 2 diabetes may last at least five years according to a new study.
It is still too early to say whether slightly overweight people with diabetes after weight loss surgery live longer than those who receive non-surgical treatments.
"Mortality data takes a long time to show anything," said Dr Robin Blackstone, a weight loss surgery expert who wrote an editorial on the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight loss surgery or obesity surgery, use various methods to reduce the size of the stomach.
They reduce hunger and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Over the years, obesity surgery has proven effective in treating type 2 diabetes, but most studies have been conducted in people who are morbidly obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a certain amount of weight in relation to height, is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9.
A BMI of 25 or more indicates that someone is overweight, and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI here: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv
For the new study, researchers from Taiwan's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data they have collected since 2007 in a study comparing two types of obesity surgery - gastric bypass and gastric tube formation - on medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were slightly overweight.
The average BMI among those who underwent this surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year in this study.
Meanwhile, the BMI remained about the same at 29 for those who received non-surgical diabetes treatments.
Among those who underwent surgery, 36% had their diabetes completely resolved and 28% partially resolved.
In the medically treated group, in comparison, only one percent of the patients with diabetes developed diabetes completely and only about two percent of the patients with diabetes developed diabetes.
In addition, the results of controls for blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol were "generally better in the 'surgical' group," the authors found.
The researchers also monitored patient blood levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects blood glucose levels over time.
Hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent, the researchers write.
After the operation, the average haemoglobin A1c level dropped from around 9 percent to around 6 percent.
In the medical therapy group, however, it remained stable at around 8 percent.
But this better "glycemic control" - as reflected in improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce mortality in five years, according to lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and his colleagues.
The research team also compared average results for the two types of surgery.
In the fifth year, the bypass surgery group had lost more weight compared to the gastrectomy group (18.7 vs. 14.2 kg), achieved greater decreases in BMI (7.4 vs. 5.1) and hemoglobin A1c (3.1% vs. 2.1%) and were more likely to have completely overcome diabetes (46.9% vs. 16.7%).
While the new study shows no survival benefit of surgery after five years, there is evidence from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery leads to a longer life, says Blackstone of the University of Arizona, College of Medicine Phoenix.
In the Swedish study, obese people undergoing obesity surgery were about 29 percent less likely to die within 15 years compared to a group that tried more conventional methods.
Although the new study showed no survival benefit in surgical patients, Blackstone said it was reassuring for people with a BMI below 35 who are interested in the procedure.
"This is the critical point of this study because it says this surgery is lower in this lower BMI group," without increased risk of death or kidney disease, she said.
Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously as soon as the patient's BMI is between 27 and 30.
"I think that we wait too long to get people to take this seriously," she said.
I think that once they have accumulated these genetic changes that have hardwired their bodies to obesity and diabetes, a reversal is really hard".

Fourfold increase in the use of hand disinfectants by children in the last 4 years
Poison control centers in the United States report an almost 400 percent increase in the number of children under the age of 12 who swallow heavily alcoholic hand sanitizers, according to the Georgia Poison Center.
According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of the Georgia Poison Center, cases of hand sanitizer receipts in children under 12 years of age reported by poison control centers rose from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
"Children are getting more and more frequent access to these products, and unfortunately a percentage of them end up going to the emergency room," Lopez told CNN.
He said that some children drink disinfectant on purpose, while some do it to impress their friends or because of a dare in social media.
Videos on YouTube show how teenagers drink disinfectants just for a cheap experience.
Teenagers have allegedly mixed disinfectants with mouthwash containing alcohol to obtain a harder drink.
Younger children can be attracted by attractive scents of the disinfectants.
"A child does not think that this is bad for him," said Lopez.
Many of the more attractive (hand disinfectants) are those that are perfumed.
There are disinfectants with strawberry, grape and orange scents that are very appealing to children.
Hand disinfectants contain somewhere between 45 and 95 percent alcohol.
Especially with small children, even a few splashes can lead to alcohol poisoning.
"It's highly concentrated alcohol," said Dr. Stephen Thornton, medical director of the poison control center at the University of Kansas Hospital, Fox 4 station in Kansa City.
So, you wouldn't leave a sip of whiskey standing around, but people leave these hand sanitizers within reach of children, and if children get hold of them, it is a quick way to consume a lot of alcohol.
Nhaijah Russell, a six-year-old girl who had recently taken four drops of strawberry-scented hand disinfectant at school, was taken to an emergency room for treatment.
Her blood alcohol level was 179, twice the legal threshold for an adult to be legally considered drunk, said Dr. Chris Ritchey, an emergency room physician who treated her at the Gwinnett Medical Center outside Atlanta.
Nhaijah slurred her words and was not able to leave when she arrived at the emergency room.
Doctors monitored her overnight in a separate children's hospital for signs of brain trauma as the girl had fallen through alcohol and hit her head, Ritchey said.
"That was very scary," Ortoria Scott, Nhaijah's mother, told CNN.
It could have been fatal to my child.
Lopez has recommended that parents and teachers use alcohol-free products or disinfectant wipes and store hand disinfectants out of reach of the child.
In addition to alcohol poisoning, some disinfectants were associated with deaths.
In 2013, two Ontario women died after swallowing hand disinfectants containing a toxic, undeclared ingredient.
Health officials suspect that the product contained methanol, a lethal solution, instead of ethyl alcohol, which was listed as the active ingredient.
In January, three fourth-grade students in New York State planned to poison their "mean" teacher by placing antibacterial products around the classroom," according to a police report.
The teacher is highly allergic to hand disinfectants and banished her from her room.

He has asked me to be one of the four official witnesses to his death.
The invitation was first extended in January through his best friend, and although I was shocked, I agreed.
As the day approached, I began to fear.
So why should I do it?
I agreed because I thought it would be a good way to tell the whole story about the death penalty.
It would offer a unique perspective.
It is true that journalists are allowed to watch executions in the USA, and since there are often more applications than seats available, a macabre lottery is held to decide who gets elected.
Oklahoma has reduced the number of media seats from 12 to five.
Those who are chosen will observe it without emotion.
I can't do this.
I will be sitting next to Richard Glossip's closest friend, with whom I have developed my own relationship over the months with phone calls and a two and a half hour visit.
I like this guy.
We often laugh a lot when we talk.
The prison authorities say that I cannot be a witness and a journalist, so I will not be allowed to take a notebook and pen to record what I see.
I just have to try to remember all the details.
A journalist from Oklahoma accused me on Twitter of giving up my impartiality.
Here's the lesson.
Tell the inmate's story the way he wants to, and you'll get access.
I complained to her.
She admitted that she "could have put it better", but she still thinks it's wrong what I'm doing.
Richard Glossip had problems with some of the things I said and wrote.
He doesn't tell me what to write, and I wouldn't do it even if he did.
I told him he could remove me from his list of witnesses at any time.
But he wants an international reporter present to write there.
When he dies, he thinks that public relations will help the movement against the death penalty.
Kim Bellware, a reporter for the Huffington Post, will be sitting next to me.
If you want to know more about the case, please listen to the series of podcasts I made.
I don't want to go into all the details here again.
I can't say for sure that Richard Glossip is innocent.
His actions after the murder of Barry Van Treese would make him guilty of being a beneficiary of the crime.
But I think there's a strong possibility he's not guilty of murder.

I believe that his execution is wrong.

Stuttgart: Extension of tropical storm "Henry" expected in the southwest
Meteorologists warn of squalls in the southwest of Wednesday afternoon.
Due to a low pressure system over Western Europe, warm sea air is currently flowing into the country, the German Weather Service (DWD) announced in Stuttgart.
The strong depression is the offshoot of tropical storm "Henry", which has crossed the Atlantic from the Bermuda Islands in the past few days.
Heavy storms and thunderstorms are expected especially in Baden.
According to the DWD, gusts of 60 to 90 kilometres per hour are also expected until Thursday morning in the Black Forest, the Swabian Alb and the Lake Constance area.

It's the masses: Every two years the car manufacturers show their innovations at the IAA.
In 2015, there will be movement above all in compact cars, which are currently selling particularly well.
Cars from the compact class are currently in particularly high demand: according to the Federal Motor Transport Authority (KBA), this segment accounted for around 28.1 percent of new registrations in August alone.
This is also reflected at the IAA (public days 17 to 27 September).
Between all the futuristic concept cars and new upper class and luxury cars, this year will see the launch of many new compact models in particular.
One of the biggest premieres for the German car industry is the Opel Astra, which will be available at the dealerships in autumn.
"The Astra is an extremely important model for us," Opel CEO Karl-Thomas Neumann said at the show.
It belongs to the core of the brand.
In order for the volume model to sell well, the new Astra should not be much more expensive.
Opel holds out the prospect of an entry below its biggest competitor VW Golf, which starts at 17 650 Euros.
The current Astra costs from 16 990 euros.
The Astra is available with a new 1.4-litre engine with 74 kW/100 PS.
In addition, the Hessians also offer other diesel and gasoline engines ranging from 70 kW/95 hp to 147 kW//200 hp, including three-cylinder gasoline engines for the first time.
Unlike its main competitors, VW Golf and Ford Focus, the Opel Astra is initially only available as a five-door model.
The second variant will be the station wagon, which can already be seen at the IAA in spring.
And what other new compact cars will be presented at the IAA besides the Astra?
Renault Mégane: Renault is launching the fourth generation of its Astra competitor Mégane.
At the show, the Mégane will be on display exclusively as a five-door model in a conventional and a decidedly sporty GT version.
It will be on sale at the beginning of next year, then also as a station wagon.

With the new model, the Nissan subsidiary wants to find its position in the rapidly growing segment.
At the same time, the compact Infiniti with its curved lines fits in perfectly with the brand's design line.
The basic model will have a petrol engine with a power of at least 90 kW/122 hp.
However, a diesel with 80 kW/109 PS or 125 kW/170 PS is also available.
Suzuki Baleno: New in the segment is also the Suzuki Baleno, which celebrates its world premiere in Frankfurt.
The model is offered with petrol engines, including a newly developed 1.0-litre turbo engine with an output of 82 kW/111 hp.
According to the manufacturer, the maximum torque is 170 Newton metres (Nm).
Sales of the Baleno in Europe will start in spring 2016.
DS 4: Not completely new, but completely renewed is the compact class model DS 4, which can be seen at the IAA.
