JVA Berlin-Tegel: Five square meters of cell are inhumane
The Federal Constitutional Court has ruled in favour of an ex-convict of the Tegel prison, who had spent months in a cell that was too small.
Because of the violation of their human dignity, prisoners are generally entitled to financial compensation if they are housed in cells that are too small.
This was decided by the Federal Constitutional Court in a decision published on Wednesday.
According to the judges, the persons concerned can even hope for money if they were locked up in the too-small rooms for only a few days (Ref.: 1 BvR 1127/14).
This meant that an ex-convict was successful with his constitutional complaint in Karlsruhe: between June and November 2009, he was housed in a single cell with a floor area of around five square metres in the Berlin-Tegel prison; the toilet was not physically separated.
Afterwards the man, who according to his lawyer is now at large again, was transferred to a larger cell.
His official liability suit against the state of Berlin because of the unworthy prison conditions failed.
But the constitutional judges overturned the ruling of the Berlin Court of Appeal and referred the case back there for reconsideration.
They see the human dignity of the man violated.
Court of Appeal now decides on the amount of compensation
Even if, for legal reasons, only a few days of imprisonment out of the period in question were relevant for the compensation, there was a right to compensation, it was said.
Otherwise, "a degeneration of the legal protection of the personality would be to be feared".
The Court of Appeal must now clarify the amount of the monetary compensation.
Constitutional judges have often strengthened the rights of prisoners in the past.
For example, it was not until April that they awarded damages to an inmate for being locked up naked in a cell.
According to a 2011 decision, multiple occupancy of a cell without a separate toilet is also inhumane.
Karlsruhe also confirmed on Wednesday the Berlin Constitutional Court, which in a parallel case in November 2009 had certified that a prisoner had been housed in inhumane conditions.
The plaintiff at the time was housed for three months for between 15 and 21 hours daily in a cell similar to that in the Karlsruhe case.
The Berlin prisons had made the headlines in the last few weeks also because of a lack of personnel.
Prisoners are therefore locked up for 23 hours again and again, aggressiveness increases, even fights are said to have taken place because of the tense situation.
According to information from the judicial press office, 21 positions in Tegel are not filled due to a lack of new recruits, 19 are to be eliminated in 2016.
Angela Merkel and the refugee policy: "We can do it"
The immigration of refugees is an enormous challenge - the Chancellor is determined to take it on.
What is in store for Germany?
According to forecasts by the Federal Ministry of the Interior, approximately 800,000 asylum seekers will come to Germany this year. According to Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel (SPD), Germany is even able to take in one million refugees.
Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU) has demonstrated determination in the face of this unusual challenge: "I say again and again: We can do this, and we will do it".
The following overview gives an idea of what is in store for Germany.
According to different forecasts, between 350000 (estimate of the Federal Ministry of Construction) and 400000 (estimate of the Pestel-Institute) apartments are needed annually - and this for the next five years.
This is almost twice as much as is currently being built (250000 apartments).
However, the shortage of living space is particularly dramatic in the case of affordable rental properties: Every year, 60,000 to 80,000 social housing units fall outside the rent control system, and refugees will also apply for these particularly cheap housing units.
Federal Minister of Building and Construction Barbara Hendricks (SPD) therefore wants to double the funding, from currently 518 million to one billion euros.
From the point of view of the Pestel-Institute, this is far too little: 80,000 social housing units would have to be built every year and for this the federal government would have to invest a subsidy of 6.4 billion per year.
The scientists and the Federal Minister of Construction agree that there must also be more tax advantages for investments in housing construction.
According to estimates by the Institute for Employment Research, it can be assumed that in the long term, 55 percent of the refugees in Germany can be gainfully employed.
However, Claudia Walter, project manager for integration and education at the Bertelsmann Foundation, criticises that refugees in Germany are not systematically asked about their qualifications to help them get started.
For the integration of refugees, however, the decisive factor is whether they find work in Germany.
Work is the key to social contacts, to the appreciation in the host society, but also to the self-esteem of the immigrants, says migration researcher Dietrich Thränhardt.
According to Thränhardt, there has been a political turn in Germany: from a ban on work for refugees to the recognition of work.
While there used to be a ban on working for asylum seekers for up to five years, this was reduced to three months in November 2014, as was the residence requirement, which limits asylum seekers to one place of residence.
In society, the majority view has become established - also due to the lack of skilled workers - that refugees should be given faster access to the labour market.
A major hurdle for access to the labour market is a lack of German language skills.
So far there is not yet a sufficient supply of general and vocational language courses.
Studies also show that jobs are most often arranged through personal contacts.
In Thränhardt's view, the establishment of networks is therefore the ideal way to achieve work integration.
The Berlin school administration has found that only a few fugitive parents give their children to the daycare centers, an estimated 10 to 15 percent: "For uprooted parents, it is first of all very important to keep the family together," says Ilja Koschembar, spokesperson for youth and family in the Berlin Senate administration.
In order to convince the family of the advantages of the Kita, the administration distributes leaflets in different languages.
If the need for educators were to rise sharply due to the large number of refugees, the Berlin Senate would try to increase the training capacities - for example, by allowing more vocational schools.
In the Länder, pupils without knowledge of German are prepared for lessons in welcome classes.
However, they are not always taught by fully trained teachers, but, as in Berlin, also by teachers who only have a qualification in German as a second language.
There is no lack of them, says Beate Stoffers from the Berlin school administration.
The German Student Union estimates that about 20 percent of the refugees want to study in Germany.
In principle, no federal state prohibits asylum seekers or tolerated persons from studying - the only exception so far has been Berlin, but Interior Senator Frank Henkel (CDU) has now abandoned his position.
Access to higher education could be made easier for refugees wishing to study.
This is because refugees with a residence permit or a Duldung no longer receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act when they begin their studies.
The latter do not receive Bafög as a matter of principle, since they do not fall within the group of persons entitled to Bafög.
Tolerated refugees had to have lived in Germany for four years in order to be eligible for Bafög; from 1 January 2016 this period will be reduced to 15 months.
However, this funding gap must also be closed, demanded Steffen Krach, Berlin's State Secretary for Science, and the German Student Union.
The students should get Bafög immediately.
Islam will play a more important role in the future, because many refugees are Muslims and for many of them religion is an important part of their identity.
The state should successively grant Islam the same rights as the churches have, and develop the existing state-church law into a new state-religion relationship.
It would also be important to set up an Islamic welfare association that would take professional care of the newcomers.
Rights also include duties.
Thus the representatives of Islam must agree on clear points of contact and be prepared to cooperate with the state in many areas and to grant it certain possibilities of control.
This also includes the willingness to take courageous action against religious fundamentalism.
The chairman of the Central Council of Muslims, Aiman Mazyek, expressed concern on Thursday that religious conflicts could also be brought into Germany.
Those who wanted to fight out such conflicts in Germany "immediately forfeited their right to stay here, in Germany," he said on Bavarian Radio.
He proposed to translate the Basic Law into Arabic.
In the future, integration will be a topic of the whole society much more than it is today.
As a result, the majority society will also have to change and the reduction of discrimination and racism will become more urgent.
Germany has - as a result of European decisions - had an anti-discrimination office and a general equality law for almost a decade.
But it learns very slowly, as the NSU murder series showed, in which police and authorities systematically ignored the racist motive.
Equal opportunities for all: What migrant organisations and the interest groups of non-white Germans have long been calling for, and what international agreements such as the Convention against Racism oblige Germany to do, must become reality in the coming years if the country is to remain peaceful and its new citizens are to use their opportunities - for the benefit of all.
In general, Germany is able to provide medical care for the refugees expected so far, says medical president Frank Ulrich Montgomery.
"As far as manpower and capacities are concerned, we'll manage," he told the Tagesspiegel.
However, additional money would have to flow into the system.
In order to avoid bottlenecks, Montgomery demands that all arrivals receive health cards immediately upon registration.
Services rendered could later be invoiced to the federal states.
And in the long run it is highly questionable to fob off so many people with the limited benefits catalogue provided for by the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act.
Otherwise, the language barriers are the main problem for doctors.
The Berlin health scientist Thea Borde has already shown that migrants are less well informed about their diseases than other patients.
Not only in clinics, but also in doctors' surgeries interpreter costs would have to be covered, she demands.
However, many refugees would have been helped by more general medical contact points in the emergency clinics.
And with a different diagnostic perspective.
Among refugee children, for example, there were significantly more untreated disabilities, and among young people the focus was on HIV education.
However, Montgomery believes that German doctors are able to cope with the partially different clinical pictures due to their training.
"Parasite infestation or tuberculosis are not so difficult to detect". And as far as the lack of doctors is concerned, the refugees might even bring relief.
The Syrians had a highly developed education system, some refugees were even doctors.
In order to be allowed to practice, however, they would have to prove their qualifications and possibly take further examinations.
At least half of the refugees arriving in Germany are mentally ill, according to estimates by the Federal Chamber of Psychotherapists (BPtK): most of them suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder or depression.
Refugee children are particularly vulnerable, explains Dietrich Munz, president of the BPtK.
A recently published study by the Technical University of Munich shows that every fifth Syrian refugee child arrives in Germany traumatised.
Anyone suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder suffers from so-called flashbacks with shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations and fear of death.
Other symptoms are sleep and concentration disorders, severe jitteriness and emotional numbness.
In order to prevent the symptoms from becoming chronic, early treatment is necessary, explained Munz.
So far, however, only four percent of mentally ill refugees receive psychotherapy.
Although mentally ill asylum seekers can apply for psychotherapy at the social welfare offices, it usually takes several months to process.
In addition, in social welfare offices, it is usually clerks or doctors who are not trained in mental illness who decide whether or not therapy is necessary.
This often leads to misjudgements, says Munz.

Thursday is family day, for the performance at 5 pm the prices are reduced.
Furthermore, the animal show is open daily from 10 to 18 o'clock.

Hewlett-Packard will cut up to 30,000 jobs
Hewlett-Packard is expected to cut 25,000 to 30,000 jobs as part of the restructuring and cost-cutting efforts in the company's services.
HP will split into two publicly traded companies later this year, separating its computer and printer business from its fast-growing enterprise hardware and services business.
The expected job cuts will result in a charge of over $2.7 billion from the fourth quarter, HP said in a statement.
"These restructuring measures will enable a more competitive, sustainable cost structure for the new Hewlett-Packard enterprise," said Meg Whitman, HP chairman and chief executive who will lead the unit after the separation.
"Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP is today, and we have a broad and deepened portfolio of businesses that will help companies transition to a new style of doing business," said Whitman.
As an independent company, we are better positioned than ever to meet the changing needs of our customers around the world.
Hewlett Packard Enterprise has more than $50 billion in annual sales and "will be focused on delivering unparalleled, integrated technology solutions to enterprises," the company stated.
It divides a company founded in the 1930s by Stanford University graduates Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard to manufacture electrical equipment, whose Palo Alto garage has been called "the birthplace of Silicon Valley.
HP has undergone a massive restructuring to manage the shift from traditional PCs to mobile devices.
The move by HP, the world's second-largest PC manufacturer and one of the largest U.S. tech companies, is the latest in a series of measures based on the belief that tightly focused companies perform better.

FriendsFest: the comedy show that teaches us serious lessons about male friendships
The lack of similar representations in shows is obvious, especially in view of how the need for men to open up has now become more desperate than ever, as demonstrated by suicide rates among young men at a 15-year high.
In 2013, it was the leading cause of death among men aged 20-45 in the UK, and it remains three times more common among men than among women.
In an effort to address the problem, the Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) announced 2015 as the Year of Man, with the aim of challenging the culture that prevents men from seeking help when they need it.
Friendship is at the heart of the struggle to meet this challenge.
A recent study of more than 2,000 high school students with depressive symptoms found that if the sufferer had a sufficiently high percentage of friends with "healthy moods", their chances of recovery doubled.
For those who are not depressed, a circle of mentally healthy friends halves the risks of mental problems.
But of course you have to have friends first for a friendship to work.
In the age of social media communication, with its emphasis on style over substance, the immediacy of the response is often more important than meaningful contact.
Our digital lives have doubled the need to appear strong, fun-loving and successful, even when in reality isolation dominates.
This superficial success is dominated by what psychologists call extrinsic values; money, image, social status, all at the expense of intrinsic values - our inner longing for personal development and friendship, which has a much deeper impact on our mental health.
And as one video game inventor and billionaire recently explained, money really can't buy happiness.
The nice thing about Friends was that this focus was turned upside down.
Each character was defined not by his work, but by his personality, which shone through interaction as a friend.
The humour of Joey and Chandler's frequent hugs, moments watching football in comfortable armchairs, and Ross' longing for Rachel - all this came from the knowledge that men can relate to it in any case, even if they are often reluctant to fully explore their feelings.
As a member of the telephone counsellor's office explained to me... "my listening role for people who feel depressed and suicidal has really shown me how even the smallest interaction between friends can make a difference."
The men who contact us often feel unable to talk to friends.
The old saying "I can handle it" has an enormous effect, like the feeling that it is perceived as weakness when you talk about problems openly."
Friends is one of the shows that comes to mind when I try to offer more long-term coping mechanisms.
It presents very clearly the small moments of male friendships.
However much my objective outsider status over the phone may help people in moments of despair, the long-term support comes from a personal network of family and friends.
And so, if you're visiting Comedy Central FriendsFest this weekend with the completely redesigned backdrop to celebrate the day, why not take your friends for a drink at Central Perk.
Or better yet, if you see someone sitting alone in Starbucks, give them a smile and say hello.
You never know what difference your friendship might make.
Friends is broadcast on Comedy Central from start to finish - the whole 236 episodes - for #FriendsFest

Angel Di Maria celebrates with Blaise Matuidi and Edinson Cavani after his goal against Malmö.

Here are the game report and the reaction to the game.
Angel Di Maria and Edinson Cavani held their course as Paris Saint-Germain kicked off their Champions League season with a comfortable 2-0 win over Malmö at Prinzenparkstadion on Tuesday.
Di Maria scored less than four minutes after the start of his Champions League debut as PSG player who set up the French champions, but then missed a number of opportunities before finally increasing their lead when Cavani scored a header in the 61st minute.

"It's not easy to win at home or away in the Champions League. So it's a good start to win 2-0, cause our opponents problems and look back relaxed, even though there are certain things we need to perfect as the season progresses," said Blanc.
"This is a good omen.
We wanted to win and we won, although I regret that we didn't score another goal or two."
Ibrahimovic returned to the Paris side after his injury in one of three changes, who held on to a 2-2 draw in their own place against Bordeaux in the Premier League at the weekend, but he was knocked out by Di Maria in the fourth minute.

However, if anyone thought PSG would win a big win, they were disappointed.
Malmö, who beat Celtic in a play-off to reach that level, came up against nine national team players at Anpiff and was a tough opponent with a five-man defence and two lined up deep in midfield.
But apart from a shot from Nikola Djurdjic, which went well past Kevin Trapp's post in the 34th minute, they offered little in the attack.
Instead, PSG sometimes gave themselves up, with a number of misses and poor finishes, not least from Ibrahimovic, who failed on no less than five attempts in the first half alone and was then abandoned after Cavani had used him after the restart.
However, he was much more skilful when he brought his team-mates into the game, and it was a pass from Ibrahimovic that Di Maria turned into a spinning shot, which was deflected past the post by Wiland in the 52nd minute ...
The second goal finally came just after the hour mark thanks to Cavani. The Uruguayan scored his sixth goal of the season after Ibrahimovic had fished up Maxwell's left flank.
That put an end to any thoughts of Malmö coming back into the game and only a superb intervention from Wiland at close range to stop David Luiz could keep the final score low before substitute Ezequiel Lavezzi was denied a goal in the end.
The Malmö coach, Age Hareide, later admitted that PSG played a class above his team, and the Norwegian said: "Our last Champions League match was in December last year.
Since then we have only played in the Swedish league, which does not have the same level.
The qualifying matches are not enough."
Hats off to Paris!
It was a great game of them!
Glencore raises $2.5 billion through stock sales
Swiss-based mining giant Glencore, which has been hit by collapsing commodity prices, raised $2.5 billion on Wednesday through a stock sale as part of its huge debt repayment plan.
London-registered company Glencore said in a statement that it has sold new shares worth about £1.6 billion to pay off its own debts.
The company, which lost 57 percent of its market value this year, is struggling with falling commodity prices as China's economic downturn depresses demand and has a devastating effect on markets.
The issuance of subscription rights brought Glencore's share price to a rapid rise to the top of the London Stock Exchange in early Wednesday morning trading.
The share jumped 2.77 per cent to 131.60 pence on the FTSE 100 Index, which opened 0.69 per cent higher.
Glencore last week announced the $2.5 billion share sale as part of its broader plans to pay off about a third of its $30 billion debt.
The company sold the new holdings at 125 pence per share, a 2.4 per cent discount to Tuesday's closing price.
It issued 1.3 billion shares worth up to 9.99 percent of the group.
Concerns about long-term inhibited growth in China have cut iron ore prices by about half and coal, copper and other commodity prices have fallen by 20 to 40 percent.

The White House confirms Xi Jinping's visit to Washington
Chinese President Xi Jinping will make a state visit to the United States at the end of the month, the White House confirmed in a statement on Tuesday.
The visit, Xi's first official visit to Washington, will take place on 25 September and responds to President Barack Obama's trip to Beijing last November, the statement said.
The US President and First Lady Michelle Obama will also host Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan at a state dinner this evening after the two leaders held bilateral talks.
"President Xi's visit will provide an opportunity to broaden US-Chinese cooperation on a range of global, regional and bilateral issues of common interest, while also allowing President Obama and President Xi to constructively address areas of disagreement," the statement added.
XI, whose visit was initially announced in February, is expected to meet several US technology leaders in Seattle on his way to Washington before travelling on to New York City for the UN General Assembly in September.
Obama and Xi are expected to address a number of contentious issues, including Washington's concerns about China's alleged cyber espionage and its growing self-confidence in the disputed waters of the South China Sea.

Once they were one of the best teams in baseball, today the Tigers are in last place in the American League Central.
The Tigers are reduced to their role as spoilers, but played this part perfectly on Tuesday against the Minnesota Twins 5-4 in target field.
The Twins wasted a chance to move up within a half of the Houston Astros for the second American League wildcard spot.
For Detroit, if only for one evening, it was a return of the three-letter F-word that had been so elusive for much of the second half of the season.
"All victories are fun, no matter how they come," said Tiger's manager Brad Ausmus.
Tiger pitcher Alfredo Simon maintained his early offensive support as Detroit scored three times in the first two innings, then once in the sixth and then again in the ninth.
Simon (13-9) served 6 times in the 1/3 innings and allowed three runs.
It was only his third successful start in his last nine games.
"I want to finish this year strong," said Simon.
It's hard to throw every game in the bullpen, so I want to go into the game very concentrated.
The designated tiger hitter Victor Martinez had three goals and was in two runs, his first RBIs since mid-August.
It was Martinez's first three-hit game since he had four hits against the Seattle Mariners on July 6.
"He swung the bat well," said Ausmus.
He looked good in (batting practice), looked much better in the bullpen, and he brought it straight into the game.
With three runs behind at the end of the seventh inning, the Twins had their best chance to get back into the game.
Center Fielder Byron Buxton finished the inning with a double on the left field line.
Right fielder Aaron Hicks scored a bunt and Simon brought his second baseman Brian Dozier to a strikeout before he was replaced by left-hander Blaine Hardy.
Hardy defected Mauer, the only man he was confronted with, ahead of rookie batter designate Miguel Sano, who snatched a two-run from right-hander Drew Verhagen.
With a pair of runners and the final run on the second, Verhagen brought third baseman Trevor Plouffe to a double play.
It was the leading 27th time in the Major League this season that Plouffe hit a double play
After Detroit added an insurance run at the end of the ninth inning, Mauer managed an RBI double against the Tigers' closer Bruce Rondon and scored the 5-4.
However, the right-hander outdid Sano on three pitches for his fifth save.
Detroit benefited at the start of the game from a Phil Hughes who was not yet mobile.
The Tigers scored three runs in the first two innings against the right-hander veteran, who was taken off the injury list before the game after missing more than a month due to a back problem.
"Obviously not the start I was hoping for," said Hughes, "but I felt more comfortable as I got going and felt that I would make some pretty good pitches there in the third inning.
After receiving the leadoff battery in the first one, Hushes handed over a single to second baseman Ian Kinsler.
A Two-Out Walk for J.D. Martinez brought Victor Martinez into play, who managed a single "up the middle" on the first run of the game.
Victor Martinez managed his 0-21 winning streak with the runners in the scoring position.
Third baseman Nick Castellanos followed with a single to the right, making another run, but Victor Martinez was knocked out of the game as he tried to get to third, ending the threat.
The Tigers gained in the second, scoring a one-out double from catcher James McCann and a two-out single from center fielder Anthony Gose to score 3-0.
"That was a big blow," said Twins manager Paul Molitor.
He didn't hit very well, but he hit the right spot.
Hughes was in a pitch count, scoring no points in the third inning, before being replaced by the reliever right-hander A.J.Achter.
Hughes had three runs with six hits and a walk with four strikeouts.
NOTES: Tigers RHP Anibal Sanchez retired due to a shoulder injury.
He is examined by Dr. James Andrews, who operated on Sanchez's shoulder in 2007.
Sanchez, who has been on the injury list since mid-August due to a pulled shoulder, is to be activated for the start on Wednesday.
With Sanchez out of the game, LHP Daniel Morris is taken off the injury list to start against the Twins.
Norris with 1-1 on four starts with the Tigers since he was acquired in exchange with LHP David Price on July 30

Hundreds of refugees to be housed in Wiesbaden
A train with hundreds of refugees is on its way to Hessen.
His arrival was expected for the night on Wednesday.
The people arriving there will then be accommodated in emergency shelters in Wiesbaden, as the city of Wiesbaden announced on Tuesday evening.
She reckoned with 450 to 750 arriving refugees.
Several sports halls in the Hessian state capital had been prepared for this case in the past few days.
Up to 1000 refugees can be temporarily accommodated there.
They should then be distributed to other municipalities.
In the past ten days alone, 7500 people had arrived in Hesse, according to information from the Giessen regional council responsible for the initial admission.
Frankfurt and Hanau have also set up emergency accommodation in sports halls because of the large number of refugees.
Ischinger: German military measures in Syria an option
The head of the Munich Security Conference, Wolfgang Ischinger, considers military measures with German participation in Syria to be a possibility.
"I believe that the decisive reflection on military options for action must not take place without Germany," he said.
He accused the European states of "collective looking away".
Four years ago, he said, people were glad that the chalice of military involvement had passed Germany by.
"Now the conflict lands crashing on our doorstep," he said on Deutschlandfunk radio.
The former German ambassador in Washington also called for a massive increase in international aid on the ground for the refugees.
Austria checks at southern and eastern borders
After Germany, Austria has also reintroduced controls at its southern and eastern borders.
The Austrian Minister of the Interior Johanna Mikl-Leitner declared on Tuesday evening on the Austrian television channel ORF that nobody would be sent back to Hungary even now.
Germany had not sent any refugees back to Austria either.
"No, that's the agreement," she said.
Regarding the question of an agreement according to which Germany could take in a certain number of refugees from Austria per day, Mikl-Leitner said that there had already been talks on this matter between the Director General for Public Security and representatives of Germany.
She did not name concrete numbers and referred to talks on Wednesday in Berlin.
In the past few days tens of thousands of refugees had arrived in Austria from Hungary via the so-called Balkan route.
Your destination is usually Germany.
Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU) and her Austrian colleague Werner Faymann, together with several other EU heads of state and government, requested a special summit for next week.
Germany had started temporary border controls on Sunday.
The EU states have not yet been able to agree on a common approach to the crisis.
The EU interior ministers want to make a new attempt at a special meeting next Tuesday (22 September) to agree on a binding distribution of another 120,000 refugees.
In view of the large number of refugees in Germany, the federal government wants to provide more support to the federal states in the initial reception and distribution of people.
The federal government will manage this together with the states, Merkel announced late Tuesday evening after almost four hours of consultations with the Minister Presidents in the Chancellor's Office in Berlin.
Merkel stressed that those people who needed protection would get it.
But those who have no prospects of staying cannot stay in Germany.
This view was impressively shared in the Round Table.
The Chancellor stressed that the state as a whole must now make a "huge effort".
Thousands of desperate refugees are now stuck on the Balkan route.
Hungary had closed its 175 kilometre long border with Serbia during the night to Tuesday.
A few hours later the government in Budapest announced that it would also seal off the border with Romania with a fence.
Unlike Serbia, this neighbouring country belongs to the EU.
Hungary wants to prevent smugglers from looking for alternative routes via Romania, said Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto regarding the planned new border fence.
The Romanian government immediately condemned the plan.
There were first arrests of people who had cut through the fence.
Meanwhile, in Turkey, eyewitnesses reported that thousands of other migrants made their way to the Greek border.
Space probe "Cassini" finds ocean on Saturn's moon Enceladus
A global ocean sloshes under the ice shield of Saturn's moon Enceladus.
This is what researchers conclude from observations of the "Cassini" space probe.
According to this the moon is slightly tumbling on its orbit around the ringed planet.
This tumbling motion is only small, but it is still too large for a continuously solid celestial body, according to a communication from Cornell University in Ithaca (US state of New York) on Tuesday.
The researchers present their analyses in the journal "Icarus".
It had been known for a long time that there must be liquid water under the ice cover of Enceladus.
In 2006, for example, "Cassini" had already discovered ice volcanoes at the south pole of Saturn's moon that spew out water vapour and ice particles and thus feed Saturn's so-called E ring.
At least at the South Pole there must be an underground sea, astronomers concluded at the time.
However, the extent of the hidden ocean was not clear.

Not a diet fruit - mangos contain a lot of sugar
Mangoes are exotic and juicy-sweet.
But if you want to pay attention to your slim line, you are often advised against it.
This is because mangos contain a relatively high amount of sugar - especially sucrose.
The exotic fruits are healthy nevertheless: they contain B vitamins as well as vitamins E and C. Above all, however, mangos contain a lot of vitamin A and its precursor beta-carotene.
Whoever eats the fruit thus supports vision, the immune system and metabolic processes in the body.
When buying mangos should not be too soft or too firm and should smell pleasant.
The colour of the skin alone says nothing about how ripe the fruit is - so even green mangos can taste very tasty.
They should be stored at room temperature and consumed within a few days.
Then they taste natural, either pure or in sweet dishes.
But a mango also gives a special touch to hearty dishes.
It softens the slightly bitter taste of some leaf salads such as chicory and radiccio.
And a mango chutney goes well with fish, poultry, lamb and game.

First a foehn storm, then a prominent cold front
During the coming night, the foehn will break through the valleys on the northern side of the Alps, as Meteoschweiz announced on Tuesday.
On Wednesday and in the night to Thursday the foehn blows partly with storm force through the foehn valleys.
After foehn end on Thursday morning, a prominent cold front crosses us, bringing heavy rain, gusts of wind and a drop in temperature.
As MeteoNews writes in a press release, Switzerland is currently lying on the front side of an extensive low-pressure system over the British Isles in a strong southwest current.
On the northern side of the Alps, the foehn breaks through the valleys in the night to Wednesday.
Subsequently, the foehn blows until Thursday morning in the foehn valleys with gusts of 60 to 100 km/h, occasionally and especially in the Urnerland partly also with more than 100 km/h.
The foehn can penetrate in places as far as the adjacent midlands, and on the mountains, hurricane gusts of over 120 km/h are even possible.
While in the north a stormy foehn on Wednesday ensures summer temperatures of 23 to 27 degrees, the humidity on the southern slopes of the Alps begins to build up.
Rain sets in here and continues until Thursday evening.
All in all, south of the Alps, over 100 litres of rain per square metre must be expected in the next 48 hours, after the last few days have already seen large amounts of rain.
On Thursday morning, the foehn runs out of air and a cold front with heavy, partly thundery rain rolls from west to east over Switzerland.
Together with the cold front, the wind freshens up strongly to stormy, and temperatures drop significantly.
The following days present themselves in the north with autumnal temperatures of 15 to 20 degrees, in the south, however, it becomes sunnier and warmer on the weekend with up to 25 degrees.
Rome now has a Martin Luther Square
Almost 500 years after the Reformation, Rome now has a Martin Luther Square.
In the presence of Mayor Ignazio Marino, a previously nameless square in the park on Oppio Hill was baptized in the name of the German reformer on Wednesday.
In the "Piazza Martin Lutero" he is now honoured as the "German Theologian of the Reformation".
The park is located in the middle of ancient Rome right next to the Colosseum.
The naming had been applied for by the Arbeitsgemeinschaft der evangelischen Kirchen in Rom.
Jens-Martin Kruse, pastor of the Evangelical Lutheran Congregation in Rome, reminded on Wednesday that for centuries the Protestants in the city of the Popes as a minority could often only live their faith in secret.
The square symbolically demonstrates that their tradition of Christian faith is welcome in Rome.
Martin Luther (1483-1546) stayed in Rome for a few months as a young Augustinian monk at the turn of the year 1510/11.
At that time, he considered the city a depraved place of sin.
According to historians, his negative impressions may have strengthened him in his later fight against Rome.
With his theses against the sale of indulgences, Luther had then initiated the division of the Western Church.
Hammer Künstler invested three years in the personal interpretation of the Bible
Jesus with the (gilded) crown of thorns is one of the main works that Otmar Alt painted for his Bible.
Klaus Altepost wrote the introduction and updated Bible texts.
In the beginning was the word?
No, not with the Otmar Alt Bible, which has now been published with magnificent pictures.
In the beginning there was the painting for Otmar Alt, who formulated his very personal interpretations of biblical stories on paper and canvas in 150 motifs.
The 75-year-old has retained his "language" with bright colours and imaginative shapes - but this is by no means synonymous with "funny" pictures.
On the contrary: Adapted to the respective topics, this can appear quite gloomy.
Otmar Alt worked for about three years on his Bible project, for which he made a subjective artistic selection from the many subject areas of the "Book of All Books".
The result are cycles dedicated to themes such as the Way of the Cross, plagues, commandments or the Lord's Prayer.
With this he spontaneously fascinated several partners at once: This applies to the Luther publishing house with its theological orientation as well as to the Kettler publishing house with its focus on art books.
And there is above all the author Klaus Altepost, who has dealt with the respective Bible passages on the basis of painting.
He interpreted the biblical passages selected by Otmar Alt and thus "translated" them into the present day, into current contexts.
These texts are like verbal mirrors of Alt's painting.
They are embedded between the original Bible quotation by Martin Luther and a sentence by the artist, who here formulates his very personal thoughts on the respective situation.
The decorative binding has golden letters.
Thus the 75-year-old allows a double deep insight into his soul, his emotions.
That's a high level of intimacy.
In the end, emotions were the trigger for the Bible Project in the first place: Otmar Alt, born in Wernigerode in 1940 and raised in Berlin, comes from a family that belonged to the strict Protestant Herrnhuter Order.
"That's when education happened with a cane," Otmar Alt remembers.
"I've tried to work this out so that maybe I can make peace with the Lord Father again."
His second concern, he says, is to help art regain its status in these fast-moving times: "Today, the perception of visual worlds is characterized by advertising, and it is loud.
Symbolism is suppressed there.
Artists have a different desire and delight to show things.
Pictures always have something mysterious and are not decorative.
"I'm a dinosaur in that respect".
Otmar Alt wants viewers to "fall into" the pictures, let them have an effect on them, discover and feel the power they have: "The picture seeks its counterpart".
Klaus Altepost confessed on Tuesday at the presentation of the Otmar Alt Bible in the Otmar Alt Foundation that he has "always" been a lover of Otmar Alt's art: "I like the way he understands life with his pictures".
Alt did not take care to grasp the Bible completely, but chose the topics that were important to him, including mysterious ones.
"This was not cooperation at eye level", says Altepost: "This is about the pictures, the text merely explains". The result was a picture Bible.
For Hans Möhler of Luther-Verlag, this work is an invitation to "deepen his life and find freedom".
Otmar Alt's pictures speak for Möhler both the (biblical) language of love and that of responsibility.
Some of the originals - paper and canvas paintings - will be presented for the first time in an exhibition that will open on 15 November at the Otmar Alt Foundation.

DFB intensifies commitment to refugees
The DFB is expanding its commitment to refugees until 2019, and the Bundesliga is sending out a clear signal at the weekend.
Football is reacting to the worsening situation in Germany and assures politicians of its help in overcoming the problems that lie ahead.
"I consider this the greatest challenge our country has faced since reunification."
"Basically, nobody can say it's none of my business, I have nothing to do with it."
"This must be of interest to every single person to get this issue under control," said DFB boss Wolfgang Niersbach.
At his annual meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel on 23rd September in Berlin he intends to discuss the refugee situation in Germany in detail.
"I'll be at the Chancellery next Wednesday and meet the Minister of State Mrs Özoğuz and the Chancellor."
"I'm sure the subject will play a central role," he announced.
Football could and would help.
But the decisive course must be set by politics.
The German Football Association has therefore extended its refugee initiative "1:0 for a welcome" by four years.
"Through the Egidius Braun Foundation, we have ensured that this programme will continue until 2019," explained Niersbach on the sidelines of the UEFA meeting in St. Julian's/Malta.
Some Bundesliga clubs also support this programme.
Already this weekend, the 36 professional clubs are sending a clear signal when they will wear the imprint "Wir helfen - #refugeeswelcome" on the left sleeve instead of the usual sponsor logo (Hermes).
"We also want to make it clear that everyone should help where and how they can," Leverkusen's head of sports Rudi Völler told the "Bild" newspaper (Tuesday), describing the project as a "matter of course".
"The refugee tragedy is everyone's business, no one can look the other way."
"We Bundesliga football clubs can, no, we must use our charisma, our influence and our possibilities to help the many refugees who have already suffered so incredibly," said Hertha manager Michael Preetz.
Hoffenheim's managing director Peter Rettig spoke of a "prominent sign of the league".
The national women's team invites 100 refugees to Halle/Saale for the European Championship qualifying match against Hungary this Friday.
Niersbach described the support of refugees as "a great joint effort of German football".
The fact that all 36 licence clubs have started their own projects in their localities is great.
Just as great is that small and smallest clubs are active there.
The message "1:0 for a welcome" that we gave out is lived in football.
"This is of enormous importance," he said.
This year and next year, the association, together with the DFB selection committee and the German government, will each provide 300,000 euros for the integration of refugees.
"The clubs have already called in the full amount for 2015," reported Niersbach.
Reports: SAP CEO loses an eye in accident
The CEO of Europe's largest software company, Bill McDermott, has reportedly lost his left eye in a fall in early July.
In the accident on the stairs in his brother's house in the USA, he fell after midnight on a glass of water that he had carried in his left hand, the "Wirtschaftswoche" reported on Wednesday.
"He almost bled to death, fainted, then dragged himself out onto the street - that's what he told us last week," the "WiWo" quotes SAP co-founder Hasso Plattner.
But McDermott could go about his business.
"At the beginning of October we will meet before the Supervisory Board meeting in Walldorf," said Plattner.
The 54-year-old manager was present at the meeting and "fully fit for work".
McDermott announced in an interview with the "Süddeutsche Zeitung" (Thursday edition) that he would come back to Germany in October and continue to lead the software company.
"I'm fully committed to SAP, fully committed to my job."
"Naturally, I was in regular contact with the Supervisory Board and its Chairman Hasso Plattner all the time," McDermott told the "SZ".
McDermott usually commutes between Germany and the USA, but since the summer he has not been at the German SAP headquarters in Walldorf.
It was important to him to go public with such a personal story, said the manager of the "SZ": "Something like this can happen to anyone.
"The important thing is to get up again after you've fallen down."

Robot cars: Government wants to play a pioneering role for Germany
The German government wants Germany to be the technological pioneer in the transformation of the car.
On Wednesday, the Federal Cabinet adopted a strategy paper from the house of Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt (CSU), which provides for investments in the expansion of digital infrastructure, among other things.
Dobrindt spoke on Wednesday in Frankfurt on the fringes of the IAA automobile fair of a "new mobility age".
Automated and networked driving will increase traffic safety and reduce traffic jams, said Dobrindt.
He also intends to discuss the topic with his counterparts from the G7 countries, who will also meet with representatives of industry at the IAA.
Among other things, the strategy paper of the Ministry of Transport emphasizes the importance of mobile broadband expansion and a rapid switch to digital radio.
A test track is currently being built on the Autobahn 9 in Bavaria to test new technology.
To ensure that drivers "are not burdened with additional liability risks", the German government wants to "review the legal framework and, where necessary, adapt it to new developments".
Germany, for example, intends to lobby internationally for an increase in the maximum permitted speed for self-propelled cars from 10 to 130 kilometres per hour.
The Federal Government also intends to work for an amendment to the Vienna Convention, which so far only provides for the human being as driver.
In automated driving, the car increasingly takes the lead and the driver becomes more and more a passenger.
The technology is mainly based on sensors and cameras that capture the environment and process the data in seconds.
According to a study presented by the Ministry of Economics, highly automated driving on motorways will be technically possible by 2020.
Nevertheless, driverless vehicles on public roads are "not expected until well after 2020".
The authors of the study estimate the value added in the field of driver assistance systems and highly automated driving functions in Germany as a business location at around 8.4 billion euros for 2025.
"Digital networking of the car can lead to more safety and efficiency in road traffic," said SPD transport politician Sören Bartol.
However, the question of liability in the event of accidents and the security of drivers' personal data must be clearly clarified.
However, Germans still view self-propelled cars with skepticism - much more so than the French or Americans.
A survey presented on Wednesday at the AA by the Forsa Institute on behalf of the testing organisation Dekra comes to the conclusion that only eight percent of Germans believe that autonomously driving cars will become established in the next ten years, 32 percent do not expect this to happen for another 20 years, and 31 percent do not believe in it at all.
In France, 21 percent of those surveyed expect to have autonomous cars by 2025, and 33 percent in the USA.
In any case, motorists in Germany are not yet ready to rely completely on a self-propelled vehicle.
According to a survey by the digital association Bitkom, only seven percent would agree to hand over control during the entire journey on all roads.
On the autobahn, 15 percent could imagine this in flowing traffic, and 45 percent in traffic jams.
A good one in four would not let the car take control under any circumstances.

Gaultier feels too old to be an enfant terrible
It is a mixture of a very large fashion show and a waxworks horror cabinet: designer Jean Paul Gaultier (63) presented an exhibition of his work in Munich on Wednesday.
The highlights: Mannequins that look frighteningly human thanks to video projections.
They wear the spectacular creations of the French designer, who became a big star of the fashion scene with Madonna's stage outfits, among other things - and by putting men in skirts.
"I can no longer say that I am the enfant terrible of haute couture because I have white hair."
"It used to be bleached, now it's real," Gaultier said.
For visitors to the exhibition "From The Sidewalk To The Catwalk", which can be seen in the Kunsthalle of the Hypo-Kulturstiftung from 18 September, it is fortunate that the fashion designer has changed his initially negative attitude towards a show about himself.
Actually, he was against it, because: "For me, an exhibition sounded a bit like death," he said.
When you die, you go to a museum.
The impressive collection had previously made stops in Montreal, Canada and Paris.
"It's about so much more than just beautiful clothes," said Roger Diederen, director of the art gallery.
It was about tolerance, acceptance and the vision of an open society.
The exhibits give an insight into the almost unmanageable work of the man who wrote fashion history without ever having completed an apprenticeship.
The show is not chronologically structured, but it is an excellently choreographed Gesamtkunstwerk, for which a great deal of effort was put into it: For example, a stylist was hired to do the dolls' hair.
According to the curator Thierry-Maxime Loriot, the creators have transported 14 tons of material to Munich.
Shortly before the start of the Oktoberfest there was a special treat: a Lederhosen outfit with corset.
Heidi meets Madonna.
He has always been interested in strong women ("women are smarter than men") and people who are a little different, Gaultier said.
Gaultier's old teddy can also be seen in the exhibition.
It stands for the designer's first, tentative fashionable attempts at walking.
As a child (he was not a good student and bad at soccer) he used to put bras and clothes on his teddy bear, Gaultier said.
His parents would not have allowed him to play with a doll.
He later taught himself to design fashion.
He stole fashion magazines and looked at the designs of other designers, as Gaultier told in Munich.
But later I bought them of course.
He had not been able to pay the models for his first own fashion show.
They got nothing, but they were allowed to keep the clothes.
Jewellery instead of curtains - Plauen lace as a fashion niche
In the past, the long embroidery machines in and around Plauen were used to make meters.
The embroidered fabrics and lace were produced in large quantities for customers who processed them into blankets and curtains, for example.
That alone no longer works, explains Andreas Reinhardt, managing director of Modespitze Plauen.
Instead, fashion is important again.
In the early days of Plauen lace, fashion played a greater role, was then displaced by the home textile industry - and is now being rediscovered as a niche.
Reinhardt gives some examples: Lace in jewelry, in accessories such as bags and in regional costumes.
In general, the so-called vintage fashion, which is based on past style epochs, represents an increasing order potential.
Those who do not serve niches in the textile industry in Germany are no longer in the market.
In our company they already account for half of all orders.
Modespitze Plauen, together with nine other companies, is a member of the Plauen Lace and Embroideries trade association.
Only they may carry the protected label.
In the last 15 years, about 80 percent of the turnover has been lost.
Private specialist shops and also the wholesale trade are almost non-existent.
Our products hardly reach the customer in this way.
Nowadays, the mass-produced goods are produced much cheaper in the Asian region and are almost exclusively sold via chains.
In addition, exports, currently to Russia and the USA, are weak.
Enough reasons for new approaches.
The trade association also tries to score points through environmental awareness, as Cordula Bauer from the Stickperle in Falkenstein explains: "Since this year we have been carrying a quality seal that shows that we produce in an ecologically and socially compatible way".
Reinhardt adds: "This also refers to the materials used".
Graduate designer Ute Schmidt teaches at the Schneeberg branch of the West Saxon University of Applied Arts in Zwickau - at the Faculty of Applied Arts - and specialises in embroidery and lace.
To counter the competition from the Asian region, you have to find high-quality and innovative products.
It takes time and courage.
There is a field of tension between the freshest ideas of the designers and the companies, which must above all think economically," says Schmidt.
Therefore, an existing design is often only slightly varied in order to retain a customer base.
A few years ago, textile designer Kati Reuter revived the historic snowball lace.
The machine embroiders small beads in some places.
Plauen's master goldsmith Bianca Hallebach-Krauße was inspired by this: "Before, I could not do anything with traditional Plauen lace".
Now she uses the snowball tip for her jewelry.
In a complex process she embosses the pattern in silver.
"Many people in the region identify with the Plauen lace theme - young and old," says Reuter.
It also delivers to the USA, Australia and Finland - mainly to customers whose ancestors lived in Plauen and the surrounding area and who want a souvenir.
With this I see my jewellery as a modern ambassador of Plauen lace.

Xi urges to open the economy more widely to the world
The economy needs to open up more widely to the outside world to promote growth, President Xi Jinping told a group charged with steering reform on Tuesday.
"China should work to attract foreign investment and know-how and improve business creation strategies," he said in an address to the 16th session of the Central Steering Group for deepening comprehensive reform.
Encouraging start-ups and driving forward reforms will create new momentum and vitality and provide a new space for economic growth, Xi said.
The Leadership Group has adopted a number of directives, including a negative list to regulate market access, easing of border control policies, promotion of state-owned enterprises (SOE) to raise private capital, and overhaul of the population registration system.
According to the statement, a negative list is drawn up, identifying sectors and companies that are not eligible for investment.
The system will be tested step by step and improved through test programs.
The initiative is important because it gives the market a greater role in the allocation of resources, ensures a business environment based on the rule of law and makes the market more open, the statement said.
The government will also relax controls on the powers delegated to companies and ensure that companies decide how to conduct their business.
The statement also said that China will allow border areas to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to promote regional growth.
As part of an offer to open up state-controlled sectors, other areas will be opened up to private investment.
"The government will not change its policy towards foreign investment and will protect the legitimate interests of leveraged companies and provide better services to them," the statement said.
Furthermore, it will be made easier for foreigners to apply for a permanent residence permit or the "Green Card" by optimising the requirements and facilitating the application process.
The right of lawyers to guarantee the exercise of their activity and to appoint professional judges and prosecutors was also discussed at a meeting.
The meeting was also attended by Prime Minister Li Keqiang and important leaders such as Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli, as reported in a statement issued after the meeting.
EU wants to double mercury limit value in predatory fish
The European Commission wants to double the limit values for mercury in large predatory fish and thus impose a significantly higher dose of the nerve poison on consumers.
The consumer organisation Foodwatch, which has a corresponding working paper from the EU, sharply criticised the plans: "Risks and side effects of misguided industrial and environmental policies will be passed on to pregnant women and small children with full force", explained Matthias Wolfschmidt from Foodwatch.
According to Wolfschmidt, the limits of the neurotoxin for large fish at the end of the food chain, such as shark or swordfish, are to be raised from one to two milligrams of mercury per kilogram of fish for "economic policy reasons".
However, large predatory fish are already so heavily contaminated with mercury that, on the basis of the limits still in force, about 50 percent of the catches may not be sold.
After doubling the limits, only 14.5 percent would then be unsaleable.
In return for this relaxation, the EU wants to tighten the limits for other fish from the current 0.5 milligrams of mercury per kilogram to 0.1 milligrams of mercury per kilogram, according to Foodwatch.
However, Foodwatch called this a "trick", because smaller peaceful fish, such as carp, are usually so lightly contaminated that they already meet the planned maximum levels.
The reduction in the price of small fish is therefore "a perfidious diversionary manoeuvre which alone helps the economy", explained Wolfschmidt.
Mercury is a heavy metal that is highly toxic to humans and accumulates heavily via the food chain, especially in predatory fish.
The German government therefore warns that "even small amounts can cause damage to the nervous system, especially in the unborn child".
However, the Federal Ministry for the Environment declares on its homepage with regard to the applicable maximum values that a "health risk to the general population" is not to be expected.
Mercury enters the environment mainly through coal combustion.
According to a written statement by the Federal Environment Ministry to Green Party member of parliament Annalena Baerbock, the German coal-fired power plants emit more than six tons of mercury per year, two thirds of the total amount emitted in Germany.
The concentration of mercury in fish, for example in the Elbe, Rhine and Danube rivers, was "permanently and comprehensively exceeded", "Spiegel" had quoted from the paper in March.
Last year, Europe-wide warnings of mercury in fish were already among the most frequently reported health risks in the EU alert system RASFF.
Foodwatch calls on consumers to protest against the EU plans at: www.quecksilber-aktion.foodwatch.de

Clinton and Trump's economic policy in comparison: It's all about the money
Both Clinton and Trump want to invest in infrastructure and prevent the TTP trade agreement.
However, the two US presidential candidates disagree on tax and energy policy and on a fundamental issue.
The differences in economic policy between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are based on a fundamental, rather philosophical difference.
The one about the role of the state.
Trump wants to keep them rather small in case of doubt and warns of how the state can harm the economy - with taxes and regulations.
Clinton wants to tax the economy to death and regulate it to death, he says.
He himself, on the other hand, is quite different, Trump claims.
He will massively reduce regulations and advocate a far-reaching tax reform with lower tax rates - for private individuals and for companies.
Clinton, on the other hand, says: The state has certain tasks to fulfil, it has to open up opportunities for the disadvantaged and needs money for this.
That's why taxes are being raised for the rich, she says.
Interestingly, both are very close to the topic of infrastructure.
Trump and Clinton say almost word for word that these must be invested in.
The democratic candidate even announces the biggest investment in new jobs since the Second World War.
State investment programs in infrastructure are classic democratic policies and are strictly rejected by the Republican Teaparty wing, which is critical of the state.
Trump could therefore still be subject to internal party discussions.
The differences in energy and climate policy are clearer.
Trump wants to build coal-fired power plants and increase coal production in the USA.
Oil production should also be possible in previously protected areas, and he wants to terminate the Paris Climate Change Agreement.
Clinton, on the other hand, explicitly wants to expand renewable energies with her investment program and demands: "A country will become the superpower of clean energies and create millions of jobs.
"I guess it'll either be China, Germany or America - I want it to be us."
But it is not only in terms of infrastructure - the two competitors are not too far apart in terms of international trade agreements either.
Neither of them wants to sign TPP, the transpacific trade agreement.
At the same time, however, both do not want to isolate the USA from international trade - they simply want to better protect American jobs.
Clinton, for example, demands that they should be better paid.
The current minimum wage of 7.25 US dollars is a pittance.
Him she wants to raise to $15 an hour.
What Trump wants to do in this matter is not quite clear: One time he says: the minimum wage must go up, then he says it must not be changed.
However, the big discussion in the coming months is likely to be about the tax policy of the two camps.
On the one hand, there is Trump, who wants to relieve the burden on the economy and citizens in order to boost growth.
His critics accuse him that this would only increase the budget deficit.
On the other side is Clinton, who at least wants to demand that the rich pay more taxes, and whose critics say: more taxes are not the solution either.
Escape: "Every escaped woman has experience with sexual violence"
Sexual violence is almost part of everyday life for women who flee alone.
When they arrive in Germany, they are often traumatised.
A house offers sanctuary.
Four women sit in a large kitchen.
Each of them has a baby with them, who is one year old at most.
One of them put her little boy in her arms.
He looks curiously into the room with big eyes.
His mother stares at the tabletop.
Until she realizes she's being watched.
She smiles briefly and kisses the little one.
The scene looks normal.
Until you talk to Katrin Bahr.
She is the divisional manager of Condrobs, a provider of social assistance services in Bavaria, and deals with the topic of women on the run, among other things.
The four women in the kitchen are fugitives.
They live in the north of Munich in one of the few decentralized accommodations for single women and their children in Bavaria.
In January, Condrobs opened the facility together with Pro Familia and Münchner Frauenhilfe.
Recently it was officially opened.
60 people live there - about 40 women and 20 children.
There are no men - not even as visitors.
The exception is a security guard at the door.
"It is no exaggeration to say that every woman who arrives here has had experience of sexual violence during her flight," says Bahr.
"Men flee because of wars, because they are politically persecuted, because they are threatened with torture or death or because their families send them to Europe as bearers of hope," she says.
In the case of women, other reasons for escape predominate: "Many steal away secretly because they see no other way out".
In their home country they have had experience of sexual violence, forced marriages, honour killings, slavery or forced prostitution.
It drives them away.
On the run, it continues.
"It is not uncommon for traffickers to demand a sexual act for a bottle of water, for example," says Bahr.
And the women are alone, they are not protected by their families.
Anyone who thinks that it will end as soon as they arrive in Germany is wrong, says Bahr.
Here too, single women in refugee accommodation are often considered inferior and, at worst, abused.
As a result, she estimates that about 90 percent of the women living in accommodation in the north of Munich are traumatised.
"Some of the children were certainly not born of free will".
Many women are so used to not saying anything.
"Or they do not dare to speak openly about what they have experienced because the shame is too great".
Since they often do not know how to help themselves, they need more shelters just for them, Bahr demands.
In Bavaria, the seven district governments are responsible for the accommodation of refugees.
When asked whether they knew of a project similar to the one in Munich in their area of responsibility, some answer in the negative.
In the Upper Palatinate and Upper Franconia, for example, there is no such thing in government accommodation.
Even in Swabia, women who have fled alone are not accommodated separately, says Karl-Heinz Meyer, spokesman for the government.
In Upper Bavaria, Lower and Middle Franconia, some communal accommodations have floors or separate houses only for single women and their children.
The exception is Lower Bavaria, where there are two central accommodations exclusively for women.
The European Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality also calls for women to be housed separately from men.
A study published for the Committee states that "it is very important that men and women are housed separately".
"In the absence of privacy, or when men and women are housed together, violence against women can - persist".
Above all, the washrooms should be separate and easily accessible for women, says the study.
The extent to which women feel this need for protection can be seen from the rush to the house in Munich.
"Since word got around that we exist, we have a long waiting list," says Bahr.
One could easily open a second house.

In response to the government's silence, the JDC board today made a formal request for a special meeting of the BMA council to approve an ongoing program of escalating industrial action starting in early September.

Russia and Turkey: An "alliance of outsiders"?
It was a gesture that ended a crisis.
The leaders of Russia and Turkey met on Tuesday to shake hands and announce an official end to eight months of war of words and economic sanctions.
But when Vladimir Putin receives his Turkish counterpart in the gilded hall of the St. Petersburg Palace, I cannot help feeling that Ankara wants this reconciliation most.
There was the handshake, yes.
But Putin's smile seemed narrow-lipped and he hardly radiated warmth, even for his reserved circumstances.
Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on the other hand, repeatedly spoke of his "dear friend" Putin - a full five times, according to one report.
I couldn't count it anymore.
He also promised that relations with Russia would not only return to their pre-crisis level, but would even improve.
The next day a newspaper described how Erdogan had behaved as if nothing bad had ever happened.
To me, his enthusiasm seemed to suggest the opposite.
But a sustained coolness radiating from Putin showed that Russia's head of state had not forgotten anything.
Rather, the cause of the crisis was the first thing he mentioned in his opening remarks: the shooting down of a Russian fighter plane at the Syrian border through Turkey.
Moscow's reaction at the time was furious.
Putin handed out and accused Ankara of stabbing Russia in the back.
The offense was even greater, since it was committed by an alleged friend.
Rebuilding trust will be difficult, if not impossible.
Public opinion in Russia has changed since November.
For months the state-controlled media carried out a fierce, unrestricted attack on Ankara.
Suddenly it seemed as if the Turks were to blame for everything.
Most serious were the accusations by senior officials that Erdogan's own family had profited from illegal oil trading in areas of Syria controlled by the so-called Islamic state.
He vehemently denied this.
But in St.Petersburg the official message was that it was time to look ahead.
After all, this meeting only took place because Putin received the apology he wanted to hear from President Erdogan.
Russia was able to record a kind of victory.
For Ankara, the advantages of a ceasefire are obvious.
Erdogan needs first and foremost all the friends he can get after he was almost removed from office last month in a failed coup d'état.
Repeated terrorist attacks on Turkey have also shaken him.
But there are also economic motives.
Russian sanctions have hit Turkey hard - especially the ban on charter flights, which usually bring several million Russian tourists to the Turkish coast every year.
The number has decreased by almost 90 %.
In Russia, tour operators and charter companies will be relieved when flights are resumed.
They count on a late seasonal rush to the Mediterranean.
This week, state television predicted cheaper fruit and vegetables as soon as Turkish agricultural imports are allowed again.
A report in Vedemosti put it this way: "Tourists this way, tomatoes this way."
But the visit had added political value for Moscow.
Ankara is angry with the West because it considers its reaction to the attempted seizure of power as a weak response.
Add to this the ongoing resentment about the snail's pace of EU accession negotiations and Putin - who is eager to take advantage of the cool mood and reduce Turkey's relationship with the West.
The Russian head of state certainly won a bonus in Ankara for demanding support for the elected state organs after the attempted coup.
This is a matter of course for Moscow, which itself has a deep-seated fear of regime change.
The summit meeting in this glittering palace by the sea enabled Russia and Turkey to present what one analyst once described to me as an "alliance of outsiders": two countries that felt repudiated and mistreated by the West and are now allied.
Nevertheless, despite public reconciliation, there are still major differences between the two.
The biggest difference is in Syria, where Moscow recently gave itself the role of peacemaker, but where Russia and Turkey support opposing sides.
It could be significant that after almost three hours of initial talks, both presidents testified at the press conference that they had not even touched on the issue.
The President of Turkey deliberately avoided answering a question about their differences, while Putin chose to emphasize them.
There is no clear consensus on where to find a common denominator with Syria.
But after months of open hostilities - and given the potential for total disaster when NATO member Turkey shot down the Russian fighter - it is certainly better that the two leaders at least talk to each other again.
Royal Bank of Scotland no longer available for customers outside Scotland
According to the bank's CEO, the RBS brand is to be reduced to a back office role only.
The Royal Bank of Scotland will no longer be available to customers outside Scotland.
Ross McEwan told BBC Scotland that the RBS brand was linked to the bank's global ambitions.
The bank has since distanced itself when it almost collapsed eight years ago and had to be rescued.
During this time, brand strategists have used "RBS" to protect other consumer financial brands.
She has supported international sport with millions of pounds of sponsorship, from Six Nations Rugby to Wimbledon winner Andy Murray.
But now she has decided to focus more on national brands.
The Royal Bank of Scotland will only be available to customers in Scotland, but will not be initialised.
In England and Wales, all RSB references, the decentralised headquarters and the stock exchange listing will be transferred to NatWest.
The Ulster Bank brand is already used for clients in the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.
There are other, smaller brands for retail banking that will gain more importance - Coutts, Adam & Co, Drummond and Holt's Military Bank.
McEwan was interviewed by customers and staff in Inverness-shire during a sightseeing tour.
He told BBC Scotland: "The RSB brand will become our investor brand as well as the brand under which our employees will work, as we become more of a bank of brands.
When the bank itself became a global brand, RBS became a global brand.
I say now that we are not pursuing global goals, but local goals.
Each of these brands will stand for something completely different in their own communities and our employees will work with customers under these brands.
RBS has already stated that it will no longer continue its Six Nations sponsorship and that it will increase the visibility of the different brands in its sports sponsorship.
"It is time for us to become the bank of brands, because how do we focus internally (we asked) on making this a better bank for customers," said the CEO.
It would have been very cynical three years ago if we had said that we were going to be a great bank for our customers and launched these brands.
But with our work, the focus on customer needs and not our own, I think you will see many changes.
We can launch these brands again, so I think the time has come.

Russia's Putin fires Chief of Staff Sergei Ivanov
Russian President Vladimir Putin unexpectedly dismissed his chief of staff Sergei Ivanov.
For many years Ivanov was part of Putin's closest circle of trust.
The 63-year-old was appointed Special Representative for Environmental and Transport Affairs.
In a statement by the Kremlin, it is stated that Putin without giving reasons "ordered the dismissal of Ivanov from his duties as head of the Russian presidential administration".
Anton Vaino, who had been Ivanov's deputy since 2012, was appointed as his successor.
Vaino, 44, is a former diplomat.
Born in the Estonian capital Tallinn in 1972, he graduated from the renowned Moscow State Institute of International Relations (MGIMO) and worked at the embassy in Tokyo.
On the Kremlin's website it says (in Russian) that he was later head of protocol and chief of staff of government personnel.
About his appointment he said to Putin: "Thank you for your trust."
I think that the most important task of the government is to support your work as head of state with regard to draft laws and controls to implement your instructions.
Putin told the Russian TV channel on Friday that Ivanov had asked to leave his post and recommended Vaino as his successor.
Are the smiling faces convincing?
This step has made Moscow shrouded in mystery.
Sergei Ivanov was for a long time one of Vladimir Putin's closest confidants and, like him, works for the Soviet secret service, the KGB.
As chief of staff he was one of the most powerful men in the country.
At a meeting with President Putin, which was broadcast on television, both men claimed that the Chief of Staff resigned at his own request.
But despite the smiles for the cameras, few here are convinced of this - especially now, just before the parliamentary elections.
So is this the result of some kind of power struggle?
Nobody knows that right now.
But the official claim - that a man who was once touted as a potential president suddenly wanted to lead Russian environmental policy - met with great scepticism.
In his remarks to Putin, quoted on the Kremlin website, Ivanov said "it is true that in early 2012 in an interview I asked you to entrust me this very complicated post - one could almost say - arduous post for four years.
As it turns out, I have been Chairman of the Russian Presidential Administration for four years and eight months.
Ivanov accepted the post in December 2011.
He was previously Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defence.
He is a member of the Russian Security Council and, like Putin, a former member of the state security service KGB.
In the late 1990s, when Putin was chairman of the Federal Security Service (FSB), which replaced the KGB, Ivanov was appointed his deputy.
When Putin came to power he named Ivanov as one of five people he trusted most.
It was once thought that Ivanov could become president of Russia after Putin's second term, as a third term of Putin would have been against the constitution.
But this post was taken by another close ally of Putin, Dmitry Medvedev.
Putin became Prime Minister before becoming President again three and a half years later.

Queensferry Crossing: Bridge now connected to Fife
The £1.35 billion project is due for completion by May 2017
Engineers have connected the north deck of the Queensferry Crossing to the viaduct - which means the bridge is now connected to Fife.
It is the first of four closures of the "deck blowers", which are approaching completion around each of the three towers of the bridge.
The Fife bridge section is now 600 metres long and weighs 30,000 tonnes.
It has 10,000 tons of steel and 20,000 tons of concrete and 46 stay cables.
The £1.35 billion project is expected to be completed by May 2017.
Economics Secretary Keith Brown visited the site today and was one of the first to leave the country and go to the bridge.
He said: "This is a historic and symbolic moment in the construction of the Queensferry Crossing.
We are all witness to an engineering feat of truly epic proportions on this project, with over 30,000 tons of concrete and steel used in this part of the bridge alone.
Despite the massive size and weight of the bridge, finishing the closure between the viaduct and the bridge deck is a delicate operation that requires extremely precise tolerances for the fit.
In total, almost 79% of the total bridge decks are in place and the last section of the deck is being given a concrete cast for the deck at Rosyth today, which means that the whole deck is ready to be lifted into place on the bridge.
Michael Martin, Project Manager of Forth Crossing Bridge Constructors said: "The first closure represents a significant milestone in any bridge project.
In this fantastic project, the closure represents forward-looking structural and civil engineering.
After installing the last section of the road deck and connecting it to the north tower deck, which is currently being extended, we then had to close the gap that still existed on the north or land side.
This was achieved by pulling the northern feeder bridge 700 millimetres south.
This was a massive and at the same time very delicate activity.
Massive, because the viaduct is 222 metres long, weighs approx. 6,000 tonnes and had to be pulled up at a gradient of approx. 3 %.
It was tricky because the tolerances the team was working towards were tiny - only a few millimetres on each side.
Fortunately, everything went very well.
