Pokémon Go, a hunt for health and happiness that pays off
It is fascinating to watch the world change.
The fact that teenagers and children no longer go outside to play but prefer to spend their free time staring at screens has been complained about by many in the last decade.
Pokemon Go is all about getting people off the sofa and getting more active.
The time spent on the screen was initially limited to television, then to video games and finally to smartphones.
So it is great to see that technology and outdoor activities are not mutually exclusive.
I'm referring, of course, to the Pokémon Go craze, an app based on the characters that were first created for video games in the 1990s (which later evolved into an animated series, game cards and other spin-offs).
Like many phenomena of pop culture, interest dropped somewhat before the game was released in the USA, Australia and New Zealand in early July.
The market launch in other countries was postponed due to massive demand, which overloaded the servers.
Within days, Pokémon Go had more users than Tinder and almost as many as Twitter.
How does it work?
In short, players go outside with their smartphones and search for Pokémon that are tracked with a GPS and, once found, can be "photographed" (via a screenshot on the phone) or "captured".
A generation that played the game when they were younger joined the madness and jumped off the sofa to search.
In the USA, the game led to a considerable increase in the number of steps that the "average" person takes every day.
Cardiogram, an app for Apple Watch that tracks 35,000 users, recently told the Washington Post that within two days of the game's launch, the number of people tracked who exercise 30 minutes each day jumped from 45 percent to 53 percent.
The company doesn't know which of them play Pokémon Go - it only sees the raw data for performance improvement.
Many public health education campaigns that try to get people to "take 30 minutes", "get off the sofa" and "be active every day" have fallen on deaf ears because many public health messages are boring and come from people who look miserable.
Nevertheless, the importance of sport cannot be overestimated.
People who exercise regularly reduce their chances of developing cancer or depression.
Physical activity helps with weight control, high blood pressure, diabetes and a long list of benefits that is too long to list here.
But the wonderful thing about Pokémon Go is that it gets people to do something outside that they enjoy.
This covers three pillars of health - exercise, fresh air and sunshine, and fun.
Some people even make new friends while hunting.
As always there are also grumpy spoilsports who always have to complain about something.
And yes, someone might walk into a door.
So what?
A breakthrough has occurred.
Even though smartphone apps like Fitbit have been able to track our activity before, they didn't give us a reason to do sports like this game does.
The new will lose its appeal and the use will diminish over time.
However, due to Pokemon's success, there will be more games that will combine apps and virtual reality with getting active in the real world, helping many people on the hunt to be more active, fitter and healthier.

The £2 per day drug that can reduce the risk of heart attack
Thousands of heart attack patients will benefit from a £2 per day drug after the authorities recommended that it be given to more people for a longer period of time.
The anticoagulant drug Ticagrelor reduces the risk of repeated heart attacks for people with heart disease.
The drug is administered for as little as 12 months after a heart attack, reducing the risk of stroke or another heart attack.
The NICE regulatory body of the NHS has recommended four years of use to further reduce the risk of cardiovascular problems.
The NICE regulatory body of the NHS has recommended four years of use to further reduce the risk of cardiovascular problems.
About 140,000 people suffer a heart attack every year and a quarter of them suffer another heart attack or stroke.
Heart attacks and strokes are caused by accumulations of fatty material in the artery walls that form plaques.
If the plaque breaks up, it can cause a blood clot that blocks the blood flow to the heart, causing a heart attack.
If the blood clot comes loose, it can flow through the bloodstream and block the blood flow to the brain, causing a stroke.
People who have already had a heart attack are at higher risk of having another one.
Ticagrelor, which is produced by the British company AstraZeneca and marketed under the trade name Brilique, reduces this risk by making the formation of blood clots less likely.
NICE's draft guidance published today recommends a 12-month course of 90mg of Ticagrelor, followed by 60mg with twice daily aspirin for the next three years.
Professor Carole Longson, Director of the NICE Health Technology Evaluation Centre, said: "Despite the availability of secondary prevention, a quarter of all people who have had a heart attack have another heart attack or stroke - often with disastrous consequences".
The fear of another heart attack can have a significant negative impact on a person's quality of life.
Experience shows that Ticagrelor in combination with aspirin is effective in reducing further heart attacks and strokes in people who have already had a heart attack.
Through a preliminary recommendation from Ticagrelor, we are pleased to be able to extend available treatment options to thousands of people who can benefit from them.
Information on the efficacy and safety of Ticagrelor - especially the risk of bleeding - is limited to a period of up to three years. The draft guidance does not recommend treatment beyond this period.

A culture of political correctness has led to widespread electoral fraud in Muslim communities being knowingly ignored, as a scathing government report revealed today.
Former cabinet member Sir Eric Pickles verbally attacks police, election observers and town halls for ignoring evidence of election abuse based on "ethnic and religious hypersensitivity".
The former Minister for Integration and Local Government, now an anti-corruption king, said that intimidation of voters for religious reasons is so bad that police should be allowed to set up barrier tapes outside polling booths to protect intimidated voters.
He recommends that voters should carry an identity card to prove their identity at elections.
At present, a voter only has to give his name and address.
The report proposes that non-removable ink should be applied to a person's finger when they cast their vote to prevent someone from voting twice.
Whistleblowers should be given more protection, Sir Eric says.
He demands that the press should have more access to community documents and decisions of unofficial committees or working groups.
"This not only serves to prevent electoral fraud, but also to protect local government from the broader culture of corruption and financial fraud that accompanies it," he said.
The report was ordered by Downing Street in the wake of the Tower Hamlets election scandal in East London.
Last year, a special election court ruled that incumbent Mayor Lutfur Rahman should be removed from office after a litany of corrupt and illegal practices.
The court found that Rahman had "cynically perverted the religious feelings of his Muslim community" and that he had silenced his critics with accusations of racism and Islamophobia.
Rahman is said to have "run his campaign on the basis that it is the religious duty of Muslims to elect him.
Up to 300 votes were either dubious or the result of an imitation in which one person votes as someone else.
Sir Eric said there was evidence of fraud across the country.
He was particularly alarmed by the fraudulent postal vote - where older members of the Muslim community put pressure on people to vote for a candidate of their choice.
Sir Eric, pictured, made several recommendations to clean up the voting system, including the use of ID cards to prove identity
In his report, he says: "Evidence was provided that pressure was brought to bear on vulnerable members of some ethnic minorities, particularly women and young people, to vote according to the will of their elders, especially communities with a Pakistani or Bangladeshi background.
"There was concern that... state institutions would have knowingly ignored such behaviour because of "politically correct" hypersensitivities regarding ethnicity and religion".
Sir Eric made 50 recommendations to clean up the system, including a ban on political activists processing postal voting documents to stop "election harvests".
The report being considered by Theresa May also calls for tougher registration checks to prevent the electoral roll from being used for immigration and social fraud purposes.
Consider options to ask voters for their ID before the election.
Use non-removable ink on a person's finger once they have cast their vote to prevent someone from voting twice.
carry out systematic checks on the nationality of persons to ensure that they are eligible to vote
A three-year limit on applications for automatic postal votes.
Ban on political activists handling complete postal votes and envelopes of postal votes.
Give the police the authority to set up barriers around voting stations.
A change in the law to facilitate intimidation charges under the Representation of the People Act 1983.
No photography in voting stations.
Requirement that only English may be used in the polling stations (with the exception of Wales)
Intensify training to ensure that staff enforce the rule that voters go into the polling booth alone.
Sir Eric falls over the Metropolitan Police and finds it "amazing" that no criminal charges were brought after the Tower Hamlets case.
"The Electoral Court has declared Lutfur Rahman and his deputy unfit to stand trial because of a litany of corrupt and illegal practices," he said.
He was found guilty on a number of grounds for sufficient - in accordance with the high standards in criminal proceedings.
He also criticises the ineffective "ticking off" controls of the election registration departments of the town halls.
Sir Eric said: "Last year's court ruling in Tower Hamlets was a warning signal.
Our country bears a proud heritage as the mother of parliaments, but the worrying and covert spread of electoral fraud and denials by some authorities threaten this good reputation.

How to protect yourself from weapon attacks with Krav Maga
The world outside is a dangerous place, but this video from Dailymail.com might make it a little safer for you.
We talked to Rhon Mizrachi, a grandmaster of the Krav Maga Association in New York, to find out how to deal with armed robbers at close range.
No matter if you are approached from the front or from behind, this video will show you how to turn the tables on your robber.
If you are approached from behind, the first thing you should do is turn around so that you can see your attacker and "get out of the line of fire," says Mizrachi.
Then grasp the weapon between your forearm and shoulder before striking him in the face with your free elbow.
Then strike him in the groin with your knee and, while the attacker is writhing in pain, twist the weapon out of his hands. Hit him in the face with the barrel and move backwards while pointing the gun at him.
For attackers approaching from the front, the technique is similar - move your body out of the line of fire, grab the gun and twist it so that the attacker cannot shoot.
At the same time shift your weight on the gun and strike the attacker on the chest, then twist the gun out of his grip before moving backwards and pointing the gun at him.
Sounds difficult?
Watch the video to see exactly how Mizrachi does it.
But keep in mind that in case of a robbery it is safest to hand over your money - unless you are a Krav Maga Grandmaster.

Mecklenburg-Vorpommern: "Go where it hurts"
Strange Mecklenburg-Vorpommern: The locals don't hear anything about the summer election campaign - and holidaymakers from North Rhine-Westphalia are not allowed to vote for the state parliament.
In Mecklenburg-Vorpommern they understood.
In 2021, the state elections will not take place again directly at the end of the summer holidays, the Schwerin parliament decided at the beginning of the year.
Because it doesn't get any stupider than it has been so far: summer holidays, heat and state election campaign - that's all biting.
The locals, who are to be convinced by the election campaigners, are on holiday.
The vast majority of holidaymakers who are in the country, travelling to Usedom, Rügen or Hiddensee, are not locals and are therefore not allowed to vote for the Landtag.
There are also practical problems: During the holidays, helpers who hang up posters, inflate balloons, hand out flyers and count votes at the end are hard to find.
Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania will have to endure another election campaign until September 4, 2016, the election day and last day of the holidays, when it will have to pass the people by.
The hot phase, if one can even say so, has just begun.
And it is also about something: Prime Minister Erwin Sellering, leader of an SPD/CDU coalition, has to fear for his office.
The SPD, the strongest party since 1998, is now clearly behind the CDU in polls.
It will be exciting to see how strongly newcomers to AfD perform and what will remain in the end that is suitable for a coalition.
Sellering, 66 years old and head of government since 2008, is conducting an almost inconspicuous election campaign, except for his big posters.
He travels around the country, handing out roses and chatting a little with the people, just like his legendary taciturn predecessor Harald Ringstorff did.
Otherwise Seelering has got cold feet and blames Chancellor Merkel for the flourishing of the AfD.
Their refugee policy, their "We can do it" has accelerated the rise of the right-wing populists, which will probably cost him his fine office now.
The CDU with its top candidate, the Minister of the Interior Lorenz Caffier, has already experienced what it is like to campaign at the wrong time in the right place.
She has twice invited Chancellor Angela Merkel to major rallies; Merkel's Bundestag constituency is in the northeast.
But the target group was not right, there were more North Rhine-Westphalians, Berliners and Saxons than Mecklenburgers and Western Pomerania.
"There was probably a majority from other federal states," Vincent Kokert, Secretary General of the CDU in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, recently complained on NDR radio.
But it wouldn't hurt anyone from other corners of Germany to listen to Angela Merkel for once.
Otherwise, the Northeast CDU largely dispenses with the usual campaign stalls in marketplaces and in front of shopping centres with parasols and balloons.
That, according to Kokert, only plays a "subordinate role".
The Union has also noticed that its base is crumbling away in the countryside, that it has to make a great effort to get in touch with the people again.
She is like the left, the SPD, the Greens: hardly present in the vastness of the country.
The advice given by CDU campaigner Kokert to his comrades-in-arms, however, is also self-explanatory: "You must go where it hurts, namely where the people are: Village festivals, golden weddings, every birthday party must be used".
Because the stakes are high, Sellering has now called on his SPD to conduct a particularly committed election campaign.
In recent surveys, the Social Democrats, with 22 percent, were behind partner CDU (25) and only just ahead of AfD (19).
In the 2011 election, the SPD still clearly won with 35.6 percent, ahead of the CDU (22).
The Greens, a small party with seven percent in the polls, are likely to make the leap into the state parliament.
They are making a modern virtue out of the holiday shortage and are shifting most of their election campaign to the Internet.
"Online election campaign", the state chairwoman Claudia Müller calls it.
Otherwise, green campaigners are looking for traces of local voters among the holidaymakers.
Silke Gajek, the top candidate, is currently cruising through the Mecklenburg lakes in a houseboat and thinks it's beautiful.
Her impression: "Elective leave in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern is not a punishment".

Which led to many a truck getting stuck in residential areas.
Since the speed limits were also not adhered to, the community increasingly requested the measuring vehicle from Mössingen.
"There have been significant overshoots," says King, who himself went to the site to check the situation.
There have been two or three flashes a minute.

Instead, District President Jörg Schmidt responded to a question from Göhner as to whether there could be financial compensation by pointing out that the restaurant would otherwise profit from the advantages of its location on the B 27, and now it would also have to bear the disadvantages resulting from the renovation.
Göhner knows from other districts where such things were handled more generously.
Despite all the complaints, Göhner is certain that his restaurant will continue to exist.

You're not overtaxing anyone.
Other, more far-reaching points would first be discussed within the parties.
I'm involved in that too.

Some things are already known, announced, targeted: The fact that a new security authority should take care of cracking encrypted communication is not new.

Some of it is politically and legally sensitive.
Some things still seem half-baked and leave questions open.

Yes, says de Maizière, it is important to differentiate between the issues of refugees and terror.

He doesn't think much of turning away from the one-two.
We have pacified the discussion in Germany.

And he has constitutional reservations about a burqa ban.

Volkswagen is still getting off lightly.
Despite the diesel scandal, delivery figures are rising worldwide.
But things are not going well in all markets.
The recall campaign is causing a stir.
Volkswagen's start to the second half of the year was more restrained in terms of deliveries.
Despite the diesel affair, Europe's largest carmaker has been able to continue its growth so far this year thanks to its many brands and a number of markets that are doing well.
However, in July, the core brand VW weakened, especially in Western Europe, and thus again weighed on overall sales, as the Dax-listed company announced.
Worldwide, the VW brand sold 449100 cars in July, 1.8 percent fewer than in the same month last year.
In Western Europe alone, the second most important market after China, sales were 14 percent below the same month last year.
Deliveries in the German domestic market fell by almost a sixth.
Brand Sales Director Jürgen Stackmann attributed the weaker figures from July primarily to two fewer sales days in Europe.
In addition, there had been a reluctance to buy in some core markets due to "changed economic conditions".
In addition to the situation surrounding the attempted coup in Turkey, the British vote to leave the EU was also a burden, a spokeswoman explained.
In the USA, where the exhaust gas affair first escalated, there is also still a minus.
The Chinese market is a great support for VW.
All in all, Lower Saxony's own brand, which was mainly affected by the diesel scandal, continues to get off lightly anyway: after the first seven months, there is only a drop in deliveries of 0.9 percent to 3.37 million vehicles.
Group Sales Director Fred Kappler was able to show a further increase in sales from January to July.
Volkswagen delivered 1.3 percent more vehicles during this period, 5.904 million worldwide.
Volkswagen had manipulated exhaust gas tests with software.
In Germany alone, VW is calling around 2.5 million cars into the workshops for conversion.
In the course of the conversion, VW confirmed that the conversion of the cars will not have any negative effects.
After the conversion of the vehicles there was no deterioration in fuel consumption, CO2 emissions or engine performance.
The car manufacturer issues a certificate to customers after the conversion that is "equal to the guarantee", but does not speak of a "guarantee", as was said in company circles on Friday.
The reason for this is legal subtleties.
The "Focus" had reported that Volkswagen was now granting its German customers a guarantee for converted diesel models after all.
This was confirmed last Monday by VW representatives in the Federal Ministry of Transport.
The Ministry of Transport has confirmed that this meeting took place.
"VW has to fulfill the conditions of my commission of inquiry and the KBA in full."
"Deviations from this will not be accepted," said Federal Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt (CSU) according to the ministry.
VW has given a guarantee that there will be no deterioration in fuel consumption, CO2 emissions or engine performance after the conversion and that all vehicle values relevant to type approval will remain unchanged.
However, Volkswagen itself does not use the term 'guarantee' as it was known in business circles.
Volkswagen sees the broad term "warranty" as an opportunity for customers to come to a workshop six months after the conversion, for example, with an engine defect - and to attribute this to the new software, even if the damage has nothing to do with it.
It was also in the interest of the customer to avoid, as was said, uncertainty about possible warranty arrangements in the event of any other damage that had nothing to do with the exhaust gas scandal.
VW therefore does not use the term 'guarantee'.
Raiffeisenbank Gmund am Tegernsee will be the second bank in Germany to charge penalty interest to rich savers.
Bank boss Josef Paul said on Thursday: "It's only about 139 customers who park 40 million euros in current or call money accounts".
The Federal Association of German Banks speaks of an isolated case and does not see this as a signal: normal savers would "not have to fear paying penalty interest on their savings".
If banks store money overnight at the European Central Bank (ECB), they have to pay it 0.4 percent penalty interest.
Raiffeisenbank Gmund will demand this fee back from private and corporate customers from September onwards for deposits of over 100,000 euros on current or overnight deposit accounts.
"The first 100,000 euros are free."
"The next 100,000 will cost 400 euros a year in future," said Paul.
For some time now, he has been guarding 40 million euros that can be withdrawn from one day to the next and which he cannot use.
"They are in my central bank account and cause 0.4 percent costs," said the bank manager.
"I can't lay down 4000 euros for every million."
He now passes on the costs in accordance with the polluter-pays principle.
Simply leaving the cash in the vaults of Raiffeisenbank would be far too dangerous: "I've already experienced four robberies, I don't want the fifth one," said the bank's board member.
Most customers would understand and switch to other forms of investment.
Only a few migrated to other banks.
The Association of Cooperatives in Bavaria stated: "The extreme monetary policy course of the ECB causes considerable costs for all banks".
It is 'not economically feasible in the long term' to bear them alone.
Some German banks have therefore increased their fees for account management, credit cards or bank transfers.
With penalty interest on deposits of three million euros or more, Thüringer Volks- und Raiffeisenbank Altenburger Land and its Skatbank branch made the headlines in 2014.
Michael Kemmer, General Manager of the German Banking Association, said: "We do not expect private customers to have to pay fees for deposits nationwide; competition among banks and savings banks in Germany is far too strong for that".
A banker said that at Tegernsee there is "a clientele that is a little more lavishly endowed with wealth".
"This can be a problem for a small bank" if they keep money for free.
The cooperative bank Gmund, founded in 1911, has branches in Bad Wiessee, Rottach-Egern, Kreuth and Tegernsee.
Well-known actors, sportsmen and entrepreneurs live in the region.
The Association of Cooperatives in Bavaria "is currently not aware of any other banks that charge reimbursement of expenses for retail customer deposits", said spokesman Ernst.
The President of the Federal Association of German Volksbanks and Raiffeisenbanks (BVR), Uwe Fröhlich, had declared at the end of June: "The threshold to go into the negative vis-à-vis private customers is very, very high".
The competition is fierce and there is a threat of investors migrating to the competition.
Customers in Germany will not put up with this on a broad scale.
Destination records: who actually buys records?
Middle-aged lonely men love records.
Before you rush to the commentary section to litter it with harsh insults under the pseudonym Not AllSomeMenMiddleAged, this statement is derived from current data.
According to YouGov, the much-discussed resurgence of records is not due to a boom in millennials who want to welcome the novelty of physical objects, but to midlife nostalgia.
Those who have recently bought a record are most likely between the ages of 45 and 54.
In fact, the age group of 18-24 is the most unlikely buyer group.
It is also not a hordes through hobby collectors - it has an emotional meaning: older record buyers tend to keep their feelings to themselves (56% vs. 53%) and enjoy spending time alone (69% vs. 66%).
But are the results of YouGov correct?
If this blog were a news report on television, the camera would follow me as I walk down the middle of a busy Soho street, wearing a modest grey suit and gesticulating wildly before I stop, hold my hands and say something decisive like: "Well, let's take a closer look.
So, let's take a look.
Even though the heart of Soho is slowly losing its charm - hotels, restaurants and offices now fill the buildings where independent sellers once resided - there are still a handful of fantastic specialty record stores.
I would probably ask the cameraman to switch off the camera for the next part, where I stand in close proximity to various men in such shops and try to estimate their age and mood by observation.
Stuart from Glasgow, 55, whom I follow from Sister Ray (data count: two young women, three middle-aged men) to Reckless Records (data count: eight middle-aged men, one woman, probably around 20), is in London for a day for a meeting and goes through the shops to fill the few hours.
Is he a collector, I ask?
"I guess so," he says.
I got about 3,000 or 4,000 records.
These records, shown above (he sent me the snapshot by e-mail, I didn't follow him home), line the walls of his living room.
The reason why he owns such a considerable number of albums and singles is the result of his disposable income: he is now able to buy records that he couldn't afford when they came out and again buy items that he sold when he was young and broke.
"Many of the things I buy are from the late 60s, early 70s, which came out when I was 11 or 12. Things that I was probably a little too young to buy," he says.
He agrees that those who buy records tend to be introverted and like to spend time alone, and adds: "I don't smoke and I don't drink very much.
That's my truck.
Wez, 25, who works at Sister Ray, also believes that many customers he meets apply to the YouGov profile.
But he has also noticed a new wave of people influenced by the media hype, people who have heard about the comeback and feel compelled to buy their old records again.
From the conversations I have had, people have usually got rid of their collection around 1998 or 1999.
Customers who once sold their records to buy CDs now sell their CDs to buy their records again," he says.
This would explain the boom in fans of the record revival of a certain age.
But what about the supposed emotional significance of records?
It only takes a few seconds in a store like Phonica to realize that record stores offer a reassuring community of like-minded people.
According to Wez, some of the older customers took offence at the contactless payment system.
Some record fans feel overwhelmed by the digital world and want to retreat to the stability of familiar record sleeves, of objects that evoke happy childhood memories.
"I think sometimes filling a void or owning material possessions can be a kind of comfort," says Wez.
This is the case with me as a collector and I think that it is the case with many people.
It's an easy way to keep yourself mentally occupied.
"We're like their social workers!" one employee whistles from a stack of records.
An ICM survey in April revealed that almost 50% of people who bought a record last month had not listened to it.
The survey also found that 41% of those who buy a record never use a turntable, while 7% of those who buy a record never own a turntable.
At this point in the news report, I would probably look very concerned as I flip through a stack of Bossa Nova compilations.
Jonny, 42, who works at Sounds of the Universe (data count: three middle-aged men), has noticed a "trophy aspect" of the revival.
"Someone came in here recently and said, 'I don't own a record player, but I'd like to buy a Radiohead record so I can put it on the shelf,'" he says.
This is not a big percentage, but it definitely happens.
More product-heavy, less music-heavy.
We got people saying, "I don't have a record player."
These are younger people, not older people who are just starting to get in.
Fopp, who has dedicated almost an entire floor to the records, has a more colourful audience when I go in.
There are couples around 70, tourists taking pictures, teenage boys and middle-aged women.
Even though the atmosphere is a bit less relaxed than in the above mentioned stores - Wild Beast's latest synthesizer and sexy pop instead of experimental jazz booms out of the speakers - it's good to see such diversity among the customers.
None of them look particularly lonely, but gnawing psychological traumas are hard to detect when you stand next to someone for 30 seconds.
Elanora, 27, has been walking around the store for a few minutes now, looking at the variety of records for sale.
She's more likely to go window-shopping than bulk buying.
She doesn't earn much, so collecting records is not really an option, she says.
It costs a lot.
It's easy to listen to music from a computer or in any other way, but the beauty of records is..." she drifts off with an amorous sigh.
I don't know how to explain it - it is truly unique.
My last stop is a store that is said to have inspired a new generation of record lovers: Urban Outfitters.
While I appear to be patterning the jeans hot pants, I watch a group of young teenage girls grouping around Polaroid cameras for a moment before a father and his daughter consider buying a Crosley turntable.
To the left is a staircase, a wall full of records by Adele, Jeff Buckley, Amy Winehouse and Fleetwood Mac: a mixture of contemporary music and classics, the essential records for an average collection.
Nobody looks at them - perhaps because they are purely decorative, some of them so high up that it is impossible to touch them.
It's pure "record art".
But considering that every attraction for these items could mean more money for the industry and send some customers into the depths of Soho for more, there is nothing to complain about.
It is no surprise that a population group that has more time and money than others is also the one that spends the most on luxury items such as records.
Even though my research showed that the results of YouGov are correct, they do not take into account, at least in record stores in Soho, the large number of female collectors and record lovers that exist in reality, record stores and online forums.
These people probably work hard at school or in offices.
They certainly don't spend their Thursday mornings strolling through record stores on Berwick Street and leafing through records while avoiding the staring gaze of a creepy, 30-year-old fake presenter towering over the shoulders of unsuspecting middle-aged men.

Scientists say that the Greenland shark has the longest life span of all vertebrates on the planet.

French court rejects offer to demolish shops in jungle refugee camp
A French court has rejected an offer by the authorities in Calais to tear down dozens of makeshift shops and restaurants in the Calais jungle, where thousands of refugees live.
At a court hearing this week, the authorities in Calais argued that the state should be allowed to tear down 72 makeshift shops where people inside the camp sell goods ranging from cigarettes to energy drinks, offer hairdressing services or sell tea for 50 cents (40 pence) or simple meals for a few euros in makeshift restaurants.
The Prefecture of Calais argued that these places should be demolished because they would constitute a parallel economy from which no tax would be paid and which would entail a fire and sanitary risk.
Humanitarian groups told the court that the shops and restaurants were important because the free meals offered by the government-sponsored association and other groups would not provide enough food for the growing numbers in the camp.
They also explained that the temporary shops and restaurants often provide accommodation and free meals for people in need.
A court in Lille ruled that there was no legal basis for the expulsion of the people who run the 72 provisional shops, but admitted that the concerns of the Prefecture of Calais were "perfectly understandable".
Judge Jean-François Molla said that grocery stores, cafés and restaurants would play a much greater role than simply feeding people who "live in extremely precarious conditions.
He said that the areas provide quiet meeting places between refugees and volunteers.
One of the places threatened with demolition was the camp's Jungle Book Kids' Café, which is run on a non-profit basis and provides 200 meals a day, English and French classes, and asylum counseling for the hundreds of vulnerable unaccompanied minors in the camp.
More than 170,000 people have signed the petition to protect the Kids' Café.
A letter to the Guardian said that the closure "would be a disaster for these children, the youngest of whom are eight years old.
The two aid organizations Help Refugees and L'Auberge des Migrants estimated on Friday that the number of people living in the jungle camp had risen to over 9,000 - the highest number so far - after a sharp increase in new arrivals over the summer.

Here comes the Enforcement Trailer
Germany's speeders must prepare for the next generation of speedometers: In various German states, including Hesse and Brandenburg, new flash devices are being tested that are designed to catch speeders particularly effectively.
The futuristic-looking enforcement trailers from the Wiesbaden-based company Vitronic can be used, for example, at accident black spots where it would be too dangerous for mobile measurement by the police.
For example, at motorway construction sites or bridges that are to be renovated with a temporary speed limit, there is often no necessary infrastructure to ensure that the speed limit is observed with a stationary speed camera.
However, a permanent mobile setup can be too dangerous or costly.
The Enforcement Trailer is self-sufficient: Its battery lasts for five days with uninterrupted measuring operation, and the case data is transmitted in encrypted form via a modem.
Laser measurement technology also allows all vehicles to be recorded simultaneously over several lanes.
Variable speed limits as well as passage bans according to time, lane and vehicle class can also be monitored.
According to the manufacturer, the trailer can be moved in the raised position with any car with a trailer coupling.
So that it is not simply stolen, it is lowered in the measuring mode, so that the wheels disappear in the armoured and, by the way, bulletproof outer shell.
In addition, a built-in alarm system should protect the speed camera against vandalism.
According to Vitronic, the trailer has been tested in various German states since 2015 and is now in use.
Foreign authorities are also using the new technology to great effect: France recently placed a repeat order for 100 units, following an order for 150 units last year.

31 years of exemplary clarity
Ruppert Göller, managing director of the "Veitenstein Group" water purpose association, retires.
The association is considered "exemplary throughout Bavaria".
A small Franconian drinking water association as a model for the large water producers.
This was the original statement made some time ago in an article by the Bavarian Broadcasting Corporation.
A little later, the Water Forum of the government of Lower Franconia paid tribute to the association.
The work of the Veitenstein Group is considered "exemplary throughout Bavaria".
Behind all this is Rupert Göller, who was an employee of the Zweckverband for 31 years, 28 of which as managing director.
Now he was retired at the age of 65.
The drinking water association of the Veitenstein Group, based in Kottendorf in the municipality of Breitbrunn, extracts about 150,000 cubic metres of water annually and supplies 32 towns and hamlets with about 5,500 inhabitants.
The member municipalities are Kirchlauter, Breitbrunn, Lauter, Ebelsbach and the town of Baunach.
There are water supply contracts for other towns and municipalities.
The current chairwoman, Breitbrunn's mayor Gertrud Bühl (FW), reminded the audience that Rupert Göller was hired as water warden in 1985 and had already been appointed managing director of the special-purpose association in 1988.
"His tasks were very varied and they ranged from water pipeline construction and maintenance work to office and organisational activities, budget preparation, calculation of fees and contributions and emergency operations at weekends," said the chairwoman.
As outstanding events she mentioned the commissioning and inauguration of the new wells (1994), land purchases in the area of the new wells (1998) and compensation for farmers, the rehabilitation of the elevated tanks (1999), the purchase of a new central computer control system (2004) and the partial renewal of water pipes.
There had been no standstill whatsoever and innovations had been taken up again and again, because water means life and drinking water is the most important foodstuff.
In her laudation she praised Göller's loyal, reliable and correct service over 31 years.
He has put his heart and soul into his water board and he has lived the water board as if it were his own company.
A few weeks ago, he was able to present the Veitenstein Group's successful concept for nitrate reduction to the Water Forum of the Lower Franconian District as a real practitioner.
He received a lot of recognition and praise for this.
Rupert Göller, for his part, praised water keeper Alfons Griebel, who had worked with him for 28 years.
He is the best water keeper and he was a loyal squire.
Together we were an unbeatable team.
As highlights from his point of view he described the well construction and the restructuring of the special purpose association.
However, the biggest challenge and most difficult operation was the pipe burst at the elevated tank near Kirchlauter on 3 January.
Here, work had to be carried out all night long at minus 17 degrees so that the villages could be supplied with water.
Also the supply of Neubrunn could only be maintained once because the elevated tank was filled with hoses from Pettstadt.
The management of the drinking water association was handed over to Daniel Stürmer from Lauter, who succeeds Rupert Göller.

Steel - a ray of hope for the German steel industry
The crisis-stricken and energy-intensive German steel industry is spared additional costs amounting to millions.
Financial burdens that the industry was threatened with from the green electricity subsidies are off the table.
The exemption from the renewable energy levy for the existing plants for the so-called own power production in the German steel industry would remain, said Federal Minister of Economics Sigmar Gabriel (SPD) in the "Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung" (WAZ, Friday edition).
"I'm really glad that after two years of tough negotiations, we finally got this."
The European Commission had initially planned to ask steel producers who use gases from the blast furnace to generate electricity for their own consumption to pay.
According to the German industry association, the steel industry was threatened with additional costs of 120 to 240 million euros per year.
Gabriel told the WAZ that there was now a basic agreement with the EU Commission after talks with Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager.
Only when the generators in the steelworks are replaced will an EEG levy of 20 percent be due.
However, the steel industry does not charge this either.
The IG Metall trade union welcomed Germany's agreement with the EU Commission on own power generation.
The status quo of the previous regulation is thus largely established.
He said that Gabriel's successful efforts were of particular importance for the steel industry.
"In terms of our 'Steel is Future' campaign, this is a first step."
"More must follow."
"Climate and employment targets must also be weighed up in the reform of emissions trading", explained IG Metall head Jörg Hofmann in Frankfurt.
The steel industry in Europe has been suffering from overcapacity and considerable price pressure since the financial crisis of 2008.
Last year the situation worsened further when the world's largest producer country, China, threw massive quantities of steel onto the world market in the face of weakening domestic demand.
European producers accuse Chinese steel companies of price dumping.
In the course of this spring the situation has eased somewhat.
On the one hand, import duties imposed on imported steel are having an effect, and on the other hand the economic outlook in China has brightened.
It is unclear how sustainable the price recovery is.
German industry leader Thyssenkrupp remained cautious on Thursday.
Recently, prices have tended to stagnate again.
The industry is reacting to the difficult situation with further cost reductions.
Thyssenkrupp did not want to rule out the closure of individual plants.
The German steel industry employed around 86,000 people at the end of 2015.
German steel manufacturers remain cautious in July despite rising prices and increasing orders.
At 3.4 million tonnes, they produced a good six per cent less crude steel than in the same month last year, the German Steel Federation announced on Friday.
After a brief increase in May, the quantity produced fell for the second month in succession.
Since the beginning of the year, production has been two percent below the previous year's figure.
The association expects output to rise in the coming months thanks to an improved order situation.
Community, Spirit, Health: Singing is good for seniors
Singing has accompanied Ursel Kipp all her life: As a young girl she was in the school choir, in her teacher training she studied music, and today the 78-year-old sings in a senior citizens' choir.
"Singing moves me - emotionally and physically," she describes.
After a rehearsal she feels balanced, happy and more alive overall, she says.
Besides, she does something good for her health and her spirit.
Because singing is a great hobby for seniors from several perspectives, says Erhard Hackler from the German Senior Citizens' League.
Most seniors sing in a choir and share the joy of music with like-minded people, Hackler describes.
By being together regularly, seniors can establish and maintain social contacts.
Because social and family structures often dissolve in old age, a choir is then an ideal opportunity to spend time with other people.
Ursel Kipp has also had this experience in her choir: "To be able to coordinate and organize, to rely on others and to learn from each other - a choir is a very special form of being together".
Singing can be exhausting in a positive sense, says Hackler.
This is because senior citizens train deep and controlled breathing.
Those who regularly challenge their lungs do not get out of breath so quickly in everyday life.
Singing is also an ideal hobby when it comes to preserving the sound of the voice in old age.
Singing often has a very special effect on older people, says Ursula Lenz from the Federal Working Group of Senior Citizens' Organisations.
In the older generations, singing together was much more important; it was part of everyday life, both at school and in leisure time, she explains.
Lenz often observes that singing or listening to songs awakens many memories in older people, often combined with positive feelings of their youth.
Through song lyrics and especially melodies, even people suffering from dementia remember events long ago.
Singing also demands a special performance from the head, explains Lenz.
To concentrate on one's own voice and on a given rhythm at the same time, while adapting to the other singers - that is a great cognitive challenge.
Especially older people who live alone practice not to concentrate only on themselves.
Another positive aspect is the recognition one gets from singing in a choir, says Hackler.
An enthusiastic audience is great praise.
Also the self-esteem grows through singing in the choir.
To show yourself: When I practice for something for a long time, I get better and grow beyond myself - this experience strengthens.
So there are enough good reasons to start singing.
Anyone who wants to try out a new hobby should not hesitate - even if he thinks he has little talent, advises Lenz.
You don't sing alone - with 50 singing people, who can hear when a note goes wrong?
In their search for the right offer, senior citizens have various options, says Hackler.
If someone from your circle of friends sings in a senior citizens' choir, you can simply join in.
Many cities also offer overviews of the choirs in the area.
If you would like to sing in a church choir, please contact the congregation or the churchwarden directly.
Many senior citizens' choirs can also be found via the Internet.
If you do not have access to the Internet, you can ask your family, friends or neighbours for help with your Internet research.
Whoever feels like singing should definitely join a choir, advises Hackler.
Singing is good for the soul and has something liberating - this is true for all ages.
Cats are more sensitive than cats to cries from kittens
Biologists in Hanover have investigated the effect of calling kittens on adult animals.
To their surprise, the meowing did not leave the males cold either - but unlike the females they always behaved the same.
Female cats can recognize the degree of excitement of kittens by the meowing of the kittens.
They react ten percent faster to the sounds of kittens who think they are in great distress, as scientists from the University of Veterinary Medicine and the Hannover Medical School (MHH) have found out.
Males also react to the calls of kittens - but always the same.
"Apparently, the acoustic differences between meowing of less and highly excited young animals are either not perceptible or not important for the males," said biologist Wiebke Konerding from the MHH.
She is first author of the study, which was published this Friday in the journal "BMC Evolutionary Biology".
In a previous study, the research team had already found that the duration and pitch of kitten cries vary with the urgency of their need for help.
A total of nine adult males and eight females from the MHH's animal husbandry were observed.
On the one hand, they were played calls from little ones, which were taken out of the litter box for three minutes and separated from mother and siblings.
On the other hand they were confronted with screams of more excited kittens, which were additionally lifted.
The researchers consider their results to be meaningful despite the small sample.
"All females, even those who did not have their own offspring yet, reacted in a differentiated way to the cries", said Konerding.
They turned more quickly to the loudspeaker when it played the calls of the more excited kittens.
This ability may be innate or develop with sexual maturity.
"It was a surprise that the males reacted at all," said the biologist.
In the past, scientists have repeatedly studied the reactions of women and men to baby sounds in humans.
Some studies also showed that women reacted more sensitively to babies, regardless of whether they were already mothers or not, reported biologist Marina Scheumann.

Despite doping: These athletes still have a chance of winning a medal at the Olympics in Rio
The 34-year-old Justin Gatlin has already been banned twice for doping (2001 and 2006).
Rio de Janeiro - Whistleblower Julia Stepanowa is not allowed to start in Rio
Other convicted athletics sinners can only laugh about it - they are fighting for medals in Rio.
The subject of doping continues to dominate the headlines at the Olympic Games in Rio.
The Russian swimmer Julija Jefimowa, who had claimed her right to start shortly before the games after a doping ban, was mercilessly booed and booed at her start (100 metres breaststroke).
A bizarre scenery presented itself: With a smile on her face, she had strutted into the hall and provoked with her performance.
When it was clear that she would not take gold, the audience broke into a storm of cheers.
But there are many more athletes who, despite their doping past, will be competing in the Rio Olympics.
Here is an overview:
Justin Gatlin (100, 200, 4x100 m relay/USA): The 34-year-old is one of the most controversial figures in athletics.
He has already been suspended twice for doping (2001 and 2006 to 2010).
Since his spell, the 2004 Olympic champion and former World Champion has been running even faster than before. He is the world's number one over 100 m in 9.80 seconds and is considered Usain Bolt's greatest challenger.
Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce (100, 4x100 m relay/Jamaica): The two-time Olympic champion and seven-time World champion had to serve a six-month suspension in 2010 after being proven to be taking the painkiller Oxycodon.
She had severe toothache after an operation, the 29-year-old defended herself.
Sandra Perkovic (Discus/Croatia): In 2011 the Olympic champion of 2012, world champion of 2013 and European champion from 2010 to 2016 tested positive for the banned stimulant methylhexanamine.
Perkovic denied knowingly taking it and was suspended for six months.
The four furthest litters this year go to the account of the big gold favourite.
LaShawn Merritt (200, 400, 4x400 m relay/USA): The Beijing Olympic Champion and two-time World Champion over 400 m, tested positive in 2010 and was suspended for 21 months.
A penis enlargement drug was responsible, Merritt affirmed.
This year, the 30-year-old over 200 and 400 m is the fastest man in the world so far.
Iwan Tichon (Hammer throw, Belarus): Hardly any other athlete was deprived of so many medals afterwards.
For example, Tichon lost his 2005 World Championship title nine years later, after he was found to have taken testosterone doping.
The now 40-year-old also had to give up Olympic silver in 2004 for steroid doping and the European Championship title in 2006 for testosterone abuse.
The bronze medal of the 2008 Olympic Games, which was also withdrawn, was returned to him following a ruling by the International Court of Justice for Sport (CAS).
With 80.04 m he is on second place in the world ranking list.

Bomb terror in Thailand - Austrian woman injured - Several dead

She had suffered cuts and had been treated in hospital, but had already been able to leave.
She had planned her trip home for the beginning of September.
Whether Austrian citizens are also affected by the further explosions on the holiday island of Phuket and in the southern cities of Surat Thani, Phang Nga, Trang and Chumphon is not yet clear.
The Foreign Ministry is in constant contact with the local authorities in this regard, said Schnöll.
In Hua Hin, about 200 kilometres south of the capital Bangkok, two bombs exploded in a nightlife area on Thursday evening.
According to police, one Thai woman was killed and about 20 people were injured, among them the Austrian, three Germans, three Dutch and three Italians.
Friday morning two more explosives went off, killing another person, according to the authorities.
A bomb explosion was also reported from Phuket in the morning.
According to the police, a taxi driver was injured in the detonation near the Patong beach, which is popular with holidaymakers.
In Surat Thani on the southeast coast of the country, another bomb then exploded, killing a municipal employee.
According to the authorities, the bomb exploded in a flowerbed in front of the coastal police station.
Finally, detonations in Phang Nga and Trang on the southwest coast and in Chumphon on the southeast coast caused several injuries.
It was said that there was a connection with the explosions in Hua Hin.
"The bombings bear the same signature," Army General Danai Kritmethavee told journalists early on Friday morning.
"We are assuming that this is a coordinated attack."
It was too early to comment on possible motives - but it was probably the actions of Muslim rebels.
Thai media also wanted to identify a pattern in the attacks that is typical of the bombings by Muslim separatists in the south of the country.
The Thai police, on the other hand, declared that the attacks were not connected with the Islamist insurgency or with international terrorism.
"This is only local sabotage, limited to limited areas and provinces," said a spokesman in Bangkok.
It was rather assumed that the bombs were laid by opponents of the ruling military junta.
In the past few days, the authorities had received intelligence information about imminent attacks in the south of the country - but they had not been informed about the exact time and place.
It was still unclear which group was behind the attacks.
The police instructed their officers across the country to increase security around key government buildings as well as airports, train stations, tourist attractions, restaurants and entertainment areas.
In Thailand there are always small bomb attacks, but they are usually not directed against tourists.
In Hua Hin there is a palace that was used for years by Thailand's king Bhumibol Adulyadej.
Following the recent bomb explosions, the Austrian Foreign Ministry recommends on its homepage that the instructions of the Thai security authorities be followed without fail.
High security risk (security level 3) applies to the provinces of Narathiwat, Yala, Pattani and Songhkla as well as Preah Vihear and the surrounding area.
Following clashes between security forces and Muslim communities, unnecessary travel to these provinces is not recommended.
Increased security risk (security level 2) applies to the rest of the country.
The attacks on Thursday and Friday came a few days after a controversial referendum on a constitution drafted by the military junta.
This gives the military great influence also in the coming years.
Junta leader and Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha said the bombs were an attempt to wreak havoc as the country moves towards stability, economic improvement and tourism.
The military aunta, which seized power in 2014 after a period of bloody unrest, considers itself lucky to have restored stability and order to the kingdom.
However, even the military has not succeeded in bringing the rebellion of Muslim rebels, which has been smouldering for years in the extreme south of the country, under control.
More than 6500 people have already been killed in the conflict.
In addition, less than a year ago, 20 people were killed in Bangkok in an attack on a popular Hindu shrine - most of them foreign tourists.
It was the bloodiest attack in the recent history of the country.

Thus, immigrants of Islamic faith or from the Middle East are defamed in an extremist manner.
That is why we are now also observing the movement.

Protectors of the constitution in nine federal states - Bremen, Bavaria, Hesse, Berlin, Baden-Württemberg, North Rhine-Westphalia, Lower Saxony, Saxony and Thuringia - are already observing the "identities".
Maaßen said that his office had closely coordinated its decision with the state offices.
"Groups like the 'Identity Movement' try to pick up their target group where they stand," said the head of the Office for the Protection of the Constitution.
In general, extremists try to address them with language suitable for young people, often with pop music.
Islamists would do that as well as right-wing extremists.
This is not a frivolous advertisement for one's own cause.
Propaganda is supposed to appeal to people emotionally.
Young people are particularly vulnerable to this.
That's dangerous.

Maaßen said he had no knowledge of that.
For the protection of the constitution, possible contacts of this kind are only relevant from a certain point on.
It depends on whether the party in question - in this case the AfD - changes its aims through certain persons who are extremist and thus becomes extremist.
The decisive factor is therefore whether such persons have a controlling influence on the party.
This was not apparent.
In view of the significant increase in right-wing motivated crimes and attacks on asylum seekers and refugee shelters, Maaßen said he would not yet speak of new right-wing terrorism in this context.
But in recent years we have seen that there can be right-wing terrorist structures.
There was the group 'Old School Society' or the Freital group.
It is quite possible that further right-wing terrorist groups or micro-groups will form that plan attacks against asylum seekers, against refugee homes or attacks from other right-wing extremist motives.
A Germany-wide or Europe-wide control of legal terrorism was not, however, discernible.
The previous groups had emerged at the regional level or in social networks.
Maaßen expressed his concern that many assaults were committed by people who had not previously appeared in the right-wing scene.
That's what's so worrying.
Many of the suspects in attacks on asylum centres had not previously been known as criminals, politically motivated criminals or supporters of the right-wing scene.
"Many people have committed crimes who previously had nothing to do with right-wing extremists, who were perhaps politically indifferent or voted for the CDU, SPD or Left Party, for example, but who then radicalised themselves through right-wing extremist propaganda.

Preparation is everything: Robel Kiros Habte gets ready for the big race.

The consumer research company GfK is replacing its boss Matthias Hartmann.
The resignations came suddenly - but not completely surprisingly.
The difficult situation of the market research company GfK made it clear that the longer the promised successes fail to materialize, the more uncertain the chair of CEO Matthias Hartmann will become.
Turbulence at the head of Nuremberg-based market research company GfK: After another set of disappointing business figures and the resignation of the company's management, the world's number five in the sector is about to make a new start in terms of personnel.
GfK's CEO plans to leave the company by the end of the year.
The Chairman of the GfK Supervisory Board, Arno Mahlert, is retiring from the Supervisory Board with effect from September 12.
Gerhard Hausruckinger, who has been a member of the Board of Management up to now, will take over the leadership of the Board as of September 1, the company announced.
He is to officially take over the function of a "spokesman of the board" until a successor for Hartmann has been found.
As a reason for the resignations, the company cited "different views" on the long-term business policy orientation.
A company spokesman did not want to give details on Friday.
It is not yet clear who will head the market research company in the future.
In investor circles it was said on Friday that the disappointment among shareholders about the continuing lack of success of the restructuring initiated years ago had been great.
Mr. Hartmann has been at the helm of GfK since 2011.
"However, the fruits of the restructuring are not yet visible even after 5 years", it was said.
In view of the recent poor GfK business figures, every shareholder at some point becomes anxious.
"If that were the case with BMW, the Quandts would do the same," they said.
Following setbacks in previous quarters, the company was unable to halt its loss-making trend in the second quarter of 2016.
At EUR 361.2 million, sales were 6.1 percent below the level of the comparable prior-year quarter.
Related to the first half of the year, sales shrank by 3.4 percent to EUR 721.2 million.
The profit in the second quarter was primarily impacted by the lower value of the company in view of its difficult economic situation.
The goodwill amortization of 139 million euros that became necessary in the Consumer Experience division resulted in a net loss of 148.2 million euros for the Group.
In the second quarter of 2015, GfK had generated consolidated total income of 19.7 million.

From 1 October 2016, the fees per cubic metre of wastewater will be 3.44 euros instead of the previous 2.10 euros for the Neudorf/Reuth/Welschenkahl wastewater plant area; 3.36 euros for Zultenberg/Lindenberg/Lopp (previous 2.26 euros) and 3.64 euros for Azendorf (previous 2.18 euros).
At the Azendorf plant, the wastewater charge will increase again at the latest when appropriate improvement measures become necessary.
According to a rough calculation, the price of wastewater in Azendorf will then be 4.37 euros per cubic metre.
As reported by Mayor Bernd Steinhäuser (CSU), it was established during the approval of the budget by the Kulmbach District Office that there was a shortfall of funds for these sewage plants.
The Kasendorf market is obliged by law to operate the plants at cost-covering levels.
From October 1, 2016, citizens and commercial and industrial enterprises from Welschenkahl, Neudorf, Reuth, Azendorf, Lopp, Lindenberg and Zultenberg will have to dig deeper into their wallets.
The fee increases are between 48 and 67 percent.
As the head of administration, Herbert Schmidt, pointed out to the committee, a recalculation of the fees for the sewage plants of the market town was necessary.
In the period from October 2016 to September 2020, surpluses or shortfalls from the previous calculation period must also be compensated.
Schmidt justified the serious fee increases by saying that all three wastewater plants are relatively small facilities with a very low wastewater volume of between 6800 and 12000 cubic meters per year.
For example, due to the small distribution base, expenses for necessary repairs of several thousand euros would have a serious impact.
In addition, the volume of waste water in all three plants is slightly declining.
Furthermore, in the past calculation period, all three plants had incurred considerable renovation and repair costs, not least because of their age.
The plant in Azendorf is almost 30 years old, the plants for Welschenkahl, Neudorf and Reuth as well as Zultenberg, Lindenberg and Lopp almost 20 years.
Schmidt pointed out that the mechanical aeration system in the Azendorf wastewater plant had to be replaced due to damage.
At the Welschenkahl pumping station, the almost 20-year-old pumping systems had to be completely overhauled, and at the Lopp pond treatment plant, after almost 20 years of operation, the first clarification pond had to be dredged, the sewage sludge had to be disposed of and an additional aeration facility had to be installed in order to be able to comply with water law requirements in the future.
Schmidt: "In addition to these extraordinary expenses, there were also the updated support and maintenance costs, which are to be taken into account accordingly in the new calculation period.
The same applies to electricity costs, which in the previous calculation for 2011/2012 were still significantly below the current level.
Steinhäuser made it clear that with the low waste water production in the three plants, the expenses for operation and maintenance "hit the ground running".
Schmidt added that the market community had been spared the high maintenance costs of the sewage plants over the past 20 years.
In Steinhäuser's view, the situation for the above-mentioned plants would remain precarious in the long term, especially since the supply area of the Abwasserzweckverband Friesenbachtal could not be extended to include these plants because they were loss-making facilities.
Bulgaria records inflation for the first time in 8 months
National statistics show that inflation in Bulgaria in July was 1% on a monthly basis.
This is the highest value (since June 2012) and the first above zero since October last year, when positive 0.2% was recorded.
The annual average inflation rate over the last 12 months (August 2015 - July 2016) compared with the previous 12 months (August 2014 - July 2015) was -0.8%, measured by the CPI.
The consumer price index in July 2016 compared to June 2016 was 101.0%, i.e. monthly inflation was 1.0%.
The inflation rate since the beginning of the year (July 2016 compared to December 2015) was -0.2% and annual inflation in July 2016 compared to July 2015 was -0.2%.
In July 2016, a price increase was observed in the following groups of consumer goods compared to the previous month: Food and non-alcoholic beverages (1.7%); transport (1.8%); leisure and culture (6.3%); restaurants and hotels (1.2%); miscellaneous goods and services (0.3%).
Prices fell for clothing and shoes (2.2%); furniture, household appliances and routine maintenance (0.5%); health (0.1%).
Prices remained unchanged from the previous month for alcoholic beverages and tobacco; housing, water, electricity, gas and other fuels; communications; and education.
Snapchat "Anime" effect criticized as Asian caricature
Snapchat says that this filter is anime-inspired, but some observers say that it is insensitive to races.
With its filtering tool, Snapchat enables around 150 million daily users to change reality and play with identities in ways that border on the absurd.
You can transform yourself into a pineapple, a dog or a figure that could be from a Roy Lichtenstein painting.
The filters are blunt, property-twisting tools that generate more than 30 million improved selfies per day.
All missteps are made public.
Snapchat filters have attracted criticism in the past, accusing the app of promoting Blackface or promoting white skin as an ideal of beauty.
This week, when it suggested a filter to some users that gave them chiney eyes, false teeth and puffy cheeks, some critics called it a racist caricature of Asians - "yellow face".
They wondered whether these repeated controversies pointed to a larger problem that the company has with diversity.
The news and outrage were widespread on Wednesday, with reports from The Verge and Motherboard, one day after Snapchat announced it had disabled the feature.
The company offered an excuse: The filter was intended as a tribute to anime characters and not as a caricature of Asians.
But to outsiders who have experienced racism, the filter reminded them of hurtful clichés.
Others firmly rejected the anime comparison.
In an e-mail, Grace Sparapani, a Korean-American art student whose tweets about the photos were widely circulated, wrote that the filter was "hurtful and unpleasant to say the least.
She added that "it is difficult to argue with the juxtaposition of a very repulsive Asian caricature and the filter effects.
It shows that the filter is not yellow-faced, but that the yellow face has been pulled to the pejorative extreme.
Snapchat is not the only company that crosses these cultural stumbling blocks.
American culture seems to be engaged in an endless struggle for diversity and integration, from conference rooms to Hollywood and the devices we all hold in our hands.
And Snapchat's large audience of young people - who are more diverse in race than their older counterparts - might be more likely to expect sensitivity.
If one of Snapchat's filters produces an image that is offensive to a user, "it's much harder for such things to go unnoticed than it used to be," said 25-year-old Katie Zhu in an interview on Thursday.
On Thursday, Zhu, who works as a product manager and engineer for Medium, decided to delete her Snapchat account and asked others to do the same.
In an essay for Medium and in a telephone interview, she said she believed that racial controversy reflected a lack of diversity in Snapchat's hiring practices.
Zhu criticized the largely white, all-male leadership and ended her essay with a hashtag: #DeleteSnapchat.
"Either they don't have a diverse representation of people with other skin colors in their workforce so they can make such decisions," said the Chinese-American Zhu, "or they have people with other skin colors working there but not in positions where they feel safe or comfortable to say anything against it.
Others share their opinion, a complaint that Snapchat has left largely unanswered.
The company does not publish figures on the diversity of its workforce and draws attention to its status as a private company.
On Thursday, Snapchat refused to discuss the cultural backgrounds of its employees, but according to a spokesperson, the company recently hired a human resources manager to focus on underrepresented groups and internal integration efforts.
For her part, Zhu said that she will keep her Snapchat account closed and added, "I wonder if they need more users like us to be able to say that this is not ok."
Military leadership falsifies ISIS intelligence information, congressional committee notes
Military members of the United States Central Command altered intelligence information to paint a more optimistic picture of the war against the so-called Islamic state in Iraq and Syria than the actual conditions on the ground would have allowed, a Congressional investigative committee reported in a report on Thursday.
The preliminary report, prepared by a task force of Republican members of the Armed Services Committee, Intelligence Committee, and Defense Budget Committee, reports great dissatisfaction among Central Command intelligence analysts who reported how superiors changed their assessments of American efforts in the fight against the Islamic state.
Central Command, or Cencom for short, is the military headquarters in Tampa, Florida, which controls American military operations in the Middle East and Central Asia.
"Intelligence information, typically nodded off by high-ranking Centcom commanders, regularly painted a more positive picture of American efforts against terrorism than actual conditions on the ground would have allowed, and was consistently more positive than analyses by other intelligence agencies," one newspaper article quoted the report as saying.
"What happened at the Centcom is unacceptable - our soldiers suffer when poor analysis is presented to our political leaders," noted Ken Calvert, Republican member of the House of Representatives.
The management mistakes in Centcom extend to the very top of the organization.
The ten-page report details persistent problems in 2014 and 2015 in the descriptions and analyses of American efforts in training Iraqi forces.
Although it provides no direct evidence that Obama's top officials have given instructions to change the reports, it does show how analysts have been under pressure from their superiors to paint a more optimistic picture of the threat to the Islamic state, also known as ISIS or ISIL.
"During the first half of 2015, many Central Command press releases, statements and testimonies before Congress were significantly more positive than they actually were," the report stated.
For example, a Centcom member publicly announced that a military reconquest of Mossul could begin as early as April or May 2015.
Mossul, Iraq's second largest city, remains under the control of the Islamic state.
"After months of investigation, it's clear this much," Mike Pompeo, Republican congressman from Kansas, said in a statement.
From mid-2014 to mid-2015, the tops of Central Command altered intelligence reports to downplay the threat posed by ISIS in Iraq.
The Republicans set up the task force after it was leaked to them that analysts were concerned about the manipulation of reports on the Islamic state.
The report released on Thursday will be completed by more detailed findings as the investigation continues.
In addition, further investigations of Centcom reports by the Inspector General of the Ministry of Defence are underway.
Democratic members of the Intelligence Committee released their own findings on Thursday that were consistent with some of the conclusions of the Republican Task Force.
"In 2014 and 2015, Centcom created an excessively restricted process for the preparation of intelligence assessments of ISIL and the Iraqi security services," the senior Democrat on the Committee, House of Representatives member Adam B. Schiff, announced in a statement.
This process, according to Mr Schiff, "delayed the publication of intelligence reports", damaged morale among analysts and "left unduly little room for dissent.
But Mr. Schiff and the Democrats stated that they found no evidence of White House intervention in the Centcom analysts regarding a "particular political opinion.
The preliminary results of the congressional investigation were published on Tuesday by "The Daily Beast".
Last August, the New York Times reported on investigations by the Inspector General of the Pentagon, which were taken up following complaints by Centcom analysts.
Lt. Cmdr. Patrick Evans, a Pentagon press secretary, stated in a statement that the Department of Defense would not comment on any congressional reports while the Inspector General's investigation was still underway.
But he also stated that "experts sometimes have quite divergent opinions on the interpretation of complex data, and that the intelligence services and the Ministry of Defence welcome a controversial discussion of these important national defence issues.
The investigations have repercussions beyond the question of a successful American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria (an assertion that is now being made by a growing number of members of the Ministry of Defence).
However, last year's accusations have raised the question of the extent to which President Obama can rely on Central Command for honest assessments of military operations in Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya and other crisis regions.
The criticism regarding the classified information about the Islamic State recalls disputes from more than ten years ago, when a Centcom analyst, Gregory Hooker, wrote a paper about how the then government under George W. Bush, contrary to the recommendations of many analysts, planned only a small occupation force in Iraq and spent little time thinking about the consequences of the 2003 invasion.
Mr. Hooker also played a key role in the uprising against the current coverage of the Islamic State.
Last year, Mr. Hooker's team, according to government officials, stated that, contrary to what the government said, air strikes against Islamic state-owned refineries would not have a significant impact on the terrorist group's financial situation, as they had started up temporary refineries to sell oil on the black market.
However, this finding was not published, the Times reported in September.
Centcom's former commander, Gen. Lloyd J. Austin III, was criticized by members of the legislature for his excessively positive assessment of the war situation at a hearing before the Senate.
General Austin retired in April and was replaced at Central Command by Gen. Joseph L. Votel.

She's on a roll.
