In the midst of the rage of the Olympic Games, the Zen of the trampoline
Wherever you are, however late it is, it is the Olympic Games.
The events in Rio de Janeiro feel constant and inevitable, a frenzied relay race between competition and aspiration.
It is as if the Olympic torch itself were a burning staff, which is passed from crossbowman to swimmer to gymnast to triathlete.
You can't turn on the TV, read a newspaper or listen to your neighbor's conversation in the coffee shop queue without hearing about Simone Biles, Katie Ledecky or the fight between Michael Phelps and Chad le Clos.
And then there's Logan Dooley.
Dooley, a first-time Olympic gold medalist and a dimpled women's man, could well have been one of those famous names that are broadcast in prime time, built up by sponsors and feel-good TV commercials, if he were a swimmer, gymnast or even fencer.
But Dooley, 28, from Lake Forest, California, is fighting for gold in Olympic trampolining.
The Olympic flame does not illuminate every event in the same way.
Further from the centre, partly in the shade, there are sports that are not generally recognized: Air pistol shooting, archery, badminton, taekwondo.
We will always have the breaststroke and may it reign for a long time.
But if I may modestly make arguments for my particular favourite, let me draw attention to the discreet charm of the trampoline.
Although trampolining has been an Olympic event since 2000, when it debuted in Sydney, it has been so little noticed for the last 16 years that many of those I interviewed did not know it was an Olympic sport at all.
This could also be regional ignorance.
Although the USA sent athletes to compete, it has never won a medal in trampoline jumping and by 2012 had one athlete who made it to the final round.
The Chinese and the Russians tend to share prices for the men and the Chinese and the Canadians share prices for the women.
Dong Dong from China and Rosie MacLennan from Canada will defend their gold medal from London this year.
Trampoline jumping has a certain outsider charm, partly because it sounds more appropriate for the unenlightened ear for a clown school than the one for the Olympic Games.
At this point I should admit that I am not an expert, but only an earthbound enthusiast.
It has humorous potential - the cartoon-like tremor of its never-ending impact - but also the grace of gymnastics and diving, the two sports it essentially combines.
The word "trampoline" comes from the Spanish el trampoline, which means "springboard."
Aspiring winners jump on a giant trampoline, shoot almost 30 feet into the air and have to perform a series of falling movements (spins, pikes and somersaults) before landing on their feet.
According to the official Olympic programme, they will be judged according to execution, degree of difficulty and "flight time".
Thirty-two athletes from 17 countries, 16 men and 16 women, will compete in Rio.
The most common Olympic vector is straight ahead.
Medal hopefuls have to go further, faster, up and over in their quest for gold, sometimes to the finish, sometimes back and forth, up and down the playground.
They are not only chasing the finish line or the starting wall, but in the television broadcast another derisive target: that of the world or the Olympic record.
The purposeful striving is noble, admirable, even fanatical - and it is enough to move even a spectator to tears.
But it's also what I find a bit tiring even watching these games.
The trampoline offers a breathing space from this.
The trampoline jumper's vector is up.
Forward movement is not the goal.
He or she bounces, seemingly weightless like an astronaut, goes up, then down, then effortlessly back up again.
Here too there is competition, not without difficulty of course, but during the exercise there is no frantic attack on the target, no arching into the distance, only the dreamy, elegant suspension of time and gravity.
It is as Zen as competition at the Olympic Games can be.
The women's qualifying and final rounds will take place on Friday afternoon, streaming at 13.00 Eastern Time; the men's on Saturday, also at 13.00.
NBC will broadcast the final rounds as part of an afternoon block on both days from 14.00.
In the midst of the Olympic mania, they promise a quiet, nice moment, one that is likely to be overlooked in the general turmoil.
If raising awareness can only be achieved by gawking at and objectifying male athletes - as the male US gymnasts recently suggested, according to The Wall Street Journal - then Mr. Dooley has a new fan base gasping for breath.
"A generation protests" in Ethiopia, Long an ally of the USA
Violent protests in Ethiopia
Demonstrators demanding political changes in Ethiopia met with violent resistance from the government.
Witnesses testify that tens of protesters were killed in shootings during clashes with police.
Is Ethiopia about to collapse?
Over the last decade it has been one of the most stable countries in Africa, a solid ally of the West with a rapidly growing economy.
But in recent months, protests against the government have shaken the country and spread to more and more areas.
Last week thousands of people stormed the streets and demanded fundamental political changes.
According to human rights organisations, the government's response was ruthless.
Witnesses stated that police officers shot and killed tens of unarmed protesters.
Circulating videos of the protests, probably from last year or earlier this year, show security guards beating young people with sticks while forcing them to do a handstand against a wall.
The head of the UN authority for human rights now demands a thorough investigation.
"It has always been difficult to keep this country together, and it will be even more difficult in the future," said Rashid Abdi, the Horn of Africa project manager for the International Crisis Group, a research group.
Ethiopia is the most populous country in Africa after Nigeria and its stability is appreciated by the West.
American military and intelligence agencies are working closely with Ethiopians to combat terrorist threats beyond the region, particularly in Somalia. Few, if any, countries in Africa receive so much Western aid.
Ethiopia's economy expanded at a remarkable pace.
Its infrastructure has improved dramatically - there is a new commuter train in the capital Addis Ababa.
The streets are generally quiet, safe and clean.
Although Ethiopia has been anything but a model of democracy - human rights organisations have consistently led the government's repression - the country's opposition has been curtailed, with dissidents effectively silenced.
Many were sent into exile or prison, killed or driven into the vastness of the desert.
But that could change.
"When you oppress people and they have no other options but to protest, it breaks out," said Seyoum Teshome, a lecturer in central Ethiopia.
The whole youth protests.
A generation protests.
There are numerous complaints covering everything from land use to stranglehold on the power of the ruling coalition.
After a widely criticised election last year, the ruling party and its allies were given the last seat of the opposition and now control 100 per cent of parliament.
At the same time, tensions are rising along the border with Eritrea; a fight over this jagged, controversial line claimed hundreds of lives in June.
Analysts fear that separatists such as the Oromo Liberation Front or the Ogaden National Liberation Front, which have been more or less defeated in recent years, could take advantage of the turbulence and rearm themselves.
Several factors explain why feelings of bitterness after years of simmering under the surface now explode.
The first seems harmless: smartphones.
Only in recent years have a large number of Ethiopians been able to communicate using social media, as cheaper smartphones have become more common and Internet services have improved.
Even if the government blocks access to Facebook and Twitter, which it does on a regular basis, especially during protests, many people can still communicate via Internet proxies that hide where they are.
Several young Ethiopians stated that this was how they gathered for protests.
The second factor is that there is more solidarity between the Oromos and Amharas, the two largest ethnic groups in Ethiopia.
The Oromos and Amharas are not natural enemies.
For eons the Amharas, who come from Ethiopia's predominantly Christian highlands, have prospered in politics and economics while exploiting the Oromos, many of whom are Muslims and live in lowland areas.
But that is also changing.
"We are coordinating under one umbrella," said Mulatu Gemechu, a leader of the Oromos.
The largest protests took place in areas of the Amhara and Oromos.
Many Amharas and Oromos feel that Ethiopia is unfairly dominated by members of the Tigray ethnic group, which makes up about 6 percent of the population and is dominant in the military, intelligence, trade and politics.
The third reason for the unrest is the death of Meles Zenawi.
Mr. Meles, a former rebel leader, was Ethiopia's prime minister for 17 years until his death from an undisclosed disease in 2012.
He was considered a tactical genius, a man who could think around corners.
Analysts say he was particularly adept at detecting early signs of dissatisfaction and using special representatives to work opponents and neutralize them.
"The current regime lacks this basic skill," said Mr Abdi, a conflict analyst.
Ethiopia's new Prime Minister, Hailemariam Desalegn, was chosen to take over from Mr Meles for relatively obscure reasons.
Unlike Mr Meles, who came from the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, Mr Hailemariam came from the south.
Analysts say he does not enjoy the trust of the security services controlled by the Tigray.
Many fear that the result will be more bloodshed.
The last time Ethiopia experienced such an uproar was in 2005, after thousands protested against elections that analysts said were apparently botched by the government and then stolen.
During the raids that followed, many protesters were killed, although fewer than in recent months, and this period of unrest passed relatively quickly.
Development experts praised Ethiopia's leaders for their visionary infrastructure planning, such as the new commuter train, and for their measurable progress in poverty reduction.
But apparently this has not prevented the Ethiopian government's internal resentment from intensifying.
And it takes on a dangerous ethnic form.
Last month, protesters in Gondar, an Amharic city, attacked Tigray-run businesses, and hatred of the Tigray is growing in the social media.
Analysts say that the protests put the US and other Western allies in a strange position.
The American government used Ethiopia as a base for drone flights over neighbouring Somalia, although it recently announced that it was closing this base.
While the West clearly wants to support democracy, it does not want its ally to collapse in an already volatile area.
"This," said Mr Abdi, "is a very thin line."
Donald Trump explains his claim that Obama had founded ISIS was "sarcasm
Donald J. Trump tried on Friday to dispel the last controversy surrounding his campaign by stating that his repeated claim that President Obama and Hillary Clinton were the "founders" of the terrorist group Islamic State was not meant seriously.
This clarification raised new questions about the communication skills of the Republican presidential candidate, whether he was able to communicate clearly and intelligibly with the American public.

After making the implication at a Wednesday night campaign rally, Mr. Trump backpedaled on Thursday's assertion and insisted in interviews that he really did not intend to imply that the President and Mrs. Clinton created ISIS.
But in an early morning tweet on Friday, Mr. Trump said he was just being sarcastic.
The tweet was in contrast to the previous day, when Mr. Trump said in a series of interviews that he meant the accusation completely seriously.
When conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt tried to help Mr. Trump soften the message by reminding him that Mr. Obama wanted to destroy ISIS, the Republican presidential candidate didn't want to know.

Reporting on Twitter, he warned that Mrs. Clinton's proposals would lead to higher taxes and that he found her speech boring.
Mr. Trump has already used sarcasm in his defense.
At the end of July, he attracted strong criticism when he thought the Russians should hack Mrs. Clinton's emails, but later he declared "Of course I meant it sarcastically".
This method allows Mr. Trump to shift the language barrier in politics and then row back as needed.
"I think it's one of his methods to test how certain messages are received by his fans, how they are received, and then, if necessary, "clarify" depending on the reaction. " said Ruth Sherman, a communications expert who observes the language of both candidates.
But I also think he is clever enough to keep his statements vague enough so that they can be interpreted in different ways.
Instead of defusing the tone for the presidential election, Mr. Trump has taken on an even more corrosive tone as his poll numbers have continued to decline.
A new poll by NBC/Wall Street Journal/Marist, published Friday, showed a lead by a wide margin in the states of North Carolina, Virginia, Colorado and a neck-and-neck race in Florida.
While Mr. Trump generally tries not to apologize for his provocative remarks, he often accuses his critics of distorting his statements or misinterpreting his humor.
But while he has been the focus of increased attention in the final months of his presidential campaign, Mr. Trump's jokes have put his loyal supporters in the uncomfortable position of having to stand by him no matter how provocative his statements may be.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, former mayor of New York and one of Trump's most prominent advocates, took great pains to defend the candidate today in a CNN interview on Thursday.
"I think what he is saying is legitimate political commentary" said Mr. Giuliani when asked about the accuracy of Mr. Trump's statements about whether Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton founded the Islamic State.
It is true in this sense that before Obama ISIS was an almost unknown, small organization, he called them backbenchers, completely wrong and that is why it happened, because he withdrew the troops from Iraq.
Most mainstream Republicans try to argue that the Obama administration, in which Mrs. Clinton served as Secretary of State, allowed ISIS to expand by failing to aggressively control the situation in the Middle East.
Before the Pennsylvania campaign rallies on Friday, Mr. Trump continued his attacks on the media, accusing them of harping on every word he said and of being biased against him.
He mocked the "poor, pathetic" television experts who try to understand him and said, "You can't!
Some of the Democrats mocked Mr. Trump's apology as just another proof that he was unfit for president.
Once driven out of the market by price, Café in Greenpoint is coming back
Verb Cafe was a seedy café in Williamsburg where you could only pay cash, which had no Wi-Fi but served good coffee for 15 years.
Of course, the prices pushed prices out of his Bedford Avenue store front.
The shop Soap Cherie, which Verb replaced in summer 2014, sells soap in the form of cupcakes.
Locals mourned it as the last loss in a gentrifying city.
Artist Molly Crabapple wrote on Twitter, "I know New York is change, but I still can't believe CBGB is dead, the Chelsea Hotel is cleaned out, and Verb is now a soap shop."
But if New York is change, then it's reinvention.
A revitalized Verb Cafe opened last November in Greenpoint, less than a mile north of its original location.
The new verb has Wi-Fi and accepts credit cards, but still has some of the same staff and a similarly simple atmosphere.
The coffee's still good too.
The new owner of the verb is Cisco Rodriguez, a long-time employee of the old café, who is the owner and manager of the new café.
He started working at Verb in 2001 and stayed there until the end.
When a client offered to provide funds for a new field office, he was excited to do it, he said.
Rodriguez, 36, retained many things.
Verb used the same distributor for the bagels bought the same espresso machine model .
It even uses the same lamps from the old verb.
But Rodriguez said he wanted to experiment too.
He introduced new ingredients.
On the menu are sandwiches with bacon and cheese and there are garnishes such as capers and sautéed onions.
There are natural rice bowls.
The café no longer serves beer, but fresh juices are available.
After nine months, Rodriguez said he had noticed a steady stream of old regulars.
"Many old customers were also driven out of Williamsburg by prices," he said.
Rebecca Oliveira was one such customer recently on a Sunday.
Oliveira, 34, used to live in Williamsburg and visited the verb regularly.
Even after she moved to Greenpoint, she would take the road.
After the verb had closed, she gave up drinking coffee for a while, she said.
"I realized it was the coffee and the culture in the verb I liked," she said.
Now she drinks coffee again, even though that day she ordered a blended chai tea instead of her usual iced coffee, which is another new addition.
Tom Rosenthal has been another longstanding and loyal customer since the beginning of Verb in 2003.
He went there before work and inevitably always ordered the same thing.
"I came a quarter past seven, every day, like a Swiss watch, and they prepare my everything bagel with butter," he said.
Photo Rodriguez said he wanted to experiment and add new ingredients to the menu.
Nowadays Rosenthal still gets his usual order, but sometimes he alternates his Everything-Bagel with bacon, egg and cheese.
Rodriguez said that he had no grudge about the soap business taking over the old premises.
In fact, the owners of the soap cherie offered to make a special soap for verb with the café's cold-brewed coffee as an ingredient.
"I think we'll take you up on your offer," Rodriguez said.
And the traditional Polish inhabitants of Greenpoint have also accepted the café.
A new client has translated the menu into Polish and Rodriguez said he plans to display it soon so that his new neighbours feel welcome.
The location also has other advantages.
A local juice shop wants to bottle and sell the cold brewed coffee.
There's a chance the café could expand to a neighboring building.
For many customers a new verb is enough to get their old favorites.
Joseph Witt was a regular customer and said he was devastated when the café closed.
When the new cafe opened, Whitt said that entering the place and ordering a new coffee felt like coming home.
"I had to smell that," he said.
The depressing food of the economic crisis in "an abundant meal
In March 1933, shortly after his rise to the presidency, Franklin Delano Roosevelt took his lunch in the Oval Office.
As a gourmet, President Roosevelt had a penchant for sophisticated Fifth Avenue delicacies like pâte de foie gras and Maryland turtle soup.
His menu that day was a little more modest: stuffed eggs in tomato sauce, mashed potatoes and for dessert a plum pudding.
"It was an act of culinary solidarity with suffering people," said Jane Ziegelman.
Her husband Andrew Coe added, "It was also a message to Americans about how they should eat."
The couple lives in Brooklyn Heights and are both food historians.
Coe's last book "Chop Suey" was about Chinese cuisine in the USA, while Ziegelman's book "97 Orchard" tells about life in a house on the Lower East Side from a food perspective.
Their latest collaboration, "A Decent Meal", which will be published on Tuesday by Harper Verlag, illustrates the history of American cuisine during the Great Depression.
They showed culinary solidarity when they met a reporter for dinner at Eisenberg's Sandwich Shop, a small, no-frills snack in the Flatiron District that has been in business since the 1929 stock market crash.
Ziegelman, 54, ordered a cream cheese sandwich with pieces of olive, while Coe, 57, ate turkey with mashed potatoes and mixed vegetables.
When the reporter ordered meatloaf, the couple found it appropriate for a discussion about food in the era of the Great Depression.
"Rich foods were very popular," said Ziegelman.
There was peanut bread, meat loaf and bean bread.
They were prepared from an ingredient and something cheap that stretches the ingredient.
Imagine eating so many peanuts that they serve them as dinner.
Coe grinned.
"It must have settled in the stomach like lead," he said.
In the years before the Great Depression, the table in an American household, especially in rural areas, was an all-you-can-eat buffet.
Teams of women cooked for male field workers and freshly baked pâté was served for breakfast, lunch and dinner.
It was the Americans who sent food to starving Europeans during the First World War. "A Square Meal" records the ways in which the country dealt with the fact that it was no longer a land of milk and honey.
"It was a time when food became a central, tense topic for Americans," Coe explained why he and his wife wanted to write about it.
The new budget diet was just as tense: mysterious dishes such as bread and casseroles became staple foods, and the casserole was seen as a "wonderful way to recycle leftovers," Ziegelman noted, as cooks could hide unappetizing ingredients under a creamy sauce.
Fresh fruit was replaced by cheaper dried fruit.
Meat, which for years was the focal point of American cuisine, became a rarely served luxury.
Peculiar mixtures were tried out, as a high-calorie and nutritious satisfaction took precedence over taste or even common sense.
During her research for the book, which also includes recipes, Ziegelman prepared a dish from this era, baked onions with peanut butter.
"It wasn't a popular lunchtime addition," Coe says.
Ziegelmann continues, "It was surreal."
Peanut butter and baked onions do not go together.
It was typical for many of the home economics recipes.
As never before or since then, household economists - including Louise Stanley, head of the Federal Bureau of Home Economics from 1923 to 1943 - have driven the country's eating habits to such heights.
By publishing recipes and articles in newspapers and magazines, they encouraged women to become "household politicians" and to meet the challenge of transforming slop like creamy spaghetti with carrots into delicious meals.
"A Square Meal" is a celebration of historical tidbits.
Especially tasty are the reports about the government's response to the starving citizens, such as President Herbert Hoover's last-me-cake-eating attitude.
While publicly praising the simple Iowa farmhouse kitchen of his kitchen, he dined like the millionaire man of the world he has become.
"He liked continental food like fish with cucumber sauce," Coe said.
He ate in an almost gilded dining room and wore a dinner jacket.
He was deliciously unrealistic.
President Roosevelt might have made the same mistake if his wife Eleanor had not asked him to make an example with his stomach.
As described in the book, the hiring of a housekeeper with no interest in flavors by Mrs. Roosevelt resulted in the White House producing not only the most boring food in Washington, but also one of the dreariest prepared."
Many of the ways of dealing with food from the Great Depression era were discarded as soon as the country was back on its feet.
The legacy lies in our continued focus on calories and food, Ziegelman said, and how science has been applied to food.
When writing the book, the couple claimed to have better understood Ziegelman's mother-in-law's eating habits - for example, how she could not throw away food.
"She had a real fear of wasting food," Coe said.
Ziegelman remembered, "She actually made people sick."
There was the cream puff incident.
After clearing the plates at Eisenberg's, she and Coe pulled out a dessert they had prepared at home: the plum dessert that President Roosevelt had for lunch.
"It's called the Prune Whip," Ziegelman said, adding that it was a common trick to give modest recipes a fancy name.
There was no whipped cream, only plums, some flour, sugar, water and cinnamon.
Everyone dipped a spoon into the tough, brown goo a little reluctantly.
Surprisingly, it didn't taste that bad.
Coe got seconds three times.
Like a can-do budget man, he told his wife, "A few chopped walnuts would help."
Killed in a bombing raid: He was the hero of Aleppo
He risked his own life to help others: Khaled Omar.
He was the hero of Aleppo: Khaled Omar dedicated his life to the people of Syria.
He risked everything to save others' lives.
Now the 30-year-old himself has died in a barrel bomb attack by the Assad regime.

They are the heroes of the war in Syria.

It made the Syrian a shining symbol in the horror of war.
But he never saw himself as a hero, said according to the picture: "For me this is the real Jihad."
"If I die saving lives, I think God sees me as a martyr."

Greenland shark: The oldest vertebrate is almost 400 years old
Rare sight.
Greenland sharks usually only come to the surface in winter.
This shark was allowed back into the sea after an examination on board the research vessel Sanna.
He was born in 1624 and swims through the North Atlantic at just over 1 km/h - until today.
Greenland sharks do not get offspring until they are 150 years old.
The Greenland shark swims leisurely along the bottom of the North Atlantic, in one hour it reaches an average of 1,220 metres.
Only when it really counts does the five-meter-long animal accelerate to a whopping 2.6 km/h - and at this top speed it is half as fast as a seal.
However, this lifestyle characterised by slowness seems to be a patent remedy for old age.
Julius Nielsen from the University of Copenhagen and his colleagues report in the journal "Science" at any rate about a Greenland shark that could be 392 years old.
"Madness", comments Alexander Scheuerlein of the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research in Rostock on this life span, which is a world record for vertebrates.
Although the evolutionary biologist has long suspected that Greenland sharks are becoming stone-age, he has not been able to prove it.
Only there was no evidence.
Greenland sharks are difficult to observe, after all they live mainly in the Arctic Ocean off the sparsely populated coasts of Canada, Greenland, Norway and Svalbard.
Because they prefer water temperatures around six degrees Celsius, they usually only appear on the surface in winter.
Researchers know correspondingly little about the lifestyle of Greenland sharks.
They measured their slow-motion speed when they equipped six animals with a transmitter outside Svalbard.
Nevertheless, these sharks still make prey: researchers found the remains of a seal in the stomach of one animal, another had swallowed the jawbone of a young polar bear.
They may hunt sleeping animals or patrol the bottom of the Arctic Ocean looking for carcasses staggering down from higher water layers.
Julius Nielsen and his colleagues have now examined 28 Greenland sharks that fishermen took as by-catch from the depths of the North Atlantic between 2010 and 2013 off Greenland or Spitsbergen.
The smallest shark was just 81 centimetres long, while the largest measured 502 centimetres.
To determine the age of the animals, they analyzed the sharks' lens core using the carbon-14 method.
This center of the eye lens is formed before the sharks are born, the proteins contained in it are not renewed later.
The two smallest sharks had a striking amount of carbon-14 in their lens core.
Their birth was therefore supposed to be after the early 1960s, when nuclear weapon tests threw large quantities of this radioactive carbon into the atmosphere.
In contrast, the lens nucleus of the third-smallest animal at 220 centimetres in length contained a small surplus of carbon-14 from the nuclear weapon tests, so it is likely to have celebrated its 50th birthday when it was examined in 2012.
All larger Greenland sharks, on the other hand, had normal amounts of carbon-14 in their lens core, which is produced by cosmic radiation in the atmosphere.
In fact, the carbon-14 clock showed an age of 335 years for a 493 centimeter long Greenland shark, while the record shark with 502 centimeters might even be 392 years old.
It was known that female Greenland sharks only have offspring when they are longer than four metres.
Now the researchers were able to assign an age to the length.
Since one of the animals was probably on the threshold of sexual maturity at 392 centimetres and its age was determined at 156 years, Greenland sharks obviously take at least a century and a half to reproduce.
This, too, should be a world record for vertebrates at the moment.
That such Methuselahs live above all in icy waters is no coincidence.
The previous record holder, a 211-year-old bowhead whale with a 120-year-old harpoon tip stuck into the bacon on its neck, was also caught off Alaska.
Due to the low temperatures, the organisms of the animals living there often run on a low flame.
So they mature later - and age more slowly.
In order to keep warm in cold water, the animals also often become particularly large.
This is because the volume grows much faster than its surface, through which the animal loses heat.
The heat loss of one gram of mouse is therefore much greater than that of one gram of elephant.
Another advantage: You have fewer enemies.
"A smaller animal therefore lives more dangerously and should concentrate on having as many offspring as possible as early as possible," explains evolutionary biologist Scheuerlein.
A very large animal on the other hand should rather invest its resources in a long life.

Frankfurt profits from brexite
The city on the Main therefore has the best chances of attracting jobs and companies relocated from London in competition with Paris, Dublin and Luxembourg.
"It is very likely that Frankfurt will benefit most from the brexit vote," says Michael Voigtländer, head of the IW's Financial Markets and Real Estate Markets competence area.
Following the brexite referendum, it is uncertain whether financial institutions will be allowed to continue to conduct financial transactions throughout the EU from London.
For the so-called EU passport, they have so far only needed a licence in Great Britain.
Large US banks are currently taking advantage of this.
Several banks have already announced that they will relocate jobs.
The lobby association "Frankfurt Main Finance" expects 10,000 new jobs to be created on the Main within five years.
According to the IW, Frankfurt is home to the European Central Bank (ECB), which combines responsibility for monetary policy and supervision of the largest banks in the eurozone, as well as other important authorities such as the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) and the Risk Council (ESRB).
Although the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has its headquarters in Paris, it is less important for the financial sector than the ECB.
"Proximity to the central bank is important for banks because it allows them to communicate directly with the supervisory authority," says IW Professor Voigtländer.
Luxembourg is home to a large fund industry, but, like Dublin, it has a poorer infrastructure.
Frankfurt is much easier to reach thanks to the large airport.
The city also scores with easily available commercial real estate.
"In Paris it is not at all easy to find free high-quality offices", says Voigtländer.
In addition, rents for first-class commercial properties on the Seine are 50 percent higher than on the Main.
In addition, Frankfurt offers a higher quality of life than the competition thanks to good medical care and infrastructure and less crime.
In a ranking by the management consultancy Mercer, the city is ranked seventh, Luxembourg 19th, Dublin 33rd and Paris 37th.
Even if quality of life is a question of preferences: "With its already strong position as a financial location for the European internal market, Frankfurt could attract more banks and investors," the IW concludes.
Despite the brexite vote, London will remain the most important financial centre in Europe, the economic researchers believe.
The balance of power also speaks for this: According to figures from Landesbank Helaba, around 144,000 people were working in the banking sector in London at the end of 2015, compared with 6,2500 in Frankfurt.

A U.S. District Court Judge ruled that Gilead Sciences Inc is entitled to reimbursement of legal costs incurred by it in the Hepatits C litigation with the pharmaceutical company Merck & Co Inc.
In June, Gilead was released from a $200 million payment of damages for infringement of two Merck patents related to Gilead's blockbuster drugs Sovaldi and Harvoni after a U.S. judge found a pattern of misconduct by Merck, including perjury and other unethical acts.

Hillary Clinton released her 2015 tax return on Friday, which showed the Democratic presidential candidate and her husband earned USD 10.75 million and an effective federal tax rate of 34.2%.
In 2015, the Clintons donated USD 1 million to charity, mainly to the Clinton Foundation; former President Bill Clinton earned nearly USD 5.3 million in speech fees; the former Secretary of State declared a USD 3 million income from the publisher Simon & Schuster for her book about her tenure in the State Department.
Clinton's vice presidential candidate, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, along with his wife Anne Holton, publishes his tax returns for the past ten years.

"Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine continue to set standards for financial transparency," Clinton campaigner Jennifer Palmieri announced in a statement.
In stark contrast, Donald Trump hides behind false excuses and backdrops on his promises to publish his tax returns.
It is common for US presidential candidates to file their tax returns, although they are not required to do so by law.
Trump, a New York businessman, and his attorneys have cited a tax audit by the tax authorities as the reason for his refusal.
"It's your move," Clinton's campaign aide Ian Sams wrote on Twitter, in reference to the release of the Democratic presidential candidate.

Federal taxes have become an issue in the election campaign.
Clinton supports a scheme named after billionaire and investor Warren Buffett, which would ensure that people who earn more than USD 1 million pay a tax rate of at least 30%.
President Obama also supports the proposal.
During a campaign rally for Hillary Clinton last week in Omaha, Nebraska, Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway industrial conglomerate is based here, called on Trump to meet to exchange her tax returns.
Buffett said he had also been subject to an IRS tax audit and Trump was "afraid" of the voters and not the tax authorities.
Clinton's campaign has published tax returns dating back to 2007.
The Clintons now living in Chappaqua, New York, paid an average effective federal tax rate of approximately 32% between 2007 and 2014 and an effective combined tax rate of approximately 40.5%.
The Clintons' 2015 tax return showed that they received only USD 100 of their income as wages, unlike most Americans.
Their main investment was a low-cost index fund, from which the Clintons taxed dividends and income of USD 109,000.

Condoms with chili powder, fireworks promote Tanzania's elephant protection
Conservationists in Tanzania are using an unorthodox way to stop elephants from entering human settlements - they throw condoms filled with chili powder at them.
The method has proven to be effective and the Honeyguide Foundation, which had the idea years ago, together with the US Conservation Society has intensified its support by training volunteers in villages in northern Tanzania to use a non-violent four-step method to protect their homes and crops without harming animals.
Before, many have used spears to defend themselves.
Friday is World Elephant Day, which is dedicated to animal welfare.
"Since we started this... Toolkit, we have seen a change in attitude within these communities, who are much more confident that they can keep the elephants from their fields without harming the elephants," said Damian Bell, CEO of Honeyguide, in a statement.
The first two steps include lighting the elephant with a torch and blowing into a horn.
If he is not deterred, a so-called "chili cloud" is thrown.
Chilli powder mixed with earth is packed together with a firecracker in a condom, the end of which is twisted up to the fuse.
When lit, the condom bursts open with a bang and sprays fine dust of chili powder into the air.
A breath quite usually already out to chase the elephant away.
A last possibility is a thrower who shoots a golden rain firework into the air, causing a loud, bright explosion.

Haigerloch: Pilgrims to the Gate of Mercy
The altar boys from the pastoral care unit Eyachtal-Haigerloch St. Anna were on a four-day pilgrimage from Villingen to Freiburg.
Together they mastered four stages.
In order to bridge the time until the next Rome pilgrimage of all altar servers in probably two years, the St. Anna senior altar server decided to prepare and carry out a pilgrimage of several days.
Various pilgrimage destinations were examined and finally the bishop's city of Freiburg was chosen, where this year, on the occasion of the Holy Year of Mercy, a special pilgrimage destination was offered with the Gate of Mercy at Freiburg Cathedral, which was opened for this purpose.
16 Minis from Bittelbronn, Gruol, Haigerloch and Heiligenzimmern set off.
The evening before Father Storost sent the pilgrims out in a small celebration in St. Anna, blessed the pilgrim crosses and gave the pilgrim blessing.
From Horb, the train took them to the starting point in Villingen, where there is also a cathedral of Our Lady, and so the pilgrimage from the cathedral began.
The individual day tours were framed in the morning and evening by a short impulse with different prayers, songs and written texts.
But also on the way the minis stopped at field crosses, chapels or churches to sing a song from a specially compiled pilgrim songbook.
For the overnight stays, parsonages of the local parishes were available.
At the stage finishes Alexandra Burkhardt and Heidi Faller provided for a tasty as well as fortifying dinner and breakfast.
On the second day we continued via Furtwangen to Gütenbach.
The next day we started the stage to St. Peter, which was the most strenuous part of the journey, as we had to descend about 500 metres in the muggy heat and then climb it again.
The well-deserved reward was a barbecue together at the Badweiher in the evening.
After the morning impulse on the fourth pilgrimage day in the imposing monastery church of St. Peter, the final stage of the journey to Freiburg began.
Visibly relieved and happy, the minis arrived at the Freiburg Cathedral in the late afternoon and passed through the Gate of Mercy.
With a small impulse, thanks was given to God here.
In the evening mass in the cathedral the minis arrived at the pilgrims' destination were welcomed by co-operator Markus Obert.
After the service the pilgrims could visit the sacristy and the high altar.
The next day there was still time for the Breisgaum metropolis.
In the afternoon we went back to Horb by train.
In the end all participants agreed that the days were marked by spirituality and a strong community experience.

Future of Portland smelter questionable due to cancellation of the energy contract
The future of the Portland aluminium smelter in Victoria - as well as hundreds of workers' jobs - is at stake as the plant operator will terminate the energy supply contract, thereby cancelling all supply contracts, according to the supplying energy company.
This step followed the decision of the government in Victoria earlier this year not to grant any further subsidies for the operation of the plant.
A subsidy fixed for 20 years expires in November.
Up to 2000 jobs at Alcoa's Portland plant are at stake.
No fewer than 2000 jobs - direct as well as indirect - could be at risk in the event of closure.
There could also be domino effects, as the smelter consumes around 10 percent of Victoria's total electricity production.
In 2014 Alcoa closed the Point Henry smelter, which led to the closure of the Anglesea power plant last year.
Alcoa's smelter in Portland is losing money and risks closure.
This step follows years of speculation about the future of the plant, originally as a result of the strong Australian dollar and more recently because of the price of electricity for the plant.
AGL, which supplies the large aluminium smelter with its Loy Yang A power plant in Latrobe Valley, announced that it expects three other owners to terminate their contracts.
The plant is majority-owned by a joint venture between Alcoa and Alumina, of which the Chinese company CITIC and the Japanese Marubeni Corp hold smaller shares.
"'AGL expects the Portland plant to continue to operate, which means that there will be further physical demand for electricity from the smelter,' the company stated.
AGL further stated that the contracts were so-called "hedging transactions" which should have come into effect from November 2016.
The contracts have a 12-month notice period, so that they will end in 2017.
"Therefore, AGL expects the contracts to contribute to revenues in fiscal year 17," said the electricity supplier.
Any potential impact on revenue on AGL from FY18 onwards is currently limited by the forecasts of strong wholesale electricity futures markets.
AGL announced that it had already written off the value of the contracts in its financial statements in the amount of $187 million in "expectation of termination".
Alcoa said that the decision to write off the contracts would undermine Alcoa's "ability... to operate the smelter or to ensure the power supply to the smelter'.
The US company said it signed a 20-year contract with Loy Yang in 2010, which should have come into force from November this year, although it still owes an explanation as to why it withdrew from the contract.
Analysts are warning of the possible closure of the Portland smelter in Victoria and the Tomago plant near Newcastle due to the poor economic conditions in the industry.
Referring to analysts' statements earlier this week, Head of Operations Stephen Mikkelsen said Portland consumes about 600 megawatts of electricity annually and Tomago about 900 megawatts.
If both plants were to disappear from the market, this would mean a significant reduction in demand on the [electricity market].
And that would not be good for us as power generators," he said.

More than 160,000 of the country's most vulnerable people are turned away from the local justice centres each year, while the industry is preparing for the impact of further cuts in funding on already overburdened transactions.
In Queensland, three out of five people - mostly elderly people, immigrants, vulnerable workers, victims of violence and those who have no resources for unjust evictions and the like - are already turned away when they apply for free legal advice and legal aid.
Legal services of the municipality, which are already overused, are getting ready for further cuts.
As of June next year, these legal centers are expected to lose another 30 percent of their federal funding.
The director of Queesland's community rights centres, James Farrell, said that the latest survey by the National Association of Community Rights Centres showed that thousands of people are already being turned away every year.
Farrell said the situation would only get worse without a reversal of the federal government's decision.
"Queensland's community rights centres are chronically underfunded, which means thousands of people are turned away from essential services you need," he said.
People leaving violent relationships, people with unmanageable and crushing debts, families going through separations, workers unfairly dismissed - all these people have problems of a legal nature and this survey shows that they cannot get the help they need.
The federal government will cut funding by 30 percent from June 2017, which means that thousands of more vulnerable people from Queensland will be forced to cope with their legal problems without any help.
We are calling on George Brandis, Attorney General and Federal Justice Minister and Senators of Queensland, to immediately reverse these funding cuts so that people can get the help they need if they have legal problems.

It is now time to look at the needs of the local law centres and their client communities and for the Palaszczuk government to invest in this important work.

In the upcoming elections in the federal states of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania (September 4) and Berlin (September 18), the governing parties SPD and CDU are facing considerable losses.
This was the result of representative surveys conducted by the opinion research institute INSA for the "Bild" newspaper (Friday).
While the red-black government coalition could continue to govern in the north, this is not possible according to the survey results in Berlin.
In both states, however, the SPD would be the strongest party and thus have a good chance of continuing to provide the head of government.
In Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, the SPD plummeted from 35.6 percent five years ago to 24 percent.
According to the survey, the party would thus be only slightly ahead of the CDU, which could again reach 23 percent.
The third place is disputed between the left and the AfD.
The Left Party would make up 19 percent (previously 18.4 percent), the AfD would be represented in the Landtag for the first time with 19 percent.
Despite slight losses, the Greens would return to the Schwerin state parliament with 6 percent (previously 8.7 percent).
NPD and FDP would not be represented in the state parliament with 3 percent each.
According to the survey, the SPD would only account for 23 percent of the vote in the Berlin elections to the Bundestag (2011 election: 28.3 percent).
The CDU reached only 18 percent after 23.4 percent.
It would still be behind the Greens with 19 percent (2011: 17.6 percent), but ahead of the left with 15 percent (previously 11.7 percent).
The AfD would be represented for the first time in the Chamber of Deputies with 14 percent.

Nokia 9000 Communicator: The first smartphone
E-mail and Internet in slow motion: The Nokia Communicator was launched 20 years ago.
The successors dominate the world today - his manufacturer experienced a disaster.
The device weighed almost half a kilogram and was more than four times as heavy as an iPhone 5.
It was thicker and bigger, so it did not lie well in the hand.
On the contrary, it was quite clunky.
The built-in memory was initially eight megabytes, which would today be enough for about two selfies with high resolution.
An iPhone is now delivered with at least 16 gigabytes.
The "Nokia 9000 Communicator" came into the shops exactly 20 years ago, on 15 August 1996 - and it was the first smartphone.
For a few euros, enthusiasts can still buy the devices on the Internet, but they somehow date back to the stone age of the Internet age.
But 20 years ago, the Communicator was a sensation.
The Finnish mobile phone manufacturer had announced the product a few months earlier at the computer fair Cebit in Hanover as a "pocket-sized office".
In fact, the new mobile phone could do a lot for standards at that time: SMS and e-mails could be sent and received, and the Communicator could also be reached by fax.
Even web pages could be accessed via HTML browser, albeit painfully slow.
A calculator was available, a digital address book and an electronic calendar.
There was a small antenna, and the mobile phone could be opened similar to a laptop.
Then a small keyboard and a black and white screen were found.
Pretty proud was the price: 2700 D-Mark, about 1400 Euro.
The average selling price of a smartphone in Germany in 2015 was 392 euros.
In August 1996, nobody could have guessed that the Communicator would be the beginning of the smartphone era.
Everything's changed since then.
The smart phones are a success story, though not for Nokia.
The mobile phone division of the Finns experienced an unprecedented disaster, was finally sold to Microsoft and wound up.
The market today is dominated by suppliers who all came much later than Nokia.
Being online anytime and anywhere is part of everyday life for many people today.
In 2015 there were almost two billion smartphone users worldwide.
Around 1.4 billion devices were sold, of which Samsung and Apple alone accounted for 555 million units.
The worldwide turnover with the devices is around 400 billion euros.
In addition, there is the well-running business of the countless app providers and telecommunications groups.
An entire industry has now developed around the smartphone.
The decisive breakthrough to the mass market did not come until the beginning of 2007, when Apple boss Steve Jobs announced the introduction of the iPhone at the Mac World.
He promised three devices in one: a music player, a telephone and an Internet communicator, all easily operated via touch screen.
Apple's triumphal march began, and even today the iPhone is still the most important product of the group.
Nokia, Motorola and Blackberry, which dominated the market, were left behind.
They finally disappeared, Blackberry is struggling.
Apple and Asian providers such as Samsung are now in charge.
The smartphone is a matter of course 20 years after its invention.
On average, every German now looks at his mobile phone 88 times a day.
"We all have to learn to put away our smartphones," said Janina Kugel, the Siemens Managing Board member responsible for human resources.
Permanent accessibility is now considered both a curse and a blessing.

Adblock Plus, Facebook in the "cat and mouse game" regarding ad blocking
For companies that make money with online advertising, attempts to circumvent ad blocking amount to a "cat and mouse game" according to one of the software manufacturers.
On Thursday, just two days after Facebook announced that it would block display blocking on its desktop page, Adblock Plus published a blog post announcing that users could update their filters in the program to block advertising on the social network again.
On Tuesday, Facebook announced that its desktop page would change the encoding regarding its ads to make it harder for ad blockers to detect which part of the page is advertising.
But Adblock announced that it has found a new way to circumvent the new codes.
In a blog post, Adblock spokesman Ben Williams wrote that "this kind of back-and-forth battle between the display-blocking open source community and the bypassers has been going on since the invention of display blockers," and that it is possible that Facebook will soon come up with a new solution.
The fact that the world's largest social media company has joined the fight is a strong indication of how worryingly indicator-blockers have become for the industry.
According to a study last year by Pagefair and Adobe, around 200 million people worldwide use display blockers; almost four times as many in 2013.
With 1.03 billion daily active users accessing Facebook via their mobile devices, mobile advertising accounts for 84 percent of Facebook's advertising revenue.
The company is targeting ad blockers on desktop PCs because mobile ad blockers have no effect on Facebook's social networking mobile app and Instagram, a spokesperson said.
Advertising on desktop PCs accounts for a sufficiently large share of revenues that Facebook considers it worthwhile investing in such a step.
On Tuesday, Facebook announced that it would update its "ad preference tool" to give people more control over ads targeted at them.
On Thursday Facebook claimed that Adblock's new filters were worrying because they would also block content on the site that is not advertising.
"This is not a positive experience for users, so we plan to address the issue," a Facebook spokesperson said in an email message.
Ad blockers are a blunt tool, which is why we have instead focused on developer tools like Ad Preferences to put more control in people's hands.

The victim was lying in the middle of the night on the highway.
Police are calling witnesses after a woman was run over by several vehicles on a highway in the early hours of Thursday morning in a suspected suicide.
The incident occurred on the A1 near Morges in the canton of Vaud shortly after midnight.
A woman lay down in the dark "in an act of desperation" on the street and was hit by several cars, the police in Vaud testified.
It is obvious that a Swiss woman aged 49 who was run over by several vehicles, including a truck, wanted to kill herself.
She died on the spot.
Several drivers have already been questioned, but some have still not been identified, said police, who are asking them and any witnesses to the incident to come forward.
A preliminary investigation was opened, which is a "logical" step in such a situation, Gilles Hofstetter told Le Tribune de Geneve.
However, it remains to be seen whether one of the drivers will be displayed.
Was a collision avoidable?
This is something that the public prosecutor must decide," said Hofstetter.
Two similar cases in the last five years show that drivers are not held responsible.
In each of the two cases - where a person was walking on the motorway in the dark - it was decided that motorists did not have to assume that a pedestrian was walking on the motorway in the middle of the night, as the newspaper said.
Last year a policewoman was acquitted of involuntary manslaughter after running over and killing a man who was lying on the A1 near Payerne one night in August 2014.
The 22-year-old victim had been drinking and passed out on the street, the court heard.
The court found that the policewoman -- who had responded to an emergency call -- was driving in a justified manner and that the presence of a man on the street was a "totally exceptional and unpredictable situation," the judge said.

NASA climate model: Venus was once habitable
Venus was probably once habitable according to the projections of a new NASA climate model.
Scientists at NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies developed a model to discover Venus' past using tools and algorithms similar to those used by climate researchers.
The model was designed to determine whether Venus, with its hot, waterless surface and CO2-tight atmosphere, could once have exhibited Earth-like conditions.
Scientists have previously suggested that the slow rotation of Venus could be explained by its dense atmosphere.
But the latest simulation suggests that Venus may have had a thin, Earth-like atmosphere and still be spinning slowly.
The model also illuminated the topography of early Venus.
The planet probably had more arid areas than the Earth, but once had enough water and geographical variability to support life and protect against rapid evaporation.
Early Venus also benefited from a sun that was 30 percent duller.
"In the GISS model simulation, the slow rotation of Venus exposes her day side of the Sun for almost two months," explained GISS scientist Anthony Del Genio in a press release.
This warms the surface and produces rain, which creates a thick layer of clouds, acting like an umbrella to shield the surface from much of the sun's heat.
The result is average temperatures that are a few degrees cooler than those on earth today.
The model produced a history of Venus that resembles the evolution previously thought to have occurred by planetary scientists.
Although it was once presumably habitable, Venus -- over the course of several billion years -- was exposed to too much heat and ultraviolet light.
Their oceans evaporated and their water vapour was burned away by ultraviolet light.
When her hydrogen escaped, all that remained was a thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide with a deadly greenhouse effect -- Venus, as we know it today.
The researchers shared the results of their new Venus climate model in the Geophysical Research Letters.

To achieve this, the vision of the coach and Vice President of Hockey Operations must be perfectly aligned with that of the organisation.
He must also have a right of co-determination in decisions that affect the performance of the team.
These conditions are currently not met.

Kepler measures rotation rate of stars in the Pleiades cluster
The latest mission with the Kepler Space Telescope has helped astronomers to collect the most complete catalogue of rotation rates among the stars of the Pleiades cluster.
The new data will help astronomers to understand why stars in a star cluster rotate at different rates and how the rotation periods are related to planet formation.
"By comparing our results with other star clusters, we hope to learn more about the relationship between a star's mass, its age and even the history of its solar system," said Luisa Rebull, a researcher at Caltech's Infrared Processing and Analysis Center in Pasadena, in a press release.
The star cluster of the Pleiades lies 445 light years away from earth.
Many stars in this cluster, which were formed around 125 million years ago, are now reaching adulthood.
They spin fastest now.
At peak rotation rates these maturing stars emit large amounts of stellar winds.
Since these winds travel through the magnetic fields of the stars, they have a braking effect on the stars.
As a star ages, its rate of rotation begins to slow down.
Kepler measures the rate of rotation of each star by detecting the time between the appearance of a recognizable starspot -- like sunspots.
The latest catalogue of rotation rates indicates that more massive stars rotate more slowly than less massive stars.
Rebull compares the stars to dancers, with larger stars turning slower pirouettes than smaller ones.
"In the 'ballet' of the Pleiades, we see that slow rotors tend to be more massive, while faster rotors tend to be very bright stars," Rebull said.
Since the Pleiades star cluster is so close, it serves as an ideal cosmic laboratory for comparing stellar qualities such as rotation rates.
"The Pleiades star cluster provides an anchor for theoretical models of stellar rotation in both directions, younger and older," Rebull said.
There is still much ahead of us about which we would like to know more, how, when and why stars slow down their rotation rates and hang up their "dancing shoes", so to speak.
Rebull and her colleagues have reported extensively in three newspaper reports on their latest analysis of the rotation rates of the Pleiades, which will soon appear in the Astronomical Journal.

Data theft: hackers so perfidiously extort their ransom money
Blackmail malware programmers are currently attacking companies in a targeted manner - and they are successful.
According to a recent survey of 540 companies in North America, Great Britain and Germany by the malware defense specialists Malwarebytes, 40 percent of the companies surveyed have been victims of an attack with blackmailer software at least once, sometimes several times, in the past twelve months.
In Germany, almost 20 percent of companies have already been the target of ransomware extortion at one time or another.
40 percent of the victims willingly paid the ransom demanded by the perpetrators in order to be able to use the attacked systems and data again.
According to the observations of malware bytes, the perpetrators are increasingly specializing their blackmailer software in attacks on corporate networks.
If they are successful there, the potential ransom to be extorted is much higher than for private users.
"We are currently observing a frighteningly rapid evolution of malware," explains Malwarebytes boss Marcin Kleczynski in an interview with "Die Welt".
In 2008, most malware programs were still designed to send advertising.
Then the perpetrators discovered blackmail software for themselves.
At first, private users were the target, but the switch to corporate attacks has been alarmingly rapid in recent months.
Ransomware works according to a simple pattern: once active on a victim's computer, it searches specifically for recently modified files such as Word, Excel or database files, as well as archives of images and videos.
These files encrypt the ransomware and delete the originals permanently.
The software then presents the blackmailers' claims.
To get the final encryption code to the files, the victims have to transfer money - usually in the form of the crypto currency Bitcoin.
But where private users' personal photo databases are at stake, companies are concerned with sensitive customer data or project databases without which production comes to a standstill.
The damage is correspondingly higher if ransom goods are knocked down.
22 percent of the affected German companies reported losses in turnover due to ransomware, 13 percent even had to completely interrupt their business activities, and in one case, people were in mortal danger.
In Germany, hospitals have already been the victims of attacks on several occasions, whose patients may be acutely threatened by the loss of medical records.
"We always tell the victims: Don't pay, you're just encouraging the problem," explains Kleczynski.
But 80 to 90 percent of the companies that pay get their data back.
It is difficult for managers to refuse the demand of the perpetrators in the face of standstill in the company.
The hackers, on the other hand, know this and try everything to build a good reputation.
In a recent study, F-Secure's security researchers have examined the user interfaces and contact with the blackmailers and come to the conclusion that the perpetrators are actually trying to build up some kind of customer service to make more money.
They explain to their victims via chat how they can pay via Bitcoin, set up freely accessible support websites or decrypt sample files for free.
And if private individuals are redeemed after payments of a few hundred euros, companies sometimes have to negotiate hard and pay five-digit sums to get their data back unencrypted.
With the potentially large and relatively risk-free profits from ransomware extortion, hackers are becoming increasingly professional and sharing the work, security expert Chester Wisniewski of anti-virus vendor Sophos explains, "A single person can write ransomware in about a week.
However, it is more likely that there are three or four people.
The programmers then sell their malware in the form of a software construction kit to the actual blackmailers.
The previous malware kits were created by purchasing the malware itself, consulting and additional tools for a one-time, fixed price between $1000 and $10,000.
"An adjustment tool is included so that smaller configurations, appearance and branding can be changed," says Wisniewski.
The blackmailers then look for other hackers to spread the freshly purchased software among the victims.
We live in a service economy.
So you log into one of the underground forums, buy the set from a criminal and hire another to install the software on as many PCs as possible.
Payment is made per infected computer.
"Usually the criminals then hire spammers to distribute it," explains Wisniewski.
The risk of ransomware is now well known by many companies who are better at backing up their data.
More than 50 percent of those responsible for corporate IT in the Malwarebytes survey rely on being able to fend off ransomware using file backups and scanner software.
Accordingly, the perpetrators are already pursuing new strategies.
"If the encryption of data alone is no longer a sufficient threat for successful detection, the perpetrators threaten instead to publish sensitive data such as customer lists or price calculations," explains Malwarebytes CEO Marcin Kleczynski.
This means that, depending on the type of data, the damage potential is many times higher than before.
The perpetrators could also target completely new targets in the Internet of Things in the future.
At the Defcon hacker conference, security researchers demonstrated how they could get a thermostat connected to the Internet under their control.
In the middle of winter, the activation of such a blocked heating system could well be worth a ransom to many a victim.
If the perpetrators then block an entire production line in a factory instead of the heating in the future, ransomware could also become an issue in Industry 4.0.

HONDA HR-V is flexible and suitable for everyday use
Honda wants to pack everything into the small HR-V: a little SUV, a little coupe and also the versatility of a minivan.
Sounds rather overloaded, but the HR-V, which was constructed on the same new platform as the new Jazz, actually proves to be extremely flexible in everyday use.
Although the HR-V, which is only 1.60 m high, seems rather small, the passengers have plenty of space both in the front row and in the rear, and it doesn't seem cramped at any point.
The materials used for the interior are well made and look pleasant, only the top of the cockpit drops off a bit.
The HR-V is more versatile than comparable vehicles in terms of storage space.
Not only is a boot of 453 l with the backrests raised and 1026 l with the backrests folded down available, but there are the "Magic Seats".
This is less magical than it sounds: the seats in the rear seat can be folded up like cinema seats, offering storage space that is 1.24 m high from floor to ceiling.
The boot can be loaded well, but the loading height of 650 mm is slightly higher than in the comparable Peugeot 2008.
The tested 1.6-litre diesel with 88 kW/120 hp accelerates the HR-V very powerfully over a wide speed range thanks to the torque of up to 300 Nm.
However, he should do his work a little more quietly.
The daily consumption of 4.7 l/100 km is pleasing.
There is another engine: a 1.5-litre petrol engine with 96 kW/130 PS.
Four-wheel drive is not offered.
The handling is well balanced, a good compromise between dynamics and comfort.
But the steering should be a little more direct.
The equipment leaves nothing to be desired in the tested top version "Executive".
The safety systems include the City Emergency Brake Assist (works up to 32 km/h), the collision warning system and the Lane Keeping Assist.
The collision warner is sometimes irritating, because he evaluates many obstacles as "approaching objects" when shunting.
The high beam assistant works very reliably.
And the intelligent speed controller reacts to traffic sign recognition and slows down speed if necessary.
But full connectivity is only available for the top equipment: 7-inch touchscreen, navigation system, app integration and more.
Two USB and one HDMI socket are located under the armrest and are therefore a bit cumbersome to reach.
The around 29000 Euros for the well equipped top diesel are ok.
Who does not want to invest so much, gets the petrol engine from 20000 Euro, the diesel from 23000 Euro.
The engines comply with the Euro 6 exhaust emission standard.
With the HR-V, Honda offers a versatile car suitable for everyday use.
Airline not liable: Fall on passenger boarding bridge
An airline is not liable for the fall of a passenger on the boarding bridge.
For liability is only conceivable in the case of dangers that are typical for air traffic, argued the Düsseldorf Higher Regional Court (Case No.: 18 U 124/14).
The plaintiff had broken a kneecap in the fall.
However, the accident could have happened anywhere - it is a general life risk, the court said.
The airline did not have to pay damages to the man.
In case of illness: When does the organizer pay
Sick holidaymakers only get money back after their trip if the cause of the illness can be found without doubt in the hotel.
However, this is only the case if more than ten percent of the guests are proven to show the same symptoms.
In the negotiated case, a family was seriously ill with diarrhoea and vomiting on the second day of their holiday in Turkey.
She spent almost the entire vacation in her room.
The holidaymakers attributed their illness to a defective sewage treatment plant that allegedly polluted the seawater.
The family was of the opinion that the trip was thus defective - and filed a complaint against the organizer.
The plaintiffs were unsuccessful in court.
The sewage treatment plant was indeed defective.
However, the organizer only found out about it shortly before the plaintiffs' departure.
Until then he had to assume that the sea water was okay.
According to the judgment, he had not therefore infringed his obligations to provide information.
Especially since no impurities were found in the water samples.
The illness of several hotel guests - possibly through infection among themselves - is part of the general life risk.
Of 691 guests, only 38 were ill.

Better traffic flow on the motorway feeder road
It regularly jams on the bypass - here is a picture from November.
But that is about to change: The right turn lane is to be extended.
This is good news for all motorists who are stuck in traffic jams on the surrounding road every evening as they drive along the motorway feeder road (A 43).
Next Tuesday and Wednesday (August 16-17), the Landesbetrieb Straßenbau will extend the right-hand turning lane in the area between Hammer Straße and the Weseler Straße exit by 700 meters.
Drivers can then turn right directly from Hammer Straße.
The big advantage: traffic is split up earlier, which improves the overall flow on the busy section of the B51.
The CDU faction in the Münster-West district council had the idea with the extended exit.
The narrowing of the lane on the feeder road annoys motorists especially between 5 and 7 pm.
On weekdays, the backwater reaches as far as the bridge over the Albersloher Weg and sometimes even beyond.
The reason is the bottleneck on the B 51 shortly before the Weseler Straße exit.
From here on, traffic is only directed over the motorway bridge in one lane.
The second track had to be removed a good three quarters of a year ago.
The reason: Static calculations had shown that the bridge no longer had the necessary load-bearing capacity to take heavy goods traffic in two lanes.
How long this bottleneck and the associated daily traffic jam on working days will last is not known to the responsible state company.
However, years are to be expected: This is because the bridge has an official remaining useful life until 2034.
For the extension of the right-hand turn lane, the regional authorities deliberately chose the time of day during the school holidays when traffic is less busy, because disabilities are to be expected.
On Tuesday and Wednesday, traffic will be guided past the construction site in one lane.

Restful night: Tips against sleep disorders
In the evening you toss and turn forever, at night you lie awake for hours, in the morning there is no thought of sleep long before the alarm clock rings.
This is anything but relaxing.
After all, one is in good company with such problems: according to the Robert Koch Institute, about a quarter of adults have sleep disorders and more than ten percent find their sleep frequently or permanently unrestful.
How do sleep problems or sleep disorders manifest themselves?
There are several forms of sleep disorders and they can have many different causes, emphasizes Hans-Günter Weeß, member of the board of the German Society for Sleep Research and Sleep Medicine.
But what is commonly understood by this is insomnia, i.e. a difficulty in falling asleep and sleeping through the night.
Many people find sleeping through the night unsatisfactory or insufficient, says Jens Wagenknecht, member of the board of the German General Practitioners' Association with a practice in Varel, Lower Saxony.
What's behind insomnia?
The causes of sleep disorders are complex.
This may be due to organic, psychological or behavioural factors, but also to medication.
Not infrequently, sleep disturbance is an expression of another disease.
"Very early waking up is common, especially in depression," says Weeß.
And it may be that different factors are interdependent.
For example, someone who has a slipped disc can lie badly, wakes up every two to three hours and possibly starts to brood over everyday problems and worries, Weeß gives an example.
This leads to tension, and sleep is no longer possible.
From when should one go to the doctor with sleep disorders?
Anyone who does not sleep well for at least three nights a week over a period of one month and is impaired during the day should see a doctor, advises Weeß.
The impairment can look very different: One is exhausted, tired, sleepless, has difficulties with attention and concentration, is easily irritable, has mood swings or physical complaints such as stomach or headaches.
In order to relieve the sleep disorder, it is important to find out its causes.
Treatment options include behavioural changes, cognitive behavioural therapy or medication - classic sleeping pills only in exceptional cases and for a maximum of two weeks.
There are hardly any sleep physicians in private practice in Germany, emphasizes Prof. Ingo Fietze, head of the interdisciplinary sleep medicine center of Charité University Medicine Berlin.
Therefore, if you have sleep problems, you should first consult your family doctor, advises Weeß.
He can clarify with examinations whether the problems have a physical cause.
Who should go to the sleep lab, and what happens there?
Doctors recommend sleep laboratory examinations for snoring with breathing difficulties, for example, or in cases of pathological tiredness during the day, sleepwalkers or when the cause of a sleep disorder cannot be found, explains Fietze.
You don't really need to prepare for the examination.
One should spend the day normally.
"Just please don't take a nap", says Fietze.
After wiring you go to bed at your normal time.
In addition to the electrodes on the body, you wear nasal cannula, a chest strap and a feeler on your finger.
In addition, a camera on the ceiling records the sleeper.
How can those affected get a grip on the problems?
There are quite a few set screws that you can use for a better sleep.
Weeß is counting: Regular sleeping and getting up regularly, not lying in bed too long, not sleeping during the day, not watching TV to fall asleep, avoiding alcohol and not looking at the clock at night - then you start calculating immediately, and that is not at all beneficial.
