Old buildings, a few lime trees, a few cobblestones in between: Rigaer Straße in Berlin-Friedrichshain doesn't look like this at first glance, but the police consider it one of the city's "dangerous places".
If you walk along the street from east to west, you will pass playgrounds, a freshly painted kindergarten and a health food store.
Someone sprayed "ugly!" on the front of a gray house.
Opposite a Lidl, which is also soon to be demolished, construction is already underway: A house with high windows and 133 new rental apartments is to be built here by 2017.
However, articles about this "trendy district", as the responsible real estate company Friedrichshain calls it, are preferably illustrated with burning cars in recent weeks.
The reason is the house with the number 94: once it was occupied, now the residents have rental contracts, but on the ground floor there are still rooms occupied and used for events.
Since the beginning of the year, Berlin's Senator of the Interior, Henkel, in particular, had repeatedly spoken out in favour of tough action by the police against the project, describing the area as a "no-go zone" for police officers and the 94 as the starting point for autonomous violence.
After the ground floor rooms, the Kadterschmiede, had been cleared on 22 June by 300 police officers, the police patrolled the area for three weeks, according to official statements, with 30 to 40 officers and three crew cars, blocking off parts of the street and preventing visitors from entering the house number 94.
Meanwhile, construction workers renovated the rooms on behalf of the unknown homeowners.
On July 13, a Berlin administrative court ruled that the eviction was illegal, and one day later police and construction workers left to the cheers of sympathizers and residents.
On this summer afternoon, the street seems peaceful: parents take their children for a walk, people sit on the sidewalk in front of the houses in the sun, others talk in front of the late afternoon.
A primary school and kindergartens are located in the immediate vicinity of the house projects.
Left-wing violence is not the main concern of many residents: Kerstin Neugebauer, who has been living in the neighbourhood since 1999, and Jana*, who is raising three children here, are particularly annoyed by the police presence.
They share with the inhabitants of the housing projects the concern about rising rents and gentrification.
It doesn't sound like a neighbourhood, the majority of which wanted police protection from vandalising leftists.
The ditch that the Berlin Senator of the Interior and the police open up between squatters and their neighbours obviously does not exist in this form.
Friedrichshain in the east of Berlin was actually a traditional working-class district, which even today has a low average income and high risk of poverty compared to the rest of the city.
Squatting and the housing projects born out of it have also long been part of the neighbourhood: in 1990, numerous houses in the former GDR were squatted, including almost the entire Mainzer Strasse near Riga.
While the people of Mainz had been evacuated in a real street battle under large police presence, many of the projects in Riga were legalized and are partly still inhabited today by the people who occupied them 26 years ago.
At the same time, in recent years the district has increasingly become a magnet for tourists and Berliners from all over the world: Residents from GDR times and former squatters now share their neighbourhood with them.
This is also reflected in rents, which have risen by almost 60 percent since 2009 for new lettings.
Many of the new buildings in Riga are attacked as symbols of this development: You can recognize them by the panes of glass that have been thrown in or freshly painted facades that have been thrown on with paint bags.
No other street was mentioned so often this year together with the words "left-wing autonomous violence".
One reason why not all neighbours see this as a problem could be that they are not necessarily affected by crime: Statistics show that crimes such as assault and battery are almost exclusively directed against police officers.
The majority of crimes involve damage to property, which tends to affect new and newly renovated houses.
For Kerstin Neugebauer, who has lived in an apartment building next to the controversial 94 for 17 years, there can be no talk of uncertainty.
As far as acts of violence are concerned, she is placative: the people in 94 are her neighbours, they certainly were not.
Also the famous burning cars have not been seen in Riga for a long time.
For the studied architect, her street is not a criminal hot spot, on the contrary: "Here people help each other, live together on the street and get to know more about each other than anywhere else".
Neugebauer deliberately moved to Rigaer Strasse - and stayed.
That's why it was so important to her that the residents get their street back: By the police, politicians and the media, all of whom suddenly claimed interpretive sovereignty over the district in July.
But in the eyes of residents and Neugebauer alike, the street continues to be taken away from them: Through faceless new buildings in former gaps between buildings, which displace the old inhabitants.
"These are condominiums that are not interesting for many people here - it's more likely that people who are not so well-off live here," she says.
"Violence and destruction I absolutely do not condone."
But what can you do if no one ever listens to you?
Frustration sets in on all sides, including the police and residents.
Kerstin Neugebauer has little sympathy for immigrants who are annoyed by paint bombs: the house projects and the left-wing scene were part of the neighbourhood.
Anyone who moves here should be aware of this - just like someone who moves into a pub district can hardly complain about noise there.

Urbach: Annika Deuschle is the new commissioner for refugees
Annika Deuschle is the contact person for integration and organization.
She is also a local social worker.
Since July Annika Deuschle has been the refugee commissioner for Urbach.
The social education worker supports the administration team around Achim Grockenberger.
It sees itself as a contact for all actors: refugees, the Working Group for Refugee Aid, the administration, authorities and whoever else is involved.
Regine Kunde from the working group suggests that the volunteers are more than grateful that Deuschle is now here, the egg-laying wool-milk sow, who has one problem above all else.
This is what some - less mockingly but rather aiming at the variety of desired tasks - had meant when the administration wanted to advertise the position.
They were looking for an administrative specialist with a talent for languages and people, combined with many years of experience in the field of social work - in other words, a woolly milkshake.
But administrative work is not her central area, says Annika Deuschle.
Above all, it is about organisation, working with people on site and behind the scenes, and networking.
The 31-year-old has been with us for about six weeks.
She has limited a 50-percent position to three years.
"It was high time", says Regine Kunde, "that Annika Deuschle supported voluntary and full-time actors.
There are big and small problems, organizational, human and communication problems.
Soon new containers will be available in Wasenstraße
For some time now, a serious problem has been finding housing for the Anschluss refugees who have been recognised.
The local authorities are responsible for the connecting accommodation.
They must accommodate the refugees in their own or rented accommodation.
The costs of building, renting or renovating these shelters must be borne by the municipalities themselves.
The responsibility changes from the district office to the municipality and job centre.
Problem: There are free objects, but not every landlord wants to offer his apartment.
The search has been proving very difficult for some time now.
De facto, the administration does not find private apartments.
It has not worked so far, but one is dependent on private apartments, says Deuschle.
Therefore, communal apartments must be upgraded, as the saying goes.
So new containers will soon be set up in Wasenstraße.
But apartments are not the only thing that will do it.
Perspective is the keyword, Regine Kunde and Annika Deuschle agree.
In addition to a permanent place to stay, there are internships, training positions, school places, one-euro jobs and temporary jobs for refugees and migrants that have to be found or set up.
"More seats would be good," reports Regine Kunde.
Many of them work in the building yard or help caretakers, do community work - and that motivates and very neatly, as Annika Deuschle reports.
She hopes that the work for the community will lead to a positive external impact.
It's "not occupational therapy."
But activity does not only mean work.
The day needs a solid structure, say Deuschle and Kunde.
People should develop a sense of belonging.
So, he says, there is a need for offers such as sports, contact with locals and, above all, language courses.
Professional courses are rare.
So administration and volunteers also help out here.
It is crucial that the refugees get the feeling that they are wanted and welcome in Germany.
The long duration of the proceedings is a problem.
They have to explain to the refugees that it is taking time and that they can bridge the time sensibly, for example with language courses.
Anyone who at some point develops the feeling that he cannot help anyone in Urbach, is not allowed to work and is useless, will never integrate.
The clear majority is motivated.
But there are also problem cases, says Kunde honestly, "people with whom nothing works". The work of Deuschle and the customer is therefore always also to motivate others.
All this is already a "mammoth task".
A difficult question: after the recent events, are they afraid of radicalisation, even in a small community like Urbach?
"No", Regine Kunde says quite clearly, "which some might call naive". However, it could not and did not want to exclude a residual risk.
But the helpers are already sensitized.
These incidents were also a topic of discussion among the refugees.
They would be afraid that the assassins would bring them completely into disrepute.
"They want to show that they have nothing to do with it," says Regine Kunde.
Many would like to stay in Urbach.
Therefore, full-time and voluntary workers and volunteers have to look for activities on site and in the region.
They always have in mind that a new batch of refugees and migrants could soon come to Urbach.
Does Germany need an upper limit?
Politicians are afraid to answer this question clearly.
Actually, it's unfair to put them on the spot.
"In Urbach we have not yet arrived where we want to go", says Annika Deuschle.
No new refugees, that would ease the situation.
Regine Kunde also makes it clear that the people of Urbach are already working at full capacity to integrate the existing people sensibly.
At the moment there are about 100 people, mostly young men.
But when people are in need, they need to be helped, both women agree.
The world political situation is so complicated that there are no easy answers.

Munich 1856: Four maps that change your view of the city
An insane asylum, where young people are supposed to meet today.
A crypt chapel, where they are now digging for the S-Bahn tunnel.
Allotment gardeners cultivate the former land of farmers.
The oldest official map of Munich brings exciting stories to light.
It sucks when maps are out of date.
Everybody knows this, who had to get upset because the car navigation system showed a green meadow instead of a bypass.
The historical maps of the digital Atlas of Bavaria, an offer of the Geoportal Bayern of the state government, are anything but up-to-date - but for this very reason they are very informative.
Especially if you compare them with current online maps.
Then it becomes clear how cities and communities in the distribution area of the Münchner Merkur have changed since the 19th century.
The digital atlas of Bavaria is a patchwork quilt that is not immediately recognisable as such.
More detailed maps, so-called Urpositionsblätter, were incorporated into the large general map for cities and municipalities.
According to the Bayerische Vermessungsverwaltung, these were created between 1810 and 1864 and originated from the first surveying of Bavaria.
Your employer: Napoleon.
The French army commander occupied Bavaria since the spring of 1800 during the Second Coalition War with Austria.
Napoleon wanted an overview of the occupied country and commissioned a topographic survey of Bavaria - for military purposes, of course.
Even if the French troops finally withdrew with the Peace of Lunéville on February 9, 1801, it was the present-day neighbors who created the idea of a comprehensive map of Bavaria.
Elector Max IV Joseph pushed the project further, founded the "Topographical Bureau" - and with it the Bavarian Surveying Authority.
The Urpositionsblatt für München dates from 1856 and can be found like all the others on the website of the Bayerische Landesbibliothek.
The comparison between the past and the present is most impressive in the case of the state capital.
The city has expanded in all directions and has grown together.
One example is Untersendling, which appears relatively isolated in the 1856 map.
Sendling was incorporated as a Munich district 21 years after the creation of the map, i.e. in 1877.
Today Untersendling lies in the middle of the city.
Untersendling's houses are concentrated around 1856 along today's Plinganserstrasse, which was not named until 1878 after Georg Sebastian Plinganser, a leader of the Bavarian peasants' uprising against Austria in 1705.
Where the Westpark is today, you see nothing but fields - at first glance: When zooming in, a smaller-scale map appears with dozens of lines and numbers: handwritten numbered parcels of land from the so-called "Uraufnahme", from which the land tax was derived.
Today, small plots of land are no longer occupied by farmers - but by allotment gardeners from the "Land in Sun" facility.
A large green area is emerging to the north of Untersendling.
The Theresienwiese, which has been the scene of the Oktoberfest since 1810, was actually still a meadow in the 19th century - and not a concrete desert.
On the other side of the Isar, the historical map gives an insight into the history of psychiatric medicine.
In the original position leaflet, one reads in the area of today's district Au-Haidhausen not only the street name "am Gasteig" or from the hill "Auf der Lüften" - but also in large letters "Irren Anstalt".
Yes, here on Auerfeldstraße, people with delusions were once locked up.
There, in 1858/59, the Munich District Mental Hospital "Auf der Auer Lüften" was established.
From 1872 onwards, Dr. Bernhard von Gudden was in charge of the institution - the psychiatrist who is associated with the death of King Ludwig II.
"He was progressive for his time and, for example, ended the chaining of the so-called lunatics.
In addition, he has forbidden the staff to use violence against the inmates," says Hermann Wilhelm, director of the Haidhausen Museum, who has been working with the institution for an exhibition.
Initially there was room for 280 patients, but this was later expanded to 500.
At some point, even this capacity was no longer sufficient - the reason for building the Kreisirrenanstalt in Haar in 1905.
The Isar-Amper-Klinikum München-Ost, one of the largest psychiatric clinics in Germany, has been located there since 2006.
On the grounds of the former Auer Anstalt, young people now meet in the Munich Salesianum.
The order acquired the building complex in 1920 and converted it into a youth centre with training facilities.
To the west is the football field of TSV München Ost, to the east are residential buildings from the 1980s.
In 2015, the children's house "Casa Don Bosco" was built - in architectural reference to the original building of the asylum, which had been destroyed in bomb attacks during the Second World War.
Marienplatz was listed as "Haupt Platz" around 1856, Kaufingerstraße was called "Kaufinger Gasse".
The Second World War also brought a decisive change in the heart of Munich.
The Allied bombs tore many holes into the city centre in December 1944.
One big one remained until today - at Marienhof.
The English Institute, small commercial buildings and a crypt chapel from the Middle Ages once stood at Marienhof, where the preparatory work is currently being carried out and the ground-breaking ceremony for the second main S-Bahn line will take place on 5 April 2017.
With the slider you can compare the old Munich map with today's aerial view - and fill up the hole at Marienhof.
Civil rights group publishes travel warning for Missouri
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has issued a warning for colored people who travel to Missouri because of the state's discriminatory policies and racist attacks.
"The NAACP Travel Advisory for the State of Missouri, which is scheduled to be effective through August 28, 2017, urges African-American travelers, visitors and Missourians to pay special attention and exercise extreme caution when traveling through the state, as a number of questionable racially-based incidents have recently occurred throughout the state and are noted here," the group's opinion states.
A recently passed Missouri law that makes it harder for people to win discrimination lawsuits and state law enforcement agencies that disproportionately target minorities prompted the group to issue the travel warning, the NAACP said.
"You have civil rights violations that happen to people.
They are stopped because of the color of their skin, they are beaten or killed," Missouri NAACP President Rod Chapel told the Kansas City Star.
"We are hearing complaints at a frequency we have not heard before."
It is the first such warning issued by the organization for a state in the USA.
The group cited incidents such as racist crimes against black students at the University of Missouri and the death of Tory Sanders, 28, a black man from Tennessee.
Sanders died in questionable circumstances earlier this year after running out of gas while traveling through the state and being taken into custody by Missouri police without being charged with a crime.
The Council also points to a recent report by the Missouri Attorney General's Office that shows that black drivers in the state are stopped 75 percent more often than white drivers.
"The recommendation is that people be aware and inform their families, friends and co-workers about what could happen in Missouri," Chapel said.
"People have to be ready, whether it's bringing bail money or letting relatives know they're traveling across state lines."
Missouri recorded 100 hate crimes in 2015, according to the latest figures from the FBI's hate crime reporting program, which rank the state 16th in the country in terms of the number of such violations.
The travel warning is also a response to a new Missouri law that would make it more difficult to sue a company for housing or employment discrimination.
Previously, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) issued travel warnings for Texas and Arizona after the states passed immigration laws that require local law enforcement agencies to arrest people for immigration violations, which the ACLU believes will help further racial profiling.
Travel alerts are usually issued by the State Department for other countries, but recently, stakeholders have been using the measure in response to certain laws and trends within the US.
Pasture fence project is elementary
The Fischerbach pasture fence project is a successful project and will be continued next year.
The CDU members of parliament Peter Weiß and Kordula Kovac have gotten a picture on site.
At the Rechtgrabenhof of the Schwendemann family, representatives of the Fischerbach CDU local association met together with Mayor Thomas Schneider and the two members of parliament.
Markus Schwendemann initially provided insights into his farm, where he manages 55 hectares of meadows and 40 hectares of forest, looks after 40 dairy cows and just as many young animals and accommodates holiday guests in five apartments.
According to Schwendemann, "Black Forest milk" is for him the only alternative marketing channel for the milk of his cows.
Only regional dishes are served to the holiday guests.
Since he is also BLHV chairman of Fischerbach, he called the pasture fence project "elementary important".
I cannot operate profitably on such steep terrain.
The grassland area is a lot of work, and much of it has to be worked with the motor scythe.
"We are struggling here with the conditions and with the topography," emphasized Schwendemann.
In 2003 he took over his parents' farm and runs it without chemical pesticides and fertilisers, even though he does not run an organic farm.
For Mayor Thomas Schneider it was clear: "The municipality has recognised the importance of the pasture fencing project and is pleased with the Leader funding".
With costs of 3000 to 4000 euros per hectare, farmers would have to be supported.
It is hoped that this will allow the reforestation of the areas to continue for quite some time.
"The greatest treasure we have are the people who work in agriculture and who are concerned about how they can take their business forward," emphasized the mayor.
Farmers are often criticised for the support
In 2013, a total of 25 parcels of land were fenced in by means of the pasture fence subsidy from eleven participants.
The area to be kept open is thus 40 hectares, which may not be afforested until at least 2023.
Of the total cost of 71 500 euro, half was funded via Leader, with the municipality of Fischerbach bearing one quarter.
This left the farmers with 12 610 euros, which they had to invest in 16.2 kilometres of pasture fencing.
"The big advantage is the durability of the fences," explained Schwendemann.
Kordula Kovac emphasized: "You are doing a really good job, it won't work without farmers and countrywomen".
For Peter Weiß, too, it was clear that "the best food is produced here".
The Landscape Conservation Directive (LPR) of Baden-Württemberg allows state funding for pasture fences.
The aim is to keep the Black Forest open.
A prerequisite is the existence of a funding backdrop designated by the LPR.
In addition, the area to be fenced must not be suitable for tractor management (slope inclination over 35 percent) and must therefore be threatened by afforestation.
For the Fischerbach pasture fence project 2018, the application of eight participants with 24 plots is currently underway, who want to build almost 16 kilometres of fence.
The area to be kept open corresponds to 35 hectares and the calculated cost is more than 112 000 euro.
Is nothing sacred anymore?
Now the White House is taking the Statue of Liberty from Trump
The surest sign of a change of regime is when they start to attack the statues.
The Americans appreciate them as much as anybody else - hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein on Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003.
Stephen Miller, one of the key ideologues of the Trump regime, certainly knew what he was doing when he took a symbolic axe to the Statue of Liberty in a heated argument with CNN's Jim Acosta about the President's proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration.
To be fair, Miller did not attack the statue itself.
A horde of boat owners and Liberty imitators would have lynched him if he had done it.
But he attacked its significance, and especially the significance that was attributed to it when the famous poem by Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903, 17 years after the monument was completed.
When Miller insulted Acosta: "I don't want to go into a whole thing about history here, but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world.
The poem you refer to, which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty."
Miller is factually correct, but as he put it himself, it is not really about history.
It is about the contemporary response to the stirring words of Lazarus, the only ones in which a state invites not just any old immigrants, but the poorest of the poor: "Your tired, your poor, / your oppressed masses longing to breathe freely, / the wretched waste of your rich coasts.
There has never been a time when the "miserable rubbish" was better visible on our screens.
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trumps USA.
This conflict over the meaning of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural debate: it is indeed a conflict over the meaning of America.
Lazarus - and her friends, who were committed to placing her words at the base after her death - knew very well that they were carrying out a highly political act.
The sculpture was intended to show the connections between French and American republicanism by depicting the female embodiment of freedom in a worn classical pictorial representation.
Lazarus changed this meaning: in her poem the female figure is no longer abstract - she has been given a voice.
And she gives herself a completely different name: Mother of the Exiles.
The combination of the poem with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism.
And just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue, the people on the right wing have long wanted to change it back.
The great shouter Rush Limbaugh, a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump, argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone, but rather an early neo-conservative who was bringing the American flame into the benighted world: "Lady Liberty goes first.
It should carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world.
The torch is not to light the way to the United States."
Quite unusually, Limbaugh came across something here.
The meaning of the statue is entirely a question of the standpoint of perception.
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see her as she was seen by the exhausted, wretched, but hopeful people after long and often terrible voyages on the decks of ships.
It is literally about seeing the world from the perspective of people who seek refuge and a chance to improve their lives.
Her statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome that they need to hear.
And that, of course, is not the perspective that Miller and Trump would ever want to acknowledge.
Their torch is not to light the way, but to ignite the hatred that is their only source of power.

Eilidh Doyle remembers a time when only two Scotsmen were on the UK team
UK Athletics Performance Director Neil Black says the Scottish 16-man contingent in the world championship squad "will make a massive contribution to the team".

Your captain's speech was incredible," says Black.

It just shows how far we've come.

About my speech as captain?
Yeah, I think it went well.
I just pointed out that we are very happy in this situation, because we have a home world championship.
So it's really important to rely on this home support and benefit from the fact that we are back in the Olympic stadium.
I get a second chance to go out there and compete and it's just gonna be such a great atmosphere out there."
Blocking critics via Facebook: Don't run for public office if you can't stand the heat of voters
The father of our country knew something about bad press.
Americans loved George Washington, but it wasn't long before the newspapers beat him for everything from domestic politics to his political principles.
He scolded at the review, sure.
But he did not silence his critics.
For in 1783 Washington said, "Freedom of speech can be taken away - and, foolishly and silently, we are led like sheep to the slaughter.
That brings me to Maryland to Governor Larry Hogan, who has to work on being more like Washington.
Hogan's employees have blocked and deleted the posts of at least 450 people who have expressed their opinions on his official Facebook page.
And the American Civil Liberties Union sued him for it earlier this week.
The governor's staff dismissed the complaint as frivolous, and the online commentary was full of a backlash with "So what?
"It's just Facebook," a lot of people said.
But it's important.
And it's especially important if it's a guy like Hogan.
This is a republican governor in an overwhelmingly democratic state that is amazingly popular.
He has the second-highest approval rating of the nation's 50 governors.
Hogan is not a reactionary hothead.
He has shown a firm hand in running his state and strict adherence to principles.
He was also very adept at using Facebook as his primary means of connecting with his constituents and easily debuting his hairless head after chemotherapy on his site.
Therefore, blocking people who come to the governor's side - which is a public forum called official and staff paid with public tax dollars - is unnecessary and ultimately dangerous.
In an interview with The Washington Post, Hogan's spokeswoman Amelia Chasse defended the governor's actions, arguing that blocking comments was nothing more than moderation.
But it's too easy to use the image of trolls or spammers or hateful people cracking the whip online.
The Post spoke to some of the real people who were blocked by Hogan.
And these are just real people talking to their elected leaders: a teacher, an entrepreneur and a priest, not trolls.
They all said that their comments were respectful, thoughtful and not profane.
The priest quoted the Bible in his mail and appealed to Hogan's Catholic faith.
Attorney Lakshmi Sarma Ramani of Bowie, Md. was not hateful, but she asked about hate crimes.
"I commented politely that I was disappointed that there was no response to hate crimes and other current news," she wrote in the comments section of The Post news program.
"I don't appreciate this idea either, when a number of people take a stand on the same issue, some tend to disregard it as a so-called collective effort rather than recognize it as a large group of concerned citizens".
What the governor's staff called a "concentrated spam attack", others would probably call "advocacy".
The Facebook era makes it easy to tailor a message by simply blocking a critic or deleting a negative comment.
It is much cleaner than it used to be if the same thing had been done, that employees were sent to collect and burn newspapers with critical editorials or arrest and silence protesters.
But this is exactly what is happening digitally.
Hogan is not the first public official to be criticized for abusing Facebook and other social media.
President Trump is being sued by Twitter users who were blocked from his Twitter feed.
One of the first milestones on this issue was last week in Virginia.
The chairman of the Loudoun County Board of Supervisors violated the First Amendment, according to U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris in Alexandria, when she banned a voter from her Facebook page.
And in Kentucky, Governor Matt Bevin (R) also received a visit from the ACLU for his use of Facebook and Twitter.
That shouldn't be too hard.
In Washington's time, the era of affordable postage had a similar effect to the Internet.
The number of newspapers multiplied between 1776 and 1800, and anonymous letter writers struck at his leadership.
And even then, Washington had trolls anonymous.
The people who used pseudonyms such as "Juricola", "Valerius", "Belisarius" and "Portius" all wrote letters to newspapers that put down Washington's decisions.
Petitions criticizing his position on the Treaty of Amity, trade and shipping with Britain overwhelmed his office, according to the historical documents collected by the online papers of the George Washington Project.
But he didn't silence her.
Freedom of speech, dissent and discourse are the foundation of our nation.
And true leadership means accepting that.
Ronan Rafferty hopes for domestic comfort at the Renaissance Club
Former European No. 1 Ronan Rafferty will be hoping for home comforts over the next three days as the Renaissance Club in East Lothian hosts the 25th edition of the Scottish Senior Open.
The Nordire, who led Links to the final round at Archerfield next door last year before losing to Paul Eales, is associated with the new venue and acts as tournament ambassador on behalf of club founder and CEO Jerry Sarvadi.
"I saw the Renaissance Club being built, and we'll see how it achieves its fame with this event," Rafferty said.
"The players will see this course at its best, it's in great shape.
Jerry did a great job fixing this place up.
He is a fervent supporter of this game and is proud of his performance here.
This is a great showcase for this course."

"This really feels special," said the Southport-based player.

Coming back to this part of the world is magical.
It's a wonderful place to play golf.
The memories from last year are coming back, and it was something special for me and my wife Sharon to win here last year.
It was a really special time and one that we will always treasure."

Fewer lung cancer deaths from passive smoking
Over the past two decades, fewer and fewer people have died of lung cancer due to passive smoking.
This is the result of a study by scientists of the University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf (UKE).
"According to our estimates, 167 lung cancer deaths per year are attributable to passive smoking," said study leader Heiko Becher.
As a comparison, he used his own study on this subject from 1994.
At that time there were 400 lung cancer deaths per year in Germany due to passive smoking.
The new study is published in the International Journal of Public Health.
House connections prove to be very complex
The construction work in the Villinger Strasse is in full swing and "is more or less on schedule", says the head of the building yard Fred Heinze.
In the area of house connections, the situation was more complicated than expected, as there was much hidden underground that was not indicated in the plans.
The traffic, which repeatedly obstructs the construction work, is a big problem for the Stumpp construction team.
"The ignorance of drivers in front of red lights and barriers is already enormous," Heinze reports.
The road is closed and only the public buses are allowed to pass through.
Angelo Caruso, Marvin Kostorz and Tim Kostorz from the Stumpp company have been working on the bridge for weeks.
"The hot days were already quite exhausting.
But fortunately we were supplied with cool mineral water by our friend Fritz Matt," says Marvin Kostorz.
Poverty and death in the Indonesian goldlands
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner, she does not use a stove.
She even rarely uses a pot.
In her wooden house in Enarotali, the capital of the Paniai regency in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua, the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called "nota" - directly into the fireplace.
After half an hour the charred tuber is removed with eager, unwashed hands and devoured.
Degei sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also does her daily work, e.g. washing clothes with cloudy water from the nearby swamp.
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine.
As the youngest of her husband's four wives, she was not assigned fields.
Polygamy is common here.
Of course, working late can be dangerous: Most of the village men are unemployed, and many drink heavily, and there are the soldiers.
"Nobody dares to walk around the village after 5 pm," she says.
It is a rare glimpse of daily life in the highlands of Papua, a former Dutch colony that was taken in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia, when only 1,026 elders were supposed to vote by a public show of hands in front of the occupying forces.
An existing movement that stirred for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the government of Jakarta, which maintains control over the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers from it.
In 2003 the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua, with the independent part of Papua New Guinea comprising the eastern part of the island.
Enarotali is as remote as it is desolate. The trip includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire and then a 5-hour morning drive by rental car.
There is no public transport.
The town with about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated iron roofs, which have been transformed by rust into different yellow-brown shades.
Very few Indonesians have made the trip here, let alone journalists and practically no foreigners.
Before Christian missionaries arrived, Mee Pago Papuans worshipped a god named Uga Tamee.
There have been other changes as well.
"We weren't used to wearing these clothes," says Degei, pointing to her vibrant, hand-woven turban, dark shirt and light-colored skirt.
"Before, we only had leaves on our bodies."
Papua is Indonesia's poorest province, where 28% of the people live below the poverty line and have some of the worst infant mortality and literacy rates in Asia.
But it is also Indonesia's gold country.
The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world, Grasberg, owned by Phoenix-based Freeport McMoran, is located just 60 miles from Paniai, a highland province the size of New Jersey with a population of 153,000.
In 2015 alone, Freeport has mined gold and copper to the value of 3.1 billion US dollars.
In addition, Papua has timber resources valued at an estimated US$78 billion.
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papuans, who ensure that Indonesia's powerful military maintains a suffocating presence.
A 2005 New York Times investigation reported that Freeport paid local military personnel and units nearly $20 million between 1998 and 2004, including up to $150,000 to a single officer.
Papuan demands for greater autonomy threaten this golden goose and are treated mercilessly.
According to activists, more than 500,000 Papuans have been killed and thousands have been raped, tortured and imprisoned by the Indonesian military since 1969.
Mass killings in Papua's tribal highlands in the 1970s became genocide according to the Asia Human Rights Commission.
In the region alone, Indonesian police arrested more than 3,900 peaceful demonstrators last year.
"We Will Lose Everything" is the title of a 2016 report from the Archdiocese of Brisbane, which includes reports of atrocities committed in the previous year, such as unlawful executions and torture - rape and electrocution are particularly popular according to another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations.
"It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week," says Andreas Harsono, Indonesia researcher for Human Rights Watch.
The screws have been tightened as Papua's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia.
The province's population of 3.5 million is 83% Christian, but demographic trends are changing as Muslim economic migrants come from the populous islands of Java, Borneo, Sumatra and Sulawesi.
Javanese Warung canteens sell fried chicken and gado gado, a mixed vegetable served with peanut sauce.
Local people are fighting to keep up.
"The migrants have started to sell chicken and vegetables at the traditional market for less than the local Papuans," explains Abeth You, a 24-year-old Paniai native who moved to the provincial capital of Jayapura to work.
"It has cost the native Papuans, the mama-mama of Papua, their market."
Indonesian President Joko Widodo, popularly known as Jokowi, promised during his 2014 election campaign to tackle inequalities and rights violations in Papua.
The former carpenter secured 27 of Papua's 29 districts - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta.
But little has changed in Papua, and today the locals feel betrayed.
"Our hearts are broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored," says You.
In fact, Paniai hit a low point just two months after Jokowski's inauguration in October.
On December 7, 2014, a group of 11 children were outside singing Christmas carols in front of a campfire in Enarotali when two Indonesian soldiers on a motorcycle broke through the darkness.
The frightened children told them to turn on their headlights.
One of the soldiers took offence at her tone and later returned with four soldiers, according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai.
The soldiers who had drunk, hunted and beat the group with their rifle butts, said victims and witnesses.
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children.
One child, 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo, was beaten so badly that he fell into a coma.
A few hours later the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire and things escalated the next day.
About 1,000 young Papuan men, women and children gathered on a football field in front of the local police station and the military command centre to demand justice.
They wore ceremonial hunting bows and performed the Waita dance - running in circles and imitating a bird song - of Papua's Mee Pago tribe.
Some demonstrators started throwing stones at police and military posts.
When the atmosphere was heated up, the soldiers were sent an order over an internal radio: "If the masses resist more than three times, they shoot them dead," according to an official document from TIME, which was not released to the local media.
Yeremias Kayame, 56, the leader of the Kego Koto district of Enarotali, saw the impending danger and called for calm and urged the crowd to return home.
No one was in the mood to listen.
"When I turned around, I was suddenly shot in my left wrist," he told TIME on the porch of his brightly painted wooden house.
Kayame still doesn't know who fired, but says the bullet came from the ranks of the soldiers gathered here.
"It was crowded, many shots were fired," he adds.
The local man Alfius Youw was hit three times, according to his cousin, who witnessed the shootings.
"I ran to him and examined his body to make sure it was him," said Yohanes, who like many Indonesians only has one name, TIME, in a gloomy mood.
"I saw that he was dead... I kissed him."
The Chief Inspector of Papua Police, Yotje Mende, told reporters that his officers were only "securing" their station because it was under attack.
"We must defend ourselves when people threaten to kill us," said Papuan police spokesman Commissioner Pudjo Sulistiyo in 2015.
"It's a matter of life and death."
According to Human Rights Watch, five young demonstrators were killed and many more injured.
The news of the killings did not come to Jakarta 'filtered' until the following day.
For three weeks, Jokowi gave a passionate speech in Jayapura expressing sympathy for the families of the victims and vowing to address the historic abuses in Papua.
"I want this case solved immediately so that it will not happen again in the future," he said.
Security Minister Wiranto said in October 2016 that he was setting up an extra-judicial mechanism to resolve historic human rights violations.
But the excuses started almost immediately.
"Most injuries occurred long ago.
Some were in the 90s and early 2000s.
The point is that we are committed to tackling these violations, but there are processes that need to be put in place," he said.
Then Wiranto made a retreat when he spoke to TIME in Jakarta on 5 June, saying that he had no plans to set up a complaints mechanism in Papua.
Instead, "everything will be regulated by law," he said.
Wiranto, who has been indicted by the UN for "crimes against humanity" that claimed more than 1,000 lives in East Timor's bloody 1999 independence vote, said 11 cases of human rights violations in Papua have already been settled, including the Paniai incident.
Families of the Paniai victims received such claims with grim disbelief.
"I have been interviewed four times in the last three years, but there has been no progress at all," says Yohanes.
"I'm tired."
He says that years later he still lives in fear.
"I'm scared," he says.
"I'm afraid of being arrested by the military, afraid of being shot."
His brother Yacobus repeated the view that people in Paniai are afraid to discuss the incident.
He says he was beaten by the military after helping to bury four of the victims.
"After I buried the bodies, the military looked for me," he says.
The shooting hasn't stopped.
On Tuesday, Indonesian police fired on villagers in Paniai's Deiyai neighborhood.
During a confrontation between villagers and the manager of a construction company who refused to take an unconscious man to hospital, one person died and 17 others were injured, including children.
The man, 24-year-old Ravianus Douw, who drowned while fishing in a nearby river, died on the way to hospital.
Excited villagers protested outside the company's location office.
The police said that villagers threw stones at officers who responded by firing warning shots.
But locals say that the mobile brigade (Indonesian paramilitary police) started shooting at the crowd and killed one.
"We were so panicked, we're afraid that there will be revenge," says 29-year-old Dominggu Badii, who lives near the hospital and witnessed the injured being quickly admitted here, according to TIME.
"I hid in my house for two days."
The Deiyai Parliament has called for the officers involved to be held accountable and for the mobile police brigade to withdraw from the area.
Paniai has always been a trouble spot for the Indonesian government.
The lack of meaningful development reinforces the dissatisfaction of the tribesmen Mee, Moni, Dani and Damal, who live in the green highlands of Papua.
Many joined the "Free Papuan Movement" (OPM), the rebel army that claims to defend Papuan rights by initiating sporadic attacks and kidnappings of Indonesian soldiers.
Some of the top OPM leaders are from Paniai, including Tadius Yogi and Daniel Yudas Kogoya.
In response, thousands of people have been arrested and arbitrarily detained in Paniai in recent years on the pretext of "safeguarding national sovereignty".
Some never show up.
Among the people of Papua, Paniai is known as "a tragic, forgotten place".
Poverty increases dissatisfaction.
The little bit of rice that is sold in Enarotali is too expensive for the locals.
Bread is just as out of reach.
The people here grow everything they eat: especially nota and fruit and leafy vegetables.
Agriculture is the task of the women, who can cultivate four or five fields of sweet potato each.
They keep most of the harvest for the family, while the rest is sold on the local market.
Ten pieces of nota cost only 10,000 Indonesian rupees (75 cents).
Over time, economic inequalities have grown between the native Papuans and the new migrants, who have arrived in greater numbers since the opening of new air routes to Nabire Airport.
The few jobs available in the region tend to go to the better educated and wealthier migrants.
Papuans rarely have the capital or the necessary skills to run their own businesses competitively.
"The young people are not interested in staying in the village... because there are no jobs or money here," says John Gobai, the chairman of the Paniai tribal council.
Isolation keeps the eyes of the world away from Papua.
In addition, restrictions on reporting in the international media remain tense.
At the beginning of the year, French journalists Franck Escudie and Basille Longchamp were deported from Papua for lack of coordination with related institutions, although they were given rare permission to film.
According to Phelim Kine, Deputy Asia Director of Human Rights Watch, the promises of Jokowski's campaign to lift restrictions on reporting to promote transparency and development have not been realized.
"There are new dangers for foreign journalists trying to report from Indonesia's troubled easternmost provinces of Papua and West Papua: Visa refusal and a blacklist," he said in a statement.
Lack of press control means that international pressure on the Indonesian government is largely limited to Papua's immediate neighbours.
In March, six Pacific states - Tonga, Nauru, Palau, Tuvalu, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands - called on the UN Human Rights Council to investigate "various and widespread violations" in Papua, including the Paniai shootings.
The same countries have historically supported the OPM.
Indonesian Foreign Ministry spokesperson Arrmanatha Nasir rejected the group's accusations and told journalists in Jakarta: "Indonesia still has a democratic system and free media, so it is difficult to cover up evidence of human rights cases.
The local people want more foreign governments to take note of this.
When an official delegation from the Netherlands, led by human rights ambassador Kees Van Baar, visited Jayapura on May 4, locals broke their silence and harassed him "We want freedom," according to a source who also attended the meeting but wishes to remain anonymous.
Indonesia has another presidential election in 2019, but the Papuans say they will probably not vote for Jokowi again.
"Jokowi is a person who has good intentions, but he is surrounded by the people involved in the Paniai shooting," says Gobai, the chairman of the tribal council.
He wants Jokowi to know that the Paniai people, apart from living under the constant threat of a predatory military, are in poor education and health services.
Gobai says that the Paniai people, like other Papuans, see their vote for Jokowi as a "debt" that he must repay.
"They don't need money, they just want justice," he says.
Despite the threats and intimidation, families of the Paniai gunshot victims carried out one last symbolic act of defiance: the body of one of the victims was buried on a site directly opposite the police and military station.
They know that they may never get justice, but at least they do not let those responsible forget their crimes.
"A member of our family has been killed," Yacobus says with his head bowed.
"What else can we do?"
Fire captures the 'Torch' skyscraper of Dubai for the second time
On Friday, a fire found its way through one of the world's tallest residential towers in Dubai, forcing hundreds of residents to flee the 337-meter-high, 79-story building.
It is the second fire to sweep through the skyscraper, which happens to be called the Torch Tower, in just two years.
The building was evacuated, no injuries were reported and there was no direct word about the cause of the flame.
"We were asleep and we got up at the fire alarm and people were screaming.
We ran down the stairs, and it took about 10 minutes to get down from the 50th floor," a resident, who gave his name as George, told Reuters.
Dubai's civil defence authorities said that fire-fighting units extinguished the fire and cooled the building around 4:00 local time (00:00 GMT).
The government said it was working on providing shelter for the people affected.
The incident may revive questions about the safety of materials used in outdoor areas of high-rise buildings around the world.
An investigation by the management of the Torch building after its fire in 2015 revealed that most of the damage came from the cladding, the outer cladding used for decoration or insulation.
In the UK, police said they believe that the system of panels for insulation and cladding at London's Border Fell Tower in June may have contributed to the rapid spread of a fire that killed about 80 people.
No Davis Cup reform: Further best-of-five
The President of the International Tennis Federation (ITF) failed the General Assembly with his major Davis Cup coup.
At the meeting in Ho Chi Minh City, the proposal, revolutionary for this sport, to play Davis Cup singles on only two winning sets was barely supported by the required two-thirds majority.
The five-set classics, which are often very long, but which are also very much appreciated for this very reason, will therefore be retained in this traditional competition.
63.54 per cent of member countries voted in favour of the reform, narrowly missing the target set by ITF President David Haggerty.
"We respect this decision, but are disappointed that our member nations have not adopted the entire reform package for the Davis Cup and Fed Cup.
We need a change to secure the long-term future of these iconic and historic competitions," said Haggerty.
They would continue to work on improving the competitions.
After many objections, the proposal to hold the final at a neutral location had not even been put to the vote.
Only comparatively minor details are new from 2018: the finalists in the Davis Cup and Fed Cup will have the right to host the first round in the following year.
In order to reduce costs for the organisers, the requirements in terms of training grounds etc. will be eased and players will have fewer official media appointments before the Davis Cup.
More than 1 in 5 US travelers bring prohibited items on the plane, a survey finds
A survey of airline passengers found that more than 20 percent smuggled prohibited items past U.S. Transportation Security Administration checkpoints, either intentionally or unintentionally, including at least 6 percent who boarded the plane while inadvertently carrying prohibited knives or other items with blades.
Less than 1 percent claimed that they discovered late that they had travelled by mistake with firearms, ammunition or explosives.
The survey of more than 1,000 people - conducted by a jet charter service, Stratos Jet Charters Inc. also found that younger travelers are more likely to disregard the rules.
Of those respondents who admitted that they knowingly tried to fly with something that was banned by the TSA, 19.7 percent were millennials, compared to less than 15 percent who were Generation X members.
The most common items that were intentionally passed by TSA agents were food and liquids.
More than 3 percent admitted to knowingly carrying items with blades through the security checkpoint, while 2.2 percent of female respondents and 3.7 percent of male respondents also confirmed that they had intentionally brought prohibited drugs onto the aircraft.
The company said it had interviewed travelers across the country to find out how many had accidentally brought contraband through airport security and how many had done so intentionally.
It is no surprise that the people who are most likely to carry contraband - knowingly or unknowingly - through security were those who fly the most.
However, the company points out that the TSA guidelines are somewhat complicated and confusing.
People are often unsure which liquids they are allowed to take with them or how much of them.
So it is no surprise that the largest amount of items seized by TSA are prohibited liquids.
For a while, people thought TSA might think of books as contraband.
Liquids are allowed on domestic flights, but not on international flights.
Elon Musk does not care: Tens of thousands of Tesla customers cancel order
Electric jack-of-all-trades Elon Musk likes to show off with the huge number of pre-orders for his new Tesla "Model 3".
In doing so, he has so far failed to mention that some of the customers have already withdrawn their non-binding reservation.
In addition to the consistently triumphant figures on sales increases and even more gigantic sales targets, Tesla boss Elon Musk revealed another, less glamorous figure for the first time when announcing the latest quarterly balance sheet: that of cancellations for the new mass market model 3.
Musk had frequently advertised in recent months with the more than 500,000 advance orders for the new car, which is just starting to be delivered.
Now Musk concedes: Of the total of 518,000 advance orders, 63,000 have already been withdrawn.
Critics had repeatedly pointed out that these are merely non-binding reservations.
In the event of a cancellation, Tesla will refund the 1000 Euros (1000 US dollars in the USA and 1000 pounds in Great Britain) "reservation deposit" in full.
Musk admitted in a conference call with analysts that there are currently 455,000 such non-binding reservations.
However, the Tesla boss does not believe that the cancellation of around twelve percent of all orders could become a problem.
His argument: the challenge in achieving the ambitious growth targets is not on the demand side, but on the production side.
Last year, Tesla delivered 84,000 vehicles.
In 2018 - all models taken together - it should be 500,000, in 2020 one million.
The demand for this is obviously there.
According to Musk there are currently 1800 reservations per day.
Anyone who orders a "Model 3" today can expect delivery in the second half of 2018 at the earliest - when Tesla manages to run its brand new production lines, which have never been tested in practice, at maximum capacity without major interruptions.
Many experts doubt that this is possible.
However, if there are major delays, the non-binding nature of the reservations could become a problem for Tesla.
Because then the company cannot prevent dissatisfied customers from running away in droves.
EPA chief Pruitt withdraws because of the Obama-Era's delay in reducing emissions
One day after being sued by 15 states, Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, reversed his earlier decision to delay the implementation of Obama-era rules to reduce emissions of smog-causing air pollutants.
Pruitt presented the change when his agency proved more responsive to the needs of government environmental agencies than previous administrations.
He did not mention the lawsuit that had been filed against his previous position in a federal appeals court.
It is a deadline of 1 October for countries to meet the 2015 standards for ground-level ozone.
Pruitt announced in June that he would delay compliance for a year to give his agency more time to study the plan and to avoid "interfering with local decisions or hindering economic growth.
Pruitt, who was the District Attorney of Oklahoma before his appointment by President Donald Trump, has long been a staunch opponent of tougher environmental regulations.
Since his arrival in Washington, Pruitt has repeatedly blocked or delayed regulations that the chemical and fossil fuel industries oppose.
Wednesday's sudden reversal is the latest legal setback for Pruitt's regulatory rollback agenda.
Last month, a federal appeals court in Washington ruled that the EPA administrator overstepped his authority when he tried to delay the implementation of an Obama administration rule requiring oil and gas companies to monitor and reduce methane leaks.
In a statement released on Wednesday evening, Pruitt suggested that his turnaround on ozone standards simply strengthened the EPA's willingness to cooperate with states through the complex process of meeting the new standards on time.
"Among previous administrations, the EPA has often missed deadlines for implementation and then waited to be accused by activist groups and others and set a date for implementation in an agreement," said Pruitt, who sued the EPA more than a dozen times in his previous job.
"We don't believe in regulation through litigation, and we take deadlines seriously.
We also take seriously the law and the authority it gives us."
Nevertheless, the EPA opinion stated that at some point Pruitt will use its "power to delay and all other legally available powers" to ensure that the rules are "based on sound policy and the best available information.
Republicans in Congress are pushing for a more comprehensive revision of the ozone regulations.
A draft law approved last month is expected to delay the implementation of the 2015 rules by at least eight years.
The measure has not yet been put to a vote in the Senate.
New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, who led the coalition of states that sued the EPA this week, said the group intended to maintain legal pressure.
"The EPA's reversal - according to our complaints - is a major health and safety gain for these 6.7 million New Yorkers and the more than 115 million Americans directly affected by the smog that is pouring into their communities," Schneiderman said.
New York was joined in this case by California, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Iowa, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota, New Mexico, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont and Washington and the District of Columbia.
Ground level ozone is formed when pollutants from cars, power plants, oil refineries, chemical plants and other sources in the atmosphere react to sunlight.
The resulting smog can cause serious respiratory problems for sensitive groups of people and contribute to thousands of premature deaths every year.
Public health officials and environmentalists cheered on Pruitt's surprising change of course.
"It is disturbing how much pressure it takes to get this sensible move from the person responsible for protecting the air we breathe," said Lori Ann Burd of the Center for Biological Diversity.
"We must continue to fight against the Trump government's ideological crusade to curry favor with polluters and their special interests.
Tumlingen celebrates 750 years St. Hilarius church
750 years of St. Hilarius Church: On the occasion of the anniversary of the mountain church, a serenade will be held on the old cemetery grounds in Tumlingen on Sunday, 16 July at 4.30 pm.
Due to its idyllic location and beautiful view of the village, the historic St. Hilarius complex is a popular place to stay.
The visitors of the sixth charity serenade can be enchanted by this powerful place.
The friends and supporters of Tumlingen have made the rescue and preservation of the oldest building in the village their concern.
Walter Martini emphasizes: "It is a unique village gem".
In 1267 the St. Hilariuskapelle was first mentioned in the Württembergisches Urkundenbuch: Count Hermann von Sulz sold "the mountain with the parish church at Tumlingen located on it, together with the bailiwick" to Magister Eberhard von Horb and to his brother Dietrich for 20 marks silver.
According to the wording of the document, in addition to the former parish church, there was also a manorial court on Tumlinger Berg to which the church or patronage right belonged and not vice versa.
So people lived there too.
As can be seen from the description of the Oberamt Freudenstadt of 1858, the "Berg" was the third, the manorial settlement core of the village, next to the Unterdorf and the Oberdorf, which can just about still be seen in Tumlingen today.
Old maps from around the year 1600 support these historical facts.
The patronage law arose from the early medieval own church law.
A gentleman who built a church, equipped it and occupied it with a pastor, remained the owner of this church and could also inherit this own church.
This was connected with the right to appoint a pastor or to propose a new pastor to the bishop.
There were three altars in the church and two bells on the tower.
The larger of the two burst at Christmas 1673.
The newly acquired bell rang for the first time in 1692, but had to be returned later during the Second World War in 1942.
During the 30-year war (1616 to 1648) the window panes were smashed and the bell ropes were stolen.
The roof was leaking.
In 1796 French troops camped near the church.
They broke out the pulpit and pews and used them as firewood.
Remains of the church threatened to collapse in 1809.
Until 1869, the Hilarius cemetery in Tumlingen also served as a final resting place for the dead from Hörschweiler.
In 1823 the cemetery was extended and the Hilarius church was demolished.
Only the church tower was left standing.
On the night of New Year's Eve in 1834 a storm split the steeple and half of it collapsed.
To prevent an accident, the tower was demolished.
Only the tower dwarf, which still exists today, has been preserved as a witness to 750 years of church history.
Today, Horst Kallenberger and Rolf-Dieter Wasem of the "Schaffigen Rentner" (working pensioners) are looking after the Hilarius facility as the successors of Dieter Dockhorn.
As organizers, the friends and patrons of Tumlingen invite you to the sixth serenade on Sunday, July 16th, at the old cemetery to the St. Hilarius Chapel.
It is designed by the combo of the Kepler-Gymnasium Freudenstadt and with contributions from Kurt Kübler and Reinhold Matteis.
Hartmut Romann, the head of the village, will speak the closing words.
The program starts at 4:30 pm.
Admission is from 3.30 pm.
The serenade will end with a drink in front of the cemetery.
"Enjoy a summer evening under the shade of old trees and with the wide view over meadows towards the forest", the organizers point out the fantastic view.
The serenade only takes place in dry weather.
The organizers hope for many supporters for the preservation of the historical St. Hilarius complex, which is important for Tumlingen and Hörschweiler.
The friends and supporters of Tumlingen feel particularly committed to the care of the homeland, as Serenade organizer Walter Martini affirms.
Association wants to have approval of wind turbines checked
"Boisheim defends itself" sees no legal prerequisite for the construction and has therefore turned to the district administrator.
The association "Boisheim defends itself" has called on District Administrator Andreas Coenen (CDU) to withdraw his permit for the erection of planned wind turbines in the Boisheimer Nette.
It was carried out unlawfully.
The association argues that at the time of the approval on 30 December 2016, no wind power plants could have been approved at all in the Boisheimer Nette, as at that time in Viersen a wind power concentration zone only existed on the city border of Schwalmtal.
Within this concentration zone, the construction and operation of wind turbines is possible in principle, but at the same time the concentration zone excludes the use of wind energy for the rest of the city.
Such zones are intended to prevent the landscape from being "sparse".
A few days earlier, the city of Viersen had decided on a second wind power concentration zone in the Boisheimer Nette through a change in the land use plan - but the district government of Düsseldorf had not approved this because of a formal error.
"Due to the lack of planning law prerequisites, the approval notice issued is still illegal and must therefore be withdrawn," said Christoph Erkens, chairman of "Boisheim defends itself".
Current state of affairs: Before the summer break, the city council has again decided on the wind concentration zone in the Boisheimer Nette; approval by the district government is still pending.
Erkens: "This means that at this point the granting of a permit for the installation of wind turbines is excluded under planning law".
The circle confirms the receipt of the request.
"The corresponding letters have been received by the district of Viersen since last week," a spokesperson explained.
The Circle takes it as an opportunity to re-examine the matter.
However, they will probably not lead to the proceedings being stopped.
With a view to ongoing proceedings at the administrative court, the district did not want to comment on the content of the argumentation of the association "Boisheim defends itself" on Thursday.
NEW Re, a subsidiary of NEW, is planning the construction of four wind turbines, each 200 metres high, on an area on the Boisheimer Nette.
Last year, the company, in which the city of Viersen is indirectly involved, had already concluded lease agreements with the owner of the approximately 65 hectare site.
With the installation of the four wind turbines, it should be possible to cover the electricity requirements of around 11,400 households - which corresponds to around a fifth of the electricity requirements of all households in Viersen.
NEW Re intends to invest around 20 million euros.
Last summer, Viersen's city council gave the go-ahead for the purchase of three wind turbines at the Linnich wind farm near Aachen and a stake in a wind turbine in Übach-Palenberg in the Heinsberg district.

Moore's Ford massacre: Activists resume racist lynching as a call for justice
A 1948 Ford Mercury drove through a group of spectators in rural Monroe, Georgia, and rumbled towards the Ford bridge at Moore.
Before the car, which had four black passengers and a white driver, could reach the bridge, a group of white men with guns stepped out to block its way.
The leader of the mob - a middle-aged man in a pinstriped suit - took a long puff at his cigar and looked intently through the windshield.
Inside, the inmates hovered in fear.
"We want that n ---- r Roger!" yelled the man.
"Get him out of the car!"
Cries broke the silence as a young black man was dragged from the passenger seat.
Fortunately, this terrible scene, which was played on July 22, is only a re-enactment.
But when a noose is then thrown around the neck of "Roger", almost everyone in the audience emitted very real sighs.
Since 2005, civil rights activists have been returning to Moore's Ford Bridge to recreate the night two black couples - Roger and Dorothy Malcom and George and Mae Murray Dorsey - were lynched by the Ku Klux Klan in 1946.
No one was ever charged with the murders.
"It's really incredible that in all these years not a single person has been arrested - even though we see them in our communities, even though we know who they are," said Tyrone Brooks, who is helping organize the reenactment.
"It's a smudge on a story, but it's a strain on our souls."
Brooks is a 71-year-old former congressman of the State of Georgia and a lifelong civil rights activist.
For him, the reenactment serves as a dramatic call to action and is an annual reminder to the Monroe community that an injustice has never been corrected.
"We want prosecution, we want ending, we want healing, we want reconciliation, but first we must get justice," he said.
"We cannot attain healing and reconciliation until we receive justice."
A medical examiner lays a sheet over the body of one of the victims of the Moore-Ford lynching on July 27, 1946.
According to FBI files obtained by NBC News, more than 50 men from Monroe and surrounding counties were suspected in the lynching process.
But no one was ever charged.
Although the suspects have remained at large for decades, civil rights activists say that the double motivation for the lynching actions has always been known throughout the city: politics and sex.
In April 1946, a Supreme Court decision allowed black citizens in Georgia to vote for the first time in the summer primary campaign.
At about the same time as the election, according to the FBI, black sharecropper Roger Malcom stabbed a white landowner, Barnett Hester, during a fight - allegedly over a woman.
Brooks said the rumor in town was that Hester had slept with Malcom's wife Dorothy and that the baby she was carrying was not her husband's.
On July 25, 1946, Loy Harrison, a prominent white landowner, paid $600 to free Malcolm from prison, according to the FBI.
He was accompanied to the prison by Dorothy and her cousins Mae Murray and George Dorsey.
But when they left the prison and approached the Moore's Ford Bridge, a lynch mob surrounded the car.
"As it turns out, it was Harrison who prepared and ordered the murders," concludes an FBI report.
"It is also obvious that there was a conspiracy between the state and local law enforcement agencies, which not only participated in the murders, removed evidence and covered up the identity of witnesses".
Brooks puts it even more succinctly.
"It was a voting rights massacre," he said.
"They were all killed to send a message to black people in this community: "If you register and if you vote, this is what will happen to you."
For nearly a decade, Cassandra Greene directed the annual Moore Ford Bridge Lynch reenactment.
Her portrayal is vivid, poignant and is rooted in a kind of deep racism that many would like to believe no longer exists in America.
It's hard to watch, and even harder to look away, but Greene said that's the point.
"We don't want to talk about lynching because then we will be confronted with its ugliness in all of us," she said.
"But I can't have a relationship with you if you won't listen to me or won't listen to what I've been through".
Rehearsals for this year's production began in June, and on the first day almost 30 actors - a dozen white and the rest black - crowded into a room and listened as Greene started a well-rehearsed overview of the play.
Wade Marbaugh is Greene's co-director here.
He has been playing the role of chief clan member for years, but he said the role would never get easier.
"I feel dirty because I'm not like that," said Marbaugh.
"But I think it's very important to keep this story alive because we don't want to go back to those times."
On the other side of the room, actors Darrius Bradshaw and Nick Rascona, who play Roger Malcom and Barnett Hester, rehearsed their lines.
The play begins with Malcom yelling at Hester and harassing him, angry that he slept with his wife Dorothy.
"I said, n- --- him, get off my property!"
Rascona returns fire.
There's a break.
And then everyone (at least all black actors) bursts into laughter.
Greene laughs the loudest.
"What?!" Rascona asked.
He is alarmed and confused.
Was I too hard?
"No," Greene said, still giggling.
"I just don't believe that white people back then said 'n he'."
"Yes," quipped one of the other black performers.
"All you have to do is hit the hard 'R.'."
And this is exactly where the energy in the room shifts, a feeling of camaraderie replaces the discomfort.
Everyone is busy getting this right, not only because of the game, but also because of the memory of the four people killed.
The scene begins again.
This time when Rascona says the N-word, he says it sharply and emphatically.
Absolutely nobody laughs.
This repetition ends violently and quickly.
There are screams, shots, and then silence.
A woman, dressed in a mourning dress, stands over the bodies of the actors and performs Billie Holiday's mourning eulogy "Strange Fruit".
Her voice breaks at every other word.
About a hundred meters behind, a group of about four dozen spectators wipes sweat and tears from their eyes.
The audience is divided almost equally between black and white.
A couple has traveled from Ithaca, New York, to see the performance, many just come down the street.
They have all experienced nearly eight hours of Georgia's oppressive humidity as Brooks leads them on a pilgrimage to the Malcoms' and Dorseys' tombs.
Up to this point the murders have remained an anecdote, but now, standing on the same land where the lynchings took place, the air feels spooky.
When the last notes of the song fade away, Greene invites the crowd to come closer and inspect the bodies.
Children squat at their heads, register the fake blood and the silent bodies and whisper to each other.
"You're not really dead," mumbles a little boy as if to remind himself.
After a few minutes Greene thanks the crowd - and suddenly it's over.
The actors throw away the lynch rope and wipe away their tears.
Bradshaw hugs Marbaugh, the man in the suit who played the clan member.
Nick Rascona embraces two of his fellow players and then collapses in their arms crying, the emotional burden of the performance finally breaking through on him.
"It's okay," whispers one of the women.
"We know this is not in your heart.
You did this for a reason."
Later, the audience sits down with the actors for dinner.
At a table, a white couple from Atlanta is chatting animatedly about the reenactment with a black couple they have just met.
Denise Duplinski struggled to find words to describe the feeling the performance left behind.
"It's hard to hear these terrible words and deeds... coming from people who look like you and who do it because they look like you," she said.
"What this really does to me makes me think that the lynching is still going on," she added, "today it's just called police shooting."
In the same room, Tyrone holds Brooks court at his table, eating and reminding him of civil rights.
He said he had already started planning the performance next year.
"The reenactment is inspiring in some ways, because it describes the horror of what we have endured, but it is also a moment of learning," he said.
"It's like this, if we don't learn from it, it could happen again.
He who does not study his own history, who does not know his own history, is condemned to repeat it."
"Götterdämmerung" reconciled the Wagnerians in Bayreuth
Also in the fourth part of Richard Wagner's monumental work, director Frank Castorf focuses on a colourful and frivolous production in front of a gigantic, six-storey backdrop.

Where everywhere?
Quantity: Usually in Steinfurt in the furniture exchange, once a week I help out here in Greven in the furniture bridge.
