EPA reverses decision to delay smog rule after complaints
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has overturned a decision to delay regulation by the Obama administration, according to which states are obliged to curb smog-causing emissions. This came one day after 15 states sued the agency for the move.
The EPA announced late on Wednesday the decision to move ahead with the so-called "Ozone Regulations 2015" and said it showed the agency's commitment to work with states.
"We believe in dialogue with and responding to our government partners," EPA chief Scott Pruitt said in a statement.
In June, Pruitt announced the EPA's intention to delay ozone regulations - which will measure pollutant emissions in part of the country to determine where cuts need to be made to meet stricter air quality standards - by one year until October 2018.
A group of 15 mostly democratic states, along with the District of Colombia, filed suit on Tuesday, saying the effort was illegal.
President Donald Trump's administration has sought to roll back a wide range of environmental requirements imposed by former President Barack Obama as part of a broader agenda that Trump says will boost economic growth.
However, these efforts have caused the backlash of Democrats and conservation groups who are concerned about the public health impact of major emissions.
The EPA website says that breathing air that contains ozone "can reduce lung function and increase respiratory symptoms" such as asthma.
Local council wants common room
In the end, the decision was clear: with two votes against, the local council of Fluorn-Winzeln decided to create a common room in the future senior citizens' residential complex.
Before the discussion, there is one important piece of information: The purchase contract for the remaining part of the property has been signed, reports Mayor Bernhard Tjaden.
Although it will take some time before the area previously belonging to the parish is owned by the municipality, there is now no longer an obstacle to planning the project, which is to be financed by a private investor.
For this there is a discussion about a common room.
One of the two investors who are still on board has offered to accommodate the community.
On the ground floor, he would provide a living space - around 55 square metres - and an adjacent terrace with no less than 70 square metres of space for a special price.
The administration and the majority of the local council have the idea of not using such a common room as a meeting place for the residents of the senior-friendly housing, but to open it up to the community.
As an example, the word "knitting café" made the rounds.
The decision, which was already pre-decided last autumn by providing funds for the current budget, is sweetened by funding opportunities.
The building is located in the redevelopment area.
According to Tjaden, the establishment of a common room would be eligible for 60 percent of 30 percent.
In order to signal to the investor that they do not want to put a spoke in the wheel in this respect, the proposed resolution provides for the statement that both saddle roof - which is based on the surrounding development - and monopitch roof - which reduces the eaves height and makes the construction more economical - would be possible.
Not only Wilfried Sohmer thinks that this addition is unnecessary.
If it helps, he passes the panel unanimously.
It is not so easy with the common room.
Daniela Ruf refers to the many buildings of her own, with which one does not really make progress, but now one leans out of the window at the common room, she says: "I have a hard time with it".
Yvonne Staiger is absolutely in favour of the common room - but absolutely against municipal participation.
It sees behind it a hidden subsidy to already wealthy or even foreign investors.
This is not the case, because the purchase of the land does not constitute a subsidy, but rather a real, marketable equivalent, is the counter argument.
Staiger's motion to split the proposed resolution accordingly finds three supporters.
Thus, with two votes against, the original programme remains, as Stefan Haller summarises it: "If we take the decision like this, we will take a giant step towards closing a huge gap in our infrastructure".

Wandering from star to star in the Harz Mountains
In the Harz Mountains, the first "Star Trail" is to be created nationwide.
This is being planned by the Sankt Andreasberg Observatory Association.
There is a planetary path in Göttingen - since 2003.
A "star trail" meets the information needs of many visitors to the Harz mountains, it was said.
It combines nature, science, exercise and sporting performance.
The members want to put up boards along the planned route and inform about stars and constellations.
In a first phase until 2018, the association plans "easily accessible installations at five to six locations" in the Upper Harz Mountains.
St. Andreasberg, Braunlage, Hohegeiß and Sieber would come into question.
The information on the boards is to be supplemented via the Internet.
Good mobile network reception therefore plays a role in the selection of a location.
Accessibility is also a criterion.
Later the Star Trail will be extended step by step.
"On the Star Trail, viewers learn a lot of interesting facts, for example about the physics of the individual stars," the association explained.
They also learned why stars have different colours or why one star shines more brightly than another even though it is much further away.
It also tells you in which constellation a selected star is located and when it is best to see it.
Since 2014, the association has been operating the highest located observatory in Northern Germany in the mountain town of St. Andreasberg.
The location in the middle of the Harz National Park is one of the six darkest regions in Germany, according to the Federal Agency for Nature Conservation.
Often the Milky Way and even the Andromeda galaxy are clearly visible to the naked eye from there.
In the university city, on the initiative of the Förderverein Planetarium Göttingen, there has been something similar to the planned star dwarf - the Planetenweg - since 2003.
Starting in front of Gebhard's hotel in Goetheallee, which forms the interior of our solar system, the Planetenweg with its steles leads up to Hainberg and the observatory - as well as an "extraterrestrial" location in Diemarden (Gleichen municipality) with the planet Sedna.
The stelae with the individual planets - including Pluto, which has been degraded to a dwarf planet at the end point - are positioned exactly at a distance and on a scale of one to two billion.
The earth thus shrinks to a sphere with a diameter of 6.5 millimetres, while the sun, which is exactly 75 metres away, measures 70 centimetres.
The total distance of the planetary path is a good four kilometres.
While the light from the sun to Pluto takes about eight hours, pedestrians need a good hour to reach the stele with Pluto.
Pedestrians are therefore faster than the light in space.
But the march to the next fixed star would still take half a year.

In an accident on the A7 motorway on Thursday afternoon, four people were injured, some of them seriously.
According to initial information, the driver of an Opel Zafira lost control of his vehicle around 4.30 pm shortly before the Marktbreit junction, presumably after a tyre blowout.

New results of Swedish asylum age assessment tests published
The latest results of tests for asylum seekers in Sweden, which have been subjected to a new method of medical assessment of their age, show that more than 80 percent of the people tested are over 18 years old. But not everyone believes in the accuracy of these results.
The Swedish Forensic Medicine Agency (Rättsmedicinalverket) began conducting the tests last year.
They are to make the assessment of age more accurate during the asylum procedure, after the Swedish Migration Board (Migrationsverket) was criticised for errors in assessing the correct age of some refugees who were minors.
To date, Migrationsverket has sent 6,880 cases to be tested and the Forensic Medicine Agency has now published the results of a total of 2,481 tests from mid-March to 31 July 2017.
Eighty percent (2002) were judged to be 18 or older, while in another 25 cases the Forensic Medicine Agency judged that the person was "possibly 18 years or older".
In 432 cases the conclusion was that the person "may be under 18 years of age".
The tests are only carried out in cases where the age of the person is in question.
According to Johan Göransson of the Forensic Medicine Agency, the results have been consistent over the past few months.
"We don't see much difference in the statistics of the past few months, the numbers are fairly constant," he told The Local magazine.
The high proportion of cases where the person was judged to be over 18 years old does not necessarily mean that the asylum seeker lied about his age.
In May, the agency published the results of 581 tests and said that there were 442 cases that "suggest that the person under investigation is 18 years or older".
When the newspaper Svenska Dagbladet examined the 581 published results, it found that in 243 of these cases the person had openly said that he or she would turn 18 this year.
The method of medical age assessment, in which x-rays of wisdom teeth and MRI images of knee joints are taken, which are then analysed by dentists and radiologists, has also been criticised in some areas.
One sceptic is the endocrinologist Claude Marcus of the Karolinska Institute, whose work involves assessing the biological maturity of people to see whether they went through puberty sooner or later than usual.
"I had reason to think about it, and I don't think that the type of measurement should be used.
To judge the biological age in this way is very uncertain.
If we can't say for sure, we shouldn't pretend that we can," he told Metro newspaper.
However, Göransson from the Forensic Medicine Agency defended the accuracy of the tests: "In general, you can say that the risk of judging a child incorrectly as an adult is low.
The greatest risk is when the person is just under 18, in which case it is about 10 percent."
Right on schedule
Work on the three bridges of the Landstraße 108 between Lauterbach and Schramberg is progressing well.
On Wednesday, a seven tonne concrete element was installed at the bridge at the eastern entrance to Lauterbach.
"We're very good on time, it's going great," says Reinhold Leicht, site manager at the Department of Roads and Traffic in the Freiburg Regional Council.
In April, work began simultaneously on all three bridges between Schramberg and Lauterbach in need of rehabilitation.
Construction is scheduled to end in October and Leicht is confident that the schedule will be met.
The first bridge, coming from Schramberg, leads over the Trombach.
It is a vaulted arch bridge made of concrete clad with red coloured sandstone and has a total length of 4.80 metres.
It was built in 1900.
Like the other two bridges, it is now getting on in years.
In order to ensure stability and traffic safety, the three structures are now being thoroughly renovated.
The other two bridges lead over the Lauterbach.
They are built of red mottled sandstone.
Both were built in 1939 and are twelve and 10.60 metres long respectively.
The bridge at the entrance to Lauterbach has now received a 1.30 metre wide and seven tonne heavy so-called bridge cap on the north side on Wednesday morning.
This is an edge fortification, which is also used as a service road.
A 2.20 meter wide bridge cap is to be installed on the southern part of the bridge on Friday.
The pedestrian walkway is then to run on it.
The special thing about it is that these are prefabricated parts, a patent of the Schramberg company Dizwo.
The other two bridges are already equipped with the patented bridge caps.
The laying of cables through the building in Lauterbach required particular sensitivity.
This is also where a fiber optic cable runs, to which many companies are connected.
The residents were informed about the project by leaflets in advance of the work.
In addition, fish and crabs had to be fished first.
For the bridges between the building yard building and the collecting pond in the direction of Schramberg, traffic is regulated by a single-lane traffic light.
For the construction work on the bridge at the entrance to Lauterbach, the road in the area of the bridge at the level of the hotels "Tannenhof" and "Sieben Linden" is completely closed.
The total cost of the three bridge renovations is EUR 700 000.
The whole thing is financed by the state.

Trombone meets trumpet
A reunion with the trombonist Frederic Belli from Wolfach will take place in the series Haslacher Klosterkonzerte tomorrow, Sunday, at 8pm in the monastery church.
Together with the Bulgarian trumpeter Miroslav Petkov he will give a concert with the motto "Black Sea meets Black Forest", or even "Balkan folklore" meets a classical German education with roots in brass music.
Both soloists are winners and prizewinners of numerous international competitions and hold solo positions in top European orchestras.
Petkov is principal trumpeter with the renowned Concertgebouw Orchestra Amsterdam and Frederic Belli is principal trombonist with the SWR Symphony Orchestra.
Both are united by the desire not only to cross the boundaries on their instruments, but also to merge the boundaries of different genres.
Thus Johann Sebastian Bach resounds with the two of them as if in a new guise, Daniel Schnyder's "World Music" combines with Bulgarian folklore, and in the piece "Exchange Suite" by jazz echo prizewinner Nils Wogram, classical music, jazz and free playing blend into a fascinating total work of art.
This core piece of the program was premiered only this spring in Freiburg with enormous success.
The renowned composer Nils Wogram wrote it especially for the two musicians, and even more: the Haslacher Klosterkirche with its special acoustics is deliberately included in the concert.

Coe praises "honest" Russian apology for doping scandal
The world's head of athletics, Sebastian Coe, on Thursday praised what he described as an obvious excuse from Russia for a doping scandal, but repeated that it was not the moment for the country to be reintroduced into sport.
Russia's head of athletics Dmitry Shylakhtin said during the IAAF Congress on the eve of the World Athletics Championships that the banishment of his country from sport was correct and that he was determined to fight doping.
He said he was sorry for "all athletes who were snatched away gold and silver medals in competitions".
Despite its comments, the IAAF Congress voted to maintain the ban, which was imposed in November 2015 after a report by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) found evidence of state-sponsored doping in Russia.
"I thought it was a very open response today, a very honest presentation," IAAF President Coe told reporters.
"The whole Council and the whole Congress were pleased that the Russian Federation has recognised in itself that it has experienced some rather hot times and will do everything possible to ensure that the Federation is reshaped".
Coe said he was also "pleased" that Russia accepted the criteria for his reinstatement.
"I think it was a very constructive day and I think progress has been made, but Congress supports the Task Force's recommendations that this is not the time to reinstate Russia," Coe said.
"Over the next few months, we must do everything we can to normalize this situation.
The guiding principle has always been to separate the clean athletes from the corrupt system," he added
Nineteen Russian athletes will compete as neutral players according to the strict IAAF criteria at the World Championships in Athletics, which begin on Friday in London.
The head of the IAAF task force, Rune Andersen, said on Monday that Russia still had to meet some of the criteria for reinstatement.
Drug testing is still insufficient and banned trainers are still free to operate, he told reporters in London after a presentation to the IAAF Council.
Mourning act for soldiers crashed in Mali
At a funeral service in Fritzlar, North Hesse, about 1000 people commemorated the two soldiers who died in a helicopter crash in Mali.
The ceremony took place on Thursday in the cathedral city under high security measures.
Defense Minister Ursula von der Leyen (CDU) did not comment on the still unexplained cause of the crash.
However, she described the two pilots who died as "experts in their field".
"We bow to this supreme sacrifice they have made on behalf of the Federal Republic of Germany," she declared.
The 33-year-old Major and the 47-year-old Chief of Staff from North Hesse had died in Mali, West Africa, a week ago Wednesday.
Their coffins were transferred to Germany and brought to St. Peter's Cathedral in Fritzlar on Thursday, accompanied by a wake of the German Armed Forces.
At noon only the relatives said goodbye in the church.
Afterwards, the funeral service began in the circle of family, closest friends, representatives of the Bundeswehr and politicians.
Among them were Hesse's Prime Minister Volker Bouffier (CDU) and the Inspector General of the German Armed Forces Volker Wieker.
Mourners laid down roses, the relatives stood arm in arm at the coffins.
In front of the church, Fritzlar citizens and numerous soldiers watched the ceremony on a screen.
Defense Minister von der Leyen described the killed soldiers as "highly decorated" and experienced in operations.
The Chief of Staff had helped to establish the flight operations of the Tiger combat helicopter in Fritzlar and was one of the first six trained Tiger pilots in his regiment.
Volker Bauersachs, commander of the regiment to which the soldiers belong, also declared: "If this crew was unable to avert the crash, no one would have been able to".
Minister von der Leyen did not express doubts about the UN mission in Mali: the mission was dangerous.
But it is also of great importance "for a country from which we are separated by only two states," she said.
After the funeral service the coffins were brought from the cathedral.
When and where they will be buried, the Bundeswehr did not provide any information on this.
Prince Henrik does not want a grave next to his wife
The husband of the Danish Queen Margrethe (77), Prince Henrik (83), does not want to be buried next to his wife after his death.
This was announced by the royal family on Thursday.
Traditionally, the Danish royal couple is buried in Roskilde Cathedral.
The sculptor Bjørn Nørgaard already made a sarcophagus for the two of them.
The queen agreed with the decision of her husband, the communication went on to say.
Where Prince Henrik will be buried is still unclear.
However, he had no intention of being buried in his French homeland.
Prince Henrik had never made a secret of the fact that he was not happy with his title.
After the accession of his wife Margrethe to the throne in 1972, he would have liked to become king.
In 2016 he retired and also took the title of "Prince Consort".
Since Henrik had not been given the title and function he wanted in Denmark, he did not consider himself equal to his wife - even after death, explained Lene Balleby, the chief spokeswoman of the Danish royal family.
It is still unclear where the final resting place of the 83-year-old will finally be.
However, he did not intend to be buried in his French homeland, but in Denmark.
He likes the country he's worked for the last 50 years.
Born Henri de Laborde de Monpezat, son of a French noble family, Margrethe had met Margrethe in London in 1965.
On the Thames he worked in the French embassy.
While his later wife always received the sympathy of the people, Prince Henrik had a difficult time with the Danes during his almost 50 years of reign.
In an autobiography Henrik said about the first years in Denmark: "A few months after my arrival, everything I did was criticised.
My Danish was fluctuating, I preferred wine instead of beer, silk stockings instead of knitted socks, Citroën instead of Volvo, tennis instead of football.
Even for the Gauloises, which I smoked instead of Virginia tobacco and which in this country had the reputation of being the brand of socially critical intellectuals, I could not hope for leniency.
I was different.
I seemed to be satisfied with this position and not ashamed.

CDU and FDP face possible majority in Lower Saxony
Following the loss of the red-green government majority, Lower Saxony's State Premier Stephan Weil (SPD) is in favour of a rapid re-election of the state parliament, but he does not want to resign.
On Friday, Weil spoke out in favour of dissolving Parliament.
Previously, the surprise departure of a Green member of parliament from her parliamentary group in Lower Saxony had plunged the government of Prime Minister Stephan Weil (SPD) into a serious crisis.
Five months before the official date of the state elections, the red-green coalition in Hanover thus lost its narrow one-vote majority in parliament to the opposition of CDU and FDP.
The former Green MEP Elke Twesten justified her move by stating that her constituency in Rotenburg (Wümme) had not been nominated for the 2018 elections.
"I see my political future in the CDU," she declared in Hanover on Friday.
CDU faction leader Björn Thümler wants to recommend his faction to include it.
This would give the CDU and FDP together 69 seats in Lower Saxony's state parliament, and the SPD and Greens 68 seats.
Until now, the ratio has been the opposite.
The new state parliament will be elected on 14 January next year.
Thümler said that the red-green state government must now decide whether it can continue to govern in this situation without a majority.
However, Stephan Weil considers it essential that the state parliament decide on its self-dissolution as quickly as possible.
The CDU faction is expected to decide on Tuesday on how to proceed.
The state constitution also provides for the possibility of the state parliament withdrawing its confidence in the prime minister and electing a successor.
"Our constitution offers several options.
These possibilities must be examined in a legally sound manner", said Thümler.
"All matters will be considered at their leisure when they have been properly and reasonably considered."
Thümler called Twesten's step "somewhat strange".
The politician herself stressed: "I am not a traitor.
I feel very good".
She called herself a follower of black and green.
The Greens called on the renegade member of parliament to return her parliamentary mandate.
"We naturally assume that she will return her parliamentary mandate, which she received via the green state list, with immediate effect," announced the state chairmen Meta Janssen-Kucz and Stefan Körner.
Green leader Anja Piel said: "We very much regret Elke Twesten's decision".
She had deliberately chosen not to have a debate in the group.
"Even against the background that there were no differences in content, we cannot understand this step."
SPD candidate for chancellor Martin Schulz condemns the transfer of Lower Saxony's Green Party member of parliament Elke Twesten to the CDU as a betrayal.
"The behaviour of the former Green members of parliament in Lower Saxony is not only a betrayal of the voters, but also a betrayal of Red-Green," the federal leader of the Social Democrats wrote on Facebook on Friday.
He supported the decision of Minister President Stephan Weil (SPD) to have the state parliament quickly re-elected.
The resignation of Twesten costs Red-Green the majority in Lower Saxony.
The politician, "in her injured vanity and frustration, puts her personal interests before the welfare of the country," criticized SPD Secretary General Hubertus Heil.
"It is a scandal that the CDU in Lower Saxony is taking part in this dirty intrigue and is trying to make political capital out of it".
Lower Saxony's CDU faction leader, Björn Thümler, wants to recommend his members of parliament to accept Elke Twesten into the CDU.
The leader of the SPD parliamentary group in the Bundestag, Thomas Oppermann, accused Twesten of distorting the results of the state elections in 2013 with personal career considerations.

Interview with the Minister of Agriculture - How do we protect ourselves from poisonous eggs, Mr Schmidt?
Germany discusses contaminated eggs.
How could the scandal happen?
How can consumers protect themselves.
Agriculture Minister Christian Schmidt (CSU) is interviewed by the RedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND).
Mr Schmidt, How can consumers protect themselves from poisoned eggs?
I can only encourage all consumers to take a close look at the eggs in your fridge and check the stamp imprint.
On the consumer protection portal www.Lebensmittelwarnung.de the federal states provide the latest information on the egg batches concerned.
Affected eggs should be destroyed or returned.
Even though, according to all we know at present, a health hazard is practically excluded.
Is Aldi now assuming the best possible crisis response - all eggs out of supply - because the central role of the reconnaissance agent is not really being fulfilled by the Federal Minister of Agriculture?
Food monitoring is the responsibility of the federal states.
Despite this, my house was immediately activated and has been in close contact with the authorities of the federal states since the German authorities became aware of Germany's affliction.
All information and the risk assessment is available to consumers.
Retailers, like manufacturers, must ensure that the products sold are marketable and harmless to health.
If the maximum residue level of 0,005mg/kg is exceeded for eggs, they are not fit for human consumption.
However, uncontaminated eggs may be sold and consumed.
This time it's not the companies' fault.
Are production companies and consumers in the same boat?
According to current knowledge, the production companies are not directly responsible.
Rather, they must expect to suffer economic damage due to alleged illegal practices by service providers.
As always, there are too few inspectors in case of emergency.
Is there a lack of personnel only or also of conclusive responsibility?
It was precisely the official controls that revealed the process.
However, it is also true that food fraud and criminal energy can never be 100 percent excluded.
Precisely for this reason, consistent clarification of such events and the handing over to public prosecutors in cases where criminal offences may have been committed are of crucial importance.
I have already made it clear on several occasions that I expect the responsible authorities to provide a complete explanation.
Is regular alarmism in food scandals really necessary?
Consumers have the right to receive only safe and marketable food.
When an unauthorised insecticide is used in the food industry, consumers are rightly outraged.
The adulterated product has put producers, traders and consumers in a situation that is absolutely unnecessary.
Basically it must be clear: The unlawful use of the insecticide fipronil in food producing animals is unacceptable and must be stopped immediately.
This must be worked on consistently and with high pressure at all levels.
I expect all responsible authorities to clarify the facts of the case quickly and completely.
How the financial rules of football affect Neymar's move to Paris
The rules, which are designed to prevent unfettered spending by European football clubs, will not interfere with Neymar's world record transfer from Barcelona in Spain to Paris-Saint Germain in France.
Some consequences are yet to come for Paris Saint-Germain of UEFA, as the governing body that oversees the European game has the power to ban teams from entering the prestigious Champions League tournament.
Financial fair play rules, which were introduced by UEFA in 2011, mean that PSG will at some point have to prove that the transfer from Neymar was financed without major losses.
Barcelona has paid 222 million euros ($262 million) to buy the Brazilian out of his contract, and Neymar will receive a salary that will be tens of millions of dollars a year.
Here are some of the financial aspects of Neymar's move to France.
PSG can certainly loosen the purse strings to get Neymar to sign and take him to a galaxy of other stars, given the team's funding by the energy-rich ruling family of Qatar.
Clubs are allowed to spend a lot of money on the acquisition of players, but must counteract this with legitimate sources of income that enable them to break even in their football related business.
FFP was conceived by Michel Platini after his election as UEFA President in 2007.
The former French player believed that clubs that had incurred enormous debts in their quest for success were effectively cheating and risked ruining themselves if banks or owners withdrew their support.
In 2011, FFP shifted from focusing on the clubs' debts to monitoring their losses.
The change meant that the business model Roman Abramovich originally used in Chelsea in 2003 - buying a club with potential and then investing heavily to improve the team and build a global brand - was to become a tougher proposition.
During the current three-year FFP investment period, which runs until 2018, clubs can incur losses of 30 million euros.
And although Platini has fallen from the presidency in 2015, his UEFA successor Aleksander Ceferin continues to work to discourage excessive spending.
"Certainly FFP is not dead and we will certainly strengthen the rules for the future," Andrea Traverso, UEFA's FFP manager, told The Associated Press last week.
Although PSG paid Neymar's buy-out clause in a lump sum, it can spread the amount for accounting purposes over the duration of his contract.
Neymar has signed a five-year contract so that the redemption sum of 44.4 million euros for the next five years can be shown in the annual accounts.
The first wave of FFP sanctions in 2014 hit PSG along with Abu Dhabi, which is owned by Manchester City, with the most severe sanctions.
The PSG was fined 60 million euros (82 million dollars at the time), which was later reduced to 20 million euros - and it was ordered that team members for the Champions League of the 2014/15 season be limited to 21 players instead of the otherwise normal 25 players.
UEFA is on the lookout for clubs that might try to outsmart its financial oversight by inflating their revenues through companies linked to the owners of a club.
While a Qatari company could sponsor the PSG if the value of the sponsorship were to exceed standard market rates, UEFA would not consider this as legitimate income.
This is exactly what happened in 2014 when UEFA decided that the value of the PSA's sponsorship was inflated by the Qatar Tourism Authority.
It was reported that part of the PSG payments to Neymar could come from payments by the Organising Committee of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.
But PSG and Qatar 2022 have denied that Neymar will become World Cup ambassador and such a manoeuvre might be easy for UEFA regulators to find out.
The sanctions imposed on PSG so far mean that UEFA will be even more vigilant in respecting any attempt to circumvent the rules.
UEFA did not have preparatory talks with PSG about Neymars transfer, said on Thursday people familiar with the situation.
They spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity, as they were not authorised to discuss the PSG situation.
The latest published reports show that PSG 2015/16 made a profit of more than 10 million euros with a turnover of 542.4 million euros.
The accounts for the last financial year still have to be published.
PSG expects Neymar's arrival to be a boon to sponsorship deals, merchandising and jersey sales.
The association assumes that the turnover will increase by at least 30 percent after the signing.
The Spanish league was clearly irritated to see one of the best football players go and they tried to prevent Neymar's departure by claiming that PSG would injure the FFP.
"It's a clear case of 'financial doping' with the club and the state," La Liga President Javier Tebas told the Spanish daily AS with regard to Qatar's ultimate ownership of PSG.
Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger, whose club is owned by an American sports tycoon, shares La Liga's reservations about a state financing a club.
"It is the consequence of ownership and this has completely changed the entire landscape of football over the last 15 years," Wenger said on Thursday.
"Once a country has a club, anything is possible.
It becomes very difficult to respect financial fair play because you go different ways or you can have different interests when a country has such a big player to represent a country".
Swiss is looking for a new chocolate supplier
In recent years, Chocolat Frey has produced board chocolate for Swiss.
Now the sweet cooperation is about to come to a possible end: the airline is putting the contract out to tender again.
At the request of the news agency sda, Swiss spokeswoman Meike Fuhlrott confirmed a corresponding report by the newspaper "Nordwestschweiz" on Friday.
According to current planning, the airline will conclude a new contract in the first half of 2018.
The products would be inspected every two to three years and subjected to quality control.
"We are very satisfied with our current supplier Chocolat Frey," said the spokeswoman.
Every year, the flight attendants distribute around 17 million small red and white chocolate bars weighing 14 grams to passengers before landing.
Swiss did not want to give any information about the costs.
Industry insiders estimate the order volume according to "Northwest Switzerland" at 1.5 to 2 million francs - the Migros subsidiary achieves an annual turnover of around one billion francs.
But the advertising effect is always more important: for a chocolate manufacturer it is a prestigious order.
Swiss does not want to reveal how many applicants there are in the new tender.
However, only Swiss manufacturers are eligible.
According to the newspaper report, Chocolat Frey intends to seek a renewal of the contract beyond spring 2018.
For the sda, the largest Swiss chocolate manufacturer was not available for a statement.
Swiss has been distributing chocolate bars on board its flights since 2006.
Before Swiss signed a contract with the Migros subsidiary, Barry Callebaut had delivered the chocolate trays in cooperation with Hug.
Swiss introduced the possibility of placing the logo two and a half years ago when it started its collaboration with Chocolat Frey.
The airline cooperates with various Swiss chocolate producers.
On long-haul flights, First Class customers will be treated to delicacies from Confiserie Sprüngli, while passengers in Business Class will be treated to chocolates from Lindt and those in Economy Class to chocolates from Chocolat Frey.
Swiss also distributes Chocolat Frey chocolates on short-haul flights, both in business and economy class.

Nostalgia goes in "Wet Hot American Summer" and "Comrade Detective"
This repetition of history is simultaneously nostalgic for the glorious days of the characters of the 1980s, for the 90s Grunge era (when masterminds David Wain and Michael Showalter shot the sketch comedy "The State" for MTV), and for themselves - that is, for 2001, before their stars, such as Elizabeth Banks, Amy Poehler and Paul Rudd, went on to bigger things.
As a cultural artifact, it is both a parody and an embodiment of our Facebook-enabled era of permanent memories.
But as a franchise, it feels like time is running out.
"First Day of Camp" worked surprisingly well, not only because of its absurd humor (it contained an original story for a talking can of vegetables spoken by H. Jon Benjamin).
By getting to the heart of the gag - middle-aged actors playing horny kids who are growing up - they still managed to win back the last part of the joke.
"Ten Years Later", with its adults now playing adults, is less emotionally rooted and its parody is more watering can, including a riff on the stalker movies of the 90s like "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle".
At one point, a character browses through an Apple powerbook, some inline skates, and "a bunch of other stuff from 1991.
Many of the central stories are the same.
The gracious Coop (Mr. Showalter), now a novelist, has still not forgotten Katie (Marguerite Moreau).
Victor (Ken Marino) has still not lost his virginity.
And there's another crazy-malicious plot involving Ronald Reagan (also Mr. Showalter), who is now supported by George H. W. Bush (a well done impression of Michael Ian Black).
As always the digressions are the best part of the franchise.
It's especially fun to see the eternally young Mr. Rudd showing Matt Dillon's lower lip beard from "Singles", whose former Big Man-on-Camp Andy now feels like an old fart.
It's the moments of random madness that could fuel this franchise like a kind of repetitive "Seven Up!" series until he reaches what I take to be his logical conclusion: "Wet Hot American Summer: Twenty Years Later", the last scene of which will show the gang visiting the movie premiere of "Wet Hot American Summer".
"Comrade Detective" on Amazon now recalls a different kind of nostalgia: the revival of the Cold War by "The Americans", the film "Atomic Blonde" and even "GLOW" with its East-West wrestling iconography.
The comedy created by Brian Gatewood and Alessandro Tanaka, with Rhys Thomas as director, claims to be a found TV series: a Romanian drama of the eighties with the two policemen as friends, two officers from Bucharest, who fight for truth, atheism and the path of Marxism-Leninism.
The leading roles - a hard-boiled Gregor and an idealistic Iosef - are played by Florin Piersic Jr. and Corneliu Ulici, whose dialogues are dubbed in English by Channing Tatum (also an executive producer) and Joseph Gordon-Levitt.
It's a brilliant idea.
But it's not much more than an idea.
There are some nice gags to watch (the police spend their time watching chess on TV, as Americans might do with football).
And the list of famous speakers - including Jenny Slate, Nick Offerman, Mahershala Ali and Chloë Sevigny - makes for a decent game of 'Find out the voice'.
But "Comrade Detective" is so committed to the truthfulness of a desperate propaganda drama - a murderer wearing a Reagan mask is involved - that it often plays like one.
With six long episodes it drags on and the comedy is not fast or frequent enough.
"Comrade Detective", which has been edited to a shorter length, could deliver its agitprop satire better, as Gregor and Iosef keep visiting the American embassy, whose lobby is always occupied by two fat men who gobble up a bunch of hamburgers.
The message for the imagined communist audience is that Western culture can make anything into fodder for a feast.
The fictional Romanian creators were not wrong: we even do it with our own recent history and theirs.
Strike against drug mafia in the country
The police have succeeded in striking a blow against the Italian Mafia in Baden-Wuerttemberg.
On Wednesday morning, numerous objects were searched in the Black Forest-Baar district, in Rottweil, Constance, Esslingen and Stuttgart, the Constance public prosecutor's office announced on Friday.
In the process, 15 accused persons aged between 25 and 77 years were arrested and warrants for their arrest have already been issued.
The officers also seized large quantities of marijuana and cocaine, firearms and several hundred thousand euros.
Two people were arrested during simultaneous raids in Italy.
German arrest warrants were issued for the two suspected Italians.
The two will therefore probably be extradited to Germany.
Italian and Bavarian investigators were involved in the operation.
A total of over 300 police officers were deployed.
Members of the mafia are accused of organised drug crime, serious acts of violence, attempted murder, robbery and extortion.
The Constance public prosecutor's office has been investigating organized drug trafficking in southern Germany since summer 2016.
There was a lively exchange between the public prosecutor's offices in Constance and Palermo and the investigators of the Rottweil CID had almost daily contact with their colleagues in Sicily.
For this reason, the major operation on Wednesday morning was also accompanied by four officials from Palermo.
The investigations focused primarily on Italian citizens with close links to the Italian mafia.
An incident in Hüfingen on 27 May, in which several shots were fired into a restaurant early in the morning, may also be attributable to the gang.
Weise complains about large gaps in the register of foreigners
"Data of citizens who should not appear there": According to a report, the register of foreigners in Germany shows considerable deficiencies.
This leads to sometimes serious mistakes in asylum procedures.
According to a media report, the Federal Commissioner for Refugee Management, Frank-Jürgen Weise, has drawn attention to large gaps in the Central Register of Foreigners.
According to an analysis in the newspaper "Süddeutsche Zeitung", deficiencies in the data registered there could lead to "in part serious mistakes" in asylum procedures and deportations.
According to the register, ten million people with foreign citizenship are recorded, including about 5.7 million from non-EU countries.
According to this, the data is administered by about 600 immigration authorities in Germany.
Because the data had not been sufficiently maintained, the data quality had not been good in parts.
In individual cases, data from 1921 had been found, "of people who have long since ceased to be alive, or of citizens who have become German citizens and who should actually no longer appear in the register".
"Incorrect data entries can significantly slow down return processes," the report continues.
Moreover, the statistics on people who are obliged to leave the country include EU citizens who do not have to leave at all.
However, such incorrect classifications "led to a distorted debate on how to deal with those who were obliged to leave the country", according to the analysis.
Meanwhile, the federal government has apparently begun to send back to Italy refugee families with children under 16 years of age, if they have entered from there.
According to the newspaper "Neue Osnabrücker Zeitung", this is the result of an internal paper of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
According to the paper, the BAMF is to conduct such procedures "concerning families with children - with the exception of infants and small children - to Italy again since 1 June 2017".
Since the end of 2014, this has been practically impossible, the newspaper said, referring to the difficult situation on the ground.
According to the Dublin Convention, refugees are responsible for the EU state which they reach first.
When a migrant travels on to another EU country, that country can send him or her back to the country of entry.
The Office now writes: "In the meantime, the reception capacity for families with underage children in Italy has increased considerably".
Italy has provided guarantees for the reception and accommodation of families.
Even the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) considers these commitments to be sufficient.
Other EU states would also send refugees back there under the Dublin Convention.
Ulla Jelpke, spokeswoman for domestic policy of the Left parliamentary group in the Bundestag, has criticised this decision: "Families with children are threatened with reception conditions contrary to human rights and a threat to the welfare of the child due to the deficiencies of the Italian asylum system".

The Bank of England will keep interest rates at 0.25%.
The Bank of England is expected to announce later that interest rates will remain unchanged after weak economic growth and weakening inflation dampened speculation about a rise.
The Bank of England has warned that economic growth will remain "sluggish" as it maintained interest rates on family incomes in the midst of mounting pressure.
Policymakers on the Bank's Monetary Committee (MPC) voted 6 to 2 to keep interest rates at 0.25%, with fewer members aiming for an increase this month as weak economic growth weakened support for an increase.
In its quarterly inflation report, the bank reduced its growth forecasts for 2017 to 1.7% and for 2018 to 1.6% and warned that pressure on household incomes would continue, with inflation expected to rise to just under 3% in the autumn.
But she signalled that interest rate hikes would be necessary in the coming years to curb the inflation fueled by the brexite and said that the cost of borrowing may have to rise more than expected in the financial markets.
The members also voted to withdraw part of the mammoth economic stimulus package issued a year ago after the brexite.
It will demand time for the funding plan to provide cheaper funding for banks from next February, although it has been said that it is now expected to provide £15 billion more under the scheme - with £115 billion sterling.
Minutes after the decision on the interest rate, the bank said: "In MPC's central forecast, gross domestic product (GDP) remains weak in the short term, as pressure on real household incomes continues to weigh on consumption.
On interest rates, she reiterated that "some tightening of monetary policy" would be necessary to cool down inflation and "somewhat more" than the markets expect.
The markets are currently forecasting the first increase in the third quarter of next year and another one in 2020.
However, the Bank stressed that increases would be "gradual" and "limited".
The Bank's growth forecasts for this and next year, which have been revised downwards, compare with the 1.9% and 1.7% forecast in May.
It has maintained its growth forecast of 1.8% in 2018.
The pound fell against the dollar and the euro after this news.
The pound sterling fell by 0.5% to USD 1.31 and dropped by 0.4% to EUR 1.11.
The decision to leave it unchanged comes after recent disappointing growth figures have dampened rising expectations of an interest rate hike and GDP rose to 0.3% in the second quarter from 0.2% in the previous three months.
Growth is expected to be 0.3% in the third quarter, although the Bank expects it to recover slightly towards the end of the year.
The latest inflation report offered little enthusiasm for households affected by rising inflation and small pay rises, as the tightening will first get worse before it will improve.
She added that monetary policy cannot "prevent" the collapse of incomes in the next few years, but she added that wages will recover "significantly" at the end of her three-year forecast.
The economy is also being strengthened by the rising demand for British goods, due to the weak pound, which will compensate for part of the lower consumer spending.
The decision comes a year after interest rates were cut to 0.25% last August following the shocking EU vote that caused the pound to fall.
The Bank estimates that it will probably take four years for this to fully reach prices and the economy.
Before the Bank's latest ruling on interest rates, calls for a rate hike had risen as inflation increased pressure on hard-pressed households, with three policymakers calling for a rise to 0.5% in July.

NHS (The National Health Service) to prescribe controversial HIV drug to 10,000 people
Patients will have access to "transformative" HIV prevention treatment from September onwards, following a battle in the High Court against the funding of the drug in the NHS.
NHS England announced that pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) taken before sexual intercourse, which can reduce the risk of infection in high-risk patients by about 86 percent, is now being delivered by the health service through an initial three-year study for an estimated 10,000 people.
He agreed to fund the process after the Court of Appeal upheld a Supreme Court ruling last year that the NHS had the power to pay for the PrEP despite the claim that local authorities should fund it.
The move announced on Thursday was welcomed by NHS England Chief Simon Stevens as "an important new intervention", while the National Aids Trust (NAT) described it as "a decisive moment".
Sexual health clinics in London, Brighton, Manchester, Liverpool and Sheffield will be among the first to register people, and more clinics will follow in October before it is rolled out across England in April 2018.
Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a series of HIV preparations taken before sex to reduce the risk of HIV infection.
Studies have shown that PrEP significantly reduces HIV transmission among those at risk of infection.
Taking PrEP before sexual intercourse means that there is just enough medication in a person's body to prevent HIV infection.
Such drugs can be taken every day or so two hours before sexual intercourse.
Those eligible for treatment include gay or bisexual men, transsexual men, and those with HIV-positive partners who have not been successfully treated.
Clinics will identify suitable participants who agree to participate in the study, including men, women, transgenders and individuals who have a partner whose HIV status is not known to be controlled by antiretroviral treatment.
People who live in England and are registered with a family doctor can also register for possible participation in their local participating sex clinic.
The programme will cost £10 million and NHS England signed a contract to supply the drugs this week following an international competitive procurement.
The study is designed to assess the full potential of PrEP by collecting clinical evidence as it is targeted, absorbed and implemented on a large scale.
Stevens said: "This major new intervention should complement and overtake the far-reaching and increasingly successful efforts to prevent HIV.
It is another milestone in the more than three decades of sustained progress in addressing one of the greatest health challenges facing humanity".
Deborah Gold, Chief Executive at NAT (National Aids Trust), said: "This is a defining moment in the fight against HIV.
PrEP, when targeted at needy and vulnerable people, offers the opportunity to change the English HIV epidemic.
From September onwards, people at high risk of HIV will have access to this NHS-funded trial in England to develop a new tool that is truly individually controlled and not subject to negotiation with a partner, leading to the improvement of many, many lives.
We warmly welcome this announcement."
Ian Green, Chairman of the Terrence Higgins Trust, said: "The priority now must be to ensure that the study is carried out quickly across the country and that no one at risk of HIV is left behind.
Now that the PrEP test medicine has been procured, we are well on the way to protecting more than 10,000 HIV-infected people".
Sharon Hodgson, Shadow Health Secretary, said: "The start of the PrEP process is welcome and overdue after months of delays and hesitant implementation by the government.
The evidence shows how transformative this drug can be as part of our approach to HIV prevention and can end the transmission of this life-changing infection.
This trial brings us one step closer to understanding the benefits of PrEP.
Now it is important that this study is carried out across the country as soon as possible to protect people who are HIV-infected and that it will help bring us a step closer to ending the spread of HIV in society'.
Living the big life: Mezzanine floor and clever designer tricks have turned this small Earls Court apartment into a spacious home
Joanne Leigh, a former banker with a passion for real estate, downsized in 2014 from a large house in Knightsbridge to an Earls Court apartment.
It is located on the first floor of an elegant Queen Anne terrace - and it is proof of the new design that Joanne did not pack and sell her bags.
"Before that, I lived in a much bigger room in Knightsbridge with my ex," Joanne says.
"I was looking for something that could compare to my price.
I was shown this apartment in Earls Court, and it had the same high ceilings.
I fell in love with her and made an offer that day."
Since the first inspection, the 1,000 square foot apartment has been completely overhauled.
Originally a one bedroom property with a nested layout - you had to go through the kitchen to get to the bedroom - Joanne wanted to add storage space and a mezzanine to make the most of the generous ceiling height.
"I wanted high ceilings, big windows, lots of light.
That was my requirement," she says.
To this end she commissioned the architecture and design studio Duck & Shed of Erfan Azadi of Notting Hill to use the 12.5 foot high ceilings to create a home that was not only a development but also a place to live for Joanne.
The ceiling was not large enough to place two rooms on top of each other, so the architectural challenge was to create a mezzanine floor in which one could stand.
Erfan had to think creatively to solve the problem.
"The steelworks is quite complicated," he explains.
"We had to arrange the rooms so that they were stacked on top of each other without having to bend down.
It was not just a matter of building a simple platform, but of placing the steel at the right height for the function at the top or bottom".
This arrangement enabled Erfan to place two rooms on top of each other at full height - with much additional drama.
For the mezzanine floor, a classic copper light window from Retrouvius looks down over the glamorous living area.
Mirrored gold furniture, silver accents and vintage Serge Mouille lighting set the style for the range.
The use of mirrors plays a role in adding theatre, space and light.
A short corridor is mirrored at both ends to make it look longer.
In the kitchen, the reflection feels like a window into another room.
At the entrance, mirrored units provide space for all of Joanne's cutlery and glasses.
By perceiving a more glamorous space, the beauty of the living room can close off the kitchen when it is not in use.
Collapsible kitchens are nothing new.
The special thing about this one is that it is a garage door.
"A bit of engineering went into it," explains Erfan of the steel-reinforced, veneered MDF door.
"It's counterweighted so that when you push up the door, it slides very easily."
Thanks to the clever use of space and storage, Joanne was able to gain an additional 16m², an extra bedroom and an improved layout.
"At the end of the day you will sell the floor space - or how your property is valued," says Erfan.
"In a rudimentary form, a real estate agent will enter and make a calculation based on the size of the floor."
Here they have managed to increase the floor area and at the same time use high-quality materials that give the room its luxurious advantage.
"The materials are the things you touch and therefore help to create an emotional bond in a home," says Erfan.
"You don't fall in love with the electric sockets in the walls.
These are important, but they don't play with your heart."
It shows that good design and increased square metres can transform a flat from something standard into something quite amazing.
In fact, like Joanne, you might decide not to leave them.
Brothers fighting over a $500 million real estate empire
Four decades after their Italian family founded the dynasty, two brothers find themselves in a dispute over one of Victoria's largest real estate empires, worth over $500 million.
The former director of the 'Carlton Football Club' and developer Colin De Lutis lives in a villa in Toorak, just three doors away from his younger brother Paul. The latter took him to the Supreme Court to clarify how their property and business assets should be divided.
Paul had wanted to retire from the family business since 2014, but a sharp dispute over the separation is taking place in the Supreme Court.
Together with their mother Anna, the brothers own 38 properties valued at more than half a billion dollars, accumulated since the family bought a business on Smith Street, Collingwood in 1973.
There the Westco Jeans family founded Jeans and grew to a chain of 160 retail stores.
It was sold in 1999 for USD 85 million.
This money was invested in real estate and De Lutis' portfolio now includes downtown offices, the Brunswick and Sorrento development areas, the Gold Coast and Mt Buller apartments and suburban shopping centres.
Under an agreement with her late father, Colin - described by Paul as the "main operator and the dominant figure" in the De Lutis family - owns about two thirds of the company's assets and Paul about one third.
A court record states that this means that Colin owns property valued at $316 million and Paul owns property valued at $176 million.
The division of property and cash has proven to be a problem for Paul.
"The divisions proposed by Colin left him with what I thought were the best objects," he wrote in a first affidavit in 2015.
Last Friday the first hearing of the Supreme Court took place after several failed mediations.
The brothers are now also fighting for control of the existing business - from which, as Paul claims, Colin has excluded him.
Colin argues that this is not true, but accuses Paul of managing some properties incompetently.
In an early affidavit submitted by Colin, he says he hopes to settle the dispute.
"My Italian heritage dictates that family is the most important priority," he wrote.
Costs are rising in this case, with hundreds of pages of affidavits, e-mails and reports from companies including Deloitte, Pitcher Partners and Charter Keck Cramer, and leading lawyers including Allan Myers, QC, and mutually owned law firms.
Mrs. De Lutis and her late husband Luigi were Italian immigrants who ran milk bars and delicatessens from the late 1950s and bought a shop in Brunswick in the early 1970s.
They used the security to buy the Collingwood property where Colin opened the family's first jeans store.
Colin says he started Westco there when he was "in my last years of high school when Paul was a little kid (about 10 years old)."
Anna De Lutis says that she and Luigi, who died in 2012, hoped to pass on their property amicably to their sons.
"Luigi often said to me that he never wanted the brothers to end up in court," she wrote.
Two other brothers, Mark and Luke, are no longer part of the De Lutis group of companies, with Colin claiming that Mark was paid $10 million and Luke $26 million when he left the company.
Both Luke and Mark, says Paul, "have become bitter about the terms of their financial separation.
Colin was very reluctant to get involved, despite being a former AFL board member and the TV star's best friend according to a 2015 biography of Eddie McGuire.
Fairfax Media contacted Colin and Paul De Lutis and their lawyers.
Only Colin replied by SMS to say "I really can't say much" because the case was in the courts.
"It is very, very sad that my brother Paul has decided to sue me and drag our family name through the courts," he wrote.
In mid-2016, Colin wrote a letter to the court saying that he had tried to meet his brother's demands.
"Our father would not have wanted Paul and I to end in our current quarrel," he said, adding that he "still hopes for a solution.
By Friday, that hope seemed to be gone.
"Our matter will be settled by the courts in the near future," Colin wrote.
Trump's new chief of staff plans to curtail the president's media-abstinence.
Others have tried and failed.
Maybe John F. Kelly can actually do it.
If so, he'll be the first.
Politico reports that the new White House chief of staff plans to restrict the flow of information to President Trump - including news media reports - in the hope of keeping the chief on a more even keel.
Here's a piece by reporter Josh Dawsey:
"When John F. Kelly, the new White House Chief of Staff, met with senior officials on his first day on the job, he identified a major problem in President Donald Trump's White House that he wanted to fix: bad information falling into the hands of the President.
Kelly told staff that information should flow through him - whether on paper or in briefings - because the president would make better decisions if he had good information."
Kelly's diagnosis makes sense, but others have tried to tame Trump by monitoring his media diet.
President Trump's relationship with television goes back decades - and now that he is in the White House, his television advertising is still strong.
"If Candidate Trump was upset about unfair reporting, it was productive to show him that he was getting fair reporting from jobs that were persuasive," former campaign consultant Sam Nunberg told Politico in February.
Politico's Tara Palmeri wrote at the time that "the key to keeping Trump's Twitter habit under control, according to six former campaign officials, is to ensure that his personal media consumption includes constant praise.
Okay.
But the idea that Trump's Twitter habit was ever "under control" is ridiculous.
Maybe these campaign officials know something the rest of us don't - that without their intervention, Trump's tweets would have been even more explosive.
We'll probably never know about the tweets Trump didn't send.
If his employees have managed to keep him out of trouble several times, their efforts have been worthwhile.
But no one has been able to consistently prevent Trump from causing controversy.
Part of the problem is that in a White House composed of competing parties, people keep trying to advance their own agenda by presenting Trump material that may advance their views of the world.
Politico - completely preoccupied with this story - reported in May about the preference of the advisors to provide the president with dubious information for strategic reasons.
This was an example described by reporter Shane Goldmacher:
"Current and former Trump officials say that Trump can react like a volcano to negative press clippings, especially those with damaging leaks, and that he is obsessed with finding out where they came from.
This is exactly what happened in late February when someone maliciously gave the president a printed copy of an article from GotNews.com, the website of Internet provocateur Charles C. Johnson, which accused Deputy Chief of Staff Katie Walsh of being "the source behind a bunch of leaks" at the White House.
Although Johnson has been permanently banned from Twitter for harassment, or that he has not offered any concrete evidence, or that he has made false accusations in the past and revoked them.
Trump read the article and started interviewing employees about Walsh."
Goldmacher added that then Chief of Staff Reince Priebus and White House Secretary General Rob Porter "tried to implement a system to manage and document the paperwork that Trump receives.
How'd that work out?
Kelly tries to do the same thing three months later.
Perhaps he will prove to be a more effective manager than Priebus, but Trump is still his impulsive self, and his advisors still seek influence.
These unchanging factors make Kelly's mission very difficult.
