Birkenhof becomes Waldhotel Luise
The former Hotel Birkenhof becomes the Waldhotel Luise.
The house at the gates of Freudenstadt is currently being renovated and is scheduled to reopen on 1 March next year.
It's good news for the city.
The closure of the Hotel Birkenhof by the former Ambiente Betriebsgesellschaft mbH on 13 April 2014 meant that around 30,000 overnight stays per year were lost at the time, as well as income from visitor tax.
In autumn 2014, in view of the dramatically increasing number of refugees coming to the district, the hotel building was offered to the district office as collective accommodation, which caused controversial discussions.
The city prevented the accommodation of asylum seekers by drawing up a development plan to secure the area as a hotel location.
The decision was not uncontroversial in the local council at the time.
But above all Freudenstadt's Lord Mayor Julian Osswald defended the hotel location and spoke even then of serious interest in the house.
He should be right.
The Luisenhotels Group with Managing Director Birgit Scherer, based in Bad Bergzabern, acquired the former Hotel Birkenhof at a voluntary auction in Berlin and wants to turn it back into a three-star-plus hotel under the name Waldhotel Luise.
The group has four houses with the Freudenstadt property.
Two of them in Bad Bergzabern and one in Bad Herrenalb.
They are called Hotel Luise, Luisenpark, Parkhotel Luise and now Waldhotel Luise.
At the former Hotel Birkenhof, rubble containers have been standing in front of the entrance for a long time, and when you enter the house, it becomes clear what extensive renovation work is being done.
The floors were torn out, ceilings were partially removed, old bathtubs were removed from the rooms.
The entire hotel building is a single construction site.
There is still a lot to be done before March.
"It's actually a nice hotel," says Thomas Scherer in an interview with our newspaper.
Everything is to be renovated in the Black Forest style.
The rooms will be equipped with large walk-in showers, the entrance area will be redesigned, new windows will be installed.
Everything should later become "nice and close to the people", as Thomas Scherer puts it.
"Let's make a jewel out of it."
Swimming pool, wellness area and a conference room are part of the facilities.
They do not want to position themselves at the high level of the hotels in Lauterbad, but already at a high level in the city centre, emphasises Scherer.
The Waldhotel Luise with its 60 or so rooms wants to be broadly spread, Scherer explains further.
Individual holidaymakers, groups or business people should feel comfortable in the hotel.
According to Scherer, he has already had talks with Mayor Julian Osswald and Tourism Director Michael Krause.
The ideas of the city are congruent with those of the hotel group.
"We're on the same page."
Asked about the amount of investment, Thomas Scherer does not want to commit himself precisely.
Just under one million euros, he reckons.
The outside facilities are also being brought up to scratch, which is already clearly visible.
In an inner courtyard, a large terrace will be created, which will be accessible from the restaurant, which is open to the public.
Thomas Scherer is optimistic: "Freudenstadt is a good market".
Russia affair: US special investigator appoints grand jury
In the Russia affair surrounding US President Donald Trump, special investigator Robert Mueller is said to have appointed a so-called grand jury, according to a report.
The committee had started work in the past few weeks, wrote the "Wall Street Journal", citing persons familiar with the matter.
The newspaper interpreted the move as a sign that Mueller had expanded and intensified his investigations.
CNN reported that there have already been first summonses from the panel in connection with a meeting between Trump's eldest son and a Russian lawyer.
US secret services have long accused the Kremlin of having deliberately interfered in the 2016 presidential election campaign.
Mueller is investigating whether there was collusion between Trump's campaign team and Moscow.
The investigation is to focus on several men who acted as advisors to the Republican during the election campaign.
Mueller also reportedly took a closer look at Trump's private and business environment.
The "Washington Post" wrote a few weeks ago that special investigator Trump had personally taken centre stage and was investigating allegations that the president may have obstructed justice in the course of the affair.
The main task of grand juries is to examine available evidence in possible criminal cases and to decide whether charges should be brought.
Grand juries are therefore also called prosecution chambers.
They are usually called in when there are major and controversial cases.
The procedure always takes place behind closed doors.
The panel can also be called in by the public prosecutor's office to summon persons for questioning under oath.
According to CNN, subpoenas have already been issued in connection with the meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer.
Persons involved in the meeting had been asked to testify, the report said.
They should also provide documents.
In addition to Trump Jr., Trump's advisor and son-in-law Jared Kushner and his then campaign manager Paul Manafort were also present at the meeting.
Legal experts said on Thursday evening on US television that the appointment showed that Mueller was not intimidated in his work and that he would act quickly if necessary.
However, it does not necessarily mean that the grand jury will be called in at the end to decide whether to bring charges.
Nevertheless, the establishment of the panel was the beginning of a new phase in the investigations and a new source of concern for President Trump.
Amidst the new revelations, the president used a speech in West Virginia on Thursday evening to portray the Russia affair as a campaign by his political opponents.
"The Russia story is a total fabrication," Trump said.
The topic, he said, gives the Democrats a chance to "feel good because they have nothing else to talk about.
His special adviser Ty Cobb stated in a statement that he was not aware of the appointment of a grand jury.
However, he emphasized that this also usually works in secret.
The White House supports any measures that would speed up the work of the special investigator in a "fair" way.
The former head of the FBI, James Comey, said three times that the president was not under investigation.
There was no reason to assume that this had changed, the statement went on to say.
But Mueller wasn't appointed until after Trump Comey fired.
Because of this expulsion, accusations had been made against Trump that he had wanted to obstruct justice.
Comey testified before a Senate committee in June that Trump had asked him to drop the investigation against then national security adviser Michael Flynn.
The president is under a lot of pressure with the investigation.
According to US media, the White House collected material against the special investigator and his associates.
This sparked speculation about whether Trump was going to fire Mueller.
Unlike an independent special congressional investigator, such as in the Watergate affair surrounding the later resigned President Richard Nixon, Mueller has a position in which he could theoretically be fired by the Justice Department at the President's urging.
However, several senators from both parties want to prevent such a step.
Two groups of Republican and Democratic senators presented bills on Thursday under which the special investigator could no longer be dismissed so easily.
Antarctica: Gigantic iceberg drifts in the Antarctic
In West Antarctica, a gigantic iceberg almost seven times the size of Berlin has detached itself from the ice shelf.
This was announced by the Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research in Bremerhaven on Wednesday.
The colossus, which weighs over a trillion tons and covers 5800 square kilometres, is now drifting north and will probably take two or three years to melt.
With a length of 175 kilometres and a width of up to 50 kilometres, it is one of the largest ice giants recorded by researchers in the past three decades.
He is not a danger to people.
The extent to which climate change has played a role in breaking up the iceberg is unclear, according to researchers.
Overall, however, there has been a series of unusual collapses of ice shelves in the region for around 30 years, writes the US Research Center for Snow and Ice (NSIDC) in a factual background.
According to many researchers, this could be related to global warming.
The now broken off colossus was previously part of the Larsen C Ice Shelf.
Ice shelves float on the sea and are fed by large glaciers.
It thus grows further and further into the sea and breaks off regularly.
The Larsen C Ice Shelf lies south of South America almost at the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula.
North of this ice shelf the balance of growth and break-up was disturbed a few years ago.
A complete ice shelf has collapsed there, writes AWI researcher Daniela Jansen.
There is a good reason to believe that the Larsen C Ice Shelf is also in danger, as the leading edge has never retreated as far as it has now.
In addition, the ice plate is under tension and can disintegrate if a piece breaks off at a key point.
The melting of ice shelves and icebergs does not raise sea levels because they float on the water and ice displaces as much water as it produces after melting itself.
However, the loss of the ice shelf means that the glaciers flow directly into the sea and can drain much faster than before.
This could possibly raise the sea level, but only to a small extent, writes the British research project for observing the Antarctic (Midas).
According to AWI, the Larsen C Ice Shelf is the fourth largest ice shelf in Antarctica, covering almost 50,000 square kilometres.
At the transition from the mainland it is up to 700 meters thick, at the leading edge to the open ocean about 200 meters.
There it breaks off regularly.
"Although it is a natural occurrence and we are not aware of any direct link to climate change, the ice sheet is now coming into a more vulnerable position," said Martin O'Leary of Swansea University in the UK.
"This is the furthest retreat since records began," he also confirmed.
Scientists are divided on whether the Larsen C Ice Shelf will grow again or whether it will recede and possibly collapse in the long term, said his colleague Adrian Luckman, adding: "Our models say it will be less stable".
But this development will take decades.
Even if these researchers do not attribute the disintegration of this gigantic iceberg to climate change, a great many ice shelves on the Antarctic Peninsula have disintegrated in recent decades.
This long tip of the Antarctic extends towards South America.
According to data from the British Antarctic Survey, the ice surface of the Antarctic Peninsula has decreased by 28,000 square kilometres since the 1950s.
The rise in temperature had contributed to the decline.
The Antarctic Peninsula has warmed up by around three degrees in the past 50 years, making it one of the areas where the temperature is rising fastest.
CDU wants house tariff for personnel
Because it is becoming more and more difficult to fill vacant positions, the CDU is calling for resignation from the employers' association in order to become more attractive.
Only shortly before the summer break, the district council waved through 41 new jobs in the administration.
More than 1100 employees and civil servants work for the district administration in Mettmann.
Now another 17 trainees have completed their first day at work.
Apprenticeships with the district are apparently in great demand.
Around 620 applications were received for the places to be awarded this year.
Nevertheless, the group still lacks personnel to cope with the increased demands and tasks.
At present there are still 50 vacant positions in the Mettmann district.
Among others, doctors and engineers as well as general administrative staff are being sought.
The CDU would now like to take the initiative in the district council together with the FDP and the UWG to counteract the lack of skilled workers in the administration.
According to the parties, the administration should "develop a concept for personnel recruitment and personnel development".
The aim is not only to cover short-term demand for skilled workers, but also to counteract the shortage of applicants in a future-oriented manner, it is said.
CDU, FDP and UWG demand that the overall concept should be internally and externally oriented, show concrete measures for career changers and include a training offensive.
That sounds like a good approach.
Because the circle has to deal with personnel problems that were not known in the past.
Other cities recruit good officials and employees and offer more attractive conditions.
There is talk of a real "competition among public employers".
In addition, there is a high number of employees who leave the service due to illness or age.
It is therefore high time for action, so that no more positions remain unfilled.
But Klaus-Dieter Völker, head of the CDU parliamentary group, and his party are going beyond the joint motion.
He recently caused a big surprise in the district council when he publicly questioned the personnel cost ceiling and astounded the other parties.
Völker would like to see all possibilities for leaving the municipal employers' association reviewed.
"If we cannot find a satisfactory solution here in the short term, the district administration should work with the trade unions - perhaps also in cooperation with the towns and cities belonging to the district - to reach an in-house tariff," said Völker.
With this, the CDU is trying to pay employees and civil servants better than the collective bargaining regulations for the public sector actually provide.
The salaries are currently prescribed exactly, increases or more money are only available if you change to a higher level based on years of service.
However, the tasks of the district have grown more and more in recent years.
Only a few weeks ago, new rooms had to be set up in which employees take care of the provisions of the new Prostitute Protection Act.
Not least because of the increasing number of asylum seekers, District Administrator Thomas Hendele and District Director Martin Richter have a problem: they have too few personnel.
Italy tightens the tone on NGO migrant lifeboats
Italy has warned NGOs using lifeboats for migrants in the Mediterranean that they must not continue to do so unless they comply with new rules for their operations.
"If NGOs do not sign a new code of conduct, it is difficult to see how they can continue to work," said Interior Minister Marco Minniti in an interview with the Turin daily La Stampa.
Minniti's warning came the day after the Italian authorities seized a boat belonging to the German aid organisation 'Jugend Rettet' because its crew had effectively worked with traffickers in a way that facilitated illegal immigration.
The aid organisation, which has only been operating for a year, refused to comment on detailed allegations by the Italian public prosecutor Ambrogio Cartosio.
"For us, saving human life is and remains our top priority. So we are very sorry that we cannot operate in the search and rescue zone at the moment," the organization said in a statement to the social media.
"We can only evaluate all the allegations currently being made after we have gathered all the information and can assess the situation."
The Italian authorities had been monitoring the boat of 'Jugend Rettet', the Iuventa, since October.
It is believed that its crew takes on board inflatable migrants delivered directly to them by traffickers and that the smugglers can leave so that the boats can be used again.
At least one such meeting allegedly took place only 1.3 miles off the Libyan coast, according to the prosecutor's file, the content of which was published by Italian media.
The crew is suspected of disregarding the authority of the Italian Coast Guard, which monitors rescue operations in the zone for humanitarian reasons and not for any other motives.
Under the Code of Conduct, boats like the Iuventa must have an Italian police officer on board to monitor their activities.
Only three of the nine NGOs involved in search and rescue operations have so far agreed to comply with the Code: Save the Children, MOAS from Malta and Pro-Activa Open Arms from Spain
The latter said on Thursday that the new rules were considered unnecessary, but acceptable, as they would not "significantly alter or impede" their rescue operations.
Among those who refuse to sign is the Nobel Laureate organisation Doctors without Borders (MSF).
Meanwhile, Minniti said that the number of migrants arriving in Italy following the rescue operations had fallen sharply in recent weeks, indicating that efforts to strengthen the Libyan coast guard and cooperation with local mayors had borne fruit.
"In the last few days we have begun to see light at the end of the tunnel," said the minister.
He announced plans for further talks with Libyan mayors this month on economic development initiatives and with Chad, Niger and Mali on measures to reduce the number of migrants leaving these countries in the hope of reaching Europe.

For this purpose, three friendly guides were available.

The castle and wine festival of Wachenheim was a welcome extra.

This was followed by lookout points, some on towers, from which one could look far over the Palatinate Forest and the plains in front of it.
In between there were always longer climbs, for which long trials were rewarded.
On the second day we went to Bad Dürkheim to the saltworks and the sausage market fair.

Console instead of turf - Bundesliga gears up for e-sports
Will the sports stars sit in front of computer consoles in the future instead of battling the stadium turf in wind and weather, all sweaty?
The fact is that e-sports have long since become a serious industry, a lucrative business - including big stars, millions of fans and huge tournaments with high fees.
The first Bundesliga clubs, which are becoming increasingly involved in this area, have also recognised this.
VfL Wolfsburg made a start in 2015, followed by FC Schalke 04 and finally VfB Stuttgart, who founded an e-sports department in mid-July and signed two professionals for the computer game FIFA 17.
"We hope that this will inspire completely new young target groups for VfB," says board member Jochen Röttgermann.
He is sure "that a number of other clubs will get on this train".
Next weekend, the world football association FIFA is organising the first "Interactive Club World Cup" in London, in which gamers from different clubs will compete against each other.
In addition to Schalke and Wolfsburg, Manchester City, Paris Saint-Germain and PSV Eindhoven have qualified.
Robin Dutt also sees great potential in e-sports.
The former coach of Bayer Leverkusen and Werder Bremen now advises an agency for virtual soccer players.
"Real football has to deal with the 14 to 30-year-olds in particular, so that young people will still go to the stadium in the future," says the 52-year-old.
And: The clubs tried to conquer all possible markets, especially the Asian ones.
With prominent e-sportsmen and women under contract, one could be present online in these markets far more often than just sending the Bundesliga team to Asia once a year.
What is it about exactly?
In e-sports, computer games such as "League Of Legends", "Dota 2", "Counterstrike" or the football simulation FIFA are fought out at competition level.
As in normal sport, leagues have long since been established in which the professionals compete against each other.
And at the 2022 Asian Games, e-sports are already part of the official programme.
But is it a real sport at all?
For many people, the idea is probably something that takes getting used to.
Ingo Froböse has also dealt with the question for a long time.
For the professor at the German Sport University in Cologne, e-sports is a sport because it is competitive and shows many biological and physical reactions that are also found in classical sport - for example increased heart rates, stress reactions, hormonal changes.
In addition, cognitive skills, technical and tactical understanding and the ability to react quickly are required.
Professional gamers should not only train at the console, but also train their body and pay attention to their diet.
"The fit player is a good player."
But Froböse also sees problems: "Doping is becoming more and more an issue".
Controls are difficult to implement in online games, and the scene lacks the structures of classic sport.
The scientist positively emphasizes the high integrative effect of e-sports.
The players travel internationally, it's like one big global family, there are no intercultural barriers.
A study by management consultants Deloitte and the German Association of Interactive Entertainment Software (BIU) predicts rapid growth for e-sports.
In 2016, 50 million euros will have been generated in Germany, mainly through advertising, sponsoring and major tournaments.
In three years the turnover is expected to reach 130 million.
This is not much against the almost 2.4 billion euros of the German Football League.
However, e-sports are "not far away from other established sports such as handball, basketball or ice hockey," write the Deloitte consultants.
Internationally, many countries are already further ahead.
Large markets are Asia and the USA, where ex-basketball player Shaquille O`Neal and baseball star Alex Rodriguez participate in the US Team NRG eSports.
Hollywood actor Ashton Kutcher invests in the eSports betting provider Unikrn.
A lot is happening in Europe too.
In a Norwegian school, e-sports has been introduced as a subject, says Froböse.
In the Netherlands and France, according to Dutt, first league football clubs are now obliged to set up an e-sports department.
"Germany is lagging behind in European comparison," explains VfB Board member Röttgermann.
Just lapsing into nostalgia and transfiguring the old times is no longer enough today.
The aim is to preserve the tradition of the association, but at the same time to align the company to the modern market.
"We live in a digitalized world," says Dutt as well.
"You can't stick to the idea that only in football everything stays the same."

Only eggs that have been shown to be free of fipronil should be placed on the shelves.
Michelle Carter convicted of lyrics urging Conrad Roy to commit suicide
A woman from Massachusetts was sentenced to two and a half years for encouraging her boyfriend to commit suicide through texts and phone calls.
Michelle Carter, now 20, will spend 15 months of her sentence behind bars and five years were suspended on probation.
Carter was convicted in June of negligently killing Conrad Roy, who took his own life on July 13, 2014.
Roy's father said at the hearing on Thursday: "My family is inconsolable.
My son was my best friend."
Carter was allowed to remain free until his appeal.
She was facing a maximum sentence of 20 years, but her legal representatives argued that both she and Mr Roy suffered from mental illness.
Dressed in red pants and a cream-colored blouse, Carter stood there with tears in her eyes, her hands folded and her eyes pointed down when she was sentenced.
"Your actions got Conrad Roy killed," the prosecutor told the court.
"She ended his life to make her own better.
She has not taken responsibility," she said.
"She showed no remorse".
But Carter's lawyer said it was a "terrible circumstance that she totally regrets".
However, Judge Lawrence Moniz said he had not found that their "age or maturity or even mental illness has a significant influence on their actions.
A prosecutor read a statement from Roy's mother, Lynn Roy, saying that "there is not a day that I do not mourn the loss of my beloved son.
I want him to be proud of me and how I deal with everything. I try to be there for his sisters despite all my pain, which we will carry with us for eternity," it says.
Roy's sister, Camdyn Roy, testified that she was "haunted" by the realization that she would never attend her brother's wedding or be an aunt to his children.
"Not having that one person with whom I have been with every day since I was born is a pain I will always carry with me for the rest of my life," she said.
The case seems to set a legal precedent, since there is no law in Massachusetts that makes it a crime to ask someone else to commit suicide.
Carter was 17 years old when Roy was found dead from carbon monoxide poisoning in a vehicle in 2014.
The case attracted national attention after Carter's text messages revealed that she had encouraged him to end his life.
"Hang yourself, jump off a building, stab yourself, I don't know, there are many ways," she said in several messages she had sent in the two weeks before his death while he was on vacation with his family.
In the moments before his suicide she wrote: "You have to do it, Conrad" and "All you have to do is turn on the generator and you'll be free and happy."
Judge Moniz said Carter was seeking attention with the death of Roy and ordered that she should benefit from the case through some press.
The case has divided the legal opinion.
Among the few who defended Carter was Amanda Knox, who was convicted of the murder of her British roommate in Italy in 2007, before she was acquitted two years ago.
Mrs. Knox, 30 years old, published a comment in the Los Angeles Times: "Michelle Carter deserves compassion and help, not jail."

It is no coincidence that Joshua Kimmich was captain of the Audi Cup.

It wasn't the eight-year-old Arturo Vidal who was chosen as captain of the C-team, consisting of youth players, debutants and professionals who had just returned from vacation, but him.
One prefers to give candy to those whom one trusts a lot and whom one wants to keep happy.
So if you have been chosen to take up the legacy of Lahm, you need a little extra motivation.
Kimmich confirmed: "This is what you want as a player: to take responsibility".
On Wednesday, the 22-year-old raced across the field as a mini lame.
Back right, that is his position now, the white bandage on his arm did the rest.
And in general Kimmich seemed to be the one who can take the rudder best in this starting formation.
He gave instructions, tried to guide the untrained troops.
He had an eye for the whole while many others were busy with themselves.

His colleague Rudy admitted that the result "was not what we had hoped for".

Shifting the game, changing the tempo: "I was called in for this style".
After the game, the newcomers could see how unusual this Bayern-Welt still is for the newcomers.
Rudy, for example, did not give one or two interviews in the catacombs, but certainly six or seven.
Kimmich said goodbye after a few crisp statements in the back of his new teammates.
There he heard an interesting sentence from Süle: "I have already noticed what is going on here.
With Bayern you simply have to win every game".
At least he doesn't have to teach that to the newbies anymore.

The relationship between the state and the regional economy was often irreconcilable when Eveline Lemke (Greens) was still Minister of Economics of Rhineland-Palatinate.
This becomes apparent after more than a year in which the new Minister of Economics, Volker Wissing (FDP), has been in office.
Chambers and companies from the region speak of a change in economic policy in response to a T V inquiry - and at the same time blame the old minister.
Frank Natus, chairman of the Trier Business Association (VTU), says: "Wissing takes up the wishes of the business community, which Lemke has blocked all of them".
Natus sees the biggest turnaround in the country's infrastructure policy: the closing of the gap in the Autobahn 1 between Kelberg and Adenau is now at the top of the country's list of priorities.
The ministry is hoping for a planning approval procedure before the end of this year, and the building permit should be in place by 2021.
The Trier western bypass also plays a role in the state's plans, as it is a priority requirement of the Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan.
The goal is to put the line into operation in December 2020, says Ministry spokeswoman Cornelia Holtmann.
Natus sees this as a signpost to support regional but internationally competing companies.

Christian Baldauf, deputy CDU faction leader, refers to calculations by the Court of Auditors that the state will invest more than 20 million euros less in the maintenance of national roads in 2017 and 2018 than proposed.
Frank Natus also expects the country to come up with a concept of how it intends to remedy the shortage of skilled workers in the region.
The current broadband expansion in the country is also sobering.
In 2016, regional companies had only given the network supply a grade of 3.4 in a survey conducted by the Chamber of Industry and Commerce.
They complained about slow Internet connections and dropouts.
Former Minister of Economic Affairs Eveline Lemke, on the other hand, is currently out of politics and is still on the supervisory board of the wind power company Pro Wind.
The Green parliamentary group left Lemke in April to become president of a private university in Karlsruhe - where she left after four months due to disagreements.

One day before Audi's announcement, BMW said it would offer to update the software in more than 350,000 vehicles.
The BMW chairman said the company believed that "there are smarter options than driving restrictions", referring to European cities - including Munich, where BMW is based - to ban or restrict diesel vehicles.
Daimler announced on Tuesday that it will modify three million Mercedes vehicles in Europe to reduce its diesel emissions.
None of the companies described the undertakings as a recall.
European car manufacturers have strongly promoted the use of diesel vehicles in Europe and the United States to help meet carbon dioxide emission regulations.
But the nitrogen oxides emitted by diesel engines are considered carcinogens and can cause asthma.
The cost to car manufacturers of installing equipment to neutralise the exhaust gases emitted by diesel vehicles is also increasing, making it difficult to keep the price of cars competitive.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel is also accused of coddling the powerful car companies and ignoring signs of the problem.
The companies are trying to avoid the mistakes of Volkswagen, which could regulate the use of so-called cut-off devices, the emissions to comply with the regulations when a car has been tested, but drive back under normal driving conditions.
In the United States, several Volkswagen employees have been charged, others are under investigation on both sides of the Atlantic.

The inclusion of Audi in the investigation could place a heavy burden on Volkswagen: the luxury car manufacturer contributes disproportionately to Volkswagen's profits.

Mordillo's bulbous noses and laughter against suffering
Mordillo was at times one of the most published cartoonists, the bulbous noses of his characters are his trademark.
Even at 85, the Argentinean is still drawing and working on a film.
His message: Laugh, "because there is too much suffering in the world".
Guillermo Mordillo was born in Buenos Aires on August 4, 1932, the son of Spanish immigrants.
In his first years as an artist, he made his living as a draftsman for greeting cards - which frustrated him.
"The happiest day in my professional life was the day I lost in my job," he once said.
After stations in Lima, New York and Paris, he made his breakthrough at the end of the 1960s with the publication of his cartoons in "Paris Match" and then in "Stern" and other leading magazines around the world.
Even in China Mordillo found many fans.
Again and again the artist was inspired by cities.
Large, rounded Mordillo figures are found in drawings with the Leaning Tower of Pisa, Big Ben in London and Red Square in Moscow.
In the early morning, he says he still sits at the drawing table today, working almost ten hours a day.
Through calendars, puzzles, books for young and old, T-shirts, stuffed animals and clocks, his quaint figures continue to be widely distributed worldwide.
For six years he has also been working on an animated film and a TV series with his characters.
The main character in the film "Crazy Island" is a giraffe - Mordillo's most popular animal in his drawings - which has a millipede as its antagonist.
For the first time, his characters speak in the 3D film, which is to be released on the cinema screen in 2019.
"I don't know exactly what they're going to say, it's strange for me", says Mordillo.
The script is not written by him.
That's why he prefers the TV series, which, like his original drawings, is produced wordlessly.
Lavender from Provence threatened by climate change
It has become a symbol of Provence in the south of France, but there is a warning that it is threatened by climate change.
Lavender is declining because of drought-like conditions and disease-carrying insects, which is causing great headaches for scientists and farmers trying to find solutions.
Eric Chaisse, an expert from the agricultural research institute CRIEPPAM in Provence, said: "The lavender in Provence is effectively under threat because the plant has been exposed to the effects of climate change in recent years, which has brought much less rain in spring and much more in autumn.
This has an effect on the life span of lavender.
There is also a small cicada, a micro-bacteria that transmits dwarf cicadas, and in very dry weather there are a lot of them."
And there's a lot at stake.
Lavender oil not only attracts holidaymakers, it is also in great demand for perfume and cosmetics.
Eric Chaisse said: "Instead of having very long plant ears with a large number of flowers, we have smaller, underdeveloped and either missing or weakened.
So we have fewer parts with essential oil."
Solutions under consideration include better water distribution and slowing down evaporation from the soil, but also spraying the plants with a protective mixture of clay and water and developing varieties that are more resistant to drought.

The highlight of the festival is this Saturday and Sunday with a medieval festival.
Merchants, guilds, traders, vagrants or a lansquenet camp are to be experienced in the city centre on these days.
The murder of a journalist underlines the growing threat in Mexico
The staff of the weekly Riodoce usually meet on Wednesdays to review their plans for reporting on the recent chaos in Sinaloa state caused by organized crime, corrupt officials and incessant drug wars.
But on that day, in the shadow of their own tragedy, they came together to talk about security.
They were told that it is important to change their routines.
Two high-ranking journalists discuss what feels safer: to take their children to the office who were the target of a grenade attack in 2009, or to leave them at home.
Security experts have written three words on a blackboard at the front of the room: Enemies, neutrals, allies.
You ask the reporters to suggest names for each column - no proof is needed, perceptions and gut feelings are enough.
There are drug smugglers, politicians, businessmen, journalists suspected of being on the payroll of the government or the cartels, a catalogue of criminals who make the chaos of Mexico dangerous.
There is no respite from the violence, and while bodies are piling up all over the country, more and more journalists are joining in: at least 25 since President Enrique Pena Nieto took office in December 2012. 589 are under federal protection following attacks and threats and so far this year there have been at least seven deaths in seven states.
Among the latter is its editor and inspirer of Riodoce, co-founder Javier Valdez Cardenas.
"The biggest mistake is to live in Mexico and be a journalist," Valdez wrote in one of his many books on drug-related violence.
His absence is deeply felt, although his presence is everywhere - a large photograph of Valdez, showing his middle finger with the word "Justice", hangs on the façade of the Riodoce building. Two reporters in their thirties, Aaron Ibarra and Miriam Ramirez, wear T-shirts showing his smiling face with glasses or his typical Panama hat.
The workshop takes place less than two months after his death, and the reporters discuss their shared themes, trauma, nightmares, insomnia, paranoia.
Although a special Federal Prosecutor's Office was established in 2010 to deal with the cases of journalists, it has only initiated two criminal proceedings, according to the Committee for the Protection of Journalists.
As with most of the thousands of murders associated with drug trafficking and organized crime each year, journalists' murderers are rarely brought to justice.
At Riodoce, they still insist on dealing with the violence of Sinaloa, although they are inconsolable and although the terrain is now even more treacherous.
Without information about the killers, without justice, the meeting to discuss security has little use, says Ibarra.
"It's very silly to waste my time in this workshop," he says.
"Until we know the why, we distrust everyone."
On the morning of May 15, Valdez left the office of the newspaper Riodoce in the state capital of Culiacan.
He only managed to drive a few blocks before his red Toyota Corolla was stopped by two men. He was forced out of his car and was shot at 12 times, probably because of the name of the newspaper - which is translated as "Twelfth River".
The shooter drove away in his car and damaged it nearby.
Valdez was 50 years old.
He left behind a wife and two grown children.
Rumors tend to fly free in Culiacan.
But on the subject of Valdez there is practically nothing but silence.
Since Guzman's arrest last year and extradition to the United States in January, Sinaloa has become one of the bloodiest battlegrounds in the country as rival factions fight to fill the vacuum.
It does not matter that in Sinaloa every day one or more people are shot in the street or that the cemetery is full of decorated two-storey mausoleums for drug kings, which are bigger than many houses for the living.
Forget for a minute that there is a state of "calm" when only one cartel has control of the coastal state with its valuable ports and drug trade routes to the United States.
Despite this, and despite the fact that Valdez was aware of the dangers of his work, Ismail Bojorquez (60), a co-founder and director of Riodoce, was shattered by the guilt of not being able to protect his friend.
He believes that two misunderstandings contributed to the murder.
First, in February there was the publication of an interview with Damaso Lopez, a leader of one of the rival cartel factions in the war with Guzman's sons.
This publication may have angered the sons, suspected gang members bought up every copy of the issue as soon as it was delivered to newsstands.
The second mistake was not to force Valdez to leave the country for his own safety after the confiscation of another newspaper that had published the same story.
Valdez was a legend in Mexico and abroad, and his killing is considered a milestone in Mexican violence against journalists.
He had survived so long that his friends and colleagues assumed he would always be there.
He was an experienced reporter for Noroeste in 2003, when he joined forces with five colleagues to form Riodoce and sold $50 investments.
In Sinaloa, "it was impossible to do journalism without encountering the narcotics problem," Bojorquez said.
Over time, the newspaper earned a reputation for courageous and honest reporting, and sales and advertising increased.
Reporters loved being able to publish hard-hitting investigations without fear of censorship, and readers were fascinated by a publication in which they could read stories that no one else dared to cover.
Eight years after Riodoce was founded, she received the prestigious "Maria Moors Cabot Prize" for her reporting in Latin America.
In the same year, Valdez won the Committee for the Protection of Journalists' International Press Freedom Award for his courage in pursuing Mexican drug history wherever it led.
He freely admitted that he was afraid.
"I want to live on," he said at the time of the CPJ award.
Drug trafficking in Sinaloa "is a way of life," he said last October in an interview with Rompeviento TV.
"You have to take on the task that falls to you as a journalist - either that or you play dumb.
I don't want to be asked: "What did you do in the face of so many dead ... why didn't you say what was going on?"
The Riodoce team misses Valdez, the joker who could curse like a dock worker, the friend who was generous with hugs and advice, a teacher who knew how to survive.
They trusted his routine.
He would always wear his hat.
He would always go to El Guayabo, the bar opposite the office, and always sit at the same table.
Now you ask: Was his love of routine his undoing?
His death has also forced them to question their own assumptions about how best to do their jobs and stay alive.
"They don't like it when you deal with their wives, their children, their clean businesses, their secret runways" to move drugs.
"These things were not allowed," said Bojorquez.
The result, even in the best of times, is a high degree of self-censorship and self-preservation.
Trust your own instincts.
If it smells wrong, stay away from it.
The trouble is, said the editor of Riodoce Andres Villarreal, that "smell is a sense that can be deceived ... and then this thing with Javier happened."
The old rules, he and others say, no longer apply in Sinaloa - nor in Tamaulipas, Veracruz, Guerrero and other states that are home to a toxic mix of lucrative smuggling routes, weak institutions and corrupt government officials.
The landscape is constantly changing.
In the room where Riodoce employees met for safety training, mobile phones were suddenly not allowed. Days earlier, it became known that spyware sold exclusively to governments was used to monitor journalists and activists in Mexico.
Outside, two policemen sought shelter from the heat of 104 degrees (40° C) in the shade of a tree.
They were commissioned by the state government to protect the offices of Riodoce in a four-storey building in a middle-class district of Culiacan.
Half jokingly, some of the reporters wondered if these officers were among the 50 percent of police officers that the governor himself described as untrustworthy.
It's been months since the reporters went into the mountainous landscape where the drug gangs are de facto under control.
For this week's issue Riodoce has looked at three main stories.
There was the murder in Sinaloa of the brother of former famous boxer Julio Cesar Chavez.
They also had an exposé on state spending, which focused on the governor's home town.
And there was a group that carried out a kidnapping in one of the most expensive restaurants in Culiacan, a block from the prosecutor's office.
There was no official word about who was kidnapped or how it happened, so caution was called for when it was time to write what everyone in town knows: that the restaurant is a favorite spot of drug dealers and authorities.
A reporter learned from public records that the restaurant was registered under the name of a politician belonging to the ruling Institutional Revolution Party (PRI), which dominated all political levels for almost the entire century.
Recently, several PRI governors were accused of high-profile cases of corruption.
Villarreal asked the reporter to write about previous incidents in this locale, including one in which a son of "El Chapo" Guzman escaped a military raid.
Just a few months earlier, readers would have considered Valdez's column the best informed source about the kidnapping.
"In the old days we would have known what was happening," said Villarreal, 46, nicknamed "El Flaco" because of his slim build.
"Now all channels of communication with our sources have been broken."
Valdez's office has been converted into a storage space for signs and stickers protesting against the murders of journalists, because the staff have become something they never expected themselves to be: activists on behalf of the press.
Reporter Miriam Ramirez grabbed a few signs and went to the prosecutor's office the next morning for a demonstration about another journalist.
Salvador Adame disappeared three days after Valdez was killed in the western state of Michoacan.
A burned body was discovered and officials say, based on DNA testing, that it is his.
Throughout the country, journalists have become louder by writing "SOS Press" on pavements and buildings in organized protests.
On that day, director Bojorquez is away in Washington trying to gather international support for the justice in the Valdez case.
At a meeting with the Governor of Sinaloa the day after the assassination of Valdez, Ramirez accused the authorities of spying on journalists and having them killed for telling the truth.
She has since asked to be reassigned by the government because she is concerned that her anger has hurt her objectivity.
Valdez had repeatedly said that journalists in Mexico were "surrounded" by organized crime, government officials involved in it and an indifferent society.
In his last book "Narco-Journalism" he wrote that reporters are not only killed by drug gangs, but also on the orders of politicians and security forces who were in cahoots with organized crime.
The media watchdog group "Articulo 19" attributed more than half of the attacks on journalists last year to police and officials.
"In Mexico you die because they want you to keep your mouth shut," said Ramirez.
Obviously the murders have a deterrent effect.
No one forgets the death of blogger Maria Elizabeth Macias in the northern border state of Tamaulipas six years ago.
Her body was found along with a note supposedly signed by the Zetas cartel: "Here I am for my reports."
A computer keyboard and headphones lay next to her severed head.
Some branches have chosen to close, such as the newspaper El Norte in the northern border state of Chihuahua after the murder of correspondent Miroslava Breach in March.
Others continue, as El Manana of Nuevo Laredo did after the murder of its director in 2004.
In 2010, the Diario de Ciudad Juarez publicly addressed the drug cartels with an editorial on the front page entitled "What do you want from us?"
Some journalists have fled from their home countries or even from the country.
It's a painful decision.
It is difficult to find work in exile, and they still watch the streets and look for dangers.
And sometimes they are hunted, as apparently the photographer Ruben Espinosa, who was murdered in 2015 together with four women in an apartment in Mexico City three months after fleeing from Veracruz.
For those who stay behind and continue the work, it is a daily dance with risky decisions.
Ibarra, who once wanted to be a poet, admits that the drug trade frightens him.
"Mexico is going to hell, and that's why I became a reporter," he said.
At midnight last Friday, when the last issue was already finished, the editors of Riodoce were sitting on the sidewalk in front of the office, drinking beer, when suddenly all their phones started buzzing.
A series of shootings with gang rivals and security forces near the seaside resort of Mazatlan had left 19 confirmed dead.
The war continued to escalate, as promised by a number of cartel embassies in the region.
From the curb, they published the news on the Riodoce website via mobile phone.
The front page had to be changed the next day.
Sirens wailing nearby - another shooting in the area.
Bojorquez took a look at the police officers who were standing guard to see if they were on standby.
If they were afraid at all, they did not show it.
Under the huge portrait of the fallen founder of the newspaper, whose middle finger was visible to the whole of Sinaloa, the staff of Riodoce followed his footsteps.
"How can you even think of closing," Bojorquez said, "when on the same day that Javier was murdered, the intern asked me to send her out on the street to report."
Dinosaur used camouflage to evade his enemies
At first sight it looks like a statue, albeit a frightening one.
Now researchers have found out that the first findings of the incredible rhinoceros of a Canadian miner were so well preserved that experts have described it as the "Mona Lisa of dinosaurs".
It was so well preserved that they could even tell that its scaly skin was of a reddish brown - and they said it had something of a "troubled past".
The report in the magazine "Current Biology" described him as "the best preserved armored dinosaur ever found and one of the best dinosaur specimens in the world.
The fossil is a newly discovered species of nodosaur, which lived in the middle of the Cretaceous period between 110 million and 112 million years ago.
Its incredibly well-preserved condition has astounded researchers who describe it as "truly remarkable
According to reports in National Geographic, the armored herbivore is the best preserved fossil of its kind.
It was found by Shawn Funk while digging at the Suncor Millennium Mine near Fort McMurray in northern Alberta, Canada, on March 21, 2011.
He came across something that seemed out of place from the surrounding rock and decided to take a closer look.
The fossil he discovered was sent to the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology.
They spent the next six years uncovering the wild animal within the 2,500 pound (1,100 kg) lump of earth.
After all this hard work, the final result is now ready to be unveiled.
"If you blink your eyes just a little, you could almost believe it was asleep," said lead author Caleb Brown, a scientist at the Royal Tyrrell Museum, where the creature is on display.
"It will go down in the history of science as one of the most beautiful and best preserved specimens of dinosaurs - the Mona Lisa of dinosaurs."
Researchers have discovered that this herbivore, although covered in armour and resembling a walking carapace, was probably threatened by carnivorous dinosaurs.
The heavily armored dinosaur used red and white camouflage to hide from predators and used a shielding technique known as counter-shadowing, which is also used by many modern animals.
This would have allowed it to blend better into its environment and evade its enemies, experts say, suggesting that it was threatened by larger dinosaurs.
The 110 million year old creature from the nodosaur family made the headlines for the first time in May and is now on display at the Royal Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology.
Researchers have now studied the wild animal and named it Borealopelta markmitchelli after museum technician Mark Mitchell, one of a team that has spent more than 7,000 hours carefully uncovering it.
The amazing preservation of the specimen enabled Dr. Mitchell and an international team of scientists to document the pattern and shape of scales and armor over his body.
They discovered countershading, a common method of defense in the animal kingdom, which means that the top of the creature was darker than its underside.
Although countershading is common, the results are surprising, as the size of Borealo pelta far exceeds that of the animals living today.
It suggests that the dinosaur was hunted by enough pressure from carnivorous dinosaurs that evolution favored the concealment of confrontation as a means of survival.
But most contemporary animals that use countershading - think of deer, zebras or armadillos - are much smaller and more vulnerable than prey, indicating that this nodosaur has faced a real fight for survival.
"Strong predator behavior on a massive, heavily armored dinosaur shows how dangerous the dinosaur predators of the Cretaceous period must have been," Brown said.
The chemical analysis of organic compounds in their scales also shows that the dinosaur's skin was reddish brown.
Scientists continue to examine the animal for clues about its life, including its preserved intestinal contents, to find out what it ate as its last meal.
They believe that when the dinosaur died, it got into a river and was driven out into the sea, where it sank on its back to the bottom of the sea.
At that time, Alberta was as warm as South Florida is today, and rivers and oceans were probably much further inland than they are today.
"This nodosaur is truly remarkable because it is completely covered with preserved scaly skin, but it is also preserved in three dimensions and retains the original shape of the animal," Brown said.
"The result is that the animal today looks almost exactly the same as in the early Cretaceous period.
You don't have to use much imagination to reconstruct it. If you squint your eyes just a little, you could almost believe he's asleep."
The Cretaceous period was a time when giant theropods, carnivorous dinosaurs that stood on two legs, pervaded the earth.
Although the king of them, the Tyrannosaurus Rex, lived millions of years after Borealopelta, the armored dinosaur was hunted by some of its fearsome ancestors.
These include the Acrocanthosaurus, a 38-foot (11.5 m) long, six-ton monster.
The scientists, whose latest findings appear in the journal Current Biology, believe that Borealopelta sank into the sea after death and was mummified in mud.
The creature was found by Shawn Funk while digging at the Suncor Millennium Mine near Fort McMurray in northern Alberta, Canada, on March 21, 2011.
According to the museum it is the best preserved armored dinosaur in the world, including skin and armor, and is complete from snout to hip.
The creatures were on average about 18 feet (5 meters) long and weighed up to 3,000 pounds (1,300 kg).
It contained two 20-inch spikes that protruded from his shoulders.
The researchers believe that the armored herbivore was washed through western Canada until a flooded river flooded it into the open sea.
But the dinosaur's underwater burial preserved its armor in exquisite detail.
The petrified remains of this particular specimen are so well preserved that the skin remains still cover bumpy armour plates along the dinosaur
As Michael Greshko has written for National Geographic, such a level of preservation is as 'rare as winning the lottery.
The more I look at it, the more confusing it gets.
Petrified remains of the skin still cover the bumpy armour plates that support the skull of the animal.
His right forefoot lies at his side, his five fingers are spread upwards.
I can count the scales on his sole'.

Deutsche Bahn: Group tests "Comfort Check-in
It is a moment that almost everyone has experienced at some point: Unsuspectingly you sit on the train and sleep.
Or you are absorbed in your work and have just had a brilliant thought.
And then, poof.
If the conductor comes and wakes you up rudely or pulls the passenger out of the workflow in the middle of the ride.
Ticket inspection.
But the times of interruptions are soon over.
Deutsche Bahn is currently testing the conductorless ticket control.
One simply confirms by mobile phone that one has taken one's seat and thus validates the ticket.
Test operations are currently underway on two lines.
"If the offer comes in, let's expand it.
It will then probably be available at the beginning of next year on many other long-distance routes in Germany," said a railway spokesman.
"Comfort check-in" is what the railway calls ticket validation without a conductor.
However, in order to be able to use them, some conditions must be met: You need a smartphone or a tablet.
And you must have booked an online ticket - which most passengers do anyway.
You also have to have bought it via the app of the railway, the DB Navigator, which is the most convenient way to book tickets anyway.
And last but not least you need a seat reservation.
Because the "Comfort Check-in" works like this: You get on the train, call up your ticket under "My Tickets".
A button for electronic cancellation will then appear on the test customers.
The train attendants receive a message on their mobile devices that passenger X is on the train and has taken the booked seat Y.
If the train attendant arrives at seat Y during ticket inspection, he knows that a passenger with a validated online ticket is sitting there.
So you can go back to sleep, keep working, keep quiet.
The "check-in" has two advantages: one for the customer, one for the train - which in turn should benefit the passengers.
"Anyone who wants to travel in a relaxed manner without having to check in their tickets with our train attendants simply checks in themselves in the DB Navigator.
This allows passengers to personalise their travel time on the train," says Michael Peterson, DB Fernverkehr's Marketing Director.
The second plus: "And our employees have more time than today to respond to individual customer needs".
Anyone who often travels by train knows that, apart from delays and missed trains, ticket checks are one of the biggest annoyances.
Often one oneself, but in any case one of the fellow travellers, does not have all the documents needed for the validation of online-tickets.
Either the credit card or the identity card or any other document that has to be shown is missing.
The result is endless discussions between the train attendant and the passenger, which leads to a bad atmosphere in the compartment or large room and delays in checking one's own ticket, and in the end takes away the time for the conductor to take care of other concerns.
Only a small number of test customers can still use the new service.
And this only on the ICE 915 Dortmund-Stuttgart and ICE 912 Stuttgart-Essen connections.
Further train numbers on the same route are not yet activated.
How an activist came to learn the answer to the question, "Whose Streets?"
On 9 August 2014, Brittany Ferrell was shaken to its core.
Just one day after arriving in New York City, the St. Louis-born woman sat on the bed of an Airbnb apartment she rented and scrolled through Facebook on her phone.
She stumbled across a mail from someone in high school.
"Police have just killed an 18-year-old child and he is still lying in the street," they said.
Confused because nobody else had posted the information on her feed, she closed Facebook and opened Twitter.
A user with the handle @TheePharoah was constantly retweeted on their timeline.
The St. Louis area rapper was about to tweet live the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old who was killed by a white cop in Ferguson, Mo.
He posted a picture of Brown's lifeless body stretched out on the street, which would stay there for four hours.
"This is wild," Ferrell thought to himself.
But death was nothing new for her and her community.
She dropped her cell phone to return later that evening to tweets about people on the Canfield Drive.
There were photos of the police tape and people screaming, and of a man claiming to be Brown's father carrying a sign saying, "Ferguson's police just killed my unarmed son!
She watched a live feed where a policeman stood in front of a group of demonstrators with a barking dog.
In another video, she said, another policeman cocked his rifle and shouted, "I'm going to kill you. Animals kill all."
"It's not usual," Ferrell recalled her testimony.
"This is not the kind of murder we're used to and can call typical."
At that moment I felt chills.
I was angry and I cried."
She booked a return flight and went home the next day.
After landing at 11pm, she picked up her 6-year-old daughter from her father's house and decided that the two would go to Ferguson the next morning.
What happened to Ferrell and Ferguson over the next three years is the subject of a new documentary, "Whose Streets?", which will be shown in cinemas from the 11th century onwards.
It is a story of survival and protest, of love and loss, of strength and resilience, which is a story of the people who live in the community and have filled the streets demanding answers.
As Ferrell drove to Ferguson with her daughter, who was wearing a flower dress and a matching crown, the two discussed a conversation they had countless times before that morning "about the black experience and the black condition.
"You remember how I taught you when black people need to fight for what they believe in?" she remembered what she said.
"We're going to Ferguson now because the police killed an 18-year-old boy and it was not right.
I couldn't take her with me," Ferrell said later.
"What happened today is a culmination of what happened in the past.
She needs to know it and see it and be raised in it.
It has to be well developed, not only activism and organization, but also knowing the different layers of the black experience and the black constitution and what we have to do to become free, to free ourselves.
Even though I am fortunate to give her an experience where she personally does not experience blatant racism, she is no different than the next black woman-child.
I feel I'd be doing her a disservice to keep her away."
The first stop when they arrived in Ferguson was on South Florissant Road, a place across the street from the police department, which became a camp area as the activists waited for Officer Darren Wilson's possible non-indictment.
There, Ferrell and her daughter connected with a local business owner who made lunch.
They prepared bags and helped hand them over to demonstrators.
Slowly a new kind of activism began to take shape for Ferrell.
"My activism changed completely after August 9," she said, noting that as a student at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, she was president of the Minority Student Nurses Association, focusing on food justice and health inequalities in black communities.
"I had no experience in organizing.
It's all come."
Weeks later, during an evening demonstration, Ferrell met Sabaah Folayan, one of the co-directors of the film.
Folayan said she and her cameraman Lucas Alvarado-Farrarar just wanted to "document" what happened.
One question crossed Ferrell's mind: "Do you want to document or are you trying to find a story to exploit?"
This skepticism was nurtured by countless cases of people, often white people - in a community that benefited from their pain and resilience.
As Folayan explained in a recent interview: "We had heard that people born and raised in Ferguson did not center their voices and we wanted to do it differently.
Folayan had already worked with then co-director Damon Davis, an artist from the field known for his activism around death row inmates.
His involvement brought Ferrell closer to the project, and together with six other locals, the Whose Streets? team followed in the years following Brown's shooting.
"This documentary is not someone who speaks for us or who talks to us. We talk," said Davis.
"That was the main thing for me, how these people are portrayed, because that's how I'm going to be portrayed."
The goal was not to focus on Ferrell's experience - to show that the movement "is not a Messiah leader, but a community that comes together," Folayan said - she proved to be the most open participant in the film.
As a result, documents from "Whose Streets?" show surprisingly personal aspects of Ferrell's life, how she falls in love and marries her wife.
"I felt like I was naked," Ferrell said, laughing as she saw the finished product for the first time.
"But I understood that there must be a certain vulnerability in this work and in humanizing black people."
In addition, Ferrell's story repeats the role of black gay women in the broader Black Lives Matter movement.
Two of the three founders of the movement, who influenced the film "BlacklivesMatter" in social media after the killing of black teenager Trayvon Martin in 2012, identify themselves as gay.
"Black, gay women in leadership positions have carried the movement as a whole," Ferrell said, "and so we are constantly fighting on different fronts.
Black, gay women must bear the brunt of everything."
Folayan agreed to note that "the movement is really being sustained by black women and many black women.
She insists, however, that "this is not an affirmative type of action," in which Ferrell was chosen for her identity as the heart of the film.
"She was the person who awakened this energy," she said.
"It is no coincidence, although she was on the front line, because there is so much at stake in a life at these crossroads as a black, gay woman.
You can feel their energy through the screen."
Meanwhile, the news cameras in Ferguson have long since disappeared, but racial ties between the community and the police still exist.
Ferrell is on probation for 2½ years for blocking a highway during a demonstration.
She describes the socio-political atmosphere of the area she calls home: "A chaos".
Nevertheless, she clings to a song and she has been committed to this memory since she took to the streets in Ferguson three years ago.
"It is our duty to fight for our freedom.
It's our duty to win.
We must love and support each other.
We have nothing to lose - except our chains."

But there is no room for a farmers' market hall anymore, thanks to the many - in my opinion - senseless building projects in Bitburg.
If the farmers' market hall is destroyed, a piece of culture will disappear again."
A fitting resemblance: artist creates portraits with Chelsea Manning's DNA
In the middle of the room of the Fridman Gallery in New York, many faces can be seen - white, black, and brown, almost imperceptibly similar - hanging from cables from the ceiling.
The 30 portraits were created by the artist Heather Dewey-Hagborg from cheek swabs and haircuts sent to her by Chelsea Manning.
Manning sent the clippings from Fort Leavenworth prison, where the former intelligence analyst served a 35-year prison sentence after making classified diplomatic messages public via the WikiLeaks website.
The new exhibition, which opened on August 2, is called A Becoming Resemblance.
It is the product of two years of correspondence between Dewey-Hagborg, whose discipline combined her expertise in technology, computer science and art, and Manning, a transwoman and seminal dissident whose conviction was commuted by Barack Obama when he had only three days left in office.
Dewey-Hagborg, through the algorithmic analysis of DNA extracted by Manning, from which 30 portraits were created of what someone might look like with this genomic data, has created a sharp, if somewhat intellectual, commentary not only on the malleability of DNA data - the many ways in which it can be interpreted and the inherent determinism of these interpretations - but also on identity.
Manning, who was born Bradley Edward but has been openly talking about identifying as a woman since puberty, was convicted on 20 charges in 2013, including six espionage law violations, computer fraud and theft.
Her image was suppressed by the prison, so much so that there was only one photograph - a grainy black and white selfie in which Manning was visibly uncomfortable sitting in a driver's seat and wearing a platinum blonde wig - with which she was associated.
In 2015, Dewey-Hagborg has just had the great success of its 2012 project 'Stranger Visions'.
In it, the artist produced portraits of strangers from forensic artifacts such as cigarette butts and chewing gum, extracting DNA from the waste to create a picture of what these people might look like.
That was when she received an e-mail from a newspaper magazine.
"They did an interview with Chelsea Manning while she was in prison, and they wanted some kind of portrait to accompany this article," Dewey-Hagborg explained at a press preview of the new exhibition.
And she couldn't be visited at that time and she couldn't be photographed, so you contacted Chelsea and asked her if she wanted to do a DNA portrait.
The artist and her imprisoned muse became unequal pen pals, exchanging several letters over the course of two years.
They even created a comic "Suppressed Images" illustrated by Shoili Kanungo, which foresaw a future in which the president would reverse Chelsea's verdict and she would be able to see the exhibition in person.
That Obama would actually demand Manning's release after seven brutal years in a Kansas military prison just days after the book was published was a welcome kind of happy coincidence.
There is also something deep and strong about the opening of the exhibition now, as Donald Trump is waging a war against government informants and transgender troops to find new, tweetable ways to further inflame the rigid divisions he was supposed to be fixing.
When Dewey-Hagborg was asked about the strange timing of all these things, she said that "things happen for a reason.
In an artistic statement written on the wall of the gallery, Manning, with her oversized signature underneath (the "i" in her family name is marked with a heart), called for an end to "automatic fragmentation, the basis of which has been gender, race, sexuality and culture.
On the opposite wall is her mitochondrial DNA sequence - a centipede of Cs and Gs and As, written in pencil.
Dewey-Hagborg hoped that by including the 200 letters (or nucleotides according to the artist's highly developed scientific encyclopaedia) she would show how amazingly similar, at least in biological terms, we all are.
"What people will hopefully take away from this is that our genome does not care who we are and how open genetic data is to interpretation and how subjective it is," said Dewey-Hagborg, whose 2007 video work, Spurious Memories, is also on display.
"DNA data can tell so many different stories, hence 30 of these stories."
The last piece in the exhibition, which is kept in a separate room, is a page from the comic novel mentioned above.
She shows Manning emerging from the disciplinary barracks of the United States like King-Kong with a hands-free telephone in her hand.
"If they kill your speech, they've won," they say.
"So don't ever shut up."
"It came straight from a letter she wrote me," said the artist, greeting from Philadelphia.
"I still get goose bumps when I talk about it."
Manning has not yet seen the exhibition in person - as foresightedly anticipated in the comic book - but if she does, she will be greeted in the middle of the room by the masks, by her own genomic simulacra, which flock together like hordes of protesters.
This was also purposeful, like everything in the exhibition, up to the size (5 " 2, Manning's stature), where her genetic haplogroups were written in pencil.
"In the past I had them on the wall, but I wanted them to feel like a crowd," said Dewey-Hagborg of the portraits.
"I wanted it to feel like a mass movement that formed with Chelsea, like the movement that was behind her liberation."

Russian Deputy Prime Minister Vitaly Mutko said it would not be long before the remaining World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) criteria for the restoration of the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA) were implemented.
"At a certain stage of meeting the criteria of the Roadmap, RUSADA has been granted the right to plan and test in cooperation with UKAD (UK Anti-Doping).
The WADA schedule has been updated in this respect," Mutko explained on Thursday.
The PM commented on the second part of WADA's Roadmap for Compliance with the Code, which describes the criteria for the reinstatement of RUSADA and was recently published on the organization's website.
According to Mutko, there is nothing in it that could give cause for concern to Russia.
"Everything has been announced, everything will be implemented.
And the results will be presented to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and WADA in the near future," he added.
However, one of the criteria in the list states that Russian anti-doping authorities must publicly accept the reported results of the WADA-approved investigation by Canadian lawyer Richard McLaren into alleged state-sponsored doping in Russian sport.
Regarding the matter, Mutko said: "We are conducting the investigation because our anti-doping system has admitted a mistake.
All measures have been implemented.
But there were no government programs, and we will not admit something that does not exist."
Mutko's words coincided with those of Vitaly Smirnov, the head of the independent Russian anti-doping commission.
Speaking with Russian sales outlet RSport earlier today, Smirnov admitted to past problems in Russian anti-doping organizations, but then added: "We have repeatedly said that the report contains controversial positions and regulations.
Nobody intends to accept this report unconditionally," Smirnov added.

However, she was allowed to plan and coordinate tests under the supervision of international experts and the UK Anti-Doping Agency (UKAD).
After a visit to the organization's headquarters in Moscow in July, WADA Director General Olivier Niggli stated that RUSADA is "moving in the right direction" to be reinstated.
