The start-ups that will help your company not to become the next super
Amy Errett wanted to measure your employees' happiness with your e-commerce start-up, but the surveys did not work.
Answers were often vague, unhelpful or - even worse - fraudulent.
And even if she promised anonymity, some workers did not trust the process.
"There was simply never any consistency or objectivity," said Errett, who runs the 75-person San Francisco e-commerce hair care company Madison Reed.
She was calling in people from the outside for help.
A new breed of human resources start-ups is growing to help companies find out how their employees feel.
By creating and licensing software that has the specific purpose of measuring employee engagement, it enables companies to conduct surveys, target specific groups and demographics, provide employee anonymity and complaint hotlines, and in some cases allow whistleblowers to bypass C-Suite executives and report directly to the Board of Directors.
"You now have tools like Strava and Fitbit to track your health, but where's the Fitbit for your business," said Jim Barnett, co-founder and chief executive of Redwood City start-up Glint, whose software analytics tools are used by companies to measure employee engagement.
Errett said that she gained a better insight into what your employees think and feel during the three years with Glint.
In addition to snap surveys and surveys of specific teams, it provides a heat map of the company that shows at a glance which units have the most complaints and which managers have low approval scores - so you can drill down to see why.
Companies are coming to realise that they need to stay at the forefront of workplace culture so that you don't become the next uber to be involved in scandals since a former employee posted a blog post describing an environment of harassment where those who spoke were punished.
For start-ups like Glint, this desire for an overview is a lucrative business opportunity.
The global governance, regulation and compliance industry could be worth more than $118.7 billion by 2020, according to the financial website Let's Talk Payments.
Denver, Colorado, start-up Convercent, which helps companies prevent and detect bad behavior, saw increased interest and activity earlier this year in the midst of the Uber-fall in discredit.
Convercent has nearly 600 clients, including Airbnb, Microsoft and Tesla.
Uber has recently registered as a client.
Like Glint, Convercent allows companies to send custom "pulse" surveys, collect confidential answers in real time and view the heat maps of your problem areas.
It also offers an anonymous SMS hotline where employees can report bad behaviour.
And if the chief executive is involved, complaints go directly to the supervisory board.
"The court of public opinion has captured the regulators," said Patrick Quinlan, founder and CEO of Convercent.
If a company is found to be mistreating its employees or behaving unethically, it can face costly consequences through consumer boycotts, employee turnover and lawsuits, Quinlan said.
Ruby Tuesday, the restaurant chain with more than 25,000 employees and over 500 locations, has deployed Convercent for more than a year to ensure that employees are aware of its policies and procedures and have an easy way to reach its corporate headquarters.
In the past, when an employee wanted to report a problem, he or she had to find a phone number or email for corporate headquarters, file a formal complaint and hope that he or she would be taken seriously.
It was often an intimidating and uncomfortable experience, said James Vitrano, Ruby Tuesdays General Counsel, who said there was no good way to pursue employee complaints.
Now that the company is using Convercent, issues that were previously hidden by executives sitting in city or state offices - such as discrimination, harassment or unfair practices - can be more quickly identified and addressed.
"I can get closer to that holistic, 360-degree view of the employment experience," said Vitrano, who leads Ruby Tuesday's Risk Management Group.
"And we protect our shareholders from employment litigation."
Companies began to take ethics, values and employee engagement more seriously in 2002 after the accounting firm Arthur Andersen collapsed over ethical violations in the Enron scandal, Quinlan said.
But it took time for the "social media to come into their own" that companies realized they could not prevent their dirty laundry from going online.
"Before the use of technology to monitor ethics, people used hope as a strategy," he said.
Both Glint and Convercent offer their software as a service and charge companies with recurring fees for the use of their products.
It is a business model and an opportunity that has the approval of venture capital investors who have both supported start-ups.
Convercent received $10 million in February financing from companies such as Sapphire Ventures and Tola Capital, bringing the total capital up to $47 million.
Glitter secured $10 million in November from Bessemer Venture Partners, bringing its total financing to $60 million.
These investments are hardly surprising, given the interconnected nature of business, culture and venture capital.
There is a growing body of research that shows that today's employees expect more from their jobs than ever before.
In competitive markets such as Silicon Valley, high salaries and interesting projects are just stakes.
The employees want to feel that you are accepted and appreciated and that you are giving your time to a company with a positive mission.
"When people are happy to be in a company, feel that their voices are heard and that the work you do is worthwhile, they feel a stronger commitment to making that company successful," said Nina McQueen, vice president of Global Benefits and Employee Experience at LinkedIn, which uses both Convercent and Glint.
Investors achieve returns when their portfolio companies perform well. Companies run well when employees are committed and engaged.
When third-party analytics tools promise to increase employee engagement and commitment, it's no wonder you find support.
The data on employee engagement according to the experts of workplace culture important.
But the data is useless if the managers of a company do not take action.
In fact, when a company asks employees for their feedback, they may have an expectation that change is on the way.
And if change does not come fast enough, or not at all, it can breed disappointment and demotivate employees.
"When you ask for 4,000 suggestions, you have to be willing to have 4,000 conversations," said Russell Raath, president of consulting at business management firm Kotter International, who has seen companies that relied too much on data collection.
"Because if you do not follow, staff will wonder, "Did you really hear me?
Will you take care of it?
And if you don't care, why should I? "
Madison Reed, which now conducts monthly employee surveys, has been able to take same-day action when a problem is reported on Glint, Errett said.
And after collecting feedback from frustrated employees, the speed of decision making and quality of communication enabled her to reorganize several teams within the company and add communication training to address the issues.
At Ruby Tuesday, the company continues to gain new insights about its employees, and it hopes that in the long run, this will lead to better retention of employees in an industry known for high turnover.
"If you are not committed to creating a culture of transparency, you will lose people," Vitrano said.
"And when you lose people, you lose customers.
And if you lose customers, you will lose companies.
The NCAA eliminates the two-day practices and makes a long day for the Bruins
It's heading towards 11pm as a crowd of UCLA football players converse on one side of the team's new practice fields on campus.
Some have taken off their jersey tops and show their backs full of sweat from the first day of training camp.
For a good part of the team these idle minutes represent a lunch break.
Players enrolled in the Summer Courses will return to their final exams after the three hours of practice before returning to the Wasserman Football Center at 6:30 the next morning.
"This is a real treadmill for the boys for the next three days," Bruins coach Jim Mora said just before Monday became Tuesday.
The NCAA is eliminating two-day practices to lighten the burden of the players, and they have actually extended their days - at least until the final on Friday.
Therefore, the first three UCLA training sessions should start at 19:15 to accommodate the already packed schedules of the players.
The compromise away from the two days is more than a day when the Bruins postponed the start of the camp for almost a week after last season and, during summer school, performed practical exercises for the first time during Mora's six seasons in Westwood.
They are to hold 18 exercises during August. 20 before the start of the formal match preparations for their opening match against Texas A & M in September.
Mora said he supported the NCAA's rule change, even if it added another point to the players' busy routes.
"We put this enormous burden on them for three or four days, and it's very challenging," Mora said.
"And they just pushed it through, they keep pushing themselves, they're great people.
I think once we get to Saturday and we have more time, it's gonna be really great."
UCLA will end its practices as soon as the camp is finished, which will not be an easy task given the clear lines of sight of its fields from an adjacent parking lot and the adjacent Luskin Center, an upscale hotel that has already been pelted with footballs that cleared a safety net behind a goalpost.
Bruins players are due to occupy the hotel from this weekend, but Mora acknowledged that there could be a problem once these rooms are available during the season.
"We will use our security," Mora said.
"This is a real problem, and it's not far-fetched to think that people will rent a room there and then get ready to record an exercise.
If you have the video tape of an exercise, it's a pretty good deal.
But we have security there, and we have security in parking lot 8.
We'll do the best we can with what we have.
I'm not too worried about it.
We have a plan."
Facebook wants to intensify fact-checking in the fight against fake messages
Facebook wants to send more potential articles with false reports to third-party fact-checkers and then display their results under the original article, the world's largest online social network said Thursday. It is one of his efforts to combat so-called fake news.
The company said in a statement on its website that it will begin using updated machine learning methods to detect possible false positives and send them to fact-checkers who may display results of fact-checking from the original article.
Facebook has been criticized as one of the main distribution points for so-called fake news, which many believe also influenced the US presidential election in 2016.
The problem has also become a major political issue in Europe, with French voters flooded with false stories in the run-up to the presidential elections in May, and Germany supports a plan to punish social media networks if they fail to quickly eliminate hateful postings as they did before the elections there in September.
On Thursday, Facebook said in a separate statement in German that a test of the new fact-check will be launched in the USA, France, the Netherlands and Germany.
"In addition to knowing what stories are being challenged by third-party fact-checkers, people want more context to make informed decisions about what they read and share," said Sara Su, product manager for Facebook News in a blog.
She added that Facebook will continue to test its "related article" feature and work on other changes to its news feed to reduce false positives.
Creating a comic novel: A castle in the history of England
In its recent past, little Scotney Castle was featured in a squeeze music video and was a loophole for Margaret Thatcher in the 1970s and 1980s.
But Scotney has experienced 700 years of turbulent history from his comfortable seat in the Bewl River Valley in Kent and has now become the inspiration for a graphic novel by Jamie Rhodes, a mop-haired Yorkshireman with a penchant for historical documents.
"I find it so beautiful to look at the handwriting of someone who has been dead for 300 years," he says wistfully.
"What a personal relationship to hold this letter in my hand."
A Castle in England' spans the period from the Middle Ages to the age of Edward and documents the families who lived in Scotney. Each story was illustrated by a different emerging British artist - Isaac Lenkiewicz, Briony May Smith, William Exley, Becky Palmer and Isabel Greenberg.
It is not the first book by Rhodes based on an archive: He wrote 'Dead Men's Teeth and Other Stories' in 2014, a collection inspired by documents in the British Library - a project he found unexpectedly emotional.
"I only reacted this way to the thumbprint on the page of a letter written by a double agent in the 1700s who worked for the Jacobins," he says.
"That's his thumbprint!
And letters always smell of smoke, because in those days they lit a fire because of the light.
For someone who lives 300 years later, the smell has an effect as if he himself was there.
Oh, I love archives!"
For someone who is so beaten with old papers that he is supported by the National Trust and the Arts Council England and lived in a castle for almost four months ("To be honest: I overestimated my welcome a little") this all seems too good to be true.
Rhodes spent his days exploring the Victorian "new" castle, looking through the archives and studying the many treasures and curiosities of the castle, such as the mounted hyena heads on the walls and the bottles that had spent centuries in the moat.
He wandered through the grounds and ruins of the old castle and talked to landscapers, gardeners and sometimes the artists who worked on the illustrations in his book.
Then, at night, he drank whiskey and started writing.
The intimate history of Scotney is relatively unknown, as the National Trust did not have full access until 2006, when the last heiress, Elizabeth Hussey, died.
When Rhodes arrived a decade later, the employees were just beginning to take care of the archive, which he described as "hundreds of years of aristocrats saying, 'Oh, throw it in the attic.
Diaries, letters from the time of the English Empire, maps showing who owned what: "You would think that land conflicts would be boring," says Rhodes, "but there was a birch tree that two families fought over.
Boys, let everything take its course!"
Some of the stories in the collection use the castle as a starting point for a broader exploration of English history, including 'The Labourer', who follows a man who leaves the newly built castle to join the Peasant Revolt of 1381.
"There is a record of a disturbance that occurred at the castle in 1380 in this book entitled 'Knightly Families of Kent and Sussex'," Rhodes says.
"The peasant uprising began in this area and I thought an uprising would be a good start.
Perhaps the two are connected?"
Other stories are deeply rooted in the history of the castle - such as 'The Priest', which tells the story of the Jesuit priest whom the Darrell family hid for seven years during the English Reformation.
Or 'The Smuggler', depicting 18th century smuggler Arthur Darrell, who staged his own funeral by filling a coffin with stones (a discovery made years later when his coffin was dug up).
The Darrells are Rhodes' favorite family of Scotney: "The gentlemen seemed to be quite crooks, always getting into debt and spending money on things they couldn't afford.
Other generations of Darrell men solved their debt crises by marrying rich old women - I imagine them as a bunch of good-looking guys with a talent for wooing heiresses.
After the end of his assignment at the castle, Rhodes is looking for other unique writing experiences
He spent two weeks in the Finnish wilderness for a comic novel about Elämänmäki, the site of an early 20th century sanatorium that has since been reclaimed by nature.
But Scotney has a special place for him.
"I was sad to leave again," he says.
It was like, "Oh, now I've got to get on with my fucking life again."

Military reforms in Turkey - Erdogan's fear of the army
Every year at the beginning of August, the Supreme Military Council (YAS) in Ankara discusses retirements and promotions in the officer corps.
Same this week.
At first sight a normal process.
But nothing is routine in the Turkish armed forces one year after the attempted coup.
The meeting no longer took place in the General Staff building, as it used to, but in the Prime Minister's office.
Under the chairmanship of the Head of Government, the five Deputy Prime Ministers and the Ministers of Defence, the Interior, Justice and Foreign Affairs now also took part in the discussions.
This outnumbered the civilians in the YAS.
The government is tightening the reins in the military.
Chief of General Staff Hulusi Akar remains in office, but the commanders of the army, air force and navy have been removed.
Since the failed coup, head of state Erdogan has fired 169 of the 326 generals and admirals.
More than 10,000 soldiers were removed from the ranks of the army - mostly because of alleged connections to the movement of the exiled preacher Fethullah Gülen, whom Erdogan sees as the mastermind behind the attempted coup.
Negotiations against 486 people who are said to have been directly involved in the coup attempt have been underway in Ankara since this week.
Already on the day after the coup, Erdogan had called the attempted coup a "gift of God" because it gave him the opportunity to "completely cleanse" the armed forces.
But does Erdogan really have control of the army?
At the end of February, the newspaper "Hürriyet" published an article entitled "Discomfort at Military Headquarters".
There are concerns in the general staff about an increasing "Islamization" of the army, which manifests itself among other things in the lifting of the headscarf ban for female soldiers, the newspaper wrote.
In any case, the large-scale cleaning up of the army and security forces continues.
In mid-July, Erdogan issued a decree firing a further 7395 civil servants, including 2303 police officers and 546 soldiers.
It seemed that Erdogan had tamed the military.
The generals used to be considered the real masters of the country.
Three times they coup d'état with reference to their role as guardians of the secular state order.
After his election victory in 2002, Erdogan pushed back the power of the military step by step, not least in reference to the reform guidelines of the European Union.
Former officers say that Erdogan is deliberately pushing for an Islamization of the armed forces.
In the magazine "Vocal Europe", an officer not mentioned by name, who sought asylum abroad after the attempted coup for fear of persecution, warned that in a few years the Turkish army would be "full of extremists and Salafists".
If this were true, such a development could not leave Nato cold.
In any case, there are doubts in the alliance after the purges about the readiness of the Turkish army.
The leadership structures and operational capabilities are "weakened", say NATO diplomats.

The rise of sex robots is real, and we should be concerned
Just when you thought it couldn't get any crazier in 2017, a new report comes out on technological developments in the field of sex robots.
Yes, indeed.
Sex robots are a big deal right now.
Recently, the Foundation for Responsible Robotics (FRR) published a report on the development of sex robots over the next five to ten years.
According to Noel Sharkey, Professor Emeritus of Robotics and Artificial Intelligence at the University of Sheffield and co-founder of the FRR, we must start to take their rise seriously.
Customers can choose the eye color of the robot, its nipple shape and the type of fingernail.
"People make fun of them, but companies are delivering plenty of them, and we will see more of them," said Mr Sharkey on the release of his new report.
Modern sex dolls have evolved from their inflatable partners to robots with a silicone skin that feels warm to the touch - with conscious human reactions achieved by artificial intelligence.
The user can also "customize" his robot according to his beliefs, choosing everything from the color of the robot's eyes to the shape of its nipples to the type or color of its fingernails.
But it becomes even more disturbing, as many robots possess the "personalities" that would make a Stepford woman look progressive.
Modern sex dolls have developed into robots with a silicone skin.
For example, the RealBotix robot allows its users to customize their robots to the characteristics they find appealing, such as shyness.
And then there are the Roxxxy Gold sex robots developed by True Companion, with pre-programmed personalities such as "Frigid Farrah", who gives the impression of shyness, and "Wild Wendy" with an "adventurous" personality.
"Roxxxy Gold has a personality that fits your personality as well as possible," enthuses the True Companion website.
So she likes what you like, and she doesn't like what you don't like, etc.
She also has her moods during the day - just like real people!
She can be tired, she can be fixated on conversation, or she can be "in the mood"!"
There are many disturbing aspects to this rise of sex robots - not least because they replace real human relationships - but the submissive female characteristics, the allusions to rape when you take a step towards Frigid (meaning here: reluctant) Farrah, worry you the most.
On his website True Companion compared Roxxxy to a vibrator, but for men.
"If women (sic) can have a vibrator, why can't men have Roxxxy?" the website says.
But these sex robots are not just a fetish or just another sex toy.
Their emergence and increasing sophistication point to something darker and deeper in our culture, a retreat from the ideal of gender equality to a desire for sex with submission as an optional extra.
Most men, of course, will not keep sex robots, and while the FRR notes their growing popularity, they remain on the fringes of consumer culture for the time being.
But what leaks out from the margins can be very instructive in terms of the spirit of the times in which we live.
And many people are not strange or offensive until the free market gives them permission to do so.
There is some overlap that these sophisticated sex robots appear at a time when women's rights are threatened worldwide, when there is a president in the White House who has bragged about sexually assaulting women.
The most frightening aspect of the television series 'The Handmaid's Tale' is not the graphic images, the intertwined bodies and the gouged out eyes, but how realistic this vision seems.
The Republic of Gilead is a leap, but right now it doesn't feel like a big leap.
The goal behind these sex robots is to create a physical resemblance to actual women as realistically as technically possible (albeit in porn star proportions).
Their builders want them to feel human, to imitate the movement of a real body.
But, in a nutshell, when it comes to their "personalities", the robots do not represent real women.
They cannot separate from their companion or simply walk away.
They have no mediation or a background story, nothing that suggests independence or anything that could disturb the fantasy of total submission.
In other words, they are pleasing slaves.
Or to put it in the 2017 expression: Maid
Trump's big achievement?
He makes Mitt Romney the epitome of common sense
It has become a truism of the Trump era that the political divisions that polarized the U.S. electorate have also split families on a small scale.
Around Christmas and Thanksgiving, there were newspapers in the USA with advice on how to deal with the horror of Trump voting relatives.
We are all supposedly working hard to burst our filter bubbles.
Less noticed is the power of Trump to bring families together.
I mention this because my cousin, a left-wing poet who lives in Chicago and has long been involved with the Republicans in our family, visited me in New York this week.
She reminded me that unity against a common enemy can have a powerful effect.
With Trump in the White House, everyone she knows, including the Republican kinship she fought with for decades over politics, is suddenly and strangely on the same side.
Around the dining table is certainly a good thing, but it strikes me in a broader context that this also entails considerable risks.
The left was strengthened by Trump, but the disfiguring effect of his presidency has the power to push us all to the right.
When we speak of "normalization" and Trump, we are referring to the spooky possibility that one day his antics will no longer repel us.
But there is an even more frightening long-term scenario in which Trump "normalizes" right-wing Republicans who suddenly appear to be the epitome of reasonableness compared to his standards.
These days I find myself infected by an active nostalgia for Mitt Romney's hilarious version of the madman - the dog on the roof of the car, the 14% income tax (but at least we knew what his tax return looked like) - both of which, compared to Trump, seem like very mild crimes indeed.
If Trump goes, the next Republican candidate only needs to be mentally healthy to qualify as a tremendous improvement.

The horses are enormously large, the fibreglass designs on the central cylinder - all the clowns are grumpy and the animals twist to look over their own shoulders in fear - extremely sinister and the jingling music conveys this in a strange way.
So many clichés of a city disappoint: The views of tall buildings are getting old, the skylines are becoming too familiar to offer much excitement, and the reality of the city does not live up to the dream.
Thirty-five years later, and I'm still not quite over the day when I found out that Swiss Cottage is in fact not a Swiss Cottage - the theme pub Ye Olde Swiss Cottage doesn't count - but a large roundabout in the north of London.
However, the Central Park Carousel is still a strangely magical experience as two two two-year-olds, one 11-year-old and two women in their 40s can walk on it and all have a great time.
If I could have rated the carousel, I would have given him the full score, but luckily nobody asked for it.
On the other hand, this week in a department store, I was forced to rate my "experience" with transactions on a scale of one to five stars before I could swipe my credit card.
The coffee shop on the corner of my street is the same, plus the option to match the rating with a 15% tip - this to buy something over the counter.
This not only slows down what should actually be a neutral exchange, but also puts pressure on the server to bring personality into a situation where none is required.
The poor woman in the department store stood smiling apologetically while I tiredly experienced handing her my five-star credit card.

Software update for diesel vehicles: What those affected need to know now
How exactly does the software update take place?
Do diesel drivers have to participate in the campaign?
The most important questions and answers at a glance.
At the Diesel Summit, BMW, Daimler, Opel and the VW Group offered software updates for a total of around 5.3 million cars.
They are intended to improve the exhaust gas behaviour of cars in the Euro 5 and, in some cases, Euro 6 emission classes.
Euro 4 diesel or worse are excluded.
Anja Smetanin from the ACE Auto Club Europa gives assessments:
Is the new action mandatory?
No, the negotiated software updates are voluntary.
"The obligatory updates beforehand only apply to vehicles that have cheating software," says Anja Smetanin.
The Federal Motor Transport Authority (KBA) has ordered their retrofitting.
How and when will customers be informed about updates?
The manufacturers have announced a speedy implementation in the coming months, but have not yet given a precise date.
Daimler has announced that it will write to each person concerned.
If an inspection is due anyway, it is carried out within the framework of that inspection.
How long do you expect the overall conversions to take?
"Hard to say," says Smetanin.
This depends on the commitment of manufacturers and political pressure.
"Because we have seen that the automakers are not taking voluntary action on environmental issues."
How long should the update take?
The conversion itself could only take three to four hours in the workshop.
It could be more time-consuming to get an appointment.
What do drivers do who do not drive a car from BMW, Daimler, Opel and the VW group?
ACE advises to wait.
Foreign manufacturers would probably follow suit, Smetanin said.
Is there now a threat of a massive drop in the price of Euro 4 cars?
The ACE is afraid of that.
But precisely in those regions where driving bans are threatened.
In rural areas, there have not been any losses in value for older diesels so far.
The ACE advises to wait with a sale.

We make the city liveable
Roland Wacker, Haslach's master builder, will retire next year.
The position is already advertised - but suitable applicants are rare.
Wacker has been a city architect for 31 years.
And he still really enjoys his work, as he explains in the press conference.
He reports on varied, but also challenging tasks that await his successor.
At the same time, he is surprised that no application has met the requirements profile so far.
The city is looking for an architect or civil engineer as soon as possible.
Thus, there should be enough time for an induction period - taking into account the regular notice periods.
Since Haslach acts as the lower building authority for the administrative community, the applicant must present appropriate qualifications.
Because the city wants to keep this function in any case.
If she were no longer able to fill them out, citizens would have to drive all the way to Offenburg for consultation.
But being close to the citizens is important to the city and to himself, says Wacker, who reports a good working atmosphere and a good atmosphere between the authorities and the citizens.
In more than 30 years in office, Wacker has accumulated a number of significant projects of which it can look back with pride.
"We make the city worth living in", he is sure about the building authority and his employees.
But the agenda for the future will continue to be varied: the redesign of the former Hukla site and the Niederhofen car park, for example, have been initiated.
The Kinzig bridge between Bollenbach and Steinach is being renewed, and the stadium renovation is also still a topic.
The latter alone will cost around 1.5 million euros, "if we do it right," estimates Wacker.
"All in all, great tasks await my successor.
It's fun to work here."
In terms of design, there is a great deal of scope for a master builder.
With Haslach's own building yard and nursery, it is possible to react quite flexibly to many things.
"You can move a lot", said Wacker, and the design of the green spaces is often praised by citizens and visitors alike.
Since the old town as an ensemble is a listed building, it is important "to have an eye for what fits in" when new buildings are approved, emphasises the outgoing city architect.
Anyway, the master builder of the city bears a high responsibility.
He's a builder-owner, "in the end, everything here will be on my desk".
For support and coordination he can count on longstanding employees: Markus Neumaier (structural engineering) has been with us for ten years, Manfred Schöner (civil engineering) for 15 years.
Wacker also hopes that his successor will stay for a long time: "We are looking for someone who really identifies with the position and wants to stay.
Continuity is not only important for a good working atmosphere, but also for the further development of the city.
According to the city of Haslach, anyone wishing to inherit Roland Wacker should have completed a degree in engineering or a bachelor's degree in architecture and have good specialist knowledge in the fields of building regulations and building planning law.
The municipal building authority is responsible for structural and civil engineering, urban land use planning, land acquisition matters, administration of municipal real estate, municipal depot with building yard and municipal nursery as well as lower building authority including monument protection.

Just under ten passenger trains were down on Friday morning, two of which were long-distance trains.
Freight trains did not break down, but they were delayed.
According to ÖBB spokesman Christoph Posch, around 200 metres of overhead lines had to be replaced.
Insulators and masts were also damaged.
Red meat, dairy products and chocolate could help relieve IBD (inflammatory bowel disease)
Red meat and chocolate can sound like a nightmare for your digestive system.
But a new study claims just the opposite: a diet rich in meat-based proteins and dairy products could relieve the symptoms of patients with inflammatory bowel disease.
The incurable condition, which affects about 1.3 million in the USA and 300,000 in the UK, causes stomach cramps and flatulence, recurrent or bloody diarrhoea, weight loss and extreme fatigue.
While sufferers are usually advised to avoid meat and dairy products to alleviate their symptoms, researchers at Washington University found that the essential amino acid tryptophane from proteins helps immune cells develop that promote a tolerant gut.
The lead researcher, Dr. Marco Colonna, explained that immune cells patrol the intestines to ensure that harmful microbes hiding in food do not enter the body.
Cells that are capable of causing inflammation are balanced by cells that promote tolerance and protect the body without damaging sensitive tissues.
If the equilibrium tends too far towards inflammation, an inflammatory bowel disease can result.
Experiments have shown that a type of tolerance-promoting immune cell occurs in mice that carry a certain bacterium in their intestines.
And the bacterium needs tryptophan - one of the building blocks of proteins - to trigger the appearance of the cells.
Professor Colonna said: "We have established a link between a species of bacteria - Lactobacillus reuteri - which is a normal part of the intestinal microbiome, and the development of a population of cells that promote tolerance.
The more tryptophan the mice had in their food, the more of these "immune cells" they had.
He suggested that the combination of L. reuteri and a diet rich in tryptophan promotes more tolerant, less inflammatory intestinal environments when the same system is effective in humans.
Postdoctoral researcher Dr. Luisa Cervantes-Barragan was investigating a type of immune cell that promotes tolerance when she found that one group of study mice had such cells but another group of the same strain, but housed separately, did not.
She suspected that the difference had to do with the intestinal microbiomes of mice - the community of bacteria, viruses and fungi that normally live in the gastrointestinal tract.
The intestines of the mice were DNA-sequenced and six species of bacteria were found that were present in the mice with the immune cells but absent in the mice without them.
Mice were raised in a sterile environment, so they lacked an intestinal microbiome and did not develop this type of immune cells, and they were given L. reuteri and the immune cells developed.
In order to understand how the bacteria affected the immune system, the researchers grew L. reuteri in a liquid and then transferred small amounts of the liquid - without the bacteria - to immature immune cells that were isolated from the mice.
The immune cells developed into the tolerance promoting cells.
When the active component was purified from the liquid, it turned out to be a by-product of the tryptophan metabolism known as indole-3-lactic acid.
When the researchers doubled the amount of tryptophan in the mice' food, the number of such cells increased by about 50 percent, but when the tryptophan levels were halved, the number of cells decreased by half.
Dr. Cervantes-Barragan explained that humans have the same tolerance-promoting cells as mice, and that most of us protect L. reuteri in our gastrointestinal tracts.
It is not known whether tryptophan by-products from L. reuteri develop cells in humans in the same way as in mice, but defects in genes related to tryptophan have been found in humans with inflammatory bowel disease.
She said: "The development of these cells is probably something we want to encourage, as these cells control inflammation on the inner surface of the intestine.
Potentially, high levels of tryptophane in the presence of L. reuteri can lead to an expansion of this population".
Jose Mourinho believes that Manchester United has signed a "genius" with Nemanja Matic

No disturbing fires from party headquarters, no headwinds from the federal government - that was the most important wish of the campaigners.
Since Martin Schulz has been leading the party, this has changed fundamentally.
Since then, the employees of the Willy Brandt House have been observing with growing horror the events in the SPD-ruled state capitals.
What Schulz has received from there since the beginning of the year would not even be described with headwind.
It was low blows.
One at a time.

Elke Twesten must immediately give back her mandate," the federal executive and campaign manager of the Greens told the RedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND).

Since then Scholz has been fighting for his political survival.
So now Stephan Weil as well.

Lousy poll numbers were added.
In spite of this, or perhaps precisely because of it, Weil has tried to set accents in the Federation more and more in recent weeks.
The efforts of the former mayor of Hanover to increase his power in Berlin did not remain hidden even from comrades in Martin Schulz's circle.
They let him go, because they expected Weil to stabilize the party.
Now the exact opposite could happen.
But Weil is basically not to blame for the internal party quarrel of the Greens in Lower Saxony.
And certainly not Schultz.
For the time being the comrades are therefore trying to keep their own ranks closed.
Their anger is directed at the Greens, and in particular at the renegade parliamentarian Twesten.
"It is intolerable and damaging to democracy how Ms. Twesten puts her own career interests above the interests of everyone else," says Matthias Miersch, head of the party left in the SPD parliamentary group, the RedaktionsNetzwerk Deutschland (RND).
Ms Twesten was not elected to parliament as a direct candidate but via the state list of the Lower Saxony Greens, the Lower Saxony MEP continued.
The logical consequence would be that she gives back her mandate.
Thomas Oppermann, head of the SPD parliamentary group, complains of an "undemocratic manoeuvre".
"The will of the voters four years ago was clear: the people have made Stephan Weil prime minister," says Oppermann, who is leading the SPD of Lower Saxony as the top candidate in the federal elections, to the RND.
"Now the personal career thinking of a future CDU member of parliament is distorting the election results", Oppermann continued.
He demanded that the background be clarified.
I want to know whether there has been more or whether there have been further commitments by the CDU Lower Saxony.
Subsidies for town centre III
Those who want to renovate their aging house can soon receive support from the state.
Mayor Albert Schindler and three representatives of STEG Stadtentwicklung informed about this on Wednesday in Empfingen.
At the beginning of the information event, Schindler gave a review of what has happened so far.
Since 1991 there have been redevelopment areas in Empfingen.
At that time, in remediation area I from 1991 to 2004, the state of Baden-Württemberg had still taken over two thirds of the funding.
In remediation area II from 2005 to 2016, the subsidy was still 60 percent.
For Schindler, the renovations to date are a "success project" - after all, he says, it is important to promote interior development as well, and not just to open up new construction areas.
On April 4, the Karlsruhe Regional Council informed the authorities that there would be a remediation area III.
The total amount of funding was 833 333 euro, of which 500 000 euro came from the Land and the rest from the municipality of Empfingen.
How is a redevelopment area created?
According to Schindler, they will investigate where the "really old" houses are.
However, it also plays a role whether there is any interest at all in the planned area to redevelop.
If necessary, the area boundaries could then shift again.
The STEG was represented on Wednesday evening by Martin Keller, Gaby Pietzschmann and Sarah Gotzel.
Keller presented the contents of the Federal-Länder programme "Socially Integrative City", under which the redevelopments would then be carried out.
The core of the programme is the revitalisation of inner cities, the improvement of housing and employment conditions and the maintenance and expansion of infrastructure.
The measures would be carried out on a property-by-property basis.
The remediation area would then finally be defined as a statute.
The period for granting subsidies runs from 1 January 2017 until 30 April 2026.
However, the stocktaking would be carried out until September of this year, during which the parties involved in the remediation area would receive a questionnaire to fill in.
In November or December, if possible, the resolution on the articles of association should be passed so that renovation work can begin next year.
Pietzschmann then explained that each municipality had to carry out the aforementioned preliminary investigations.
It was a matter of assessing the urban planning shortcomings and deciding when and to what extent renovation should be carried out.
A notice of reorganization would then also be entered in the land register for the respective property.
She promised that Pietzschmann himself would come back to the reception and get an idea of the situation.
Gotzel emphasised that an essential factor in the success of the project was the involvement of all those involved.
Therefore, there will be questionnaires that will be sent to citizens by post in the coming weeks and can be filled out until after the end of the summer holidays.
The yellow questionnaire is the "building and property sheet", which deals with, among other things, the structural condition and the renovation intentions.
In the grey questionnaire, the "Household and Apartment Questionnaire", information can be given on the size, division and occupants of a dwelling.
The blue 'farm return' is to be completed only if business premises are operated in the building.
However, it should be noted, Gotzel pointed out, that a completed questionnaire is not at the same time an application for subsidies.
Moreover, new construction measures were not eligible for aid.
Schindler also emphasized that the distribution of the subsidies is based on the "first come, first served" principle - first come, first served.
It is not possible to "reserve" funding for later.
Finally, photos of the "Ortskern II" project were shown to make the renovation "palatable" to those present.
British inventor puts a microchip on himself to get into house and car with one hand movement
A British inventor is the first in the country to be equipped with a microchip so he can open his front door, enter his office and even start his car with a flick of his wrist.
Steven Northam, 33, implanted the tiny chip between his thumb and index finger and now offers the service to companies and individuals who want to simplify their lives with technology through his company BioTeq.
He has teamed up with Dr Geoff Watson, a consultant anaesthesiologist at the Royal Hampshire County Hospital in Winchester, Hants, to ensure that the implant procedure is performed to medical standards.
The technology is similar to a microchip implanted in cats and dogs and takes only 30 seconds.
Mr Northam's company also wants to modify locks on houses and cars to be compatible with the chip, all at an extra cost of £300 per lock.
The married father of one now has technology built into both his home and his BMW Z4 that starts when his hand is at the wheel.
White House advertising costs cost the taxpayer thousands
The White House's decision to fly a Navy helicopter to South Lawn for an event that highlights American manufacturing last month is costing taxpayers up to $24,000, according to military sources released to TIME magazine.
The green and white Sikorsky VH-3D, known as Marine One when the President is on board, was the centerpiece of the July 17th event at the White House with American construction programs.
President Donald Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and White House senior officials took a tour of products from all 50 states.
The Connecticut-built helicopter was displayed alongside a yacht from Maine, a fire engine from Wisconsin and a forklift from Mississippi.
The White House Military Office requested the presence of the helicopter in a fragmentary order, or FRAGO, barely 36 hours before the helicopter landed on South Lawn, according to the records of Marine Helicopter Squadron One (HMX-1), the unit responsible for operating the helicopter.
"I just wanted you to be aware of this because it is such an unusual event with high visibility," the commander of the HMX-1 wrote to his superior, the Deputy Naval Aviation Commander, the evening before the event.
The news indicated that the helicopter arrived on July 17 at about 7 a.m. on South Lawn for the 3 p.m. event, and stayed until the lawn was cleared between 6 and 9 p.m. that evening.
The note adds that if the departure from the White House were to be delayed, a second crew would be needed for the return flight due to the limitation of duty hours.
The original flight crew was with the helicopter during the event, while the unit's security personnel remained with the aircraft during the time on the ground.
It was not clear from the records made available to TIME whether a second flight crew was ultimately required.
The Hatch Act prohibits federal employees from using government property for political purposes.
Records indicate that HMX-1 asked if the event could violate the determination.
"One question we asked was whether it was a violation of the Hatch Act and we were informed that it was not," the commander wrote.
"Sounds like you're locked up," replied the deputy commander.
The "Made in America" event was designated by the White House as an official event and would not have been covered by the Hatch Act.
But official events also have political overtones.
At the event, the president gave an impetus to the health care reform process underway in the Senate and he promoted efforts to curb government regulations.
The use of the aircraft known as Marine One or Air Force One for politically advantageous purposes is hardly a new phenomenon.
Presidents are obliged to use them for the trip.
But to request their use only for a photo op is unusual.
Trump was conducting an investigation in February when the presidential aircraft was providing taxi services against the backdrop of its first campaign rally in Melbourne, Florida, and his Twitter account is full of messages complaining about the use of the presidential aircraft by his predecessor.
"The White House is excited about the show 'Made In America' - which shows products from all 50 states, made by American workers using American materials," said White House Assistant Press Secretary Lindsay Walters.
HMX-1 crews frequently conduct training flights in the Washington area and South Lawn to drop the U.S. President at the White House with precise centimetre sets.
When Trump was at the G20 summit in Germany in early July, HMX-1 made 58 practice landings at the White House.
The flight for the "Made in America" event counted among the flight crew's training needs for the month, an official said.
Helicopter units flew an additional 11 hours that day for "non-presidential support missions".
The White House said the taxpayers did not take the burden for any of the other props presented at the event.
A spokesman for Sikorsky said that the company was not involved in exhibiting the helicopter on South Lawn.
HMX-1 does not maintain budget records for the presidential flights, and it is difficult to determine the exact cost of the event.
However, according to the hourly rates of the US Department of Defense for the 2017 fiscal year, the DoD reimbursement rate for the VH-3D is USD 24,380 per flight hour.
The unit's records record the aircraft's flight time as 30 minutes from the Marine Corps Air Facility home base at Quantico, Virginia.
The White House argues that the actual cost of operating the helicopter is far below this rate.
"To base the cost to taxpayers on estimates for reimbursement rates is highly misleading," Walters said.
"These estimates include personnel, maintenance and many other hidden costs that are included in the annual budget."
According to a RAND study from 2015, the reimbursement rates for DoD do not include personnel costs, but take into account the costs for fuel, maintenance and contracting.
At that time, former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the use of the helicopter for the event.
"The idea is to showcase things made in America this week," Spicer said.
"And I know that Sikorsky and the state of Connecticut are very proud of the fact that they contribute to our national security, and I expect hundreds if not thousands of people depend on them.
And I think, like most Americans, we are all proud of the helicopter and other military equipment for which so many Americans have worked tirelessly.
It is, of course, appropriate to emphasize that."
It wasn't clear if Trump was interacting with the helicopter as he walked his tour of South Lawn for the event, but he sat in the driver's seat of a fire truck.
At the White House, Trump spoke to representatives of Sikorsky and joked with the media about his own fleet of corporate products.
"I know Sikorsky very well," the president said, "I have three of them."

Roll backwards: The city hires 46 kitchen helpers
The city is once again organising the day care centre lunch itself.
With fixed contact persons for the children and an assignment to the team.
In the municipal day-care centres the clock is turned back.
As of September 1, the city of Krefeld will once again take over the food supply in the city's day care centers (kindergartens) on its own.
For Sonja Pommeranz, deputy head of the youth welfare department, this is good news: "We were all very pleased".
Cooking continues to be done outside the company: a caterer takes over this task and delivers freshly cooked, chilled food.
The city runs 46 day-care centres in the Krefeld area, in 44 of them the children get a warm meal at lunchtime.
In the last year of kindergarten, 2800 children sat at each table and the demand is growing steadily.
"In the meantime, it is not only children who are looked after for 45 hours a week who eat lunch at the daycare center," Pommeranz explains.
"Offer also applies to 35-hour care if children stay until 2 p.m."
46 part-time employees will be on kitchen duty from 1 September: they will warm up the delivered food, add salad, raw vegetables and fruit, portion the meal individually, serve the food, clean up, wash up and clean the kitchen.
"The employees are permanently assigned to a day care centre," says Pommeranz.
The size - there are two-group as well as seven-group facilities - determines the amount of hours.
"The kitchen helpers are now a permanent member of the daycare team," says Pommeranz with satisfaction.
"This way they are much more involved and it is easier for the kindergarten management to implement pedagogical concepts".
Because that's what it's all about: healthy eating and cooking lessons.
"Let the children help prepare the food."
The direct connection of the kitchen staff to the team makes sense.
Also for the children.
"They have a known force in the day care centre, a person they know, and not constantly changing people".
This continuity is important for the children.
The cleaning of the kindergarten rooms - previously also the task of the kitchen staff - will in future be carried out by special cleaning personnel.
This variant - the separation of cleaning and kitchen service - not only improves the quality of the kitchen service but also has the charm that it has proven to be the most economical for the city in the cost comparison between in-house and outsourced services, according to the press office.
And this despite the fact that 46 part-time employees are being recruited.
"But with around 750 people in the education sector, these hours don't carry much weight," says Sonja Pommeranz.
Afghan democracy depends on the political role of women, says the UN
Elections can only be representative if all members of society, including women, play a role, said the head of the UN mission in Afghanistan on Wednesday.
Nicholas Haysom, Acting Head of the United Nations Mission, said hundreds of women will run for office in provincial council elections. Three women are running for the role of vice-president and more than 30 percent of the newly registered voters are women.
"The role of women cannot be overestimated," he said in a statement on Wednesday.
Elections can only be truly representative and credible if women participate fully and are involved in all parts of the electoral process.
Afghan elections for the provincial council and presidential elections will be held on 5 April.
The Taliban have issued threats against an electoral process, coinciding with the transition from international fighting to a consultative role.
This year, for the first time, the elections will see the peaceful transfer of power from one democratically elected government to another.
Haysom said a strong role for women will further enhance Afghanistan's democratic success.
The Afghan Independent Electoral Commission reports that 1.2 million women are registered out of a total of 3.6 million registered voters.

When Manchester City expressed interest in signing Blaise Matuidi in 2014, Nasser Al-Khelaifi had a stern warning for any club wishing to have one of PSG's top players signed.
"I am not worried because they know that if they touch one of our players, we will be in opposition to them, we will contact their players," said Al-Khelaifi.
"We respect all clubs.
But if they try to have one of our players sign with them, there will be consequences."
Barcelona seem to have crossed that line, with the Spanish club expressing interest in PSG midfielder Marco Verratti earlier this summer.
PSG made it clear that they would not allow the international from Italy to leave under any circumstances, and Barcelona could feel the consequences of this interest by losing one of its price offers for Neymar.
Scooter overturned and damaged
In the night from Friday to Saturday, an unknown perpetrator deliberately knocked over a scooter parked in Königsfelder Straße in front of property number 30, causing property damage of over 200 euros to the lining of the vehicle.
The Schramberg police, telephone 07422/ 27 01-0, is asking for information.
The police are looking for witnesses to an accident on the B 215 between Stolzenau and Leese.
Because a car was coming towards him in his lane, the driver of a VW Touran had to swerve and touched the crash barrier.
On Thursday evening, the 34-year-old from Rehburg-Loccum was on the B 215 coming from Stolzenau in the direction of Leese with his VW at around 19.55 hours.
In the area of the Stolzenau bypass, a car was coming towards him in his lane, so he had to swerve to the right.
The Touran driver touched the crash barrier.
Property damage was caused to the car.
The driver of the oncoming car, a Mercedes Benz, had overtaken a truck and continued his journey without taking care of the traffic accident.
According to the accident victim, it may well be that the Mercedes driver had not even noticed the accident.
The police are now asking witnesses of the incident as well as the driver of the vehicle responsible to contact the police station in Stolzenau under Tel. 05761 / 92060.
Interview: "Domspatzen report exonerates pope brother Georg Ratzinger"
The Regensburger Domspatzen report on the abuse cases exonerates pope brother Georg Ratzinger.
This is the opinion of author and historian Michael Hesemann.
The final report on the abuse scandal at the Regensburger Domspatzen continues to cause discussion.
Christian Weisnder, spokesman of the reform movement "We are Church", told the German Press Agency after publication that he expected an apology from the former Bishop of Regensburg and now Cardinal Gerhard Ludwig Müller as well as from the Cathedral Kapellmeister Georg Ratzinger, the 93-year-old brother of the emeritus Pope Benedict XVI.
It would serve the reputation of the Catholic Church greatly if Müller and Ratzinger were to express their deep regret about their own omissions or their then wrong assessment of the events.
The Vatican newspaper "Osservatore Romano", on the other hand, criticised that the coverage of violence among the Cathedral Sparrows was measured with "double standards".
With regard to the attacks in Regensburg, no one doubts that these were "shameful and shameful acts" that should be punished and prevented in the future; however, the "degree of media manipulation" is striking, according to the author Lucetta Scaraffia, historian and member of the Italian National Bioethics Committee.
"The habit of referring to the Catholic Church as the source of all evil is already part of everyday experience and prepares public opinion to consider it normal," writes Scaraffia.
Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis also said in an interview with the Bavarian Radio: "People like to go to church and that's a real treat".
She also pointed out that in her youth, "beatings were a perfectly normal pedagogical tool" to "deal with naughty children like myself".
She thinks it is unfair to apply today's standards to earlier decades, because the world has changed.
In connection with the reports about the abuse cases often also Pope Brother Georg Ratzinger appeared.
Completely wrongly, says author and historian Michael Hesemann, who together with Ratzinger wrote the commemorative volume "My Brother the Pope" (translated into 12 languages).
"I must defend Georg Ratzinger", says Hesemann, "because all this had nothing to do with him", he evaluates the results of the final report.
What exactly does it say in the 440-page report presented by the lawyer Ulrich Weber, who was commissioned by the diocese of Regensburg to clarify the matter?
A total of 547 Regensburger Domspatzen were victims of assaults "with high plausibility" between 1945 and the early 1990s, 67 Domspatzen were sexually abused.
In the final report it says about Georg Ratzinger, who was active in Regensburg from 1964 to 1994: "In summary it can be stated that in many cases forms of physical and psychological violence were used by Cathedral Kapellmeister R.
Especially when the emotions were high, the punishment for the students could be more severe.
Nevertheless, in contrast to numerous other accused persons, it is noticeable that many victims appreciated the general humanity of R. and therefore in many cases, despite the violence, even associate positive memories with him".
In an interview, Hesemann explains why he believes that the final report on the abuse scandal involving the Regensburger Domspatzen exonerates Georg Ratzinger.
Mr. Hesemann, the 440-page report on the "incidents of violence against subjects of protection at the Regensburger Domspatzen" gives a contradictory picture of the cathedral conductor Georg Ratzinger.
For one thing, many students emphasize his "humanity".
On the other hand, he also appears as a choleric and perfectionist, who often became violent when a Domspatz did not give a top musical performance.
As his biographer, what do you think of this final report?
Michael Hesemann: If you take the trouble to read the entire 440-page report from front to back, you have to ask yourself why the name Georg Ratzinger is even mentioned in it.
There are just eight pages dedicated to him and he is clearly cleared of any suspicion of complicity or complicity in the horrific cases of sexual abuse.
The violent excesses at the preschool also occurred outside his sphere of influence.
At best, he can be accused of learning about it too late or of not taking initial hints seriously enough.
The Domspatzengymnasium, where he worked, was perceived by practically all those questioned as - so literally - "redemption", "heaven" and "a better world".
The vast majority of his students also give Georg Ratzinger an excellent report card, describing him as "warmhearted", "popular", "sincere", "competent" and "understanding", as an extremely good-natured teacher who regularly supplied the boys with cakes, cookies and sweets and was "always surrounded by grapes from children".
Only a minority complains about his perfectionism and high emotionality, which sometimes led to outbursts of rage.
He himself admitted years ago that he not only banged chairs and threw his bunch of keys on the floor, but also slapped and pulled too cheeky boys by their hair or ears, he deeply regretted and apologized for that.
In his honour, however, it must be said that such educational methods were widespread in the period in question, the 1960s and 1970s, among parents and teachers alike.
Do you also know such methods of corporal punishment?
Of course, I think any of us born before 1968
I too experienced this in a secular school, a state grammar school.
Compared with what this report is actually about, namely the appalling sexual abuse and excesses of violence at pre-school, these are admittedly trifles.
One wonders whether it has not rather to do with his fame and his role as brother of Benedict XVI that many media pounced on him.
Many who have never understood the Bavarian Pope are still working hard on him.
But the truth is: The report relieves Georg Ratzinger in every respect!
In connection with the report there was a lot of media coverage of the subject of abuse among the Regensburger Domspatzen.
Does the final report also accuse Georg Ratzinger of any involvement or complicity in sexual abuse?
Michael Hesemann: Clearly not.
Not a single one of the 67 victims of sexual assault claims to have confided in the Cathedral Kapellmeister.
Not even the parents were in on it.
"I never dared to talk to my father or my mother about it," said one person concerned on behalf of the others, "It was all very embarrassing for me.
The real problem in clearing up sexual abuse was and still is that most victims remain silent out of shame.
If they did not even confide in parents and siblings, then certainly not in a choirmaster, who would have been a colleague of the perpetrators in a professional sense.
How do the Domspatzen students evaluate Ratzinger's role with regard to the cases of abuse?
Michael Hesemann: One of the students questioned put it this way: "With regard to sexual abuse ... I see... no case in which he (Georg Ratzinger) of all people would have had timely knowledge and could have stopped the respective perpetrator.
I think it... it's really absurd to assume that he, of all people. boys have opened up more forcefully or clearly or even earlier than to their parents, boarding school directors, counselors, etc.
Talking to him about sex... - unthinkable."
Thus the report comes to the very clear conclusion: "The fact that pupils and/or their environment confided in him beforehand could not be confirmed during the investigation".
As far as sexual abuse is concerned, Georg Ratzinger is therefore to be acquitted of any complicity.
Thus, he cannot be accused of not having prevented him or brought him to court.
There is therefore no reason to associate his good name with these heinous crimes, as has unfortunately happened in some cases.
In the media there was much talk of "excesses of violence" among the Regensburger Domspatzen.
The former cathedral conductor Georg Ratzinger is accused in the report of "looking away".
Does he have to live with that accusation?
Michael Hesemann: That's the big problem, after all, that in reporting everything was mixed and blended into a huge melange of sexual abuse and excesses of violence and somewhere, in the middle of it all, Georg Ratzinger.
But that is precisely what is again an abuse of the report.
There is a clear separation: between the pre-school and the grammar school of the Domspatzen, between sexual abuse and excesses of violence and, let's say, other accusations.
The report also deals with incidents from the period since 1945, i.e. also from four decades in which Georg Ratzinger was not the choirmaster of the Domspatzen.
The whole terrible pedagogy of beating, the cases in which boys were downright harassed and maltreated by sadistic teachers and suffered terribly from it, all happened at the preschool in Etterzhausen and Pielenhofen, where really scandalous conditions must have prevailed.
But cathedral conductor Georg Ratzinger had nothing to do with them, because he only got to see the boys when they were already at the Domspatzengymnasium.
On this one, as most witnesses emphasize, the topic "pre-school" was taboo.
One was only happy to have escaped it and enjoyed the so much better treatment and for many even "paradisiacal" conditions.
What was different at the Domspatzengymnasium?
Michael Hesemann: There was already discipline, but not sadistic violence.
And this also applies to Georg Ratzinger, for whom the report comes to the conclusion that "many victims appreciated R.'s general humanity and therefore in numerous cases, despite violence, even associate positive memories with him".
So the only thing left is the accusation of having looked away.
But despite all efforts, the report could only define two periods of time in which he was informed about the conditions at the preschool.
The first time was in 1970/71, when he was just beginning to establish himself and did not want to hear anything about what was going on at a school where he was not active and responsible (according to the witness), and then again around 1993.
Did Georg Ratzinger consistently close his ears to the conditions?
Michael Hesemann: No, because already in 1989 he wrote a letter to the director of the Domspatzengymnasium, which the report even reproduces.
In it he points out to the latter "that corporal punishment is still practised in pre-school".
Already in view of the danger of negative press releases he recommended urgent intervention.
This was of course at a time when there was legal clarity, when corporal punishment had long been prohibited in Bavaria as well.
Before that, they occurred in a legal grey area, as each of us probably remember.
It was also difficult for him to assess where those affected had perhaps exaggerated or dramatised and where the permissible limit had really been exceeded.
But you can't say he always looked away either.
That's just not true.
Only in 1980 the corporal punishment at schools was officially abolished in Bavaria.
Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis claimed that it was unfair to apply today's educational standards to that time.
What do you think?
Michael Hesemann: We historians talk about the "trap of anachronism", i.e. the danger of evaluating the past according to today's moral standards.
The Princess is right.
But of course this does not apply to sexual abuse, which was abhorrent at all times, nor to what was done to innocent children's souls in preschool in terms of repulsiveness and violence, which already goes far beyond what was usual at that time.
This is all terrible and I am glad that it is finally being dealt with.
But at the same time I have to defend Georg Ratzinger, because all this had nothing to do with him.
His means of disciplining and punishing, i.e. slapping and pulling hair and ears, were widespread in the 1970s.
When corporal punishment was then forbidden, he also strictly adhered to it.
What image of his Regensburg time did Georg Ratzinger give in his talks with you for the book "My Brother the Pope"?
Did the issue of corporal punishment also come up?
Michael Hesemann: Well, the book is about the life of his brother Joseph, Pope Benedict XVI, told from his perspective, the cathedral sparrows only played a minor role.
Nevertheless, I do not hide the fact that he led a strict regiment there.
But this too must be said at some point: Without this perfectionism, without the demand for absolute discipline, it would hardly have been possible for him to form a world-class institution out of the Regensburger Domspatzen, until then nationally known, true cultural ambassadors of Europe and its musical tradition, who toured the USA twice (1983 and 1987) and Japan (1988 and 1991).
Cookies and candy alone do not turn stubborn boys into great singers, and they are facing every success, no matter what the field, but always discipline, passion and self-conquest.
What kind of person did you experience Georg Ratzinger as during the discussions about your book?
Michael Hesemann: Through the work on the book and beyond, I really got to know Georg Ratzinger quite well and experienced him again and again as a wonderful, humorous, kind, deeply religious and good-hearted person, of whom you can't imagine that he could harm even one fly.
I regularly hear how many former cathedral sparrows still keep in regular contact with him, visit him, read to him - he is almost blind - and treat him like a member of their family, 23 years after his retirement.
So those who have not forgiven him to this day for once being strict with them are clearly in the minority.
Most of the cathedral sparrows are grateful to him today for enriching their lives and introducing them to the world of music.
And that he was always a good, fatherly teacher - a strict father, certainly, that may be - but also a lovable and respectful person, whom they still look up to today and whom they almost adore.
And please, once again very clearly: All he is accused of are educational methods that were the order of the day back then.
We can be glad that we have long since overcome this time.
But it is highly unfair to make a man a media scapegoat just because he is prominent and has an even more prominent brother.
The evil intent behind it is all too obvious.
Because the report that has just been published exonerates him.
Now would be the decency to finally leave in peace a 93-year-old man who has earned great merits and without whom no one outside Bavaria and perhaps even Germany would know the Regensburger Domspatzen.
